I started coming here with my sister who recommended this place to me a couple years ago.  Every time I go, I love it.

Its huge portions, clean, healthy, delightful and incredibly flavorful!  They have a bunch of options and each dish is done incredibly well.

The soups are the cures for hangovers - its the answer.  But anytime you are feeling like a great healthy meal to warm you up, here is the place.

And also whats nice about this Asian restaurant is that they are friendly!!!!!
author: Alexis B.

description:
I will not be eating here anymore. My first visit the food was decent. I ordered the Beef over Jade Noodles and it was DELISH! However my 2nd visit cause my to have FOOD POISONING! We were serve Raw Shrimp on one of our cold noodle dishes. Shit happens! It was no biggie I just ordered a new dish. The only reason I am writing this review is because I had an early flight the next morning. Thats when my anger came! How COULD YOU SERVE ME RAW SHRIMP!? It like 90% raw and 10% cooked! Our waitress was very nice and did not charge us for the shrimp. 

Sadden story but we will never be returning....
author: Jangalina J.

description:
Had their: 

Sweet Chili-Glazed Tofu and Greens
Thai Coconut Tofu Soup
BBQ tofu spring rolls
Edamame

Yum!! Their tofu is satisfyingly rich in texture and flavor..The flavors marry all so well together amongst your palate forcing you to take another bite and another until your belly can take no more ;) Prices are very reasonable as well.  Our entire meal for two only costed us roughly $32.00

Not bad..

The only thing I think I would complain about is that it's a little too dark in there for me.  Great attempt to create an ambiance of romance or for hiding something they really don't want their customers to see(?)...I'd come back again in any case, maybe during the day to affirm that they really aren't trying to hide anything..
author: Cat V.

description: This place gets four stars because their food was good and price cheap - the latter being tough to find sometimes in SF. But would it hurt for the waitress to smile just once???
author: John H.

description: Superstar here is the Garlic Edamame. I can eat that thing all day everyday. Other than that, ordered BBQ Spring Rolls, Chicken Curry Noodles, Korean Short Ribs over Garlic Noodles and I must say.. They're pretty tasty but not anything more outstanding than what I've ordered elsewhere. Would I visit again? Yeah.
author: Laurice C.

description:
Situation
- Getting food at the bar at 3pm on Monday, Presidents Day 2012.  
- Ordered the Yellow Curry Tofu and Nuts.

Pros
- Excellent service at the bar
- The interior was nice
- They take credit cards
- Large portion size
- You can see the cooks make the food

Cons
- My dish was bland

Overall
- Perhaps only the dish I ordered is bland and the other dishes might not be, so I may have to try another dish at this place.
- If the other dishes turn out to be as bland as the dish I ordered, then I most likely will not want to come back
author: Dipesh G.

description:
After 3 trips this year in 2013, I'm giving up on this place:

Food - 
- I got the veggie noodle soup and it was served warm. noodles were overcooked and the tofu and shrimp (which I added for $2) was waaayy overcooked and chewy.
- Cold spicy lime soba noodles were overcooked and over-sauced.

Service
- my party of 4 was sat next to the bathroom and we were given attitude when we asked to move. they only save the large booth for parties bigger than 4 apparently so when our first moved situated us near a piss-reaking window, they finally gave into giving us the big booth.
- The server was friendly, unlike the hostess/waitress who neglected to check in with us after throwing our food down.
- Lastly, when the server delivered out to-go boxes, there were was hair all over one box. When I told the above mentioned waitress, she just blankly said "okay". What the F?

Kitchen
- I love open kitchens if they are clean but this one had an abundance of gnats and the cooks seemed to be more into slapping each other on the face and butts rather than on making food...

Scene
- Dark, outddated music, and what's up with derby caps? 

Note the last "scene" comment didn't factor into my star count.

I'm not going back. Sorry guys.
author: Clay L.

description: Never disappointed and wroth the trip for the spring rolls and spicy coconut noodle soup!!!!
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
I guess all good things come to an end... After a good 10 year run of being a delicious go to spot, this place has gone way down hill in both service and food quality. We waited at least 10 minutes for our drink order initially, then 45 minutes later our food arrived. They screwed up one order, and tried to deliver one of our 4 entrees 25 minutes later than the rest (we refused it).

Not sure the reasons, but the net result is in wont be coming back again.
author: Jo E.

description:
Citrus Club is quick, clean, cheap and cheerful. Well, the portions are so gigantic that you can share and eat very well. 
If I'm feeling sickly and lazy I often opt for one of their delicious soups. Some people say their food is bland but that's what hot sauce is for!
author: Rachel D.

description:
I love you, Citrus Club. Marry me.

I'll admit with chagrin and guilt, as I always do, that though I've rated Citrus Club 5 stars, I really haven't tried too many things off this menu. So take that into account.. But I have been here many many times and I wish to speak on its behalf. 

I think my love is not only because of my overwhelmingly fabulous food experience but the warm and wonderful feelings i have when dining there. I love love LOVE the darkness, the little red lights,  the intimacy, the unique feel of this place at night. 

The wait can be brutal. I have waited more than an hour for a table. It's worth it. Bring friends and wait in shifts while everyone else busies themselves across the street at Amoeba.  
Service is about what you would expect - a little slow when they're very busy but otherwise it's your typical service. I've found  nothing wrong with it here, yet.

Come hungry. These portions are ridiculous. There is nothing like the giant bowl they serve you noodles or soup in! Nothing!!
Actual food I have eaten: 
-Garlic edamame (I know I know, but damn if it isn't amazing. I'll eat the whole thing myself! Damn!!)
-Beef/shiitake mushroom chow fun (sweet and savory! Very tasty!!)
-Marmalade/lemongrass jade noodles with shrimp. ( The grand prize winner of my taste buds. This is nothing short of crazy good. Spicy, sweet, tangy! Oh wowowowow! This is what I get every time now. There is no room for another.)
-Won ton soup( the only meh thing I've ever had. It was on their specials list and I'm not sure if its a regular item, but I found it severely under-seasoned, especially compared to everything else on that menu, and just BORING. Pick anything else and you'll be ok?

But yes. So good. I will always return to you, Citrus Club!
author: Jessica W.

description:
Ah the Citrus Club.. for those moments when I actually refrain from ordering delivery yet again and get my lazy ass off of the couch and onto the street.

The Pho Ga is surprisingly decent here. The portions are big and the cuts of chicken are nice and lean. I'd recommend this for Pho newbies who don't want to immediately start off their Pho experience with liver or testicles in their soup.

The other dry dishes here are good as well. Again, the portions are big. Come here if you want a quick, cheap meal that you can get full from (aka you are a stoned Haight St. Hippie).
author: Charles H.

description:
Let's talk about their House Pad Thai, shall we. 

Description: 
Tomatoes, garlic, shallots, chilies, tofu, egg, bean sprouts, peanuts and scallions served with our peanut tamarind sweet/sour sauce over rice 
noodle.

Mmmmk, everything looks just about right, with the exception of the peanut tamarind sweet/sour sauce. But of course I didn't read the description before ordering. The reading happened after a plate of what looked like fettuccine Alfredo was placed in front of me. At first I thought it was a mistake, but nope, that there dish of creamy rice noodles, was my Pad Thai. It tasted like really bad fettuccine alfredo. I get that they make things 'differently' here, but really, no part of that dish had any semblance of a Pad Thai. 

In summary, what the fuck?!
author: Juliette J.

description: Ordered two items. Gave a good tip. Told to come back in fifteen minutes. Long wait but okay. Came back 15 minutes later. "Sorry, we sold out of one of your items." Uh, okay - would have been good to know that fifteen minutes ago. Waiting further...oh! My other item wasn't started yet. I'll need to wait. Uh...can I at less get half my tip back for the item I never got and the long wait? "Nope. We're too busy for that." Oh. Lesson learned. Never coming back. The half of my order I did get was mediocre. I ended up throwing half of it away. Sad thing is this place used to be fantastic. I had been warned. I should have listened. Go anywhere else.
author: Xian J.

description:
The food here is amazing. As soon as you walk in, you're by a wave of incredible smells: hot curries and exotic spices flood your senses and leave your mouth watering. It may not look like much from the outside, but there's something about the casually western yet slightly exotic vibe inside Citrus Club that to presents some of the best of Asian Fusion.

For food, I ordered the Vietnamese Spring Rolls, which were surprisingly good. Having grown up eating Vietnamese food, I'm generally sceptical about encountering Vietnamese food at non-Vietnamese places, but I was impressed here. The spring roll was incredibly fresh--everything from the vermicilli noodles to the rice roll was light and springy. Importantly, the peanut dipping sauce was amazing--not too salty and not too light--and perfectly complemented the spring rolls. Amongst some of the best spring rolls I've had anywhere.

For my main dish, I had the Spicy Curry Tiger Shrimp, which was exactly what I expected. It wasn't actually too spicy but was very rich and creamy. The flavor was more subtle than I expected, but overall the dish was good and the portions generous. 

I'd like to try some of the other dishes I saw (and smelled) people trying and will definitely be back!
author: Phong Q.

description: I never leave a raving fan of the meal, but also never mind having eaten here - it's always fine. I never suggest going here but also never say no if someone else wants to go. In general they are less flavorful or "correct" than restaurants that serve one national cuisine. So, mostly the food is fine, but in no way in the running for best pho, tom kha gai, shanghai noodles, etc. in the city. Lots of vegetarian options, some nice healthy options. Portions are generous and the staff is always friendly and attentive. The 66 health department score is concerning.
author: bill d.

description: Just had my sola blown off. The beef and shiitake mushroom wok tossed noodles and a large serving of delicious soup. Coming from Denver you just can't get authentic food like this, very impressed.
author: Diana D.

description: Started off with the shrimp spring rolls. The peanut sauce was amazing. Chicken Satay was perfectly grilled and served with an even better peanut sauce. Pho-ga was great. Chicken in it a little over cooked. Marmalade coconut lemongrass shrimp was very good. I got mine spicy and added even more heat because i love it hot! PRICE WAS RIGHT!!!!
author: Rebecca M.

description: Unfriendly service and possibly the worst bowl of pho I've ever had. Idk what made it taste bad but it had a weird bleachy flavor to it. Would not go back.
author: Kelly T.

description:
It's not your typical asian noodle place.  I love sitting at the counter and watching the cooks bring up a huge bowl and fill it with vietnamese or thai noodle dishes. 

I pass by it all the time, but dropped by to try it from a friend's recommendation.  If you near Cole Vally and the Haight, give this a try.

Between 9th and Judah area and the Haight, you've got all your needs for Asian noodles fulfilled!
author: Tony T.

description: 2 out of 3 dishes were good but we had to send one back (yellow curry) due to lack of flavor. Our server Noon was extremely rude and made the experience quite uncomfortable for our table.
author: M S.

description:
I've been here at least 3 times.  Although conceptually I want to love this place, the quality of the food is just not great.  

After reading lots of Yelp praise, on my latest visit I tried the Hot and Sour Soup.  Yes, it was flavorful, but it was SO SALTY.  I literally felt like I was desiccating at the table. Also tried the Grilled Shrimp and Scallops on Garlic Noodles, which were generally lacking in flavor.

To their credit, on previous visits I tried the Garlic Beef & Shitake Mushrooms and the Tom Ka-Thai Coconut Tofu Soup, both of which were much more flavorful (and less salty).  I suppose it's kind of a hit or miss type place.  They do make a FANTASTIC Pomegranite Martini though!
author: Andrea P.

description:
Ok, yes we know in the [?recent] past there was a health warning about this place.  But we tried it anyhow.  We had the [rice paper] vegetable rolls and each had the Sa Choy vegetables/noodles dish (first one on the menu).  The rolls were very good and the noodle dish was rocking.  Usually you get too much salt in a noodle dish, or not enough vegetables, or just not enough soup.  These bowls were huge and the taste was yummy.   Service was absolutely solid.

I don't know the details behind the previous health warning, and I can say that they do need to keep up a little more with the floors and the overall look of the place (vacuuming and painting could help).  BUT, we've been to worse looking places on this trip to SF including highly rated places where the food was not as good at the Citrus Club.   If you are strolling down the Haight, don't hesitate to try it.
author: Mike T.

description: Just what the dr.ordered, tasty soup and fresh shrimp spring rolls. Highly recommend this neighborhood place, full of locals on this chilly mid-week night. I'm really happy I tried it!
author: Scott W.

description: Super friendly. Large serving sizes, definitely worth the price. Tasted great my friend and were even scooping the sauce up afterwards.
author: Laurel S.

description:
This place exceeded my expectations.
Service was very fast and the food delicious. We tried the Pad Thai, Peanut Noodles & Spicy Veggie Soup. ALL DELISH! Watch you wish for though, because the portions are pretty big; perfect to share with a date :)
author: Reyna G.

description:
I don't like to review the places I like, because popularity is so often the death of good restaurant, but CC is too good not to say something about.

It's all about the food. Big bowls of delicious food at reasonable prices, what more do you want? -1 star for being so small that there's always a line, but, what are ya gonna do. I will always go back here. Noodles w/ chicken and peanut sauce are my favorite.
author: David K.

description:
Well, it is finally Goodbye, Citrus Club.  My last visit was my last visit.  I came home exhausted (I live a block away), walked in to an almost empty restaurant and thought, Perfect.  "Hi," I say to the lovely server, "Yep, just me."  

She flips the menu over her shoulder to me and says, "Sit at the small tables".  Okay, hello to you and welcome.  I know the drill, so I take a small table in the back, Beach Boys music just a little too loud for frayed nerves, but, hey, it's for staff not me. No problem.  She takes my order, and returns twice asking, "Balsamic?"  Yes.  'Shrimp?"  Yes.  No problem, it's around 3, shift end, begin?

I get the salad soaked (no exaggeration) in vinegar and the shrimp not cooked, looking grey, like it had just been defrosted, cold.  Not edible.

So, I pay the check, "No, thank you.  I do not want to take it home."

Now, I've had some good, some mediocre meals at Citrus Club over the years, but I won't be going back and will not be recommending.

Goodbye, Citrus Club.
author: Susan L.

description:
This place is ok. The portion was really big but the noodles with curry was really bland. Extremely bland. The curry flavor was lacking, it was not spicy at all ( menu indicated that it was), and the worst part is that my noodles were soggy and soft.

Meanwhile, the shanghai beef and garlic noodles were good at first but instantly became a little to sweet for my taste. 

Prices were kind of high for a non-authentic noodle house but the environment was kind of cool.
author: Reiko n.

description: My tummy screams in happiness when I eat: garlic edamame, coconut chicken noodles and spicy seafood soup, not necessarily in that order. I may have the names off, but you get the just.  Hot, tasty goodness, with the right amount of spice!
author: Elle L.

description:
We have consistently gotten good take out noodles from Citrus Club. So last evening, when I was in the mood for some "home-style" food, I chose Citrus Club. When I got there at 6, the restaurant was practically empty. I was given a menu and told to sit anywhere. I picked a spot in the back that was a bit out of the way - which may explain why the staff totally forgot I was there. Ten minutes later, I had to flag my waitress down to take my order, but when she did so, she seemed appropriately attentive.

Once I ordered some chicken pho, I was pleasantly surprised by how quickly I was served. The pho was hot, tasty and delicious - and the portion size - for $9.95 - was incredibly huge - enough for me to take it home for at least another meal. By the time I left at 7, all the tables were full.

I'd probably stick with ordering food for pick up, but I'd definitely eat their food again.
author: Susan L.

description: One of my favorite places to eat in S.F. Cheap, reliable, chill ambience.  Order the garlic edamame.  Then order the coconut tofu soup and the madarin style chow mein.
author: shawn l.

description:
I first ate here 2 years ago.
I came back again earlier this week, as I was staying nearby and have been back 4 times this week!! The portions are huge, there's a wide selection of pan-asian flavors to choose from and I've loved them all - pho, pad Thai, chow fun, curries - yum yum yum!
author: Tony L.

description: I really wanted to like this place but everything is really just ok. I had the pho and that was not very flavorful. The spring rolls were crap. All it had were carrots and vermicelli noodles. Not worth $6. The garlic beef & mushroom chow fun noodles was actually decent. My only criticism was that it was a little bit watery. There are definitely better places for noodles in that area. The portions are our however quite large and is easy to share with others.
author: Gary I.

description: I came here the other night after a friend highly recommended this place. I was NOT disappointed! Servicewas great and food was absolutely delicious. We had the garlic edamame and vegetable spring rolls to start and the coconut noodle soup (don't know the exact name of it)..The bowl of soup was huge. Both me and my friend ate two bowls each with left overs to take home. Pricing is very decent. I can't wait to come back!!!!
author: T A.

description: The Citrus Club was recommended and the pho was freakin awesome! U ever get to San Fran go there for the PHO!!!!
author: juanita s.

description:
The people that work here are always great and nice. There's always a line to get seated but I usually call-in and grab stuff to go. 

While I don't love the stir-fry noodles in this place (they're a little bland for me but I am a total salt love), I will say that it *is* my GO TO place for Vietnamese Chicken Noodle Soup. The best remedy for a gloomy, sad, or illness-ridden day. The broth is super tasty and the chicken, bean sprouts, garlic, and green onions are the perfect mix. Bonus: the portion is huge!
author: snowhappy P.

description:
Service was waaaaay below acceptable but I did have the best Chow Mein ever... so guess it evens out. Went with friends, one of which was vegan, so this place is veg-friendly! I really want to go back but instead make reservations since sitting at the bar seating was a MOST unpleasant experience.

Yeah, make reservations here and don't feel guilty about leaving a small tip if the service was horrible.
author: Dana M.

description:
I think this place is great.  I had the garlic beef & shiitake mushrooms.  It was soo good. I could have even done without the beef because the shiitake mushrooms were so awesome.  The portions were huge and the wait was not bad.

Thai iced tea was great here.  The spring rolls were ok not enough fresh herbs in there so it was kinda boring but I loved the peanut sauce.

Overall I would totally love to come back here.
author: Thea S.

description:
My experience here was spectacular.
Went in with a group of 6, maybe an hour before dinner rush. Service was prompt and polite.
I had the best Tom-ka (Coconut soup) I've ever eaten, literally mind-blowing.
HUGE portions are a plus.
I advise against the Chicken Noodle Soup, quite bland.
author: Alana B.

description: I had the best (and biggest) bowl of Tom-Ka soup when I came here. It was bigger than my head! I got maybe 1/3 or the way through it (with help) and then still had an entire large soup takeout containers worth to go home with. Amazing.
author: Maggie C.

description: The service at this place was terrible. I came in with 3 of my friends and they told us for a table for 4 we had to wait 20 minutes so we said okay and looked around in a nearby shop. We came back 20 minutes later and they had forgotten about us and asked us to wait just a little bit more. We stood around waiting for another 20 minutes, the whole time being treated like an inconvenience. The waitress was extremely rude and sat every other group that came in besides us. Finally we decided to order take out and waiting another 15 minutes for that and by the time it was done there was a table for us. Nobody was helpful or kind to us at all. The food was good but I will definitely not be going back.
author: Emily S.

description:
Although I enjoyed the ambiance and thought the service was great, I didn't enjoy the food here as much.  It's an Asian-fusion type place that has some interesting combinations that I wasn't ready for.

The Kalbi was one of the better dishes, but don't order pho here or the noodle dishes or you may be sorely disappointed.  I had a Tom Kha noodle soup which was difficult to eat.  The papaya salad tasted more like white vinegar had been poured on it without any other flavors.  It was rough.

Asian-fusion can be interesting, but it depends on your palette and how you might handle some of your favorite dishes with a twist.  You may love it or you might be shocked at how such food could exist.  I had a hard time, possibly because i'm so accustomed to particular flavors in certain Asian dishes that I believe should remain the same.  

Two of our friends, however, used to come here all of the time though and recommended this place to us...I say, try it once and see how you like it, but choose wisely!
author: Mary B.

description:
Disappointing dinners. 5 of us ordered entrees and didn't like them.  We had came several years before and really enjoyed but now quality of food was consistently bad. 
We will not be back again. 
Tom kha stock was bland. Cashew chicken tasted like a mall food court.
author: Jon J.

description:
Citrus Club is aiiiite. Review for NOODLE SOUP(s) ONLY.

I mean, it's great when I want noodles. And I love noodles! 

Working at USF, it's a quick lunch stop I like to stop by at. I usually have their noodles soups, but have to sort of tweak what I want each time. I wish I had more soup every single time.  I get their hot sour shrimp noodle couple mostly (there's like 4lbs of veggies in there) BUT lately, their beef pho has been really disappointing. 

I chewed one piece of "rare beef" for 70 seconds. That is not ok. It was really thick, and I'm not sure having such thick slices of beef is good, especially when there are only four slices. I was really surprised since their other soups are good. My Bf loves their stir-fry noodles, so sadly I'll venture into that territory. 

The Good: Flavorful broth

The Bad: Pay better attention to your accompaniments, please. They make or break the dish.
author: Christina L.

description: This place was okay. I ordered the pad thai and was slightly disappointed. It didn't have the authentic pad thai taste and it had sliced tomatoes in it. It honestly tasted off.  The saving grace was that it was a huge portion, so at least I was full. I was also there around 6 pm and it was so dark in the restaurant, it was honestly off-putting.
author: Emma W.

description:
One good thing - cute ambiance with candlelight

Now the bad...

1) Absolutely BLAND BLAND food...my lemon coconut noodles had a hint of coconut milk but I literally put peanut sauce from my spring rolls on them for some sort of flavor!

speaking of Vietnamese & spring rolls...also completely flavorless

They serve soups in humongous bowls, but only put 3-4 won tons and the rest is plain noodles

Also the Large hot saki was actually smaller than one you would normally get at any sushi restaurant & I barely felt any buzz 

I saw many people drinking cocktails, so perhaps it is their speciality...I wouldn't know

Conclusion..really mediocre overpriced asian fusion with cute ambience
author: Nina M.

description: The Veggie Hot and Sour Noodle Soup was delicious!  I ordered take-out and it was hot.  Just FYI, the tofu is fried and I prefer it soft so that it doesn't taste "spongey."  Other than that, I loved it and will definitely be ordering it again!  It satisfies the salty/spicy soup craving!!
author: Kelly M.

description:
I've eaten here once and had take-out once - only because it's JJ's favorite noodle place in my 'hood. 

My dine-in experience was fine - no complaints about service or anything. The take-out experience was also fine. JJ doesn't eat fish or mushrooms and I was one a no-nut (amongst other things) homeopathic thingy so we opted for the Vietnamese tofu spring rolls, vegetables with tofu (variety of veggies were nice and fresh, minimal tofu), and grilled chicken and grilled short-ribs, both of which came with delicious garlic noodles (yes, yes, leftovers!). The chicken was awesome, the ribs were tasty but a little tough and dry. 

So, yes, it's "asian fusion" I guess. Not that I care. But if you want Authentic, this isn't your place. If you want cheap and decent food in the Haight (not there aren't a thousand options), then this is as good as any other. I am a big fan of their tofu dishes, though, and happy they do vegetarian options for when I don't feel like meat.
author: Mi M.

description: I'm standing at the counter a full hour after placing a pickup order, still waiting. Placed the order through eat 24 hours and had the order confirmed in their app. Arrived at the restaurant for pickup and no one had bothered to make the order. They said it was because their eat24 console didn't work. Wondering why I was charged, I messaged eat 24 to ask them to refund me. Walk back in to pick up and pay for my order and they tell me they cancelled it because eat24 did (the same app that they had just said they couldn't actually get orders from) BUT my food was already made. Great, can I just pay and take it? They say yes, I pay, and ten minutes later I am still sitting here. I come here a lot, or I did, because I just realized the food isn't good enough to be worth this.
author: Jessica H.

description:
I stopped in with friends on a Thursday night for dinner. I had their wonton noodle soup. The size was good, but the quality of the wonton was doughy and the noodles al dente. Definitely not good to get such a simple dish so wrong. My friends did like their dishes. 
On top of that, their restroom was locked. After an hour, we asked about using the restroom, and the staff just said it was occupied. When we loudly knocked on the door, there was no response. The staff was unconcerned, but my friend, who is concerned for all living things, suggested to call the SFFD, because obviously someone has passed out in the restroom. Then the staff said they didn't have the key to open the door. My friend reassured them that SFFD didn't need a key, they will bust the door down. By now we are the last patrons and the staff seemed more interested in closing up than the person locked in the restroom. My friend finally had enough of inaction, she called 911 to make a report. Now the waitress is pleading to the rest of us to convince my friend that calling 911 is not necessary. 
My tips for Citrus Club are:
1) empty your bladders before going to Citrus Club. 
2) make sure the restroom is functional at the Citrus Club before ordering a pitcher of beer (which was good) or drinking most of the broth (it was tasty).
3) don't order the Citrus Club's wonton.
4) if you can overlook the fact that locking the restroom is not to code, you will also have to stop yourself from wondering what else is not to code at the Citrus Club.
author: Spencer F.

description:
Great place in the NoPa/Haight area. I ordered their spicy shrimp noodle soup and it was HUGE. Never had so much pho in one meal before. The soup was average - hot enough, but nothing special and not particularly rich with flavors (pretty one dimensional). Wished they put more care in gutting their shrimps, and I didn't feel their ingredients were all that fresh. 

The reason why I said it's a great place is mostly because of the portions and their variety of choices on the menu. It satisfied my craving for a hot bowl of noodle soup. Hard to find what they offer in that neighborhood late at night.
author: Jackie C.

description:
That 66 out of 100 from SF Health is not a misprint!
I used to live in the neighborhood many moons ago and would love visiting for a quick giant bowl of soup to cure a weekend of fun.  I guess I never really looked around too much when I was there... Fast forward 10+ years...
I was walking by the other day and thought "man.... I haven't had that Egg Drop Chicken Soup in awhile.... Lets Do It!".  I peaked in the window at the menu they have up to see if they still have the EDCS, yep, there it was.  "Hmmmm, that's weird there's a fruit fly on the menu as well.... ohh well, not a big deal".  Sat at the bar and ordered my soup.  Throughout the meal I starting looking around and noticed the place is dirty, really dirty.  Behind the bar everything looks dingy and worn out (maybe that's why the lights are always soo low in there?).  I also noticed a few more flies zooming around as I ate.  I ended up taking the soup home to finish.   After dumping it out in a big bowl in my brightly lit kitchen I counted 3 fruit flies!! F-ING GROSS!
I called the place back to voice my concern and all the manager said was "Ohh, well, what do you want me to do?".  Nothing.  I'll never be back
author: Gerard A.

description:
I make a point to eat here when I'm visiting my friends who live a block away. Recurring dish: Cold coconut lime buckwheat noodles. I love that stuff, but I feel the sauce used to be a little different? Maybe I just don't remember. I also like their broths, but I order what I think is miso soup and get some other (mind you, pretty tasty) broth. Whatevs, it's soup weather and it hits the spot :)
Don't expect real thai food, and you won't be disappointed. The flavors are good, but not even close to authentic.
author: Andrea S.

description:
Brought my boyfriend here for a 2nd try and I must say, in the daylight, this place transformed into a gloomy noodle house. All of it's trendiness went out the window when the typical noodle joint furnishings are revealed in the daylight. 

The food was still yum but as other yelpers mentioned, service was eh.
author: Tiffany U.

description:
We went around 615, ordered food, then 15 minutes went by and we asked when our food was coming. The waiter told us there were "a lot of to go orders" but ours would be out soon. We waited longer. I finally had to tell them if our food wasn't out in 5 minutes we were leaving. We waited 10 minutes and a full 30 minutes after we ordered, we left and the staff offered us no kind of "make good" - they seemed stunned, even though I was pretty clear.

I actually like the food. But the service SUCKS.

Recommendation: don't go to eat, order to go.
author: S. S.

description:
Delicious. Cheap. Delicious. Cheap.

I dont think that there is anything else that needs to be said.
author: Alyssa M.

description:
I like Citrus Club. It is a great place to get an inexpensive noodle dish if you are in the area.
Some of the dishes I usually get are the Pho Ga ("The ultimate mommy soup") and the chow mein with tofu and chicken. The soup is good, definitely a good choice on a cold day. The chow mein is also tasty too, I like the fact that it is not greasy...it has a light sauce mixed with veggies and meat (if you choose).
Portions here are large and prices are $7+ and get more expensive if you add meat (only $2 or so to add meat to most dishes).
Service here is friendly and attentive also. Definitely a more intimate restaurant, tables are close together and lighting is dimmed. 
Definitely one of my favorite noodle joints to eat at in SF next to Hotei!
author: Miss H K.

description: I got the Thai-Coconut Shrimp Wonton Soup and it wasn't great. It lacked flavor and it tasted like I was drinking straight coconut cream. There was no saltiness, spicyness, or any sort of savoryness. The shrimp wontons weren't bad but it didn't save the dish. Mind you, I had a couple drinks before I came here and even with the help of alcohol in my system, I knew how bad it tasted (everything usually tastes good when you have the drunchies right?). The only reason why I'm giving this place a two stars is the service. The hostess and servers were very friendly and attentive and it pains me to write this review because they were so nice. Will come back to possibly try the other dishes but never getting the wonton soup again.
author: Hana K.

description:
The Citrus Club is definitely a local neighborhood's best kept secret! Portions are large and the price is right. Wait was a little long considering that we went and signed up our names at 8:15pm - waited about 30 minutes before we were seated.

Between my two friends and I, we all ordered a noodle dish and split family style. This place is known for their superb noodle dishes and being the carb lovers we are, we had to try this place.

We ordered:

* a special off the daily special menu (sorry, can't remember what it was!)
* Peanut Noodles with Chicken
* Tom-ka Thai Coconut Noodle Soup

Like I said before, portions are HUGE for the price - but everything was so delicious! The waitstaff was very accommodating and friendly throughout our service. 
Environment is really cozy and the restaurant can get really busy/loud. But who cares? The food is absolutely delicious for the typical noodle-lover!

We couldn't finish all of our food - kind of impossible actually. But, our noodle cravings were satisfied.

Will definitely come back to try more dishes! Only downside...Parking is really difficult to find.
author: Julia K.

description:
MAN, this place is good. I come here with my roommates all the time. It's in such a neat location and it's fairly priced for the amount of food you get. We're a bunch of hungry college kids, and it never fails to satisfy our hunger (and our wallets!) It's so trendy and you can meet really cool people there.

 It's really just for adults and small groups of people, since seating is extremely limited. It is very loud and dark, like a club. (I guess that's where the name comes from!) It's a very cool atmosphere!
author: Madelyn S.

description: Best fusion restaurant I've ever been to since eating in Hong Kong. They have a spicy Thai chicken salad that is a must try when in the Bay Area.  Not very expensive considering its on Haight St.
author: William S.

description: I love this place. Huge bowls of noodle soup! The garlic edamame is a must. Also a fan of their spring rolls and tom kha soup. The best!
author: Jessie B.

description: Pretty good food, with great sake. I personally wasn't a huge fan of my dish, but my friend loved his, so maybe it was just what I ate.
author: Zach H.

description: Ordered the House-garlic Edamame as appetizer because they had run out of both Vietnamese Bbq Tofu and avocado Spring Rolls. However, the soy beans were yummy, mostly because of the garlic spiced dressing, but too expensive in my opinion. I also ordered the grilled salmon w/ salad and the Burmese coconut curry chicken. The salmon was good cooked, but nothing outstanding. The salad was good too (maybe they put too much vinegar on it). The chicken plate was just ok, even though the coconut sauce was delicious. I read several reviews which talked about huge portions. I have to say that the dishes I ordered had a normal size. I paid $34+tax (tip not included) for the three plates. Average/good food quality, but a little bit overpriced for what you get.
author: Fer S.

description: The food was good and plentiful. Everything except for the short ribs had noodles, even green colored noodles. Service was strong, but one star off for the fact that some of the dishes were a bit too salty.
author: Dan Z.

description:
Thankful that this spot was my first stop in SF because it hit my craving and hunger more than words can describe.

My only disappointment was that I wasn't with more people to try other things! With portions big enough to share, I suggest getting an appetizer--the garlic edamame was honestly one of the best things I've ever tasted, I practically licked the plate ;) -- and a a few noodle dishes with a group to get a good idea of the amazingly unique varieties on classic Asian cuisine.
author: Kelsey G.

description:
OH MY GOD the Tom ka-Thai Coconut Tofu Soup is THE BEST.

It's $7.95 w/ rice noodles, carrots, cabbage, snowpeas, cilantro, galanga, onions and tofu in their delicious vegetarian coconut broth & is like a big bowl of dessert.
I've never been ultra fond of coconut based curries or broths, but this soup is to die for. Some of the other dishes I've tried have been pretty tasty, but nothing compares to the Tom Ka. SO GOOD.

The outside of the place isn't impressive, but it's quite cozy inside.
 Oh, and  I love the Tom Ka.
author: Danielle B.

description:
You know, I liked the Citrus Club, although with almost 900 reviews, I doubt I have anything new to add to the mix. However ...

I liked that it was dark and cramped and that the bathroom was a little suspect. It was a perfect, grungy little place filled with character.

Our waitress was funky and friendly and the service came at the perfect pace -- not too fast, not too slow.

Their drinks are generous and cheap, especially the cloudy, undistilled sake and something called the electric lemonade which looked and tasted just like an Otter Pop. 

The garlic edemame was so powerfully garlicky that I smelled it on myself as I went to bed -- even after I washed my face and brushed my teeth. Overall, I'd say Citrus Club is BIG on flavor.

The rest of the food was just okay. Friend and I shared the peanut noodles and the Burmese noodle special and I thought the peanut noodles were too peanutty, without any other flavors to mix it up at all. I did prefer the Burmese noodles, however (let me try and fit the word "noodle" into this sentence a few more times).

Anyway, maybe because I'm a visitor and I have not been to enough places in San Francisco to know the difference, but I liked the Citrus Club and had a fun time there. I'd come back.
author: Sandra V.

description:
Citrus Club is a local neighborhood's best kept secret. This local 'hole-in-the-wall' has some of the best Asian-fusion dishes that I've had. 

The food tastes great every time, the portions are great (I'd recommend you share as the dishes are pretty big), and everything is priced very reasonably. 

The interior decor is a bit on the dark side, yet it provides a relaxing tone for the evening. 

If you're planning on a dinner or late evening outing, plan on getting there early or be willing to wait, as this place tends to get busy. 

Highly recommend checking out this local treasure.
author: Stefan S.

description: Very inconsistent, perhaps they have more than one chef... This place can be yummy one time and tasteless another, 50/50, which is not good enough... In addition, the service sucks.
author: Galina R.

description:
Official 1st Date was this past Sunday -- date took me here since I still can't eat rice. He said that they have good food and good drinks = the man knows how to please me! =P

We came before 8 and the place was already packed. He wrote his name on the board and he asked if I wanted a drink = well of course =)

I got their apple martini (a good size and really, really, really smooth!) he got the Electric Lemonade (didn't taste it...he didn't offer and I felt bad just asking...)

Date got Edamame b/c he was hungry - opted not to eat any b/c I was still jet lagged and I felt full even though I wasn't. 

For my entree: Shanghai Noodles (Tender slices of beef, shitake mushrooms, onions, bok-choy and tofu tossed in our caramelized soybean sauce over udon noodles.) Their portions are huge! I picked some of my food (mainly meat) and took the rest home. It was good, but didn't have enough appetite to create major damage.

Date ordered: Spicy Lemon & Coconut Chicken (Marinated chicken, broccoli and bean sprouts served over egg noodles.) It looked spicy so again, I didn't opt to try. He loved it though =)

At the end, service was decent. Very fast actually and good food. I told Date that I want to try the place again once I get my appetite back.

When we were leaving, the place was uber packed. Thus, go in early to avoid the crowd!
author: Cath M.

description: Usually you would expect a place that specializes in noodles to cook its noodles properly and not drown them in sauce.
author: Omer G.

description:
Yummy noodles and the dishes pack a lot of flavor!

Garlic edemame is a must! Try and go on off-times if you won't want to wait for a really long time. The grilled Korean Short ribs is a great choice. Udon noodles are a winner. As is the garlic noodles and shittake mushroom noodle dish.

Good sized portions and almost always enough for leftovers. (These make great leftovers btw)
author: An-Nhien L.

description:
Came here before, may not come again.

Got the veggie soup and the broth was SOOO salty my tongue is still stinging. I asked for lime to try and tone it down a little but it wasn't too much help.

Bummer because in theory this place is so good.
author: Rachel G.

description: I dont about any other dish here besides the coconut lemongrass spinach noodles with shrimp..that dish is the bomb! Add some hot sauce and im tellin you your mouth will water thinking about it. Add the garlic edamame and you have a tasty lunch. Def a 5star dish.
author: russ s.

description: I wish I had checked the Yelp warning before dining here. I went on Monday night with my boyfriend . After we left we stopped in a near bar so my boyfriend could make an emergency diarrhea .We went straight home after that. I became violently ill , puking and diarrhea for 2 days! It is late Wednesday night and I have still not been able to keep food down! How can a place like this still be open? I have never felt this sick in my whole life!!!!
author: Chris L.

description: Ok, I'm  HUGE fan of this place. They are famous for their soups but should be famous for just about everything in there! Besides the tiny location space which I wish they would find a way to expand. That is the only reason I took off a star. The soups are rich, cleansing, and tasteful. The salmon I ordered was perfectly grilled, succulent, and fresh tasting. The garlic vegetables were absolutely perfect. This place is also great for vegetarians. I recommend trying everything here at least once.THEN try picking your favorite dish, it'll be pretty hard! Great place, a MUST try. Also, even though this place is usually packed, although I've gotten lucky and have never had to wait, you can still clearly hear the conversation you're in. Enjoy!
author: Karina G.

description:
We were visiting San Francisco last week and decided to pay the Haight-Ashbury area a visit. We were in the mood for noodles and happened upon The Citrus Club so we decided to give them a try.  It was late in the afternoon so the restaurant was pretty empty - perhaps a couple of tables occupied.  

A couple of us had the Thai Coconut Wonton Soup and another of us had the Shrimp Spring Roll and a Thai Tea.

The Wonton Soup was pretty good and certainly different from a typical wonton soup, both in the presence of coconut in the broth and the use of of rice noodles.  The broth was tasty and the serving generous.  The spring roll was fine, though nothing special.  The Thai Tea was smaller than we're accustomed to at some other restaurants and at $4.50 with no refills, I thought it was a little pricey.

So the food was decent if unspectacular, as was the service.  So why only two stars? Because from the moment we entered the restaurant to the time we left, they were blaring loud non-stop hip-hop.  I don't necessarily have a problem with the style of music (though I didn't think it fit in with the ambiance), but EVERY song was full of swearing, degrading lyrics and I would think a little common sense would say very inappropriate for a restaurant. It just ruined the meal for me.

As we were leaving, I noticed a family with a young boy walking in.  I hope someone had the sense to change the music.
author: R C.

description:
I use to go here all the time (during college).  Back then, it was an awesome place with great noodle dishes at reasonable prices...there was always a line.  I don't know if the owner/chef changed but the food was pretty horrific last time we went.

-Spicy Curry Tiger Shrimp-the noodles clumped together and was pretty bland.  I think we only had four forced bites
-Thai Coconut Tofu Noodle Soup -This was the dish I always ordered!  Huge bowl of yummy soup but this time the soup and veggies had a film of oil

What happen Citrus Club!?  More importantly, revisit your old recipes.
author: Michelle M.

description: Not the best. I got the Shanghai Noodle dish and the beef was very rubbery. The dish was $10.95, which I think is overpriced for the quality and quantity of the food. My friend got the Ton Ka Soup and neither of us enjoyed it. THE SERVICE IS VERY BAD. The waitress just sat in the corner of the room and barely helped us. I would not return.
author: Fiona M.

description:
This place is cheap and delicious.  

My favorites are Shanghai Noodles and the Mongolian Beef w/ Spinach Noodles.  

That is all.
author: Mike H.

description: I was there last night and had the chicken pho. It was delicious and the perfect comfort food. Great little find on haight. Good service and price. Will definitely be back.
author: Ramsey M.

description:
Eleven years I have been chowing here and I've never written about it? Yowsas. Well, I went over the weekend for the umpteenth time and figured I'd finally get down to business.

I like this place for its simplicity: menu is traditional, straight-forward and easy to navigate the healthy from the not-so-healthy, though most of it belongs in the former. It's ridiculously affordable and just an all-around solid place to waltz into should you be on Haight looking for a noodle house (among all the other things you dirty peeps are looking for on Haight).

Truth be told, I'm never completely "wowed" like many are, but I absolutely support it and will never say no when one of my Citrus Club addicts are fiending when in the 'hood. One of the cheap(er) addictions you can feed on Haight...all good...
author: Meredith R.

description: The last time we went to the citrus club was quite disappointing. The go to dish for me is Thom Kha Gai and it was bland, had to be spiced up with the condiments they keep on all the tables. The service was rather unfriendly. It's sad because it used to be one of our favorite places in the Haight for Asian fair.
author: Audra S.

description:
Ok, sorry, but this place is really gross.

Had I read the reviews first, I wouldn't have stopped in, but a friend suggested we meet for dinner and I was in town visiting so I agreed. The line was out the door and the place was packed so we waited about 20 mins for a table. I asked the waiter what was better: the Thai coconut milk soup or the chicken pho and almost before I finished the sentence he said the chicken pho. The bowl that arrived at the table was pretty impressive but unfortunately the smell preceeded it. I'm a big pho fan; I know that if you get meat in it it's usually sliced thin enough so the soup can cook it. But, I'm pretty sure that someone had dumped strips of raw chicken in my soup. This things smelled BAD. All I could smell was raw chicken and it was really hard to remotely enjoy the soup because of it. The broth was pretty bland even though I used up all the basil, lemon, and little jar of hoisin on the table, and was also pretty oily. The one thing they did get right were the noodles. Surprisingly, they were just about the best I've had! When the bill came I reluctantly handed over my $8.95 (sad because I'm used to paying $6 for GOOD pho), but was cheered by the fact that I never have to come here again.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Tofu spring rolls... gooood gooood.

peanut noodles.. more peanutty than a schulz gallery. yeah duh, it says peanut noodles but didn't know they was serious about it.

shitake mushroom and beef chow fun?... not so good. it was okay because i had leftovers and i was like oookay.. can have some later. nope, it decided to internally rape my insides and i had absolutely no desire to touch it again.
author: Tyson T.

description:
A friend took me here, raving that this was one of the best little known Asian fusion joints in San Francisco. 

All I have to say is meh. It's not terrible. It's not amazing.

Tom Ka soup was bland and watery.
Pad Thai was creamy, alfredo and pasta-like.
Spring rolls were okay. The rice paper wrapping was on the tougher side.
Had a couple other dishes that were also okay.

Service is not bad. The bathroom is small and kind of nasty.

But on the bright side, portions are huge.
author: Paulina D.

description:
I've moved from TenderNob AKA Little Saigon to Cole Valley. The accessibility to awesome cheap Asian fare is no longer within walking distance. I should have thought about this one earlier. 

I don't care what people say, this place isn't all that. I understand it's Pan Asian. Maybe I should stop trying Pan Asian food, because I'm Asian and shit.. I just like it how it is supposed to be. 

The food is flavorless. No, I take that back. The food is either really over the top or it is on a single flat note. It's like saying the guy you had a date with last week was really nice. Nice, but not interesting enough for a second date. Every time someone suggests coming here, I cringe, but think, "hey I must be picking the one bad thing from the menu." So I've given this restaurant a few too many tries throughout the years... but I'm thru pretending.. Citrus Club and I have been through a string of should of's, could of's, and we're now finally breaking up.
author: sally y.

description: This was the first and last time I'm ever going to this place. Service was horrible and the waitress was very rude. The restaurant is cute and very tiny but if you're looking for a peaceful place to enjoy your meal and have a conversation,  this is not it.  The seating is very overcrowded and the noise level is loud. I ordered the pad Thai(I love pad Thai and it's the only thing I get at every Thai restaurant I go to) and it had no flavor and the noodles were very overcooked and mushy, worst I've ever had. If you're looking for traditional pad Thai, look elsewhere, they put tomatoes in theirs along with other undercooked vegetables. Mine also had undercooked chicken, wasn't kidding when I said worst ever, it made me sick.
author: Adrienne F.

description: I love Citrus club. I especially like to come here for the huge bowls of noodle soup. They are so big that I find they are enough for 2 meals. The hot sour vegetable noodle soup is my favorite- it's great comfort food but also feels healthy.
author: Sarah G.

description: I am giving this review on my server only: She was a vegetarian with beautiful tattoos and she gave us great service and helped me order and that is a difficult feat, I am not big on exotic menus but I found something. She was kind and very informative. The food was okay
author: Tashema M.

description: The Citrus Club is on our short list of favorite places to eat on the Haight.  I should say that the decor and furnishings are nothing special, but if you like a little place to duck in, get warm and get your tummy happy, this is not a bad spot.  Soothing noodle soups are right for so many weather occasions - notably in the City - and the Citrus Club has a variety.  I seem to stick with the Pho-Ga Chicken Soup.  My dude loves all things coconut, so his favorite is Tom ka-Thai Coconut Tofu Soup.  Service is always efficient; we understand a wait when we've been seated with a large group.
author: Liana R.

description: Spicy sour shrimp soup is perfect! Huge bowl of tender rice noodles with plenty of veggies and the broth is a delicious balance of hot and sour.
author: Nyna R.

description:
Pretty good food served in a typical hole in the wall place in Upper Haight.  

The lighting is on the dim side so if you want to eat in a chill atmosphere with that new girl you just met, this is your place.  Beware though, it can get crowded and loud at times and no matter where you sit, you won't have much room.

Service is prompt and their bathroom seems more sanitary now than it used to so what the hell, 4 stars.
author: Mark J.

description: I was very disappointed this time coming into Citrus Club. I'm from out of state and every time I come to the San Francisco I always make sure we come and eat here. The food was great as always, but the service was the worst service I have ever received in my life. I was with two other people and we were shocked how bad of a server we had. First she didn't write down any of our orders and out of 4 things we ordered she got two of them wrong. Second she never said your welcome when we would say thank you. Third she never smiled. Fourth we saw her putting our food in to go boxes and she only put half of our food in to go boxes. If I ever walk into there again and she is there we will choose some where else to eat. She has reddish hair and tattoos on her arms and she is very unapproachable looking. She should not be working with customers.
author: Kasandra A.

description:
Messed up our order. 
Pad Thai was sub par.. Soggy really. With tomatoes? 
Bleh. Not coming back
author: Joan J.

description:
Someone really awesome took me here and she heard about it from her friends, so we thought we'd try it out. 

For starters, the garlic edamame is a must try! edamame always a good appetizer, but they threw their own twist on it with the garlic and its awesome.

I got the spicy lemon and coconut chicken noodles(which looked like chicken alfredo) and the garlic beef and shitake. although they looked plain and like something you may have had before, the tastes totally catches you off guard like two naked people hopping out of your closet like a damn magic show. overall, a delightful lunch experience.
author: Alvin P.

description:
Purrrrfect! It's getting to be that time of year again in the Bay Area. The days are cold, and windy, the rain falls in a constant mist - soaking everything. But we have one of the coolest parks out there, Golden Gate park. So what's a girl to do when she's been playing out in the park, in the rain and wants to warm up? Head to The Citrus Club! Conveniently located in the far western part of the Haight, the range of hot hearty Asian inspired soups warm you all the way down to the bones. Do I need to say more?...your bones, they get toasty, it tastes great and you'll forget you have soaking wet feet.

Oh and get a Thai iced tea too. Goes great with a spicy soup.
author: Sarah M.

description: Pretty good food and the spring rolls are very tasty..... not a bad spot to enjoy and good vegetarian meal...
author: Tony F.

description:
Asian noodle lovers paradise!  Or hell, possibly, if you're bad at making choices.  Basically, every Asian noodle you could want - tom yum noodle soup, pho, pad thai, pad see ewe, chow fun...ASIAN NOODLE FEAST!

Furthermore, some of the portions are HUGE!  The noodle soup bowls are comically large and I actually had some pan-fried noodles left over which was a combo of large potions and my attempt to hide my inner fattiness amongst my company.  :)  It was a little hard to find, but definitely a good dinner option in the Haight.
author: Krystle S.

description:
Bland and mediocre food.

Bland and mediocre service.

Non-existant rice. 

What kind of asian restaurant does not serve any kind of rice whatsoever?
author: Pity D.

description:
Let me ask you this: what is the protocol on drunk dining? Furthermore, what is the protocol on drunk yelp-reviewing?

Is it.... objective? No. Ethical? Mmmm No. Approrpiate? Proooobably not. But F it. It's happening. It's happening riiiiight NOW.

This is why Citrus deserves at least 4 stars: they had to freaking deal with my group of friends. That alone, is definitely 4 star worthy. Not only did we show up, pre-liquored up from another restaurant, but we proceeded to completely fill their reservation chalk board with doodles and requests (*insert drawing of chinese dude* and "feed us now!!!"). We were very very.... very loud, drank waaay too much sake, dropped stuff, spilled drinks, stole other table's chopsticks, interrupted other people's dates and then ordered even more sake.

Our server deserves a purple heart for that stuff- AND she did it with a giant smile (and the ocasional giggle when my friend did something stupid). Thank god for you, lady.

Don't get me wrong, drunken dining is all the rage, but you still need to have damn good food. One thing to note when you come here is that this place is Thai-Japanese fusion, so don't expect to see your traditional Chang/Singha beer, red/yellow/green curries, pad siu, som tam and all other traiditional Thai dishes. You CAN expect good food though. My Pad Thai was far from traditional - they used a thinner noodle and a creamier base, and although my Thailand days make me crave the legit stuff, I have to admit that this version was absolutely amazing. It was less eggy, a little bit sweater and I could have probably eaten a gallon's worth of it. 

So why the -1 star? Well, my snobby-ass self wants to go full 5 stars (its usually my standard for drunken dining, if you haven't noticed already) but the lemon & ginger chicken and Thai iced tea were pretty flavorless. Minimal complaints though. Most of the food is still rad, prices are decent and the environment is awesome for a fun dining experience. 

I suggest all of you to try this place [to get/when drunk], but don't tell them I sent you... I don't want to start a bad rep in there. ;)
author: Emily G.

description:
I went here for dinner one time. The staff was rude and unfriendly. The food was either too salty or too bland, both without real flavor. 
I probably won't come here again. It was too crowded and you feel uncomfortable.
author: Dat P.

description: Garlic beef and shiitake noodles are my favorite!  Been coming here for 10 years and it's always great!
author: Sara C.

description: The citrus club is one of my favorite places for pad thai in the city and their lychee martini's are awesome! The place is a little dark and crowded, but the food is well worth it. I have never been disappointed here.
author: Courtney H.

description:
I went to The Citrus Club tonight with Rosy. What I love about hanging with foodie friends is they also know good places to go eat. 

We went to The Citrus Club in search for some soup for her and as soon as I saw that sign that said Noodles, I knew what I wanted. NOODLES.

I ordered the Mongolian Beef Noodle Special. Not too saucey, vegetables cooked perfectly and the shitake mushrooms were sauteed and sooo good ~ all served on top of a pipe of noodles.

My friend Rosy had a Coconut Thai Soup with Tofu and Noodles. It was so good and probably the perfect thing when you are not feeling good, very warming and a little sweet on the throat. (Keep that one in mind next time). 

We also ordered some Vietnamese Spring Rolls which were fresh and served with a yummy peanut sauce. 

All that - plus lots of leftovers to take home for only $25.00. Definately a good value for the price.
author: Rebekah T.

description: I was set on having me some Ploy II my favorite Thai place..they were closed so we ended up at Citrus Club. We got the hot and sour shrimp noodle soup and the Shanghai noodles with beef and vegetables. The food came out within 5 minutes, umm did they even cook it? ha. Well the noodles were WAY overcooked! to the point of being soggy. The Shanghai noodles were soggy and way too sweet and the beef was chewy dry and hard. The soup dish was ok, the flavors were all there but there was not enough noodles, and they were soggy overcooked noodles. I don't think I would ever come back.
author: Karen T.

description: My favorite thai food on Haight Street. Great noodle dishes, and portions re HUGE. Service is very fast usually, but the place is tiny and does not take reservations, so often you have to wait for a while.
author: Gina T.

description:
I can't think of one negative to this place.

Noodles? Amazing. 
Garlic Edamame which is the best I've EVER HAD? Check.
Eat in or order take out? Both
Takes credit cards? Yep.
Walking distance from my house? Mmm hmm.
Cheap? Like under $10 cheap.

Come here and get the Marmalade Coconut/Leomongrass shrimp. $9.95. Worth every penny.
author: Melissa N.

description:
Yes to the Citrus Club!

Make sure to start with the garlic edamame. Also advised is the Mandarin style chow mein. 

All in all you can't really go wrong here. The food is good and entrees tend to range from  $5-10, WIN! Drinks are also inexpensive ;)
author: Rachel R.

description:
First, I liked the atmosphere of The Citrus Club, especially because it's so unexpectedly nice given it's location on a skeezy block in the Haight. It's too bad their food sucks.

Tofu and Seaweed Salad: Very good seaweed salad, but it waserved ringed with blocks of cold, raw, plain tofu with a dash of chili powder for color. Who does that? Pale, uncooked tofu is like the food equivalent of a dementor in Harry Potter -- it sucks the happiness out of anything nearby. 

Spicy Coconut Lemon Chicken: In spite of its name, this dish delivered only bland, strung-out flavor with a hint of spice and an almost criminal lack of saltiness or any sort of richness. In fact, this item was almost weirdly bad, considering that it contained some good looking ingredients. 

Pad Thai: Another strange dish that must have taken a special effort to fuck-up so badly. The poor noodles were smothered under an odd, sticky, gloppy sauce that was too thick to coat them and, instead, just sat there looking pale and yucky. It had an unpleasant washed-out rancid peanut taste and, as with the spicy coconut chicken, a studied lack of any richness or savoriness. Just bad.

Garlic Beef with Shitake:  Uhm ... this was delicious! I mean, this dish was somehow really, really good,. The mushrooms were rich and flavorful, redolent of star anise, soy sauce and garlic. The beef was flavorful and tender and the chow fun noodles were perfect. Lucky for me, this was my entree. It delivered far more flavor than the sum total of everything else we ordered.
author: Todd H.

description:
I came in here and I was just confused.  There was a line, so we proceeded to wait in line.  Then we find out that there's a sign-up sheet that was obscured by the people in line.. Why didn't anyone tell us sooner?  Fortunately, the wait wasn't too long.

The place was also super dim (and CRAMPED).  It seemed as if candles were the only things keeping the place lit.  Then, our neighbor's candle went out and it reminded me of when I was in high school and there was a blackout, and I had to finish my homework by one candlelight.

The food also wasn't fantastic.  I am not a fan of coconut but I ordered it anyway because I didn't think it would be so strong.  I was wrong.. it was strong.  Their tom yum noodle soup was good though, not too sour.  Service was great -- there was someone to refill our glasses every 5 minutes it seemed.

I love noodles.. but I won't be coming here again.
author: Vivian H.

description: Got the grilled Salmon and garlic noodles and it was DELISH.  Prices were good and portions were generous.
author: Lucia M.

description:
I eat in and get take out from the Citrus club pretty often. They are usually not too crowded compared to other places on Haight street. The food is decent and the quantities are huge. My favorite dishes are the BBQ Tofu summer rolls and the peanut noodles. The peanut noodles can definitely use more spice though (more of that dark peanut sauce they serve with the rolls would be great).

I have also had their coconut soup but found it very bland. They really just need to add a lot more flavor to all of their food!
author: Vrushali P.

description:
Nice and cozy.
Bland food.
Felt pretty bad afterwards. 
meh!
author: Amalie A.

description:
Ended up here eating here before an Earthquakes game last week. The boyfriend was in the mood for noodles and the restaurant looked interesting enough. We needed something quick to eat and noodles are generally a safe bet for quick dining. 

The food was okay. I ended up with one of the daily specials. Spinach noodles with beef or something to that extent. It wasn't really bad and it was pretty decent to eat. I thought the sauce was kind of salty and it was generally kind of bland. Meat was also a little chewy.The food and drinks were relatively cheap, though, especially given the generous portions you're given. 

We were kind of in a hurry, so time was of the essence. It was a little slower than we would have liked, and it was kind of annoying to see people who came after us get their food first. Really, it did get crowded the longer we were there, but it wasn't when we first got there. 

I really do have to give our server a lot of credit though. She was very nice and even though there ended up being a food mix up, she handled it very well. 

I was also impressed at how different the interior looked from its relatively non-spectacular exterior. It was actually kind of cute inside. It was also a lot more spacious than what I expected when I first walked into the joint. 

Overall, it was good at the time. While I don't know if I would give it two stars, I doubt I'd eat there again if I'm in the area.
author: Alea G.

description: Not bad, not bad. They give you a hefty helping of food for minimal dollars. I had shrimp with curry sauce and noodles. It was fresh and flavorful.  I'd go here again if I was passing through the neighborhood.
author: Linnea H.

description: I'm sick and all I could think about all day was the Thom-Ka Coconut Tofu Noodle Soup. I couldn't get out of bed so I found a website that I could pay to have someone pick up my soup and deliver it to me. 4 hours later right as Citrus Club closed the delivery person finally brought it to me. Even after waiting that long and paying so much to have it delivered it is still the best damn noodle soup I have ever had. No comparison and I have tried a bunch! I only just wish they would deliver!
author: Devin S.

description: Best Hot & Sour Soup I have ever had!  Loved the Garlic Edamame too!
author: Stacey H.

description: The prices are decent, as is the food, and they're fast. It's just that they're unspectacular. Had the special chicken curry noodles.
author: Maximillian M.

description: This place is on of my favorite restaurants in SF. It has a cool SF vibe on haight. The place isn't too big so if you're coming past 6pm expect to wait a bit. The food is great! The service is outstanding! The place is clean! A bowl of food is usually between $8-12. It could be two meals, if you go for lunch split it. For dinner one bowl per person is more than enough. I've visited this noodle house more often than any other restaurant in the city and will keep coming back. Thanks to everyone that works here. You all are doing outstanding!
author: Lucas P.

description: I'm being 70% serious when I say half the reason I go to SF is so that I can get a warm bowl of  Citrus Club's vegetable noodle soup and avocado rolls. The bowls are around $9-$10 and the portions are HUGE - to go bag almost always necessary unless you are particularly starving. You can tell there is no MSG or unnecessary additives in the soups because you always leave happy, full, and trying to figure out how you can get a bowl to go on the way to the airport in the morning (okay, maybe that's just me...).
author: Sabrina S.

description:
The CItrub Club is a quaint asian fusion restaurant in the Haight. The food was great, and the menu provided a wide variety of all kinds of asian cuisine: japanese, thai, vietnamese, and chinese. I tried the garlic edamame (It was good, but a little bit oily), the soba vegetable soup which was very good. But warning the portions are large! I did order sake however and the large was not large at all....

Overall the ambiance was alright; the lighting was very dim and there weren't many seats so I wouldn't really advise going here if you're with a large party.

I had a good experience and definintely reccommend it  for a casual night out.
author: Sara Y.

description:
My first time here for dinner and it was packed! We had to wait about 20-30 minutes for a table, but I can't blame them since it usually takes longer to sit a party of 4. After we sat and ordered we still had to wait another 20-30 minutes for our food to arrive which was a bummer since we were all hungry.

We ordered a Viet spring roll and a Chicken salad which was very tasty and flavorful. I guess these two dishes made me have high expectations about the food, but when food came I've gotta say I was a bit disappointed. I ordered a tofu curry noodle, which tasted bland. The bf ordered a Ginger chicken noodle and his brother ordered a Korean short rib, both meats tasted good but the noodles weren't that great. At least they were very attentive and made sure our water was always filled.

I guess this is a nice spot for a casual dinner with friends or family with good service and not very expensive, I might give them another chance, but for now it's A-OK.
author: Oriel F.

description:
Super affordable, delicious, and huge portions!  
The place is super chill and the staff is always super friendly.

If you are on a budget, this place is definitely the way to go.
author: Andrea F.

description:
If you are looking for a good lunch or dinner, the Citrus Club should do. They have a great selection of noodle dishes all at a decent price. As pictured, we ordered the cashew chicken, BBQ spring rolls, and the baru soba.

The cashew chicken was soooo good.... wok tossed egg noddles with chicken, mushrooms, zucchini, red peppers, carrots, cashews and tamarind sauce. Even though I really do not like zucchini or red peppers, the juices from everything else make them delicious! 

Oh ya.... BBQ spring rolls, thai iced tea, and the soba... all great!

From what I remember, the garlic edamame was great! It just seemed kind of pricey...

If you are in SF, I definitely recommend trying this place out.... I go back  whenever I am up there.
author: Brien M.

description: This is an asian fusion restaurant, great flavors and we like the atmosphere and location. If you want soup, this is the place to go!! My review on their other food, is just whatever, I can get that anywhere, but the SOUP is the star of the restaurant. This place is cheap, gets crowded in the evenings (so there may be a wait) but the wait and crowdedness is part of the experience. They also light candles and have low lighting in the evenings, which is nice for a cheap restaurant for any day of the week. I like it!!
author: K K.

description: Highly recommend this Place if you're in the mood for asian fusion. I had the Garlic Beef & Shiitake Mushrooms......which was delicious!!! I also tried the Sake Margarita.....not my cup of tea but may be yours (too sweet).....I'll stick to hot sake or beer next time and be a VERY happy camper!
author: Sean F.

description: Obsessed with the garlic edamame. Delicious food / very friendly staff / quick service / reasonable price.
author: Renee G.

description:
I feel pretty comfortable eating out alone, and after I placed my order for Tom Ka-Thai Coconut Tofu Soup with rice noodles I was pretty comfortable eavesdropping and checking out what other people ate, until the soup came...

Really this portion was enough for 3 people - - I am dead serous, if you go alone -- take to go container, to contain the soup leftovers, it will last!

However, beside "complaining" about the portion size, I should say that the taste of the soup itself was sweet and tangy, really enjoyed pieces of fried tofu, which tasted a lot like "not tofu, but better".

I noticed interesting dish at the nearby table -- rice noodles aka fettuccine alfredo with Thai twist -- next time i will go for it!
author: Anelya S.

description: We had the spring rolls and pad thai. We also got the coconut lime noodles. Delicious and very inexpensive.  Great lunch options. Enjoyed our service and food. Will return.
author: Cat M.

description: Not a great meal. Greasy, overcooked noodles with passable shrimp served in a giant pile, with some boiled-to-death vegetables mixed in. "Egg drop soup" was really just chicken noodle with some egg white thrown in. Portions are indeed large, but the food wasn't any better after being reheated the next day.
author: Alex L.

description:
I'm not quite sure why I stopped in here tonight - my last experience was over a year ago and I swore it off after eating some sort of odd creamy dish they tried to call pad thai.

I think because it was cold and I was feeling lazy, I stopped in for some beef pho. Now, I basically live for pho and I'm admittedly spoiled by all the delicious options that I frequent in the tenderloin.

But this was just not good. The broth was somehow greasy and flavorless at the same time. The beef was of questionable quality. And it was a few dollars more than I'm used to paying for a quality bowl.

It didn't make me ill or anything, but I won't be coming back again.
author: Lauren B.

description:
Is this is what passes for acceptable asian food in SF?  Why do the yellow coconut curry tofu & nuts, spicy curry tiger shrimp and pad thai look exactly the same?  

B is for bland, boring, and blahhh.  I guess I'm spoiled by all the amazing thai food in socal because this place was so disappointing.  An insult to my asianness.
author: Alissa M.

description: This place is great. Really good food and it's not that expensive at all. 2 dishes, an appetizer, and drinks for 2 came out to be $37. RAD!
author: Andy D.

description:
My sister, cousin and I came here while shopping on the Haight. Boy, were we glad we found this hidden gem! The entrance to it makes it look like a small, order-at-the-counter type of place, but we were greeted by a nice hostess and taken to the back part of the restaurant where there are a dozen tables you totally can't see from the front.

The menu has all sorts of Thai dishes, noodle soups and noodle dishes. Considering my love of noodles, I had no problem with this. I got the chicken curry with jasmine noodles, my sister got the Pad Thai and my cousin got the Peanut Noodles with Chicken. We also ordered the Thai Iced Tea which comes in two sizes.

My dish was very good, I have no complaints, as was my sister's. My cousin's Peanut Noodles was too peanutty though, so much peanut sauce and little chunks of peanuts t was overwhelming at times. Still delicious, but that was my only complaint.

The food was served in a timely manner, the server was very friendly, and it was all decently priced. They also had a specialty mojito drink I wanted to try, but wasn't quite in the mood for a drink at that time. It was decently priced at only $6. That's pretty awesome to me.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
We stopped here on our adventures walking SF, so I was tired, and wanted a place to sit and have a drink and something small to eat- since we had been eating here and there all day. 

The Citrus Club is a cute little place with a nice atmosphere.  There were lots of people seated at tables, and the wait staff were friendly.  Since we were not in the mood for a heavy meal, we opted to chill at the bar.  An ice cold Sapporo and Vietnamese spring rolls and beef satay later, we were happy campers.  It was awesome that they had Sapporo ON TAP at the bar.  Maybe the East Coast isn't as friendly to Japanese beer as on the West Coast, but this was one of the first times I've even had the option of having a draft Sapporo.  
Anyway, the spring rolls were nice and fresh, and the beef satay was decent.  

Since we were sitting at the bar, we would see all of the food and drinks coming and going from the kitchen to the tables.  We were intrigued by the waitress stirring cream into this dark orange liquid, so we asked what the concoction was- turned out to be Thai iced tea.  But the waitress offered us a taste- which was nice! :)

We were disappointed to not be hungry enough to try their noodles, but next time we are in SF that's one thing on our list!
author: Jaemie D.

description: We live in the neighborhood and come here periodically.  The Asian fusion menu has good variety.  The servings are large, so it will fill your appetite.  The surroundings were at one time not great, to the post of being dirty, but they have fixed it up considerably.  I had the chicken egg drop soup most recently (wasn't feeling good) and it hit the spot.  The severe are very nice.
author: v n.

description:
A friend of mine brought me here and it was so good!  I got pho which was pretty good and the house noodles were amazing too.  Prices were pretty good as well as the spring rolls! 

i will definitely be coming back here more often.
author: Julie B.

description:
This doesn't get 4 stars because it's the best quality of asian fusion I have ever had, but it's super convenient, quick, cheap, and the staff is always super attentive and friendly.

Also it's pretty impressive you can get beer, wine and cocktails. 

I've had too many of the items on their menu, but their tom-ka and hot and sour shrimp noodle soup are common favorites amongst my group of friends.
author: Kari G.

description: Great place to get a large, filling bowl of noodles at an affordable price. My favorite so far has been the Pho. Every time I have gone, I have been able to get seated quickly when nearby bars are filled to capacity. As an added bonus, their lemon-lime margaritas are also very tasty.
author: Karina L.

description:
