As a vegetarian, I want to like this place.  They have a ton of meat free options.  I've eaten here a few times, and my opinion is mixed.   The noodle soups are delish.  The BBQ tofu satay, delish.   The hot noodle dishes are sort of creamy and weird.  The Pad Thai does not resemble any other Pad Thai I've ever eaten.   I would avoid.   

BUT... my friend and I wanted to have a mommy date with both of our one year olds.  Unfortunately they don't have high chairs.  WHAT?  No, seriously.  The waitress told me "we used to have one, but it broke."  I'm not really sure how you can be so close to Cole Valley, Whole Foods, and in the middle of a tourist hub and not think that your customers may benefit from a high chair or two.  That alone will keep me from coming back for, say, another year or two.
author: Nicole B.

description:
I have always had a great time and great food here.
One of my favorites is the Garlic Beef & Shitake Noodles.
HUGE PORTIONS!
The only reason for 4 stars is there has often been a bit of a wait.
author: Jacquie R.

description:
I used to not like this place very much.  Afterall, with two superior Thai places on the same block, what reason do I have to frequent this place?  It's true that they have more of a specialty in noodles, but I never found their noodles to be that special.

In fact, I once went to get lunch takeout from them, and decided to get their special that day, the "jade noodles" that are supposed to be made of spinach, I think.  Sounds good, right?  Oops, wrong, of course.

Now, I was not aware that spinach was in the family of glow-in-the-dark vegetables, so imagine my surprise when I opened the container, and found that the noodles were this color: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spring_green_%28color%29

It reminded me of playdoh, which, while I did in fact eat at some point in my life, is now off the list of foods that I regularly consume.  It was unnerving, to say the least.  I tried a few bites, and while it wasn't the worst thing I've ever tasted, it did not make up for the unholy food coloring used.

This experience traumatized me so much that afterwards, everytime I am tempted to order jade noodles from other restaurants, I would ask the waiter what color their jade noodles were - are the the green on that man's ugly sweater? Or are they the natural green of that dying plant in the corner? 

That said, I recently gave them another chance and had their chicken noodle soup, and it was delicious.  The portion was so large I ate out of a mixer bowl.  It was perfect for a rainy Sunday night.

So...in conclusion, I think the quality of their food can be a little mixed.  I will probably return on another rainy day, and get their soup noodles, but I am staying far far away from their jade noodles from now on.
author: jon y.

description:
After eating at the Citrus Club for what must be my 50th time over the years, I was surprised to see I'd never reviewed it.  The Citrus Club is currently and has always been my go to joint.  When I have friends in town, when I'm low on funds, when nothing sounds good, when I want a mellow night - it fits most occasions.  

I've seriosuly never had a disappointing meal here.  I adore their soups, their noodles, the BBQ tofu spring rolls and the garlic edamame.  I love the casual feel, the intimacy of the space and the open kitchen.  The servers are always friendly and efficient, the ingredients taste fresh and the dishes don't sit around for a second when they're done cooking.  

Suffice it to say, this is a "love" place.  And I will continue to go back again and again.
author: Mac M.

description:
The portions and the prices are reasonable.
The service is friendly.  Quick too!
Decor is simple. 
Bathroom area...interesting.  (Very small, sink area is outside of the toilet.  It's weird to me, with an open door to the sink, m'kay!)

Well, the food is okay. But.... I'm still not a fan of Asian fusion.  The pad thai was different, and my tofu and greens were delicious.  Plenty of vegetarian options too! Yum.

Note: There was a hair in our shrimp spring rolls *eeeeks*  which we sent back....but it's all good.  But I thought I'd share that tidbit.
author: Fannie S.

description:
Oh the Citrus Club... you ol' dog, you.

Like an old friend, the menu at Citrus Club has not changed since the heady days of the late 90's when it first opened. 

Had the Lemon Coconut Chicken noodles and the folks at the table ordered the curry Tom Na soup. As expected, massive portions. Everyone left satisfied.

Let's be honest, it is not the best bowl of noodles in the City, but Citrus Club adds enough ambience, location, and good drinks to make it a worthwhile visit.

3 star food, with a 4 star experience. I love that place!
author: Jefferson S.

description: Recommended by a coworker.. Generally unimpressed by the flies, service and pho. Want to love this place, so hard to find good Vietnamese soup in this city!
author: Kevin J.

description:
I love this place but on my last visit I received some of the worst service I've had at a restaurant.

I was with two friends who had eaten, but were down to accompany me to dinner and share some appetizers. It was busy, but we were seated pretty promptly. 

The server with glitter all over her face seemed pretty dazed from the permanent burning man that must be her life and went from saccharine sweet to total bitch mode when she realized we weren't going to all order a full dinner. Apparently they have a $9 minimum before drinks, per person, at dinner hours. This wasn't posted anywhere in the restaurant or on the menu. The server stormed off before asking if we'd like to order more, or sit at the bar, or order to go. 

Awkward. We walked back to the bar area, where there was no one waiting for a table. There were 3 vacant tables in the restaurant. 

I had my heart set on soup and decided to order to go. Everyone working completely ignored me for 10 minutes. I was finally able to order from the dude at the bar and was told my order would take 15 minutes. Went down the street for a bit and returned 20 minutes later. I was ignored AGAIN for 10 minutes. After which time the dude at the bar glared at me and told me my order still wasn't ready. Waited another 5 minutes, got my food, and left. 

My bill came to $20. Which is only $7 less than their "minimum." We would have been happy to order more if we'd been treated with more respect and the server had given us that option. 

I regret leaving a 20% tip but I'd rather kill people with kindness than follow their bad example and be an asshole. 

As someone who works customer service jobs 6 days a week I feel like I have a right to expect the same kind of service I provide people. I deal with my share of assholes, and know what it's like to have to follow certain rules within a restaurant, but I also know how to treat people with kindness and respect, and be honest about wait times.

I've been a regular customer at Citrus Club for 5 years now, used to eat here several times a week, and in the last year I've been by at least once a month. The daytime staff are always lovely, and even on busy nights I've been happy with service, but the attitude I got this last visit is enough to make me not want to go back.
author: Kelly Kate W.

description:
While working at Cal, a woman and I discussed how she and I both live in San Francisco. The Haight is not a neighborhood I've spent much time in, so I asked her for some restaurant suggestions. This is one of three places she recommended (others were Magnolia & Cha Cha Cha). 

Being the adventuresome people we are, the boyfriend and I decided to venture out of our comfort zone and explore the Haight Ashbury side of things. (PS: I LOVE the housing in the Haight!!!!) We discovered parking in this area blows.

Anywho, we decided to have an early dinner and ventured into the Citrus Club. As it was 5ish on Saturday night we were seated immediately. The Citrus Club is a no "frills" restaurant- the decor isn't anything special (little red strings of lights), but it's comfortable and cozy. I dug the random music they played while we were there (Chris Issak, Amy Winehouse, etc...) but the volume was a little loud. I found it difficult to hold a conversation with the boyfriend across the table from me.

I ordered the Pho-Ga (Asian Chicken Noodle Soup) which I must say is my FAVORITE soup to date that I've had in San Francisco. The next time I'm sick, I'm totally ordering this out. It was fantastic, and the portion was FABULOUS for 9 bucks. The Citrus Club is getting a 4-star review solely because this dish is awesome! (You must add the lemon, herbs, jalapenos, and bean sprouts. It just does the trick!!!!)

My boyfriend ordered the Shrimp Wonton soup and loved it. I wasn't as big as a fan, but he said he'd absolutely order it again.

The Citrus Club has won me over. I'll be back!
author: Annalise F.

description:
I'm a HUGE noodle fan. If you knew me back in college of sophomore year (which was a LOOOOOOOOOOOONG time ago), I ate noodles for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Seriously, I'm not joking! I really did! So when I found out that citrus club was a noodle restaurant, I was super excited! I've been here a few times so let me tell you what I love:

Tom ka-Thai Coconut Tofu Soup(One of my favorites)

Hot-Sour Shrimp Noodle Soup (tastes like tom yum noodle soup)

House Pad Thai (Best pad thai in the entire universe! I think it's a fusion mix of pad thai because it's creamier than normal pad thai)

Garlic Beef & Shitake Mushrooms (Beef is very tender)

I would skip out on the Sweet Chili-Glazed Tofu & Greens, was not my favorite. It was a bit too sweet to be a dinner dish. 

This place is not a very big place so you need to come at a good time to ensure you get a table. Also the prices are reasonable! Everything is under $10 and I always have leftovers because the portions are large.
author: Nancy Y.

description: Went in for dinner on a Thursday with a friend who's been coming here for years. Spectacular service from the get-go: they were able to seat us immediately and get us started with some drinks. I opted for a good ol' bottle of Saporo. For food I had the grilled ginger chicken which comes over garlic noodles. The portion size was pretty big for the low price -- and the taste was yummyyyyyyyyy. Lots of refill on water (always a plus for me) and friendly chit-chat. It's on Haight street near Amoeba. I want to come back!
author: Jonny A.

description:
Oh, the Citrus Club. One of my favorite cheap, hole-in-the-wallish Asian food joints, even if I have to haul myself across town to get there. I can't believe it's taken me this long to write something. Anyways, went with the BF on Saturday evening, mostly because I was tired of eating at the same Asian restaurants in Nob Hill (no offense) and I needed to leave the house (no take out please). 

The pros:
- Good variety of food, from cold noodle salads to piping hot soups to grill meats
- Outrageously large portions....only come when you're hungry, stoned, drunk or are in need of several days of leftovers. 
- Good range of drinks (both leaded and unleaded, if you will)
- Amazingly well priced

The cons:
- There is almost always a wait for a table, although the bar is first come, first serve
- The service ranges from overly friendly to overly surly, with little consistency

Overall:
A great bet if you're in the Haight and find yourself craving a huge portion of some sort of Asian cuisine.
author: Jenn G.

description:
Since when 7.95 for a bowl of Pho is considered to be equal to $ pricing range....

Obviously, you haven't lived outside SF if you think this place is really cheap. It's moderately priced, but not cheap at $15-20 a head, especially when I can go get a bacon dog and a coke for $4 and I'm paying $6.50 for just garlic edamame. Albeit, kicking and aromatic edamame that only further reinforces my love for the unpretentious baby soy bean. 

But despite the incorrect pricing rating on Yelp, the Pho ga Chicken Noodle was right on the money and our pitcher of pear cider washed everything down nicely. The wait was long, but really it just means you need to either suck it up and eat at the bar or bring good company to drown out the wait. Our waiter wasn't fussy and the busboy remember to fill our waters twice. 

Now if only the Pho were as steamy naughty as the thoughts circulating through my head throughout this dinner....
author: Alita M.

description:
This place makes me really sad. I tried three bowls of noodles, and I liked NONE of them. Jackpot! 

I was kinda excited coming in. Nice decor at the entrance, and pretty good service too. Plus, I love Asian fusion... menu looks interesting. 

I ordered the hot and sour noodle soup aka Tom Yum, because people speak Thai in there~ So I thought maybe they do thai food well. Friends also ordered beef with shitake mushroom noodle, and chicken noodle soup. 

SO SALTY! I hate to give bad reviews, but it's worse than instant noodle. I am so sad. Plus, there's no effort in plating. My bowl has a big chunk of noodle with some slices of carrot, broccoli all over~ it just doesn't look appetizing, at all. The broth is not thick enough. It's the same thing with my friend's chicken noodle soup. Beef with shitake looks better, but it's way too sweet on the first bite~ and second bite is full of salt. 

Well at least, they have a good selection on drinks.
author: Marlis T.

description:
GARLIC EDAMAME! House speciality and local legend. If you come to SF and don't eat here you are an idiot. Where else can you have a homeless punk offer to let you kick them where ever you want for a few dollars and then eat an amazing giant meal? I have even driven from San Jose all the way to San Fransisco just for this restaurant. 

I wish i could give this place six stars but i can't. One day i will move to this area and rent a closet in this restaurant for a ridiculous price (2000$+). Even if they fed me scraps and made me wash dishes i would still feel that it would be an even trade.
author: Charles O.
Casey C.

description: Yummmmazing. I am so happy with my meal at this spot. We've struck out a few times in San Fran on the food situation and this spot made up for it. Easy on the purse... Under $10 for a meal you can split and super great quality food. I try to only write reviews when I am overwhelmed with the great quality of a place (yelp love) and this place made me do it.  You MUST get the chicken noodle soup. Trust me. And split it because it is huuuuuuuge.
author: Leah L.

description:
Citrus Club has been a favorite of mine for about three years and counting! It is my go-to for comfort food, especially as the weather starts to get damp and cold.

THE GOOD STUFF!
I can"t say I've ordered anything here that I didn't enjoy. 
-I usually go for the peanut noodles with chicken or the garlic beef noodles dish substituted with egg noodles. 
-The Pho soups are fabulous and the portions are always more than expected. -Make sure you get the garlic edamame for an appetizer. It will rock your world if you love garlic as much as I do. 
-The space is warm and cozy with cute decorations and a totally comfortable vibe.
-The staff is always friendly and efficient

THE NOT-SO-GOOD STUFFS
It can get real busy, not that this is a bad thing. I'd like them to stay open. 
-Just avoid the dinner rush and do take out or try to snag a bar spot. 
-If your coming with a hoard of people I'd advise against it, the restaurant is fairly cramped. What makes it one of my favorite things also becomes its downfall as it becomes more busy. 

Overall, I'll expect to continue to get my noodle on here in the future as long as this establishments continues to represent Haight St.
author: Jeremy R.

description:
Like Christian N., "I don't get this place." I've eaten here 3 times. After the first time, I was disappointed with the Jade Noodle dish; the flavors were bland and the overall dish was soggy. Yuck.
Months and months later, I was invited back by a friend and I agreed, with reservations but a somewhat open mind. I wanted to like Citcus Club as much as everyone else does. Fool me once, shame on you; fool me twice, shame on me. I don't know if I'm just ordering the worst dishes on the menu, or if I'm getting the worst serving in the batch.

2 weeks ago I was headed to Martin Mack's pub trivia and needed a quick bite for better performance. Enter the shrimp and vegetable spring rolls, hold the tofu please. The rolls I actually liked, as well as the peanut dipping sauce. For the quality and quantity of the appetizer, the price was steep. I can easily get the same quality rolls in inner richmond for 1/2 the price.

Sorry, Citrus Club is just not for me.
author: Alyssa G.

description: I come here all the time now and really like it! The beef Pho is delicious and huge!
author: Katie P.

description:
Hmm. I used to have a boner for this place because the only thing I ever got was the Tom Yum Soup (I think it it listed as sour-something soup). That soup will make you slap your mama! The garlic edamame is also a tasty surprise. Get some of that fo sho! 

But the last time we went, I got adventurous and ordered the coconut noodles... bland!! I tried so hard to like them, I really did. But they were so bland. I ended up sticking my chopsticks in everyone else's dishes for "just one more taste" just to fill me up. I didn't finish them, I didn't take them with me to go. One other dish was dull as well, and I wish I could recall what it was, as well as the dish that I did enjoy. 

Bonus for this noodle-lover: noodles in the window= very inticing. I'll be sticking to tom yum soup, which comes in a giant-ass bowl & never disappoints.
author: Eva T.

description:
We ordered a pho-like dish which was miserable. Bland and unexciting.  We ordered some short-rib-like thing which we tossed out they were so bad.

Granted this was take-out, but I don't think I'll be back.
author: Todd S.

description:
Raleigh and I dropped by Citrus Club on Friday night, my expectations were high.  I was told of the amazing values of enormous bowls of noodles and inexpensive prices.  I figured such a place would be crowded as hell on a Friday night.  Lucky for us there were two spots at the bar for us.

I ordered a "special" cashew chicken over noodle dish, Raleigh got an enormous bowl of garlic beef noodles.  After devouring my entire plate, I eyed Raleigh's still half full bowl with envy.  As we gorged ourselves on our noodles, I noticed the ever growing line behind us had snaked out the door.  Ouch

This place is across the street from the Red Vic, and the Alembic.  I hear take out is very convenient too.
author: Eric L.

description: After a long wait (no fault of the place) and watching dish after enormous dish of food shipped off I was pretty confident my hunger would displace any bad thoughts on the food. While the dishes look brilliant and have great color that beauty is only for the surface. My noodles were over cooked and squishy as was my friend's. Great portion sizes but the quantity didn't account for the quality.
author: Josh S.

description: My uncle brought me there and that place, to be honest, is alright. The ramen in there, though, is a hit! Too bad some small kid sharing the same table with us ruined it for us (especially me) and I almost lost my appetite because of that. I could go there again anytime, but even so, I'd like to be in the table alone without screaming kids (don't get me wrong---I have nothing against kids, but I just don't like to be near screaming ones).
author: Roxanne P.

description: Comfy Thai food is how I would describe this fine establishment. Portions are large and no skimping on the veggies (yay!). The edamame is the best I've ever had. I like the spring rolls. Many different items I have ordered and I've yet to be disappointed. I've been coming here since I moved here back in 2007. Though I no longer live close by, I make the special trek over the hill from time to time because it's that good. The soups are great when you're feeling sick--the vegan version of chicken soup. I order extra veggies. The servers are friendly. In fact, I once lost my wallet here and they kept it in safekeeping.
author: Shannon D.

description:
I'm rumbly in my tumbly

Cold, drizzly and a windy Saturday evening called for drastic measures in terms of foodage that was not too erratic on our somewhat befuddled digestive senses (I had preplanned for a little French) but that would have been too rich and Pork Chops at Park Chow would have been a true blow to the slow evening.....

W volunteered the Citrus Club.  The place is known for soups and Asian Fusion cuisine located in Upper Haight so I happily acquiesced.

I almost walked right past it if it were not for W steering me in the right direction.  A true hole in the wall, but perhaps it was due to the major dim lighting and wooden ambiance of the establishment.  It was so dark, most of my pictures did not come out since I own a crappy two year old camera that plays blind in dimly lit situations  ;o)

We ordered two items, the Shrimp Won Ton soup bowl and a noodle dish (beef with shittake mushrooms) and proceeded to converse on a variety of topics while awaiting our dishes.

First, the servings are huge.  The bowl of soup is large enough to feed four people with double servings.  And the noodle dish equally large.  The Won Ton soup was warm and savory, even better than most of the Won Ton soups I've ordered from Chinese Restaurants.  Lots of juicy won tons and two handfuls of baby spinach flooded the broth with texture and green intensity.  The tossed rice noodles were reminiscent of my fave Pad See Ew dish with bits of tender beef and mushrooms in a slightly sweet soy sauce base.  I would have thrown in some chili flakes and chili oil for a kick.

Ambiance was fantastic, as was the staff (quick , efficient and always kept our waters/tea filled) and the food was fabulous (cheap, large portions and good)......this is my new place to come to, even if I have a hill to climb over.
author: Miika M.

description: Hadn't had CC since USF days and was so happy to be back.  I am on day 6 of being sick and was tired of mediocre thai places in the outer aves, so we decided to venture out and get Citrus Club. Got take out and the Tom Yum soup w shrimp was perfect. Not too thick and creamy, but not just water with raw mushrooms, the broth was filled with crunchy cabbage, large sliced carrots, and snap peas.  The broth also came in its own seperate to go container with another container filled with the rice noodles, shrimp, and tofu.  The tofu was substantial and not slimy and cheap.  The shrimp was clean and delicious.  The portion size was huge and enough for two ppl. The grilled veggies with tofu and garlic is also a crowd pleaser.
author: Chelsey G.

description:
a little gem of comfort food on the otherwise blighted haight.  I was feeling sick, so went to the Citrus Club for the Hot and Sour soup - it was very very nice.  Exactly what i wanted and needed, i even asked fro extra veggies [a nice add-on if you have read my KOTN reviews].  

I will surely be back when i only have a few bucks and want a healthy and savroy soup.  Thanks Citurs Club!
author: Artnok A.

description: Limited for vegans/vegetarians, but that's expected. I orded the vegetable Soba noodle soup to go and it was very bland. But the atmosphere inside is nice and I think it's best to eat in house. I'll probably try it again and try something else.
author: Mary E.

description:
I really wished I liked this place since I live very close by.
I tried Citrus Club twice before giving up and giving in to the definitive "meh".
The lowlights:
-Exceeding loud in this club. You can forget talking to anyone you brought with you.
-The usual standard thai dishes are not standard, but not in a good way. Dishes like pad thai, satay, tom yum soup, etc. taste really odd and have weird ingredients and/or texture for the dish. (For example, the peanut sauce for the satay is as thick and chunky as peanut butter. Why is unclear.)
-Soups are served in bowls the size of your head. Possibly larger. I would prefer less with more quality.
-Noodles are really overcooked.
The highlights:
-It's open later than most restaurants on Haight St.
-They serve beer, wine and a few kinds of cocktails.
author: Veronica J.

description: You can't go wrong at Citrus Club. The portions are huge and the prices are really good! Everything I've had here is great: The noodles, soups and appetizers are all worth trying. Plus its dark and cozy- a good place to go on a foggy cold day.
author: JD W.

description:
garlic edamame. garlic edamame. garlic edamame. can't get enough!

great ambiance: upscale asian and actually not too busy to seat us right away on a fri night at 7. the lighting is pretty dim but it looks nice and warm. 

food and drink are both good deals. our server was nice enough to replace my friend's beer when she accidentally spilled it at no extra cost and didn't make a big deal about the mess. we started with the garlic edamame to share (duh). i was happy with my grilled ginger chicken served on garlic noodles - could have been a little more garlicky. my bf got the beef and shitake noodles - we all loved the noodles and sauce, but he wasn't huge on the quality of the mushrooms. other friends got and enjoyed the chicken noodle soup (huge! and best with hot sauce) and the cashew chicken noodles. 

all in all, pretty good asian fusion that's worth the price and a nice place to take friends for dinner on haight st. either after happy hour or before bar crawling.
author: Holly M.

description: I came here once before and had the Cold Coconut Lime noodles. Didn't like them all that much, or at all really. For cold noodles, I felt they were a bit thick and chewy, also they were tossed in a sauce that was sweeter than I expected. They almost tasted as if they were tossed in sugar water. I had all but written this place off but I decided to give it another try. I had the Ginger Salmon on noodles. It was delicious. The salmon was perfect, the seasoning was right on and the thick noodles taste so much better hot. I've had the salmon about three more times since then. I think I might be hooked.
author: Melina M.

description: Let me start off by saying I went to culinary school in New York and have traveled the culinary capitals of the world and hand's down, this place is one of my favorite places to eat ever.  I have driven up from Santa Cruz to San Francisco a few times just to have dinner here, it's literally that good.  Everything from their menu to the atmosphere to the waitstaff.  It is all what you want and more.  The Burmese chicken noodle was a recent special and it was one of their best. The drinks are nicely priced and the portions are hefty.  It is an honest to goodness hole-in-the-wall diamond-in-the-ruff noodle shop.  Everyone I have ever taken here has LOVED it.  If you ever make it to San Francisco, this is an absolute must.
author: James F.

description:
I wasn't disappointed with this place but I wasn't blown away either. The location was good, right in the heart of the Haight, which is nice if you're into the hippie thing I guess...I'm more of a fan of Berkeley but anyway...

Thai Iced tea was scrumptious and I enjoyed my wonderfully saucy Pad Thai (which was more of an approximation of the pad thai I'm used to...), but I guess it just wasn't what I was expecting when I ordered Pad Thai. I never thought I would say this but I guess there was too much sauce...extra points for using huge chunks of tofu though. Nom.

But anyway, service was good, and if indeed all you want is some saucy noodles with some condiments, then this is your place.
author: Leslie C.

description:
This is definitely a go-to spot of mine. They are consistent, cheap and their food makes my mouth incredibly happy.

From the outside, it doesn't look like much...but don't be deceived by the lack-luster outside of this magical land of Asian fusion. 

The servings are HUGE (definitely sharable) which is a good thing because you will want to try everything on the menu.

I highly recommend starting with the garlic edamame. From there...well, it becomes a "choose your own adventure" type of situation. My personal favorites are the lo-mein noodles, the spicy lime and coconut soba noodles and the vegetarian coconut tofu and noodle soup...but everything is so flavorful and wonderful...you really can't go wrong.
author: Fiona A.

description:
It's San Francisco. It's freezing. And I've just witnessed far too much public nudity (60+ y.o. nude man in 50 degree weather) for one Bay to Breakers!

Luckily, Citrus Club was around the corner ready and waiting to satiate my need for warm, tasty, goodness. 

My dish, which was essentially Tom Yum Noodles w/Shrimp, was fantastic. Hot and steamy and delightful and plentiful. That's how I like it. My soups, that is.

To top it off, a friendly girl left us her bottle of Sho Chiku Bai mild and silky sake! What?! Free sake!? Good heavens, thank you, sweet mysterious angel!
author: Lans S.

description:
Walk in, find the chalkboard, grab some chalk, write your name, and wait to be called. This is all completely unnecessary if you don't require a table. We required a table and thus, completed the aforementioned steps.

We were in the mood for food. They had food. I like noodles. They had noodles- cold noodles, hot noodles, soupy noodles, fried noodles... you get the picture. Our dinner would consist of noodles.

I ordered the coconut ginger chicken noodles, I think I was expecting too much when the result was kind of bland- all I could taste was the coconut and ginger. There was no salt at our table so I ended up pouring in the juices from our appetizer (which ended up working out quite nicely). 

My dude enjoyed his hot and sour shrimp soup.

The portions are huge, the dining space small, and the price is decent for the amount of food you get.
author: Loli L.

description:
Mmmmm.. citrus club.... 
One of my new favorite thai joints near my house. Not too pricy and they give you enough food per dinner plate to feed two people. Dimly lit, cozy atmosphere. Their coconut shrimp wonton soup on special right now.. delicious!
author: Monica W.

description:
I love Citrus Club...

OODLES OF NOODLES! I had the Marmalade Coconut/Lemongrass Shrimp noodles. It comes spicy, but you can adjust the spice of you want. The portions are really generous so I would recommend sharing. Next time I'll be sure to try their Ginger Salmon over garlic noodles. A guy two tables down ordered it and I kept staring... mmm Citrus Club.
author: J B.

description:
Thank you Citrus Club for being there for me throughout the years.  You've been there for me through 2 boyfriends, 2 break-ups, 1 Valentine's Day, numerous work day lunches and countless dinners with old friends.

I always order the same thing; spicy lemon coconut chicken and have deviated three times in the past 9 years.  Once for pad thai, once for tofu hot and sour soup and once for BBQ tofu spring rolls.  I recommend the soup and the spring rolls, pad thai not so much.  The spicy lemon coconut chicken is neither spicy nor that lemony but its still pretty awesome.

To top off your meal order some sake or a cranberry sake martini.  

I heart the cranberry martini.
author: Kristin Marie S.

description: If you are looking a place to take your friends with great food... than this would be it! The food is great and a decent selection at that! One of my favorite places in SF to go to. Enjoy!
author: Matt C.

description:
One of my favorite places in SF! Huge portions for cheap, great flavors. Can be a bit of a wait on crowded evenings but it's worth it. I recommend the garlic beef and shitake mushrooms and the garlic edamame for an appetizer. 

Only thing on the menu I don't like is the vegan soups - vegetable broth just isn't my thing.
author: Ben P.

description: Got a horrible customer service experience. Our waiter said sit anywhere, so we sat in a booth and was asked to move seats to a table in the middle just in case a large party would happen to come in. The waitress was really quick to offer no options, and 'I'm sorry I can't help.' Went a time before when I saw a waiter having drinks with a large group when the water refills were pretty poor. It's a shame because the food is pretty good but the service ruins the whole thing.
author: Keenan H.

description:
Unless I've just finished a marathon, I wouldn't come back here for a heapful of bland noodles and 4 pieces of tofu and a few nuts, in what was menued as "Coconut Tofu and Nuts" with wok-fried noodles.

Wait on a Sunday night took 30 minutes for 3.
author: K G.

description: A tiny hole in the wall place with amazing takes on noodle dishes. I only give this place 4 stars because sometimes its hard to get a spot and it can be very smokey inside at times.
author: Adam V.

description:
I second no stars. 

This place is not Asian. Even if it were Asian, what type of Asian would you call this place? It's definately not Chinese or Vietnamese. It's not Thai. So what is it? Reject Asian food?

The wait is long for something that isn't worth it. The best part was probably the tea and the garlic edamame. I usually find one dish that I grow keen on, but couldn't do so here. I had a bowl of noodles with peanut sauce which was mediocre at best. 

But the exbf loved it so I had to suck it up and go. 

Parking sucks, food sucks, service from what I remember sucks.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
The pad thai was really pretty gross - overly saucy, and frankly, I've had a stomachache ever since eating here the other night. 

If you value your gastrointestinal health, I'd stay clear.
author: jette s.

description:
The garlic edemame was the show stopper here. Very good. I'll go back just for more. The prices were right on too. Service was decent but as we were some of the only people here, it felt a little lurky. But can't blame our server. He was very kind. The food was  only Meh after the appetizer. Nothing really remarkable and I took mine home just so I could add flavor to it later. The chicken Phad Thai was unique and kind of creamy, but very good. I was told from across the table that the pho (in a HUGE bowl) was great. I had the sweet/spicy tofu noodles. I won't order that again. But I'll be back. 
The only real problem here was the temperature. It's BEYOND freezing. Bring a jacket and perhaps a blanket for that matter.
author: Jena D.

description:
I stopped in here based on Yelp reviews, and was not disappointed.   I tried the Shanghai Noodles -- great dish.    However, it is fairly bland, so feel free to use the chili sauce if you would like some kick.

Although I did not order soup, those next door to me did and they all looked great.    Soup bowls are enormous.   Prices reasonable.  Whats not to like?
author: Paul B.

description:
Really it's 5 stars for two dishes: the garlic beef with shitake mushrooms and the shanghai noodles. Everything else gets 3 stars. And it still averages to 5. Damn.

Those two dishes are just sublime. I'm stuck in a rut, but what a rut. Every time I try to mix it up, I regret it for days: why!? It's the perfect 20 dollar meal -- there are so many lousy 20 dollar meals in the city -- and the bonus is that it's less than 20 bucks (unless you get one of the pricier entrees; see previous point).

It's the kind of spot where you could take a date, an old friend, a (hipish) parent, a coworker. You'll wait on the weekends, and -- of course -- parking can be a drag. The line moves, and you can often skip it if you're willing to sit at the bar.
author: Adam L.

description: Love it here. Great food and nice atmosphere. I always order the same stuff im trying to branch out but its hard. The bowls of soup are huge. Nice little hidden hole in the wall place with great food and service in a small dimly lit space.
author: Scotty G.

description:
Used to go here frequently because it was reasonably priced, flavorful and they served large portions. I was always curious how they could afford to do that and I suspected it was cheaper quality ingredients. One day I found out they use COTTON SEED OIL. YUCK! All those oily dishes are soaked in the industrial by-product that is cotton seed oil. I don't go out to restaurants very often anymore not just to save money but for health reasons as I try to limit my toxic load. I assume many places use GM oil, but cotton seed oil has got to be one of the worst, if not the worst. It's insulting that they are okay serving their customers this crap. And the fact that their dishes are soaked in it in order to mask the dullness of their other most likely cheap/low-quality ingredients is disheartening to say the least! Don't eat here if you care about your own body or supporting a business that further contributes to the toxification of our society! 

Further reading on cottonseed oil:

http://agriculturesociety.com/politics-and-food/whats-the-truth-about-cottonseed-oil/
author: Macaulay H.

description:
We went with a party of 8 and the experience was great overall; service is good, the dishes were big and tasty at an affordable price. Although, my fiance won't vouch for his Beef Noodle Soup, he did really like the Edamame, Thai Iced Tea, and my chow fun dish. The Garlic Edamame was so good that some of the people at our table also ordered more of it to-go.

Pros: affordable, service is great, tasty dishes

Cons: parking, large group? call 1st

Appetizers:
+++ garlic edamame
++ shrimp rolls partnered with peanut dipping sauce,

Entree:
++ shrimp or veggie chow fun

Wait time is eehhh... I'm not sure if you can call in to secure a spot for your group; but if you can, go for it.
author: Anita J.

description:
Noodle... use your noodle... noodle... do the noodle dance!

Maybe it's an Asian thing, but sometimes I simply ACHE to get my noodle on. In such situations, Citrus Club does the job to satisfy all my slurpalicious cravings. I've been coming to this place ever since my older sister introduced it to me my freshman year of college. Now she lives in Portland, and when she came down for my graduation last month, she gave me a big ol' kiss when I suggested the fam eat there for lunch. Even my parents, who aren't the most adventurous when it comes to dining in the city (they prefer chains and overpriced restaurants on the Wharf when they're visiting from Hawaii) were more than satisfied when I brought them on one of their previous stays, and were enthusiastic to eat there again. I love sharing places I love with people I love!

I've read some of the others reviews saying the service here is really bad, but I honestly have never had a problem with it. While the wait staff (mostly sassy hipsters) do seem a little nonchalant, they're usually pretty efficient with bringing your food, water, check, etc. The place also does tend to get more jampacked the later it gets, so I'd suggest arriving for an early dinner or dropping by for lunch, when it's usually less busy.

I like the laidback, trendy yet unpretentious ambiance of the place too... though the sink outside the bathroom (lit by a single tealight?) has always puzzled me a bit.

As far as food suggestions go, I've tried a lot of different things and only remember being disappointed a couple of times--I think with the hot 'n sour noodle soup (too much of an overpowering flavor) and the peanut noodles (kinda bland). Other than that, the broth in most of their noodle soups is amazing, and my personal favorite, the garlic beef and shiitake mushroom noodles, has a hint of Christmas in it... yummy!!

Oh, and who could argue with the undeniably reasonable prices? You can throw in a couple of appetizers, a pot of oolong tea, and STILL have cash leftover to buy that cd you've been looking for at Amoeba after lunch.

With all that said, my favorite pan-Asian noodle shop, though hardly Asian besides its main staple, earns a stunning four stars from me.
author: Kate V.

description:
Alice S turned me onto this place.  Good and cheap - good and cheap!!!  
We had:
Spring rolls - average
Spring Salad with noodles n chx - tasty
Green noodles with marmalade shrimp and coconut cream sauce - YUM!! 
A good respite from a day of shopping and dodging dogdgy dudes in the Upper Haight.
author: Julienne G.

description: We have been going here way too often and we don't even live that close. We ventured into this awesome noodles place some time again and it has become our regular place to go in the height. I recommend the wok jade noodles dish with beef and broccoli.  It was really awesome. We bright friends and they all love the place. One down side is the super hectic seating time. You might as well wait forever for this place if you go after 6pm. The place is rather dim too and loud at a point. But overall, food is great.
author: Sutheerawan A.

description: This place was nothing short of amazing! I had the vegetarian noodle soup which was a spicy veggie broth, tofu, and vegetables and my boy had the chicken chowmein which was made in a super cool wok.  We also tried the bbq tofu spring rolls? AMAZING. This place was so fresh and SO good. Please go to improve the quality of your life, thanks.
author: Bree G.

description:
This place is kind of small and can be pretty packed after 6. I've been hear in the past and sworn it was way better, but now i think their food has slumped down to another level.

Ordered the garlic beef and shitake mushrooms and it was a disappointment.  I felt as if all the seasoning they added over powered everything.  Also had the pho ga here.  I might as well have ordered chicken water.
author: Cedric F.

description:
Whenever my girlfriend and I are going to the Haight we always make it a point to eat lunch here. LOVE their shrimp spring rolls with the sauce. I wish the sold the sauce by the jar. LOVE their noodles and soups too. Both of which are served in a bowl the size of a car tire. You will definitely get your fill even if you just have soup. 

The staff is extremely nice and on point with drink refills and service. The prices are reasonable (about $30 for two people with drinks and an appetizer).  The only problem I have here is trying new dishes because my favorites are so good already.  Even though I'm never dissapointed with the food. Today I tried the coconut cream won ton soup for the first time. It's probably the best won ton soup I've ever had. 

Highly recommend trying out the Citrus Club.
author: Cyrex G.

description:
Wow, their Miso soup was so salty, I was glad to have a bland noodle dish to counteract it.

My friend's curry was especially bland, and my monogolian beef had no bite.

I think the chef better start tasting his food.  Wonder if it was his day off on Sunday.
author: Steve F.

description:
Oh man, where do I even start with the love that's been brewing between me and this place? First, let's get the important stuff out of the way (so you can give me some cred, this being my first review and all).  I LOVE FOOD! and I've eaten at this place often enough that, even from all the way across the country, I feel like a local every time I eat there, and that's a good feeling. Since it's a local joint, it's a relatively small, no-frills hole-in-the-wall. It doesn't even deliver an awe inspiring super authentic Thai food experience, but what it does deliver, almost consistently, is fresh, tasty, cheap, and plentiful food. Waiters are attentive, seats are mostly comfy, but it can get a little drafty in there on chilly days. 

And yeah, I said "almost consistently" with the food for a reason. The soups are usually REALLY delicious (and huge), and I've never been disappointed with any of them that I can remember (I've tried almost every single one, Hot & Sour, Tom Ka, Chicken Noodle, etc.) but some of their noodle dishes can be hit or miss. The Shanghai noodles, the Mongolian beef, and the Coconut/Lemon grass shrimp and jade noodles are amazing and delicious, but others can be disappointing (Pad Thai is ok, Sweet chili-glazed Tofu is eh). 

Oh anyway, Citrus Club, how I love thee... let me count the days... 

Until I return, your faithful east-coast guy.
author: Ben G.

description:
This is definitely one of my favorite places!   I've tried so many things on the menu but my favorite is the special coconut thai shrimp dumpling soup.  I crave it, it's so good! You can get in & out at lunch fairly quick.  Friendly wait staff too. 

My only complaint is that it ALWAYS smells of cleaning solution in the dining area (at least at lunch time).  Not a very appetizing smell.  

However, the food is just so good, & I know the place is clean! :-)
author: Donna W.

description:
Citrus Club is right up the street so we thought we'd try it out and ended up having a nice little dinner there.  The restaurant is actually really cute on the inside which is hard to tell from the street.  We had solid service, not the best ever, but good.  

I got the pad thai and feel I must defend it.  It's not a traditional pad thai, but it was still a good dish!  It still has a pad thai-like flavor profile and many of the same ingredients but they do it with a creamy sauce.  Who doesn't like a creamy sauce?  Maybe it is just the Citrus Club rendition of pad thai... I thought it was yummy.

All and all a good experience, I'll be back to try the soups which also looked great.
author: Kim U.

description:
I had the Shanghai Noodles, it was Very, Very Good.  

I want to come back!

Good prices

1 Star off for the flies, that was getting annoying (indoor)
author: Andrea V.

description:
Came here for lunch after going to Amoeba music. This place was recommended to us by a few friends, and unfortunately didn't live up to their great reviews.

We ordered the ginger chicken and pad thai with chicken (although I asked for shrimp...). The chicken was a little rubbery in both dishes and the noodles weren't great. I've had better pad thai elsewhere.

Overall, big disappointment.
author: Chrim K.

description: My boyfriend and I love this place. They have all kinds of noodles. And noodles are my comfort food. The wait is never really that long and the service is very fast. I'm not sure I will ever be able to try all of their dishes as there are so many. Thanks for being so close to our yoga spot.
author: Kathleen T.

description:
I had heard things about the cold coconut lime noodles and since I am totally and absolutely bored with all the food around the Haight (where I work) I wandered over there. The waitress (who was super nice) recommended the same dish when I asked what to get. I added some shrimp! (for $2 more, not bad).

I loved it! Super tasty! although it was very, very far from being even remotely spicy, which I think it was supposed to be...i'm pretty sure spicy was in the title but maybe I'm making that up...anyway great sauce, just enough of the julienned cucumbers and carrots.

my only qualm with this dish was that the shrimp that I added had not been completely de-veined. I hate that. I'm sure there are people that don't mind that but it always grosses me out, so I just did it myself. But other than that, a great, tasty, unique meal!
author: Allison P.

description:
Everything about this place is amazing. Nice ambience, good prices, and great food!

Pad Thai with shrimp is awesome, not to mention it is a ton of food! The fresh shrimp spring rolls with the peanut sauce are a perfect appetizer. I can't get enough of them!
author: Alex G.

description:
This is a fun little spot. Apparently it been around for many many years. It's Asian-fusion, with many flavors all rolled into one! I loved the food :) the BBQ tofu spring rolls actually were served with BBQ peanut sauce..! That was a first for me! Delish!!!! :) 

The coconut lemongrass jade noodles w shrimp was amazing! Only thing..I couldn't tell if there was dairy like creme or some sort of cheese in this dish instead of the traditional coconut milk.... The Pad Thai was awesome, and the papaya salad was different than any I'd had....very good but a whole new dish! 

The mint tea was good and refreshing! Love that you can order any tea by the pot, small or large. 

Service was good, but it was late, so it wasn't busy. Cute cozy spot and great music! It was Buddha bar/yoga/spiritual music...very nice and relaxing. 

I will be coming back :)
author: Lauren S.

description:
Deeeeeeeeelicious and super cheap; get there early or you'll be waiting forever.

Very cute interior, very prompt service.

Lovesit!
author: Tasha D.

description:
Great Restaurant in a Fun Neighborhood!

I tried this restaurant purely on the yelp reviews and they were right, this place is a great cheap Asian restaurant.  I had the Shanghai Noodles due to a yelper's review.  It was delicious!  The shitake mushrooms were amazing.  

The quaint ambiance of the small restaurant add to the fun.  I would definitely recommend this restaurant to anyone who likes Asian food.  I wish that I was in San Fran for longer so that I could go back and try something else.
author: Amber T.

description:
I moved to the 'hood a could of months ago and this place has become a staple.

They focus on Asian noodle dishes of all types.  They also have the best rendition of chicken noodle soup I've ever had ("just like mom used to make").  Great garlic edamame, and everyone I've eaten with or sent here has come back very happy.

Best of all, an $8 bowl of soup or noodle dish will feed a very hungry person twice.  

This place has a line at prime mealtimes all nights of the week so arrive early or late or put in a to-go order and pick up drinks from the very friendly Ethiopian liquor store two doors down.
author: Lauren J.

description:
We started with the green papaya salad since it's on the specialty section. No flavor SAD! :(
 
We ordered Spicy Tiger Shrimp $11.50 again no flavor I guess they need to call it "non-spicy cat"

Shanghai noodles has  flavor and very tasty. 

A ok, but please add spicy and more flavor!!!!
author: Aemar E.

description: I'm allergic to seafood, and it says nowhere on the menu that there's a fish base in their chicken soups, nor even a generic "warn your server if you're allergic to seafood" type of thing. Tasted the fish in it immediately and sent it back, and then received a chicken soup with tough chicken in vegetable stock. Even though I had to wait longer when I made the switch (and needed my phone for Gps) they wouldn't charge though there was clearly an outlet right behind the bar where I was sitting. They didn't apologize for giving me seafood in a chicken soup that says nothing about seafood in the description and comped nothing, and also didn't take my credit card. Not going back. The noodles themselves were fine.
author: Bes T.

description:
Listing this place as an asian fusion joint is a bit misleading. 

Solid cheap eats. though. Had the peanut noodles. Good portions worth a meal and a half.
author: Ray J.

description: I ate the BBQ tofu spring rolls (appetizer) as my meal and they were fantastic, the sauce was to die for. The staff were super friendly and the atmosphere was nice and relaxed, plus my food came out in literally 3 minutes. Would definitely come here again to try other things on the menu, but if you're in doubt, the spring rolls are the way to go.
author: Eileen T.

description:
The Citrus Club may very well be my favorite place to have a good nosh-fest when I'm in Upper Haight, which usually means I'm attending a free in-store performance at Amoeba or hunting for some assless tights at American Apparel (not to wear, simply to carry in my purse to whip out and use as an icebreaker at parties).  The Citrus Club is described as being an Asian-Fusion place, which to me kind of just means Americanized Thai/Chinese food.  This is not necessarily a bad thing, especially in regards to The Citrus Club. 

I'm in love with one specific dish that I must order every time I come here, but luckily my friends are more adventurous, meaning I've gotten to try a bunch of other things too.  Still, in my opinion, the Mandarin-style chow mein with beef is the best dish on the menu.  If you sit at the bar, which can be a better option when dining alone than waiting an hour for an actual table, you can watch your noodles being wok-fried to awesomeness and brought immediately over to you.  The beef that they cook up is also great, all very lean and never overcooked.

The pho-ga chicken noodle soup is also superb.  Once when I had the flu, my roommate returned home from a Haight thrift-store spree with this soup in hand, swearing it had magical healing qualities.  I admit that at times I can be a bit of a picky eater, so I was a bit skeptical when I saw that the soup is served with basil, chilies, lemon and bean sprouts.  I don't know what I was thinking, because that sounds amazing, right?!  Like I said, I was sick.  Anyway, one bite of this stuff and I was feeling 100 times better AND had a new favorite rainy-day treat.  

I really like eating here because its small size ensures I feel super cozy while eating, but the wait time can get up there and make me HANGRY (a very real emotional state in which one subconsciously becomes angry by virtue of the fact that one is hungry). I definitely wish The Citrus Club took delivery orders, but I like it enough to risk feeling hangry.  Just don't talk to me until I've had that first bite of chow mein.
author: Christy J.

description:
I think the Citrus Club is a classic case where more quantity does not necessarily translate to a better eating experience.

I went in for lunch with fairly high expectations based on reviews on this site, and my own foggy recollections from several years ago. I was seated at the bar, and served by a fairly abrupt, slightly distracted bartender. I decided on the Garlic Beef & Shiitake Mushrooms noodle dish & some draft Sapporo beer. I was served a tasty cold beer and an intimidatingly huge bowl of noodles, with a heap of beef & mushrooms & bean sprouts on top. I was really taken aback at the size of the bowl...! I delved into it and went as far as I could - the beef was tender and the soupy broth was tasty. However, I was a bit grossed out by the fleshy shiitakes, and for a finish, I threw my hands up, defeated by the great depth of noodles and soup still awaiting me in the huge bowl. 

The dish was initially tasty and filling. However, by the end, I felt slightly nauseated by the sheer volume of it. Sometimes, less is more...

Also, possibly, lunchtime may not be the time to go to the Citrus Club. There's none of the seductive, hip quality I recall from my last visit. Instead, in the daytime, the place feels slightly dingy, and the staff are busy with their backroom chores, keeping only half an eye on their lunchtime customers.
author: donal c.

description: Came with a party of 7. 2 people in the group weren't eating, they just came to say hi. She tells us that there is a $8 minimum even if you don't order anything. Might I also mention that there were only 2 other parties in the restaurant!!! Our two friends decide to leave. A couple of us wanted to split a soup because the portion sizes are huge, but she said we would be charged more because it does not add up to $8. She goes on to say that the table we are sitting at is for big groups which is why we have to pay $8. We switch tables to a smaller one, but she says we still have to pay $8. She was extremely rude and kept contradicting herself. Don't go here unless you are looking for terrible service!!!!
author: Dani C.

description:
When I have money to splurge, I go to the Citrus Club and order the grilled salmon. It's what I always order and it's always terrific. Huge portions and fast, friendly service.

Since I do work around the corner, I've always get my food to go, so I can't comment on the dining in experience.

5 stars anyway!
author: Austin B.

description:
My sister was raving about this place so she brought me on over to eat there. I was craving something tangy so I ordered the House Pad Thai. Adding on meat would be an extra $2 so I didn't bother. My sister ordered the Shanghai noodles

I should've known that eating in such a dark place wouldn't make food taste too good. I mean, it's SO DARK IN THERE. Maybe it's cause the lightbulb right above our table was out. -_-

My noodles came out kind of white and pale; it almost looked creamy! I never knew pad thai was supposed to look like that, i mean sticky sure, not creamy. I ate some and it completely lacked that tangy flavor i was looking for. It almost tasted like there was mayonnaise in it! Wth. The noodles also weren't sticky anymore..:\ it was just kind of soggy and fall apart-like. at one point, i swapped with my sister because she said her noodles was too gravy-like. I took a bite and the noodles were also very soggy....and there WAS a lot of gravy.

Everything was also really, really bland. There was now PUNCH to it like I expected. Didn't like it...not worth $9 of my life, honestly. ): Won't go back anytime soon.
author: Chia W.

description: Eeh new find! And just a few blocks from my house. I've always had high standards for pho and ramen and it's not something I eat on a regular basis but yesterday I NEEDED chicken noodle soup and not the canned kind, I wanted something good. I read the reviews on Yelp and everyone mentioned the chicken noodle pho at Citrus Club was great when you're not feeling well. I'd had a long weekend of Outside Lands and was not about to trek anywhere so I walked up to this joint and ordered chicken noodle pho to takeout. When I got home I had a large cup of broth, a separate cup of chicken slathered with roasted garlic and green onions and a bag of sprouts, jalapenos, siracha and a lemon wedge. My excitement was mounting. Long story short, I made my soup with all the fixings and was instantly rejuvenated after and it was beyond delicious. I had enough for a second dinner later this week left over. Also, I did take out but the atmosphere in Citrus Club seemed great for a meal and it smelled amazing.
author: Madeline S.

description:
700+ reviews?! Holy mother... I have been coming here for years & honestly thought it was one of the Haight's secret joints, but thanks to Yelp apparently it's not so secret! The Citrus Club has a lot of charm & personality- they have an open kitchen, play lots of trance/house music, the space is quite tiny (what SF restaurant isn't?) & for as long as I can remember, the same cute male waiter has been working there...

Note to that waiter if you read this review: thank you so much for being patient & putting up with my friend's child who is suffering from the terrible two's & for putting up with me & my friend who are suffering from the terrible late 20's!

For all my Asian peeps out there (holla!), they do not serve rice. At all. I know, blasphemous. But they do have a lot of other good things to sink your teeth into. When my girl & I go out to eat, we go to feast. Case in point, we ordered:
* shrimp wanton- good tasting broth & spinach, but only had 4-5 shrimp wantons
* from the grill ginger chicken & garlic noodles- it might be the filipino in me speaking here, but i really wish i could have had the chicken with rice.
* fresh spring rolls w/ peanut dipping sauce (i'm not a fan of this appetizer from any restaurant)
* shitake mushroom & beef noodles (did not taste the beef, but the noodles & crispy sugar snap peas were great)
* chicken soup (did not try, but looked very light)
total: $47 (not including tip.)

Obviously (or maybe not so obviously!) we had a lot of food to take home. Prices are fine, especially considering how generous the portions are. As far as taste goes, I think you can find more flavorful Thai out there, but it is still a decent option if you are in the Haight.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
From the outside looking in, you'd never guess this place was worth the try. The ambiance inside is really nice - very dim lighting and quiet in the two occasions that I've eaten here for lunch and dinner. Although it can look busy, there are always seats at the bar or tables to accommodate. 

Good variety of cold noodle dishes, and all of them are good! Everything is fresh and the flavors are not salt or overwhelming. There seems to be a hint of citrus in every dish, or at least so it says. 

My favorite appetizers are the shrimp/veggie spring rolls. Any of their tofu appetizers are good also. I usually go for a cold dish noodle. The two that have been my favorite so far are Peanut Noodles and The Coconut Lime Noodles. You can't get this taste anywhere else but here!
author: Linda T.

description:
Staff was friendly and quick, ambiance was simple and lovely, prices were cheap, food was excellent. Can't ask for more!

Went here for Valentine's Day dinner with my boyfriend on a trip to San Francisco. I had the beef and broccoli over spinach noodles and it was delicious. HUGE portions, as well. I'd definitely go back on our next trip.
author: Stephanie P.

description:
The appetizer was pretty good and it came quickly but everything was pretty much down hill from there. 

There was a huge time delay between the apps and the meal. (Which I don't understand considering how quickly Pho can be made.) Also they were completely out of Pho Beef so I got the Pho Chicken instead. This was the saltiest broth I ever had! I couldn't eat more than a few bites of it without feeling like I was getting a headache.
author: Shayna Y.

description:
One star is for the garlic edaname  appetizer. Otherwise for the rest of the food, you can get the better taste and quality food at an average Chinese delivery place.

Parking was difficult in the area. Luckily, it took it less than ten minutes this time around. We got seated very fast, because the restaurant was almost empty. They came to take our order very fast; barely had time to look at the menu. 

I was very mixed with the garlic edaname. Some were warm, and some tasted very cold but the flavors were good. 

However, the worst plate of food I got was the grilled shrimp and scallop with garlic noodles. The most expensive item on the item was also the most unappetizing thing there. My shrimp and scallop was completely dry and burnt in color. It was cold!!!! It appeared that someone had completed the cooking process, put it in the fridge, and then took it out. The garlic noodles were so sweet and drenched with sauce. There was no hint of garlic in there. It just tasted like the egg noodles you used in chow mein. I asked them to redo the skewers of shrimp and scallops and they said it was going to take a long time. It was almost like they were trying to deter me from making the decision from having it cooked again. After 15 minutes, I got two hot skewers and again they were burnt and overcooked. I was just fed up.

My boyfriend ordered curry noodles and it was the blandest thing. The black mushrooms tasted like it was dried mushrooms in a package.  With so many great noodle places, I would never come back.
author: Thia T.

description:
I'm just really excited that I'm not allergic to this place! =)

The concept of an all noodle (okay, fine, it's mostly noodle) menu intrigued me. I saw a lot of people ordering the spring roll, but I went and ordered the pad thai with shrimp. I didn't expect my pad thai to taste so coconutty, and I was definitely missing the peanut sauce taste...but it was still yummy. My friend order a bowl of soup that could have fed all of us. 

They only get 3 stars because we Asians like to travel in large groups. They don't take reservations, and they apparently only have one table available for groups larger than 4. Next time I come back, I'm going in a little group or solo.
author: Mari M.

description:
So I've been wanting to try Citrus Club for months, ever since I found out it's the sister restaurant to Kan Zaman, which is an SF favorite of mine.  Citrus Club is Asian Fusion and they are famous for their noodle soups and dishes from Vietnam, Thailand, and China. Apparently, its name comes from substituting all the heavy oils which are mainly used in this type of cuisine, for citrus! 

I arrived around 715 pm last night and it wasn't too crowded.  I was waiting on my two friends to arrive and the server just told me to take a seat at the bar and that we would be seated immediately upon their arrival.  That wasn't the case.  It started to get busier and busier, and after the others arrived, a different server told me we needed to sign in on the chalkboard, which I wasn't even aware existed.  We then had to wait about 15 minutes, which wasn't too bad.  It's definitely super tiny inside and there aren't many tables.  

We started with the garlic edamame and the shrimp spring rolls.  Both were awesome, especially the garlic edamame. I could've eaten the entire plate...! Between the 3 of us, we had the Beef Pho, the Tom Kha Thai Coconut Tofu Soup, and the Shanghai noodles.  The beef and udon noodles were served with bok choy, shitake mushrooms, with a flavorful soy bean sauce. All were tasty with very strong flavors. The soups were yummy and perfect since I'm a bit under the weather.  The beef pho was very ginger-y tasting and the beef was sliced very thin had a wonderful consistency to it.  

I definitely plan on coming back to Citrus Club. We each paid about $25, which is pretty reasonable for 2 apps, 3 entrees, and a bottle of cabernet.
author: Jenny W.

description:
I am rating Citrus Club based on the pad thai I ordered - tasted like noodles scraped from scrap food from dishes soaking in the sink.  Ya feel me?  First I thought the kitchen sent the wrong order as it was far too soupy to be pad thai or that they may have ran out of pad thai and decided to scrap leftovers together and voila!  Really do yourself a favor and order Pad thai from Ploy II (a couple of doors down from Citrus Club) - and NO I do NOT work there nor am I affiliated with Ploy II - just being honest.

I gave them one star for the soup my kids and hubby ordered - they thought it was sincerely better than my pad thai.

Might give it another try to try other items on the menu -
author: Michelle B.

description: This is what 5 stars looks and tastes like. I can say with certainty this was the best waiter I have had in my entire life. He was incredibly friendly, attentive, and fast. We all ordered something different, but everything was amazing. My boyfriend said the scallops were the best he's ever had. I will visit here every time I am in the area from here on out!
author: C B.

description:
As with many good restaurants in San Francisco, I would have walked right by this place without giving it a second look. But my friend brought me here and I was really impressed. The atmosphere is not what you would expect when you walk in the door. It has warm lighting, dark wood, bamboo and comfy chairs. The food is delicious and very reasonably priced. Their soup bowls could hold a basket ball! One bowl of soup here is good for two meals!

I was going to give this place four stars, but there were a few things that just didn't seem right to me. When you walk in they don't automatically sit you if your whole party is not already there. This would be fine if they had a decent place to wait, but you are stuck standing in the way of the front door. Also, non of the wait staff bothered to tell me there was a sign in chalk board that they seat you by. So even though I had been standing there for about 5 min (and no one bothered to even make eye contact with me) someone else walking in, signed in their name and was seated before me. 

In all I would definitely return here for the food. I would just meet up with my group ahead of time and all come in together.
author: Krystal W.

description:
Came here on a cold, wet, windy Saturday night. The place was really packed, and I was getting grumpy with the wait.  My man and I were finally asked if we would mind sharing a table with another couple--a pair of girlfriends--since there would be no 2 tops for a while. Since he had a gig to play at Deluxe, we agreed (me more  begrudgingly so than him.)

Well since the booth-style table was so big, we were actually farther apart from the couple than if we were to have sat at our own table. I immediately felt like a bi-atch for being all rolly-eyed about the situation.  The server was really nice, despite the chaotic bustle of the place, and holy cow the food was AMAZING!  The garlic edamame was killer, and our entrees: a thai coconut-tofu noodle soup and a spicy lemon coconut chicken broccoli noodle thing--were SO GOOD!! So nice to get a huge heaping portion of steamy hot food after too many "small plates" dining experiences as of recent. And the prices are great.

This place deserves more stars. I'll definitely be returning before a night out at Club Deluxe (if Giovanni's pizza doesn't win me over first.)
author: Acacia Q.

description:
Not sure what the rage is about here.  Yeah, the garlic edamame is good, but we live around the corner from this place, have been here a few times, and haven't been really impressed by anything we've ordered.  

Now, some people say the soups are the thing here, and we tend to order the noodles; but overall, I'd say it's pretty disappointing.  Maybe we'll go back to try the soups.  Probably not, but maybe.
author: Joshua B.

description:
First Amy gets me hooked on this place, especially the edamame and the drinks, THEN i have to find out that the owner's best friend sits next to me in my Genetics Law class in D.C.  

It's sad really.  I could totally use an all-you-can-eat free pass to Citrus Club.  It's amazing.  Especially sitting at the bar and watching them make the edamame.

(yes, it's an obsession at this point, and I'm fine with that)
author: Mike V.

description:
I went in with a few friends, intrigued by the long bar up front and the hanging lamps.  I also enjoyed that they were playing TV on the Radio in the background.  

this place is more about image than taste or flavor.  A friend commented that the indirect lighting enables diners to appear more superficially beautiful than they actually are.

Even the fluorescent green "jade" noodles say, "I'm so cool."  I was hungry and I gobbled them up, but I don't know how well they worked out in less deliberately cool settings.  You won't leave hungry.
author: Matthew L.

description:
This is a hidden gem, or fairly hidden, in the upper Haight.  Its cute and the decor is quirky and fun.  My favorites are the spicy lime and coconut noodles (salad) and of course the fresh spring rolls because the peanut sauce is absolutely incredible.   However, the peanut noodles with tofu were meh at best.   Their soju cocktails are yummy and inexpensive.  
Best bet:  Mid afternoon on a hot sunny Sunday.
author: Molly B.

description: Spring rolls were good but I was disappointed by the beef and mushroom noodle dish. My daughter had the shrimp chow mien and was also disappointed. Being new to the area, I will be trying more places and won't be returning to The Citrus Club.
author: Evie Z.

description: I had the Chicken Noodle soup. I forgot the name, but it tasted like chicken noodle soup, only blander.
author: Mike Z.

description:
We stop in here a few times a month since it's so close to work.  The veggie spring rolls are a great start, they have fresh mint in them which really gives them a crisp and vibrant taste.  I am kinda a creature of habit here as I tend to order the same thing just because it's so good.  I order the beef with shitake mushrooms and garlic (except I sub chicken instead of beef).  The portions are quite big to the point I can never finish it.

All in all the place cranks out some great soups and noodle dishes so if your in the Haight and ChaChaCha has a line out the door check out the Citrus Club across the street you won't be disappointed.
author: Pat C.

description:
3.5 is totally appropriate, but I'm rounding down because I think Zao, what I'd consider a 4-star or even 5-star place, has better food.

THE LOW DOWN ON DISHES I'VE TRIED:
1) Garlic edamame: If you only order one thing here, get the garlic edamame!  It's seasoned so well, and soooo delicious.
2) Hot-sour shrimp soup: I got this before, and I love spicy, but damn!  This has some kick.  So much kick, that you have to stop eating it at some point before you want to stop eating.  My friend who ate here with me tonight said the same thing, so I know it's not just me...
3) Shanghai noodles: Flavor was good, but I didn't get udon noodles like they said on the menu!  Sad.  I obviously still ate them in typical fat kid fashion, but I think the noodles were a bit overdone and could have been more firm.

OTHER MISCELLANEOUS THINGS YOU SHOULD KNOW:
1) Portions are huge!  You'll most likely have leftovers, or have to leave with your top pants button undone.
2) Good ambiance; feels clean in here.
3) Better for smaller parties...I'd say 4 or more, and you should expect a longer wait. (Restaurant's kinda small.)
author: Alice C.

description:
I haven't been to this restaurant in awhile, but I used to eat here at least once a week when I was assisting at Yoga Tree Stanyan and taking classes at the Circus Center.

The wok-tossed chinese greens & shitake mushrooms are really tasty. I like to order the thai coconut tofu soup (with chicken instead), the beef pho, and the chicken soup. The coconut soup is so savory and perfectly spicy/spiced. Occasionally, the coconut doesn't feel so good moving through my system... 

I also love their big soup spoons! I want some of my own. And I don't understand how it works to substitute citrus for oil in the cooking process, but I'm thrilled to believe it's healthier for me and brightens the flavor of their dishes.

The ambiance feels a little dank and close, and I think the wait staff are robots. But, the price is right and I've never really had a problem being seated in a timely fashion. I can't wait for an excuse to eat here again!
author: Ali W.

description:
Big portions, fast service.  My friend took me here when I suggested we eat at a place in the Haight.  I got the peanut noodles w/ tofu.  Got a HUGE bowl (enough for 2-3 meals for me) with bean sprouts, thin vietnamese-style noodles, fried tofu and peanut sauce.  It was really good but being me, I thought the veggies got too much in the way.  I'd give the food 3 stars.

We had gone in the late afternoon (around 4-5) and halfway through our meal they dimmed the lights considerably.  I guess it was for ambiance but it suddenly became difficult to see our meals.  Also a light in the back area was flickering.  Around dinner time it became much noisier and harder to have a conversation.

Asian fusion food was good but not something I'd go out of my way to get again.  I'll probably get the spicy dumpling soup next time since that looked good.
author: Kimiko Q.

description:
After one of the most epic nights of drinking to date I was in serious need of a recharge. My eyes half blurry and my tummy rumbling something fierce I stumbled upon the Citrus Club.

Once I walked in to this noodle house oasis and found the perfect little table tucked in the very back of the restaurant with my name written all over it. The waitress pegged me from the moment I stumbled in as she brought a huge glass of water the moment my ass hit the seat. nice! I promptly ordered a large Sapporo (don't judge, hair of the dog works every time) and sunk in to the cushy booth and tried desperately to re-piece the events of last night. When that plan failed I flagged down the waitress to put my order in stat! The cashew chicken with steamed veggies over egg noodles came out pipping hot about 10 minutes later. The food, as I've mentioned before, is just packed with flavor and the meat is always cooked perfectly. My Sapporo went down way too quickly so I decided to step it up a notch and order some sake (don't judge! I had a long night and needed a little hair of the dog). $25 and 1 hour later I was feeling recharged and inspired to continue my trek back to Nob Hill. 

The one fall back of this place is their slow service. It seems they have no innate sense of urgency and having you wait for your check for almost 15 minutes is perfectly normal. Buuuuuuut I will say I appreciated the friendly smile and non-judgmental attitude (needless to say I looked like a train wreck) while slouched down in my booth downing my Sapporo and playing with my iPhone for an hour. So thank you Citrus Club for taking me in with open arms and accepting me for whatever sins I *may have* committed the night before.
author: Kristy M.

description: Consistently good asian noodle cuisine. Their hot-sour vegetable noodle soup is on my list of the best
author: Chetan I.

description: Ordered Chicken Pad Thai and receive veggie pad Thai with tofu instead- they weirdly added tomatoes too. Pho is kind of hit or miss as well.
author: Katie B.

description:
Great reasonably priced restaurant in the haight.  Quick and delicious.  I like to get take out here often.  I usually order the cashew chicken.  Lots of veggies and it's a big serving.  When I'm sick I will get the pho to take home as well.  Good heart warming soup.  It's not the best food ever but the quality is always good.  

Everyone should get an order of garlic edamame!
author: D C.

description: Rude service and disappointing pho. When we walked in, the server told us to sit anywhere in the back room. The restaurant was practically empty, so the two of us took a 4-top table. The next time she came over, she told us bluntly that we had to move in case a larger group came in, despite the fact that there were other larger tables available and it was an off-hour. While we were gearing up to move after a bit of an annoyed back-and-forth, she put a Reserved sign down on the table right in front of us and walked away. She was stone-faced and inattentive the rest of the meal. The experience would have been salvaged if the beef and chicken pho weren't quite literally just flavorless broth and meat. Even the sriracha being masked as authentic chili sauce couldn't save it. Maybe the rest of the menu is more promising, but as a past server and restaurant manager myself, you couldn't pay me to go back to a place where the service feels much like a visit to the DMV.
author: Jana B.

description:
Is there a Yelp tag for noodles? No, there isn't (just checked). I think that would be helpful, Yelp,...because the total noodleyness of this place took me by surprise. 

The reason why I'm giving it two stars is because the three noodle dishes that circulated the table were not very tasty. They were very oily, however.

1.  My pad thai was extremely creamy. As in fettuccine alfredo consistency.
2.  A friend got the Marmalade Coconut/Lemongrass noodles, which were awesome because the spinach noodles were BRIGHT GREEN (!!! me gusta!), but kinda tasted like my noodles (how could this be??)--except more bland. 
3.  The other friend got the Shanghai Noodles, which were good in the sense that oil + oyster sauce will make anything = good. 

The only way I'd come here again would be for comfort food in the form of copious, copious noodles. (Portion sizes were generous! ;)
author: cecilia y.

description:
Totally agree with Eva A.

Stick to the Edamame for appetizer and Tom Yum soup for main. I've tried a bunch of other stuff from here over the years. Everything else seems bland to me except for these two dishes.
author: Kyle L.

description:
