I came to SF on a short visit and my friend (who lives there) couldn't stop talking about noodle bowls.  We just *had* to have noodle bowls!  So, after our trip to The Legion of Honor, we headed over to The Citrus Club - her favorite place in the city for noodle bowls.

As others have said, from the outside, it doesn't look like much, but it's pretty nice inside.  It was rainy that day (imagine that) and a bowl of warm noodle soup was just what we wanted.

I ordered the Tom Ka-Thai Coconut Tofu soup and it was pretty good.  The only few things I could complain about was that there was just a touch too much coconut milk in the broth and the heat could have been turned up a bit.  I like my Tom Ka a little spicy.  

The portions are ridiculously huge for the price, but I hate wasting food, so I guess I would have appreciated a "half" order option.  I couldn't finish it all and my friend isn't a fan of Tom Ka, so unfortunately, it had to go in the bin.

Other than that, the service was just so-so, but I would most definitely come back here on another rainy, San Francisco day.
author: Sara B.

description:
I recommend, but first an important tip: do not eat more noodles than are reasonable for a person of your size.  I say this because it can be hard to achieve the mind/body connection needed for your overstuffed belly to override thoughts like "there's no way they would give me enough food for five people". Especially if you are drinking, say, a delicious electric blue cocktail. Case in point: I consumed half a bowl of tofu peanut noodles here three days ago, and haven't had to eat since*. 

That said, I've been here several times, and I like the concept (nooooodles! yum), as well as the general vibe of the place. The service has always been good, and I don't remember being displeased with any of the dishes I have ordered/tasted. I wouldn't make the trip if I weren't already in the immediate area, but it's a solid option when you're in the Haight.  Just be sure to exercise portion control, as there are no positives in going on a noodle bender.

*This is a true statement. I have not had to eat in three days. Unfortunately, this hasn't stopped me from doing so.
author: Janna M.

description: This is the second time I've been here and its ok.  I dont think its catered for an asian taste bud.  A friend and I ordered the shanghai noodles with beef and mushrooms.  Noodles were too overcooked, the beef was hard, the sauce was way too sweet.  Plus there wasnt enough noodles!  The second thing we ordered was the hot and spicy shrimp noodle soup.  The soup was tasty with just enough spice and tartness. Although the bottom of the bowl had a super pungent taste of lemon grass and ginger.  And once again....the noodles were over cooked!!!  I also didnt think the service was that great too.
author: Gina S.

description:
I was here last night around 9.30 pm  to order some thai food. The restaurant is kind of hidden and small. The quantity is great for the money you pay for. I was kind of dissapointed with the quality of food. The food smelled like it was from yesterday. It could be the vegetable toppings that kind of had a foul smell. 

Would never go here late in the night or else i would be stuck with ROTTEN smelly food
author: Kishor K.

description:
This review is for the service.

Quite frankly, I was actually offended by the server.  I didn't see her stop at our table since she took the order.  I had to ask the busboy at one point for a knife.  When she dropped off the check, she didnt even make eye contact and dropped the check literally on the table while walking by.
author: Heather L.

description: Been there a few times since I live in the neighborhood but yesterday was probably the last time I will ever go there.  Service is fast and pleasant but I fell sick not even an hour after I left and got very sick the whole night.  I will spare the details but I am 100% sure my soup was not prepared with only fresh ingredients.  First time ever I get sick after a soup and it tasted fine, not great but not bad at all.  The experience of a lunch ended up a nightmare the following night.  So I won't go back there and won't recommend the place.  In 2013 we should expect perfect hygiene and the freshest ingredients.  Yesterday Citrus failed to deliver and I ended up paying the price.
author: Laurent G.

description: The garlic edamame was very delicious, although the rest of the food was just OK. The restaurant had a cute atmosphere and friendly service though, and considering the prices, Citrus Club is certainly not a bad place to enjoy a casual dinner and catch up with friends over a few drinks and a decent meal.
author: Savannah C.

description:
Citrus Club is for sure one of the best place in the Haight Asbury neighborhood and here is a couple of reasons:
- Price are still very low despite the popularity: with some soups around $7 and entrees price from $9 to $11 with huge servings, you will have a great bang for your buck
- The setting is nicer than most of the restaurants around, more intimate with red walls and small candles on each table
- Last but not least, the crowd is eclectic and the noise level is acceptable, high enough to feel entertained but low enough to be able to discuss

The only negative part: the line could be up to 20 minutes especially for groups of 4+ people since ... the popularity is still very high.
author: Fabien-Pierre N.

description:
Went here to get some quick eats before a night on the town.  We wanted something fast and hoped this would work out and boy it DID.  We ordered the burmese green curry special which came out in less than 10 minutes and was phenomenal.   We also ordered the tofu coconut soup which was ginormous for less than 8 dollars.  

Service was super fast and friendly.  Would def go back.
author: Andrew Christian C.

description:
I've been here a few times and my overall impression of the place is that it's mediocre (view last paragraph for why I don't go here anymore).  There are definitely better food finds in San Francisco, even near Haight.  

All the noodle dishes are Asian inspired, but if you've had good Asian noodles, this place does not even come close when it comes to taste.  For the most part, the noodles lack flavor (mainly because they make too many noodles with not enough seasoning) OR are too overpowered by soy sauce (the beef, flat noodle stir fry).  

Every dish will be filling, and it's a nice place to share if you have a group of three or more.  It's a little pricey for what you get (mainly noodles) at about $10 a dish.  

Oh, and the last time I went there, the seating (booths and tables) smelled of FECES!  It was disgusting and made me want to puke!  My friends and I haven't been back since that incident.
author: Christine K.

description:
This little restaurant is one of my favorite places in all of San Francisco. It's ambient, candle lit, and atmospheric which makes it perfect for first dates. The place is really beautifully designed as well. 

The prices are great. Everything is usually under 10 bucks and the portions are so large that you'll always have something to take with you. 
God, I could go for some noodles right now. The BBQ tofu spring rolls are bomb too. Actually, everything on the menu is bomb. Try it. Seriously. Fucking bomb. My only issue is that you'll sometimes have to wait about 20 minutes or more for a seat on really busy nights, but whenever that happens I we would head over to Cha Cha Cha across the street for some sangrias to pass the time.
author: Erick S.

description: Friendly and enthusiastic service, and tasty cocktails compensate for the rather average Asian fusion.  Even though the edamame was overcooked and the pho bland, I am grateful to the waitstaff for being incredibly accommodating and tolerant of our yelping toddler, who happened to be there past bedtime.  Nevertheless, the waitstaff was all smiles and even helped us look for a missing pacifier.  This is by no means a kids restaurant -- it's more of a neighborhood hangout for drinks and an affordable meal -- but the kid-friendliness is always appreciated.
author: Chris T.

description: I've eaten here a few times having worked in the area for nearly 6 years. The soups are okay, but the noodle dishes are meh. Not a lot of flavor in the Marmalade Coconut Lemongrass Shrimp. The spring rolls are okay. I feel like for an $18 lunch I should feel way more satisfied in the flavor arena. As one colleague says, everything here tastes the same.
author: Sarah L.

description:
We stopped into the Citrus Club on Saturday evening, after examining the reliquaries at the de Young. It seemed fitting to leave the darkness of that exhibit and enter the darkness of the Citrus Club. A bright shiny meal would have somehow tarnished the effect of examining art containing chunks of humans past.

Yeah.

The shanghai noodles and hot-sour shrimp noodle soup were so very good and paired nicely with a large pot of ginger tea.
author: Amanda R.

description:
I don't know why this place doesn't have more stars! I love me some asian food and this place is bomb. Dim lighting is great for a beer or two (last night the waitress recommended half pear cider half sierra nevada for a light beer and it was awesome) and a late dinner. It closes at 10 but last night my friend and I stumbled in at 9:45 and enjoyed dinner, non-rushed until just before 11.

The garlic edamame is delish, thai iced tea is great, the Garlic Beef & Shiitake Mushrooms is one of the best items on the menu. Last night I tried the Spicy Lemon & Coconut Chicken and it was good but not as good as the Hot-Sour Vegetable Noodle Soup/Hot & sour shrimp soup. I've also tried the Pad Thai which was pretty standard and when compared to the garlic beef/shitake mushrooms dish it might as well have been flavorless. 

Hope this helps :)
author: Lillian S.

description:
I love that they have Sapporo beer on tap.  Weight staff was perfect and accommodating.  Good spring rolls.  Music was a bit tooooo loud; however, I could have asked them to turn it down and they would have obliged I'm sure.  

I had the Singapore noodles with rice noodles instead of what the menu suggested.  They also added peanuts at my request.  The dish was good.  Not amazing...but good.  I'd go back but probably order Tom Kha soup.
author: Austin C.

description: It's good for Asian fusion, which is an all time favorite of mine, but it doesn't necessarily knock my socks off. The best thing I like about their menu is their drink list. Their sake margarita was super yum, but their papaya salad was not done right which was a disappointment. I really try to like this place but each time I keep craving more flavor. But for most, I think this place will not disappoint, I'm just a flavor junkie.
author: Dani B.

description:
Tummy was feeling a little sick and kinda drained after a pretty fawking stressful morning so I said to myself I need some kind of soup for lunch to calm the nerves and I ended up here.

Cozy place with table and counter seating available in front of an open kitchen area. The minute I sat down I couldn't help notice the beaded curtains that lead to the restroom. It was like something out of a Bruce Lee flick without the subtitles of course.

I quickly cruised through the menu. Basically it's broken down into four categories - appetizers, soup, stir fry and grilled food. 

I decided to go with the Shrimp Won Ton Soup with Noodles. When it arrived at the table, it was very, very temperature hot! I waited a few to cool it down a bit then dove in. The chicken and lemon based broth with spinach was okay. The shrimp stuffed wontons and noodles we're good. A hefty portion per serving.

Though I'm still trying to figure out the Asian "infused" theme from what I've eaten to what was offered on the menu. I must have missed this altogether.

Sevice was okay. Anyhow I will live to Yelp another day...
author: Gary E.

description:
OK! It's a 5-star whoop-tee-doo for these folks!

I'm officially barred from gorging on the garlic edamame! There's enough garlic in that dish to cure a country of any illness and vamoosh any vampires that might be skulking in the vicinity. But ummm! they are so tasty (the edamame... not the vampires)!... burp! pardon that garlic breath matey!

Their special this month is a broccoli beef which was very different from the usual "broccoli beef" you get. Love shallots, snow peas and green (?) noodles. But filling and the perfect balance of sweetness and spiciness.

And great sake martinis especially if you get the lemon version.
author: Amit S.

description:
Ummmmm, bland. Three stars for the variety, novelty of some of the dishes, several veggie options, and the fact that they substitute healthier citrus for oils in their food. 

But healthy isn't always yummy.

My yellow curry was pretty much flavorless....not offensive, just not what curry should be. I added a bunch of sriracha to give it a kick, and it was much better after that. But the pad thai was also pretty tasteless, nothing like what I'm used to, and my roomie's shrimp marmalade fettucine noodle-thing was just plain weird. I appreciate creative dishes, but creative is useless unless it's tasty, you know? The general consensus was that the beef shiitake noodle bowl was good, but since it was meaty, I couldn't get in on that action. 

Good spring rolls, though.
author: Tara W.

description:
To tell the truth...our group wanted to venture over to Cha Cha Cha's....but the bus ride was meant for this place instead! We went across the street and soon forgot about the 45 min wait Cha Chas wanted us to endure...NO WAY! We had been to a Giants games, sun-soaked and tiiiiiiired....but really hungry!!

Hunger was defeated with these HUGE bowls of yumminess.

So a few of us were happy and ehhh, not so much when it came to the dishes. The fresh spring rolls (6pieces) were typical, minty, noodly, rice papery....yeah, you've had it before.

My boyfriend got the best thing at the table, the garlic ginger beef with egg noodles and shitake mushrooms, so flavorful and delicious!! I however got the WORST thing on the menu...ugh. Don't get the coconut marmalade shrimp....it was like I got a low budget alfredo dish. But, the bright side was there was PLENTY to share with my BF and I was happy to dig in. 

Our friends didn't enjoy their dishes.. 3 stars is right. The shitake dish saved this review. The yellow curry was bland and the pad thai was not as flavorful as I would have liked. 

The thing with this place was they don't use oils, substituting for citrus! Great for the health conscious, but may have been why the flavor was lacking.
author: Rachel Z.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. It's not that fancy and not that expensive. The service is great and everything on the menu is amazing. It is also a fairly quick meal if you need it to be. I usually get the garlic noodle and broccoli dish as I'm a huge fan of the dry noodles. The salmon over noodle dish is bangin too. I have also been sick as a dog and or just a cold rainy day in which you cant go wrong with their chicken noodle soup, which is one of the house regular items. Also try the fresh rolls with Tofu. The wait is never that long and often enough the music is really good in here too.
author: Joe B.

description:
First of all, if you are looking for an authentic Thai place, this is not necessarily your spot. However, if you are looking for some asian fusion, new age, California-style noodle bowls... this is your spot. They have FANTASTIC vegetarian options that are very well seasoned into a fantastic, savory meatless wonder. The garlic edamame, garlic and tofu green beans, noodle soup bowls and wok plates are all fantastic. I especially enjoyed the BBQ tofu spring rolls, the pad thai and the thai coconut won ton soup.

Noodle bowls are HUGE and should be shared with at least one to two other people. This is a great family-style dining spot. Portions are very large. Sake cocktails and beer available. I didnt drink on this visit, but friends raved about the cocktails.

As for lemon in the water... i didnt notice any in mine, but I would be all for it! Lemon is good for our body. The wait staff is very friendly and were on top of it. Our food came out quickly - and I payed attention to this because I was starving.

Went with a group of nine and they accommodated us on their biggest table. From the outside, this place looks like a little hole in the wall or that it may not even be open at night. The branding and signage inadequately illustrates the charm and wonderful asian fusion going on here.

Ill be back for more.. yummy!
author: Betsy F.

description: Don't let the dingy exterior fool you, this is one of the best noodle houses in the city for sure. My go to is the coconut/lemongrass shrimp with jade noodles but I suspect that everything is delicious. Prices are super cheap too. Lunch with tax and tip will run you about 12 bucks.
author: Tommy P.

description: First of all, let me just say. THE SERVINGS! They demand all caps, as they are sooo very big. Which isn't a bad thing, as I'm all about leftovers. The food was good, but not great. I wouldn't bring a friend from out of town there, but I would meet a fellow SFer for lunch there.
author: Amy S.

description:
I agree with some of my fellow yelpers....the food here is VERY bland.

Food: Had something new today (Yellow tofu curry), I had to douse it with the peanut sauce that came with my spring rolls to make it semi-edible.
Also, sake seemed watered down.
I've been here more than a couple of times to give this place its fair share of chances but it disappoints.

Service: Today waited 20 minutes after I ate for my server to give me my check and no cigar. I had to go up to the counter and ask for it.

Overall: The only good thing I've had here is the Pho broth and spring rolls.
author: Brenda I.

description:
Third time wasn't a charm for this place.  The food is soupy, goopy, and droopy.  I had the "burmese green chicken curry" with noodles last night.  It was an enormous plate of sticky, gummy, overcooked noodles.  Seasoning was not a problem in this place.  Didn't find the food bland like a lot of these other reviews.  Overseasoned if anything.

Service is friendly and they do a pretty good job considering the terrible layout of this place.  The kitchen is right where you walk in, making the front door area the narrowest and most cramped part of the restaurant.  There is always a log jam of people in front whether the place is crowded or not.  They have counter seats looking straight into the kitchen which just adds to the cramped space and the noticeable lack of Thais, Burmese, Vietnamese or any other SE Asians working the kitchen.

There are better and more authentic places within a block of this place.
author: Tom R.

description:
This place is definitely high on my list of Asian eateries...love the location (in the Haight, diagonally across the street from Cha Cha Cha).  The atmosphere is  low-key, although it is a little noisy...but no louder than most other small restaurants.  It can get pretty crowded, especially later in the evening, so make sure you're not starving in case there's a wait.  However, don't think I've had to wait more than 15 minutes.  The food is so good - last time i was there, it came about 6 or 7 minutes after we ordered.  If you like soup, i definitely recommend the hot and sour with shrimp (it's got some kick to it, so make sure you can handle the spice factor =).... it comes in one of the biggest bowls i have ever seen - easily enough for 2 people, if not 3.  The mandarin chicken chow mein is my favorite...i am hungry just thinking about it!

Their prices are super reasonable...last time i went, we ordered the soup and the mandarin chow mein...although we didn't order drinks, the bill for 2 of us was only $19 bucks, and we were stuffed when we left.  They also have Pho on the menu...i haven't tried it, but the people at the table next to me sure seemed to like it.  

I would recommend this place to anyone who likes pretty much any type of Asian cusine (Thai food, Chinese food, etc)...it's worth the crowd...try it, you'll love it =)
author: Spookee X.

description:
3.5 stars.  

I don't get to the Haight very often but  next time I do, I will definitely come back here.  Citrus Club is a fun little noodle house serving up Asian fusion at an affordable price.  CC strikes that balance you can only find on Haight - it's a hole in the wall yet hip and trendy.    

Everyone in our party really enjoyed the food (the Pho-Ga, Egg Drop Soup, and the Spicy Curry Tiger Shrimp especially).  I can't really speak to the authenticity of each dish but I would agree with Joseph that the food does have a western feel to it.  Being Asian fusion you can't really fault the place for having a slightly different take on the cuisine.  Bottom line, the food is pretty good, especially with a glass of Sapporro (on tap) or a bottle of Nigori.

We were all pretty happy with the service as well.  Our waitress was a lot of fun. 

So a couple of things about this place.   I arrived a little late but from what I gathered to put your name in for a table mark the chalkboard located near the front.  Again not 100% on this so if you may want to follow someone else's lead.  Or just ask the hipster playing on his macbook at the bar.  

Also the bathroom is basically a pair of adjacent coat closets in the sidewall of the main dinning area.  The sink area is even partially exposed (no door for the sink) which makes washing up a little weird (but at least it keeps people honest).  I actually stopped for a second to wonder if it wasn't a wash station for the staff.  The red candles were also a nice touch, although It felt like someone was about to conduct a seance.  All part of the charm I guess.

All in all a very good experience.
author: Garrett F.

description: The service was quick and friendly.  Both of our noodle orders came out nice and hot; very delicious. The curry needed more flavour but the hot sauce and hoisin sauce added enough zest.  The washroom was clean and easily accessible. The lighting was extremely dim.  Would we return, YUP!
author: Christine A.

description: Yummmm I am in love with this restaurant.  I wish I could say all their food is delicious, but I've never been able to order anything but their noodle soups since they are so good.  Oh yeah, I got the edamame once, that was pretty good.  The noodle soups come in a bowl the size of your head, and I ALWAYS have a full meal for leftovers.  They also have unique drink specials, and the food comes out very quickly.
author: Gabrielle L.

description:
No inclination, whatsoever, to ever come back to the Citrus Club.  Although the lure of the strip club-like name is strong (some sort of Carmen Miranda type get-up), I don't quite remember the last time I had food that left me so underwhelmed.  Sure, the location sucks you in with its Haight Street cool, but other than great people watching, I'm not quite sold.  

My friends had the yellow tofu curry.  I had a bite and found some of the rice noodles to be undercooked.  I ordered the coconut curry seafood special.  I guess I should have known better about dishes with the name "seafood special."  Artichoke hearts have no business being in Asian food.  Lastly, don't try to fool my Asian palate.  The scallops had the taste of rehydrated dried scallops.
author: Wendy L.

description:
You know me, where there is Sake, I am not too far away....(Oishii)

The food was good but not as good as the sake!
But I have had good chow mein in day.
The portions are take home worthy.
Should have gotten just the garlic noodles.

But thanks for the suggestion Liz.
author: Nicole R.

description:
The place is really delicious and inexpensive. 

The ambiance for dinner eat in can be fun and romantic. The first time I went I tried the Pad Thai. I love pad thai, it is one of my favourite noodle dishes, and it had a good strong flavor. They have two excellent sauces at the table (fantastic hot sauce). 
My friend got the Kind Stir fry that had mushrooms that were cooked in anaias oil (it tasted like black licorice- but i a really good way. I dislike black licorice and my friend said that it tasted "like Christmas")
The second time I went there I ordered a coconut tofu soup that is served over rice noodles. This time it was for lunch and the soup had enough spice that it didn't need to be embellished, which was great because this particular meal was take out.
author: Sarah S.

description:
I love soups, and I love noodles, and I especially love noodle soups. But I'm also wary of Asian fusion food, and this restaurant definitely pushes me over to the "hell-nooo" side. Sorry, I don't think I'll be coming back to this place. I don't know if I was reacting to the citrus that the restaurant uses to substitute heavy oils in the cooking, but the flavors just didn't resonate with me and were actually weirdly unpleasant. 

The edamame appetizer was slimy, and the soybean pods were way overcooked to the color of a dark grey-green - just the opposite from how they're typically served in many Japanese restaurants. I ordered the shrimp wontons in soup with some hope but was fairly disappointed. The dumplings had an untasty peppery flavor, while the soup was super bland and dominated by ginormous slices of carrot - a weird combination to begin with. I tasted my friend's garlic noodles and tasted not garlic but a soupy soy-based sauce that was again, bland and unpleasant. 

One upside is that our waiter was super friendly and attentive, even as the place was packed and the line went almost out the door. If you sit at the bar, you can watch the cooks working hard behind the glass, and I must say the portions of the dishes we saw were quite large. But considering I didn't like what I consider to be pretty basic dishes, putting that much food in front of me wouldn't make a difference for me at this place.
author: T. K.

description: This place is just ok. Nothing to rave and rant about. The Vietnamese springs rolls were dry and the peanut sauce was too salty.  The papaya salad was kind of greasy:( The place is definitely affordable though and good  customer service.
author: Miss Giallo M.

description:
Great food, reasonably priced. The hot & sour veggie soup is amazing.

However, the service is HORRIBLE. A few of the waitresses are the rudest girls I've ever encountered. But, I wont rant on about the horrible experiences I've had with their attitude and overall service.

So, go for the food. Expect a wait on busy nights and don't expect good service.
author: Coco P.

description:
Dropped in last night heard this is a great noodle house.
Great Ambiance, we got seated quickly for being pretty busy,& huge portions!  Its a definite tight knit hole in the wall but friendly staff which makes all the difference.!

Maybe I am too picky with my asian food, but for a noodle house I thought the noodles would be perfect.  I ordered Marmalade Coconut/Lemongrass Shrimp and it seem to be missing something.... I just couldn't put my finger on it.  Maybe a little salt???  But it was in a creamy sauce- Not a fan, and the noodles were just over cooked for my liking.  Kinda mushy in a liquidy coconut sauce.  
The garlic edamame was fantastic tho.  We also tried the special lemongrass/coconut wonton noodle soup.  That was pretty tasty.

I tried a few friends dishes and they were good.  The mongolian beef noodles were tasty , and the salmon dish was also good.  The salmon was a bit dry and not seasoned or anything,  just as it says on the menu-grilled-lol!  not marinated then grilled....

Not my first choice to call upon for a must have, but I wouldn't completely dis-own it.  IT has potential, maybe next time I will love the dish and all its flavors.
author: A. C.

description: I think this place had really good atmosphere, a fun place to go with some friends or on a date..but the food is just okay. I rather go to Ploy II for good coconut curry soup, theirs doesn't have as strong flavor. I have tried some other dishes that my friend have ordered like some of their noodle dishes, but I wasn't impressed. Last time I ordered their coconut curry shrimp wonton special. It was good... but lacking favor..would rather have gone to Ploy II- only if Ploy II had the atmosphere!
author: Lisa W.

description:
Went there on a date and was really impressed. We ordered two Thai dishes, both were about $8, either one alone could have fed the two of us, and the best part: they arrived within minutes! 

Cheap, fast, and tasty. I'll definitely be back.
author: Jarrett S.

description:
The food here handily deserves a solid five stars, but the service barely deserves a mediocre 3 stars, so I'll settle on the high side at 4 stars.

We both had the beef noodle Pho and it was perfection. Just the right amount of heat and fragrant spice, with generous portions of noodles and thinly slide beef. Served up in over sized, steaming bowls the portions are so large there is any entire container tucked away in my fridge from the "leftovers".  During other visits to the Citrus Club, I've had their Pad Thai and other Grilled Chicken over Garlic Noodles and both were excellent. I think you'll be hard pressed to find food ont he menu that will not delight you. 

We also tried the "Citrus Punch" which is a nonalcoholic house speciality very closely resembling the offspring of an Orange Julius and Citrus Dream Jamba Juice. Not too sweet and not too rich, the Citrus Punch would be a good hot day treat although its fairly filling so imbibe with care if you are waiting for your meal!

The service was pleasant, but really lacking. When we walked in, we were handed menus and told to pick a table of our liking. When we went to sit down at the table we chose, the waitress hurried over and encouraged us to "find a different Seat". This was a little confusing as the place was relatively empty (mid afternoon on a Sunday) and she had just told us to pick anything. Whatever, it wasn't a huge deal just a little odd since no explanation was offered! Food was served up quickly, but water was never refilled and the waitress had to later be flagged down to get our check. Not terrible service, just not great service!

Ending on a very positive notes - the prices are very reasonable. All in with tip, we walked out only $25 lighter...and keep in mind my lunch for tomorrow is all ready to be enjoyed!
author: Megan L.

description:
Yummy yummy yummy, I got love in my tummy....

Ok, so I've only been here once, but I am definitely going back if the Mongolian beef noodles are anything to go by.  Delicious and hit the spot exactly.  Huge portion (which I still managed to polish off!) and cooked to perfection.  The shiitake mushrooms were soooo good.  There were so many things on the menu I wanted to try!

The peanut chicken and tofu noodles my friend got looked delicious too.

The prices were totally reasonable.  Again, the menu had lots of mouthwatering options, the service was prompt and our waiter was super helpful and when I gave him the list of things I was trying to choose between he was able to immediately tell me which ones he thought I should get (this is a key skill I look for in a waiter/waitress, given my indecisiveness).

Top place, and a great option for lunch because you can go shopping on Haight afterwards and ward away the cheeky gutterpunks with your garlicky noodle breath.  YAY Citrus Club!
author: Melanie B.

description:
This is one of my weekday brunch/lunch places. It's located near me ad offers a good variety of veggie and "asian fusion" food. It's not the best place to get anything authentic, but it'll do the job.

Location: A great location right in trendy and touristy Upper Haight. Easy to get to via any means of transportation and tons to do around whether it's shopping, eating or art.

Space: It's a very Californian decor inside. It reminds me a lot of those LA places that always have "egg whites" options. I take a point off just for such a typical and boring interior decoration.

Ambiance: Mostly tourists, people that live nearby and hipster people. 

Service: They're nice. They're on time, never rush you and are attentive.

Food/Drink: It's not the best but it's good enough for lunch. It also tastes very, very fresh which is really nice. They can also custom make things so that they're vegan or veggie. I usually have the pho with no chicken and they always add tons and tons of really fresh not overcooked vegetables. This is the reason I come back to this place. They also have delicious soju based martini things like cosmopolitans, appletinis etc. which really makes any lunch that much better. The only down side is that they don't have coffee so it's definitely not the ideal place for a hangover recovery joint.

Overall: A nice place to have lunch. Not super expensive, not super cheap. Nice food. A-OK.
author: SF N.

description:
This place is TEENSY!

Went here yesterday with Katie V. and our (slightly less culinarily adventurous) moms, post-pedicures. We took up the biggest table in the place, which might seat six small people.  So, if you're a big group, go elsehwere!!

The moms had the house Pad Thai, which is--not gonna lie--kinda weird.  It's super creamy but doesn't have much flavor, and has diced tomatoes on top (whaa?) as well as the more traditional accoutrements.  

Katie's coconut-lime soup was lacking in lime.  It took a few minutes to flag down our overwhelmed waitress, but she was quite quick in bringing out a bowl full of lime wedges.

My peanut noodles were, again, slightly lacking in flavor and more creamy than I was expecting.  I also wanted way more veggies to go with the MASSIVE bowl of noodles I received.  

Incidentally, all bowls of food are roughly twice the size of my head.  No joke.

The best part of the meal was definitely our starter--the garlic edamame.  That's one I'm going to have to try to re-create at home... YUM.
author: Caitlin M.

description:
I'm pretty impressed that I came across this place after hours of music digging at Amoeba down the street. The prices alone is fairly reasonable and the food is incredible. I've read some other reviews that the service has been horrible. During my experience, the service was really great and the waitress that was serving us mentioned some of her personal favorite dishes. 

Looking forward to hit up that spot again!
author: Arnold R.

description: Unimpressed with service, and food. I could barley  ask for a wooden chopstick without attitude and the server didnt check on us once. Party of three.
author: Shea T.

description:
parking is back and forth around here.  you should find some though...not too long before something opens up.

it looked great and smelled great too.

i went in, looked at the menu...saw the dishes coming out for other tables and it looked great.

i ordered the peanut noodles and chicken to go with it.  i wasn't entirely happy.  the noodles tasted too cold and the clung to each other too much.  like if youu overcook the noodles they stick.

i'll try it again sometime because there were so many people the food smelled and looked great.  just mine might have been one bad day.
author: Bing D.

description:
NOODLES!!!!!!!!!!!!! ok I am a noodle girl..and this place has really good noodle soup bowls. it's a cute place to hang out with a friend over a warm bowl of soup..and the eclectic styles of dishes is quite fascinating and tasty.

the only problem is the service that they need to touch up on. Mentioned in another review, I agree that the customers are an inconvenience to the workers. it's a really strange thing. They don't seem happy to serve you. Or being stared at from the servers when you ask them how long it takes to get a table when you're waiting.. hmmmm uh ok..
author: Cindy S.

description:
Been here twice, took me a second time to realize they had seating in the back. Its a great way to peak away from the Haight-madness.

We started with the garlic edamame, holy goodness! I swear I could drink the marinade by itself.

I had the Pho-Ha-Ni (BEEF NOODLE SOUP), I wish there was more meat but the serving size of soup and noodles was great, I don't think it's meant to be finished in one sitting, but I did finish! And for the sake of your nourishment, if you can't use those plastic chopsticks use a fork! I read a few comments about the soup being plain, I think it should be.. you have to add spices, sweets and saltiness to appeal to your taste. Those sauces and plate of basil, spices and lemon aren't sitting there for nothing! And add bean sprouts, it satisfies the texture.

My friend had the Pho-Ga (CHICKEN NOODLE SOUP) and he ate the whole thing so I'm assuming it was really good.

The service was great. Minutes after we arrived the place got busy but our server was always there to ask us how we were doing. I have yet to try their version of pad thai and tom ka, I will be back. Gotta get more soup for the (Asian) soul. Peace *two fingers up*
author: Jamie Q.

description:
2.5 stars...cuz they were friendly, and cuz it's pretty standard for the haight.

The service is friendly and attentive, the food got to us fast, especially considering how slammed they were. We opted to sit at the bar (the line was crazy long), and had a reasonably good meal after a day of looking for prom dresses (handtohandkajukenbo.com/prom/). 

Portions were ok, noodles decent serving, not nearly enough short ribs. (But my buddy chacha thought the noodle servings were large, so it could be my undending gluttony.) 

- Miz sy got the shrimp wonton soup. Reasonably light and tasty, decent dumplings. 
- Cha and I shared the grilled shortribs over garlic noodles. Ok, but not really garlic noodles. More like slightly soupy noodles stir fried with veggies. The ribs were reasonably good, but only two for a $13 plate? Meh.
- We shared the garlic edamame. Interesting sauce, lotsa garlic, and something like the thai sweet chili sauce (but different). This was prolly my fave.
- I could easily have had another entree, but again, that's prolly just my undending gluttony. 

Not bad, for the haight. And I might go again. But I wouldn't miss it if I didn't.
author: eliza w.

description: What the hell is this place?  OK, so it's Asian fusion but NOTHING works.  The Pad Thai was creamy and had no flavor.  I was putting the vietnamese peanut sauce on it so at least I could eat it.  I got it with chicken and while there was a lot of chicken in it, it was also flavorless.  The Edamame with sauce was interesting.  The sauce was flavorful but overpowered the taste of the Edamame.  I guess it's for people that don't like vegetables ;)  Overall I wouldn't come here again, it's Asian food for Americans that have no idea what Asian food is.  Other people had other dishes as well that I tasted and nothing worked!  It's kind of humorous because it was totally crowded.  Probably with tourists that come into the Haight looking for something different, which it is, but on a food quality level it fails miserably.
author: Mitch A.

description: I have been walking in to The Citrus Club for over 12 years.  For the better part of that I keep telling myself I am going to order something different this time... I always cave and go for me favorites, go figure.  I'm so predictable because the food is so consistently good.  A pot of ginger tea, an order of the salad rolls (the fresh ones, not fried) and the Thai Coconut soup with fried tofu.  I am sure that there is other stuff on the menu that is good, and I've seen people I have eaten with over the years order some of it, but for me it is always the same.  The bright spot in all of this is that I am always happy, and I keep going back.
author: Douglas T.

description:
Five stars because of the Sweet Chili-Glazed Tofu and Greens. Yeah, I've tried other things here (Pho-Ga, Garlic Beef & Mushrooms -- both good) but I always wish I ordered the tofu and greens. Slightly sweet, chock full of vegetables and nice big rectangles of tofu.

It's delicious, 8 bucks, and enough food for 2+ meals. 

Oh and those candies at the end of the meal? Wonderful!
author: Jennifer B.

description: We had BBQ tofu spring rolls- good. Then I had a huge bowl of beef pho- very decent. Really big bowl, generous portion of noodles but it's so big because of all the broth. A little lacking in the types of beef department, but I can't turn down beef pho on a breezy day. My friend got green noodles (spinach) with coconut sauce or something and shrimp. She liked her dish a lot. Good prices, ended up being 34 with tip for 2 including drinks, appetizer, and, meals. One thing that I didn't like was their service. Very spotty. Service was unfriendly and short. My friend had to ask for a refill. They aren't attentive. Took 10 minutes to get the bill after we were done. And we'd been waiting for longer. Come here if you're not in a rush. And don't sit next to the bathroom. The main way to the restrooms has a beaded door way, so no door. Not a good place to be sitting, trust me.
author: Ally W.

description:
700+ reviews?! That is usually unheard of where I live, down here in the Dirty south (Orange County). Located at the top of Haight, easy to find and always a pleasure to visit. Can hardly beat the location, this is a true diamond in the rough.

Cheaply to moderately priced dishes, anything with shitake mushrooms in it at The Citrus Club will always turn your mouth into a smile. They do amazing work. 

Rather small inside, so on busy days, be prepared to wait for a few minutes for a seat, depending on party size. This is always a visited place by me when I visit. I do not live in SF, but i have been here about 5 + times.
author: Barry H.

description:
Service:  the service was amazing. They frequently stopped by our table to check in. 

Menu:  I was disappointed with the menu options. It advertises itself as a fusion restaurant, but it was mostly Vietnamese. 

Price: very reasonable

Atmosphere;  it's a great place when its not busy. It's a small venue, located on haight St, so I could see it getting packed
author: Joustin C.

description:
Came here after school one time with a few friends... LOVE the atmosphere! It was super packed, but we surprisingly didn't have to wait that long.

The menu was pretty extensive but I was feeling boring that day and just tofu pad thai... it was really good, but the peanut sauce was really creamy and not necessarily what I was used to when it comes to pad thai. Definitely made me paranoid about the fat content. Haha.

I like how the lights and dimmed down and there are candles and nice decor. 

What I didn't like... Sake in a wine goblet? WTF? What is this... where is my like... fucking CARAFE of sake? That's what I want. Not a wine glass full. Is this a large? What is going on? Confused about it to be sure.
author: Liane V.

description:
Bare with me friends, this is my first Yelp review, EVER! Citrus Club has quickly become one of my favorite Thai spots on Haight Street. Quick grab and go cafes, casual diners and shopping line the streets. But if you have a moment to breeze past all of that, you'll find the hidden, quaint, trendy Citrus Club. Careful what times you go because it does get very crowded on the weekends after 7pm. May I suggest catching, what we like to call the "early bird special" before 6pm. Still, if you plan on going to experience the non-typical Haight ambiance, it's definitely worth the wait. The garlic Edamame will knock your socks off and the coconut soup will last you through the winter. The spinach noodles (don't be put off by the pastel green color) are shockingly delicious. 

Look for the subtle maroon awning...
author: Jamie D.

description:
Noodles noodles and more noodles. The food is good, the prices are low. The place gets packed so its good to go slightly before lunch or dinner time. 

The garlic edamame is delcious! I've tried several different soups and stir fried noodles and i have yet to meet a noodle i didn't like. My favorite is the lemon coconut chicken noodles!! Mmmmmm...

The only downside is the parking on Haight can be hard
author: Jenn V.

description:
My review is largely based on the service I received at this restaurant.  The pho & spring rolls were decent, nothing to rave about... but as Peter Griffin would say, "You know what really grinds my gears???" waitresses who have attitudes when they really shouldn't.  That's what really grinds my gears!

The whole thing came about after a very wild bachelorette party the night before.  We were tired, hungover, and probably still semi-drunk but very well behaved patrons despite the conditions.  All we wanted was some sugary / syrupy / soda goodness but alas, the restaurant was out of soda water or something like that.  

Our very very sober and chivalrous friend ran to the corner store to appease us with our soda of choice.  I like my cola BUTT freezing cold so I asked for a glass of ice.  The waitress then proceeded to say we couldn't bring outside beverages inside.  I completely understand when it is something the restaurant provides, but considering they weren't able to that day, it was completely ridiculous not to allow us to go get ourselves some sodas from outside.

Seeing that we had a reasonable argument, she obliged but then proceeded to give us attitude only Asian women can (trust me, I know, I am one too), ignored us the entire time, practically threw our food at us, and just had a stick up her butt the entire time.

I guess I should blurb a bit about the food just to be fair.  The spring rolls were decent.  We were famished, it was there, I ate.  I can't say I really liked the pho.  There was WAY too much cinnamon in there.  With pho, I love the broth, and they really ruined it with that cinnamon.  Completely RUINED.

After this review, I know I will no longer be welcome at the establishment, but I could care less.  The food isn't all that it's cracked up to be, and for someone to have such poor customer service, don't really deserve to have a business at all.
author: Melissa L.

description:
At first glance, the menu seems rather typical of any Asian restaurant boasting fusion food - a little of everything from different parts of Asia that leaves you wondering if they'd be able to execute such a diverse menu with any sort of success. I am not a big fan of fusion food for this very reason: trying to do it all means the food comes out rather mediocre. 

Also, I thought it was rather pricey - $8 for a bowl of noodles???

But hey, there were people in there, I was tired of walking and they actually had Zagat stickers everywhere. That means at least a good handful of people like this place so it must be worth a shot. 

My sister had the garlic beef and shitake mushrooms; I had the spicy lemon and coconut chicken. They were both pretty yummy so I stopped feeling like I was being ripped off. 

My spicy lemon and coconut chicken was not very spicy and not very coconut-y and a little under-seasoned, but I have a rather bland palette so this didn't bother me so much. Others might not find it as flavorful so maybe a little salt will help. 

Then, as I continued to work on my bowl, I realized that I was barely making a dent in the noodles - there was SO MUCH food! They definitely do not skimp on the chicken; I kept encountering more and more as I ate. Most places would give you a handful of chicken and leave you to get full on the noodles. Definitely not the case here!

The only problem I have is with the servers. The two women who take care of the tables on the floor are rather strange and anti-social for servers. They do not speak beyond the minimum - if that - and they don't smile. But the girl at the bar is much more cheerful and hospitable, so if you're not with a large group or don't mind sitting at the bar, go for the bar if you want a more lively server. 

Otherwise, a pretty yummy place with very, very large portions at a suddenly quite reasonable price.
author: Christine C.

description:
Yes, it's like a club.  

Looking for vegetarian food in the Haight, we found the Citrus Club through Yelp.  As we walked in off the sidewalk, and I could have sworn I was in the tropics.  Thai waitresses all over the restaurant, a crowd of people filling both rooms, club music (techno house, etc.) pounding through the room, tables so close together I touch both sides walking to my seat.   And I'm in a weight reduction contest, so it must be a really crowded place for big guys.  

All of this at 3:30 pm on a Saturday.  

We ordered a shrimp spring roll, egg drop chicken soup, pad thai with chicken, oolong tea and a small Sapporo, for $35.10 + tip.  

The spring roll was tender, and interestingly, the cooked shrimp were cut in half lengthwise.  I loved the peanut sauce that came with this.  

My Lady loved the chicken soup, and said it was a perfect chicken broth, but that next time she would order it without the noodles.  It came in a full-size pho bowl.  

The pad thai was bland, and the chicken and sauce were overcooked.  I guess it wasn't moving as fast as the chef had expected.  Nevertheless, it got better as I ate it, and despite it being a huge serving, I ate it all.  So I guess being a little overcooked wasn't a deal breaker for me.  

The oolong was pretty ordinary.  Like something you'd buy at Safeway.  

The Sapporo was made to strict Japanese standards.  In Guelph, Ontario.  

The observant reader may notice we didn't order vegetarian food.  Oh well.  Maybe next time.  

Walking out at 4:30 pm, we noticed the place was still packed.
author: David D.

description:
This is one of my go-to dinner places in the Haight, but the service really is terrible. As much as I want to give one of my casual, easy-going regular places at least a four star, I just can't.

It took me 8 minutes last night to even get the attention of the cashier so I could pick-up my phone-in order, and every time I have eaten-in my table is kinda sticky and my arm constantly gets bumped by the too-busy servers as they rush by me as I am trying to shove jade noodles into my mouth.

Lucky for the Citrus Club that their food rocks. I have not had a bad noodle dish yet (the sweet chili tofu was the worst of a good bunch) and they have the best peanut sauce ever. Their soups are plentiful and their specials are always delicious. Prices are very reasonable.

Despite the crazy loud noise and the servers being too busy to serve (maybe they should hire some more people?), I will go back again. And again.
author: Lauren O.

description: Yummy spring rolls and chicken pho. Service could be a little friendlier but over all I find Citrus to be a trusty spot in the neighborhood.
author: Olivia G.

description:
First, I'm a Haight-Ashbury resident, and often dine at Citrus Club. This review was prompted by a recent visit...

Citrus Club is a pan-asian noodle bar, halfway between a shoddy thai restaurant and a fairly good Pho stand. This is California, not Ho Chi Min City nor Bangkok, and a neighborhood with few ethnic vietnamese and thai. Citrus Club is dumbed down to American palates. It works in this neighborhood, it wouldn't in the Tenderloin or Richmond, or ... it is what it is and the food reasonably priced and of decent quality.

Whatever happened to the management of this place? Our last visit was like visiting the zoo on a sunny San Francisco day. The entrance was blocked by a bicycle, but there was an empty bike rack right outside. We were handed menus and instructed where NOT to sit, then waited. Our waiter was new, in fact, the entire wait staff was new, and the attention we got somewhat rushed.

Our appetizers and entrees arrived before our drinks. We complained, the waiter offered to comp the appetizer in lieu of taking back the hot dishes. We were then visited every four minutes, "is everything okay, are you done eating?" Too much attention, or a subtle "finish and get out". 

In short, if you're seeking an ethnic dining experience, this is not the place. If you're expecting exemplary service, order each item category and have the waiter come back after you get your first course. If you want real Pho, go visit any number of restaurants in Little Saigon or the Sunset west of 19th. Citrus Club is one of the few 'okay' places on Haight that serve hot food for a reasonable price. Don't expect much more than that, and you should satisfied.
author: Joseph F.

description: My cousin said it was the best noodle soup she's had in her life, and she's been to Korea and Taiwan. It was something off the specials board, a Thai coconut curry thing. It was spicy and good, and in one of the biggest bowls I've ever seen in my life. I had the garlic green beans, which were so good!! I'd definitely go back, it wasn't expensive either.
author: Erin A.

description: Ah...all the memories I have of the city. This is always a must stop for me & my girls as the hot and sour veggie soup is pretty damn tasty. It's kind of a hybrid between Pho & Tum Yum & it's huge! We've tried a number of things over the years & everything else is good as well. Just went there last week & had the Edamame w/a little too much beer & sake but it started off what became our very first "Haight Pub Crawl". Good prices & good service. Oh & the Citrus Banana dessert is awesome too. Mucho Gracias to the cook who was perving on me & my friend & hooked it up for free!
author: Jazzy S.

description:
Ate here with a group of friends and was a bit skeptical hearing this was an asian fusion place as they tend to be over-priced, but was pleasantly surprised.  

BBQ tofu spring rolls: a bit plain.  I couldn't taste any 'bbq' flavor in it
Garlic edamame: so good I even remembered it the next day and tried to make it at home
Shanghai noodles: huge plate of noodles.  The sauce had just the right balance of sweet-salty and the beef was really tender

Great place to chill with friends and order individually or family style.
author: Jean O.

description: My boyfriend wanted me to go here for quite some time and we finally got there yesterday. I love noodles but was somewhat turned off by the exterior of the place. Kind of looked like a hole in the wall. But I was pleasantly surprised that when I entered, it was completely different than what I expected. Very modern with lots of nice art and great atmosphere. The food I got was excellent, inexpensive, and was enough for 2 meals. I used to go to Zao Noodle Bar for my noodles but I think I found a new favorite noodle place! I had the Lemon-Coconut Chicken and definitely recommend it.
author: Chris D.

description:
I stumbled across this place when my friends and I were looking for a quick bite to eat. Given the somewhat gloomy and windy weather, the large bowls of soup and enticing aroma quickly pulled us in. We were seated right away and it took about 15 min to get our food. Our waitress was prompt and very nice. I ordered the Thai Coconut Soup with Shrimp and Wontons - It was a menu special that day. It was about $9 but the bowl was massive. Well worth the $$! The soup was so flavorful and had just the right amount of spices and perfect for the sad day outside. I split the bowl with my boyfriend and we were both completely stuffed but couldn't stop, so we managed to eat the ENTIRE THING!

I would definitely recommend this place again. A couple next to us had the garlic edamame and that looks absolutely fantastic.
author: Lindsey C.

description: BLAND.  The Citrus Club's only redeeming quality is their large portion sizes, but when you're basically eating a bowl of some dilute mixture that you've unsuccessfully tried to doctor with Sriracha, perhaps this isn't really a redeeming quality after all.  The closest this restaurant came to Asian cuisine was the way the food LOOKED, because the flavor was not there at all (I posted pictures and the food actually looks yummy...don't be fooled).
author: Andrea Z.

description:
Whenever I think of Citrus Club, a light bulb turns on in my head for these reasons:

1) Who doesn't like Asian Greatest Hits type restaurants?
2) Intimate atmosphere (but I did see someone bust out a pointer light to read the menu)
3) Citrus! Must be healthy.
4) I need fiber.

Sounds great right? But every fricken time I come here, I make the mistake of ordering one of their salads. The ingredients might be good, and it can help you poo -- but they have the WORST salad dressing.

I got their Soba Salad the first time, and I thought, oh the dressing is a bit watery. The 2nd time, I got their Citrus Crunchy Noodle Salad. It came with a bunch of orange slices and the salad dressing could well have been water filled in a cup that used to have orange juice in it. It has no body whatsoever. I ended up throwing some hoisin sauce on the table to make it better.

Citrus Club: Please please please step up your game on your salad dressing!! I do really want to come back.
author: Faffy L.

description: Maybe ive been accustomed to Asian flavors so i wouldnt say that this place is THAT good. I tried the pho chicken noodle soup and honestly ive had better pho than this place. The broth is okay, but not super great. But i gotta give credit to the portion and service for this place. They give my food within just 3 minutes! Thats hella fast for an order, the service is nice and efficient. I dont mind coming here again if im in the area but i certainly wont come here again just for the taste of the food. Given that the type of restaurant is "Asian Fusion", Id say that the taste is already accustomed to more of the Western taste than the Asian taste. So, to sum up, the place is pretty decent(for the service and portion) but the taste of the food is just okay.
author: Cavin T.

description:
I came here once with some friends to celebrate a birthday and it was my first time going there. Throughout my entire life I've always been to hole-in-the-wall noodle places that offer the authentic goodness found nowhere else so I was somewhat skeptical about the "Asian" food here. The restaurant itself has a nice look and vibe and was small enough to create an intimate atmosphere.

To start off, my friends ordered the garlic edamame for appetizers, which I liked, but I would take regular non-soy sauce drenched edamame over that any day. 

I ended up going the safe route ordering a bowl of chicken noodles. How does it compare to regular pho? Well, it wasn't bad but you really can't beat the real thing. At least the pricing was somewhat similar. Drinks there I thought were kinda pricey so I had to settle for a soda. Some of my friends ordered a mushroom noodle dish which I didn't get to try but it looked a little more appealing than my plain bowl of noodles.

I found this place to be like the Chipotle of Asian food. If you're in the mood for Asian, I would recommend going to an actual Asian joint. The Citrus Club is better for groups and dates looking more for a cool place to eat and order Asian inspired food. It is what it says it is.
author: Kathryn B.

description:
I was coming down with a cold and was walking home from my friend's work. I thought to myself: "I could really use some soup ... and some ginger tea, and some garlic edamame." Okay so not the last one but I did want the first two.

So I meandered over to Citrus Club where the pho is hot 'n spicy and the ginger tea could soothe any sore throat. Usually when I am not sick I get one of their drinks as well.

The staff is always nice and very attentive. The ambiance is good - nice and dark - and it would be a good place for a casual date.
author: Matt S.

description:
I have been coming here for years. I love this place!! The spring rolls are awesome!! The shiitake mushroom an garlic beef bowl is a total winner
and everything else I've tried is yummy!! I just tried the garlic edamame Mmmmmmmmm :) The Lemongrass marmalade dish with the green noodles is outstanding!!
author: Melissa M.

description:
You know what always perks me up on a cold, rainy day?
A giant bowl of Thai cocount soup with tofu from Citrus Club.
I'm never able to eat the whole thing, and so I always get to eat the other half for lunch the next day! Double tasty!

Also, get get get GET the garlic edamame. It's totally an abomination, and totally awesome.
author: Erin P.

description:
Great service, nice environment (dark yes, but in a good way.), decently priced for what you get, but the food is mediocre and the menu is pretty limited for a noodle house. 
I didn't notice the whole "citrus" thing really making any difference tho.
author: Heather G.

description:
1) Expect to wait.
2) Atmosphere-Dark, liked it (though was a little loud) 
3) Seating-not much
4) Food-it was okay. Bit bland for our taste so we only went there once
5) Price-A bit over priced (by like $1 a dish)
6) Quality of ingredients-seemed pretty fresh 

Over all it wasn't bad, but wasn't amazing either. We live around the corner and eat out 4x's+ a week and have only been there once for the past 5 months. (If that tells you anything). We will try them again I am sure, but it wasn't worth the wait....
author: Kat M.

description:
I've been handing out 4-star ratings like nobody's business, so I figured it was time to scale back and complain about my least favorite meal in the city (so far). This bar/cafe has a surprisingly cool, hip atmosphere, and my girlfriends and I enjoyed watching all the hipsters who apparently flock to this place. With seating options at the bar, booths, or tables, there were several other large groups, so we figured that we'd picked a pretty popular spot.

Perhaps I just ordered the wrong thing, because a lot of my friends seemed happy enough with their meals... but, word to the wise: do NOT order the Pad Thai. I should've known better than to cheat on my favorite Thai restaurants with this dish (I'm sorry, KoTNH#2, it'll never happen again), because the one here was pretty disgusting. Not only that, but they got my order wrong - which happens, of course - so I calmly and patiently explained this fact to our server (after trying for several minutes to flag her down, even though she was right across from our table). After I politely explained the issue, she responded by giving me the mother of all death stares, snapped that it would take another half hour to have the correct dish brought out, and ever-so-helpfully suggested that I "just deal with it."

At this point, I figured that I might as well just eat it, since this was a simple matter of taste, and not anything so drastic as an allergy issue. I had about 10-15 bites, each time willing myself to keep shoveling the food down because I would "like it eventually." The tofu was tough, and a weird consistency, and the flavors were super bland. Not even my friend S, who likes pretty much everything, would touch my dinner. 

The pros: The portions here are huge - which was unfortunate for me - but a big plus for people who actually like their food! And again, the cafe/bar has that "effortlessly cool" vibe... so it might honestly be a better place to grab a drink and people-watch. However, I'm not in any rush to try it again, after experiencing the awful food and awful service. Le sigh.
author: Sam S.

description:
Brought by a date years ago and fell in love. Brought pretty much every friend or date; even the country Texas in-laws and they all loved it. Who by the way weren't a fan of the neighborhood. So no conservative types here. 95% of the time my food came out great.  Best time to go is mid afternoon during the weekday. Dinners are busy and forget about the weekend. You'll be waiting for awhile. Come with a snack while you wait or you'll end up a starving animal smelling all that great food. God, only knows that would put everyone in a bad mood.
      You get your money's worth with the huge portions they serve. It's best to share and at least you try different things.

   Favorite thing to order at this place is  spring rolls, of course the garlic edamame, coocnut curry soup, and the beef mushroom noodles..
author: Ness C.

description: Decent service, but the pho was inedible.  How do you mess up pho?
author: Dan S.

description:
Definitely one of my favorite spots in the City.  

There are a lot of good stuff in their menu.  My fav is the Tom Ka-Thai Coconut Tofu Soup.  I've also ordered some not-so-good items here, so be careful if you're not familiar with what you're getting.  But still, something about this place lures me to keep coming back again and again and again.  Maybe it's the intimate setting and the comfort food and oh yea, the coconut tofu soup!

**Vegetarian friendly
author: Cesar Thomas V.

description: I love this place! The food is always amazing and it's very reasonably priced. Everytime I have friends in town we stop by. The garlic edamame is to die for!
author: Phaedra S.

description: shrimp tom ka & ginger tea are exquisite. the automatic water refills are hilarious - just one sip and someone shows up unexpectedly to make sure your water is topped off - can kill the conversation vibe a bit but not worth taking a star away - the food is too good!
author: N M.

description:
Whenever Tamie M. and I gather in a public place for food something weird inevitably happens.

The last time we had met for lunch at Flippers we arrived to an elder woman lying on the ground in the back patio waiting for an ambulance to arrive.  It didn't seem dire as the staff was attending to the situation and whatever companions she had were there with her, but it just felt odd sitting there eating french fries with someone just...laying there.  

Sunday night, after seeing The Muppet Movie at the Red Vic, we sauntered over  to the Citrus Club, which was close by. And I needed close by because I was starving and noodles were definitely called for.  Spending most of the movie in damp clothes from the rain, sticking my head in a vat of broth was an attractive option.

The bowls here are gigantic, so the soups are large and in charge.  I wasn't completely impressed with my wontons for some reason but eh, I'll live.

We sat at a small table for two slurping away next to a lone diner who put away some noodles, some wine and even a dessert as he sporadically NAPPED through his meal.  Weird.  He'd sleep between courses.  And when the bill came and he claimed to have left his wallet at home, Tamie and I slurped as he got arrested a mere 2 feet away from us.

I don't know how we kept straight faces throughout the whole thing.  The staff was calm and handled the whole situation with ease, but less then stellar wontons may drive me to my other default noodle location, Siam Lotus.
author: Jen I.

description:
Oh Citrus Club how I love thee. This is one of my favorite hole in the wall spots to get down and dirty with some legit grub. Fancy me to say I can shell out a whole dish of shanghai noodles and no bitch, I ain't sharing. Ha-ha. (My poor boyfriend. See what he has to live with?)

Get here early as the place is small and/or what I like to call "intimate" - there is usually a line and you're in close quarters so if small spaces make you insane don't come here.

A trip to the citrus club is a must when I'm back visiting my hometown, and it wouldn't be quite the same without it. Come here and often.
author: California G.

description:
I have been to the Citrus Club too many times to count, so I have had the distinct pleasure (or displeasure in some cases) of being able to weed through its pros and cons.  If you can focus on the pros and avoid the cons, this is a 4.5 star place.

Pros: excellent noodle dishes (not soups), friendly and helpful servers, cozy setting
Cons: soups (hit and miss, mostly miss...particularly the pho), is crowded on just about any night of the week during normal dinner time (due to the small size... I guess it's tough to be both cozy and accomodating...)

So if you come for a lunch or early dinner (or don't mind waiting) and order the noodle dishes (my favorites is the peanut noodles with chicken) then you should expect a enjoyable, flavorable meal in a cozy atmosphere.  My guess is that most of the lower ratings for this place are due to people who were unfortunate enough to stumble into the cons... caveat emptor!
author: Ben G.

description: Citrus Club is a regular dinner destination for me. The noodles here are awesome, the portions are large, and it is pretty cheap. The restaurant is small though so you may have to wait a bit if you have a big group, but they are nice about splitting the check onto different credit cards. I like the servers too. They're attentive but not smothering.  I probably go once a week.
author: Stuart S.

description:
I was on a trip to San Fran (but not my first, probably about my 5th) for a conference, and my local friends wanted to bring myself and my boyfriend here before we hit the airport. She raved about it and it was located in the hip Haight Street district so I really wanted to check it out.

WOW was I disappointed. I'd been to dumps with better and tastier food. The atmosphere and surroundings were great - relaxing, and super chill, as were the staff. But that may have leaked far too much into the food.

Not sure if the Citrus Club's direction in food was to PURPOSELY make it bland and tasteless, because if it was, then it deserves 5 stars. But being Asian myself, working in Asian restaurants and sampling foods from various Asian countries, the taste of Citrus Club cuisine seems watered down and very American-style. Traditional Asian foods are robust with flavor and I was very, very disappointed in the Citrus Club.

I had high hopes to start with because we ordered the chicken satay appetizer - which was delicious, but not hard to mess up. Then came the entrees - I ordered the Pad Thai. I'm a die-hard Pad Thai fan and I love it slightly sweet and almost too spicy. I almost cried into my Pad Thai after my first bite. I almost wished I didn't quit smoking so my dead tastebuds could enjoy it. It tasted more like a white person's chow mein. That being said, my (white) boyfriend ordered the chow mein, which was equally disappointing. He added chicken but sadly, the chicken couldn't save it. Lastly, our other out-of-town friend ordered the Shanghai Noodles - and boy, am I glad we passed around our plates. The Shanghai Noodles were the best of the 3 plates, but that's not saying much. Also, not being a fan of beef made it harder to enjoy the best tasting plate on the table.

I really appreciated my local friends' enthusiasm of the Citrus Club, but I definitely will not be going back on my next trip to SFO.
author: Jessika M.

description:
I'll start with the good things:
The staff was very nice and mostly attentive. Also, the artwork and overall look of the restaurant was nice. Unfortunately, those are the only good things I have to say about The Citrus Club.

To start, there were flies everywhere. More flies inside the restaurant than I noticed outside all day. Most importantly, however, both what my friend and I ordered was terrible. Mine was steamed vegetables with rice noodles in sugar water (it was supposed to be a sauce of some sort), and my friend's wasn't much better. We could hardly eat them. It was very disappointing. Maybe there's better things on the menu and we just happened to get the two worst ones, but I definitely will not be going back to test that theory.
author: Aaron Z.

description:
This is a good solid 3 star restaurant.  I've been here twice with the love of my life.  Once for lunch and once for dinner.  The interior definitely outshines the exterior.  It's very dimly lit and the tables are awfully close together.  

I think the first time we were here we split the Vietnamese Spring Rolls (which were good) and I believe I had Shanghai Jade Noodles.  Something like that.  I'd never had jade noodles before, so that was different.  They're just green color.  Green noodles.  Maybe if I eat enough green noodles, I'll turn green like Elphaba in Wicked.  Yes, that would be cool.  But anyway, the second time I was here I was craving some garlic noodles, so I ordered the Korean Short Ribs from the "grilled" section of the menu.  Why did I order that?  Because it said it came on top of garlic noodles.  And who was craving garlic noodles?  Did you say me?  Because that would be absolutely correct.

Service seemed a little bit slow for me and it's very dark at night, but I suppose it is very romantic that way.  Oh, and definitely order the garlic edamame.  Super yummy.  They give you a lot!
author: Kris L.

description:
Great food and pleasant ambiance.

- Garlic edamame is amazing
- A large variety of noodles (buckwheat, spinach, others)
- Coconut/Shrimp combo dishes are yummy
- reasonably priced

NOT A GOOD PLACE FOR A LOW-CARB DIET.
author: M Z.

description:
Delicious food. Large portions. Mediocre service.

Citrus Club is well worth the (typical 10-15 minute) wait. I wish their staff was friendlier... They act like they're inconvenienced by the diners. But the food is excellent, and the atmosphere is generally pretty cool. (I'd give them 4 stars, but the service is bad enough to drop it to 3).
author: T T.

description: Just came from another lunch at Citrus Club. I can't get over how good the beef pho is! Funky little place but I can't say enough about the pho.
author: Dan D.

description:
It's really too bad when you can't give one of your favorite restaurants a five-star review. I mean, I LOVE the Citrus Club. Their "healthy" tofu chow mein is positively orgasmic for me (if not actually healthy). Ditto the garlic edamame. And the cold spring rolls. And the lime cilantro cold soba....

Woo! Cold shower here...

But seriously, I've never, EVER had good service at this place. I've had enough bad service that if I had any self-respect, I really, REALLY wouldn't go back there. Like, every time I tell myself, "Man, I'm not going to take this shit anymore. I'm good enough, I'm smart enough, and gosh darn it, people like me!" 

But then inevitably I find myself in the Upper Haight, and my mind starts wandering to the thought of that damn "healthy" chow mein, and I go crawling back.

So I guess it's too bad when I have to give a four-star review to a place with service as bad as the Citrus Club. Yeah -- THERE!

Yesterday, while cat-sitting for a. a. in the 'hood, I knew I wouldn't be able to resist. I ordered the chow mein for takeout, knowing very well those hot Asian waitresses would end up bitch-slapping me around and I'd end up taking it like the noodle-loving pansy that I am.

And sure enough, that's pretty much how it went. I went in there all smiley, saying I had an order for pick-up, and the waitress DIDN'T SAY A WORD. She basically threw the bag and the tab at me. So I took my precious noodles, said "thank you," smiled, and put a $10 bill on the tray for a $5.93 tab. 

She rang it up -- again, not saying a SINGLE WORD -- and gave me $4 in change. She didn't even give me the seven cents. 

Okay, not like I'm a spangein' Haight Street gutter punk here, but that seven cents is mine. Do I say anything? 

Nope. I just walk out with my tail between my legs, go straight home, and scarf my noodles.

I TOLD YOU, ALRIGHT?! 

It's that good.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Ya'll... I just paid 5.97 (including tax) for a shit ton (there's like half of it in my fridge right now) of noodles AND they're really good!

Someone in another review said that this place looks like a total craphole (it really does) from the outside, but walking in (especially at night) you're transported to a magical land of noodle heaven. Mmmm hmmm that's right!

If you order to-go, (which is ideal if you live close by and don't feel like waiting as he lines are incredibly long) the food is ready in 5-10 minutes, which is great because there isn't much standing room to dilly dally while you wait for your grub.

Did i mention that this place is really cheap? Okay, I probably did, but allow my to remind you just one more time. It's suuuuper cheap! I'm so happy this place is only 500 feet from my place. Woohoo!
author: Richard T.

description: I am always a little wary of places like this - "fusion" places that don't actually mix different cultural foods creatively but instead dumb down the flavors of traditional dishes.  but i actually like this spot a lot, and it's definitely a go to when you need some asian comfort food.  love the hot and sour noodle soup and the spring rolls.
author: Anna V.

description:
This place will give you a fantastically filling, reasonably healthy mean for an amazing price.  They menu has a lot of options but I always get the same thing: spring rolls, and the noodle soup with chicken and spinach.  Sometimes I can't even finish it.  

I had one bad experience here once with a snotty hostess/waitress, but really, only the one time.  Usually the service is just as good as the food.
author: Joe C.

description:
. It's cheap and since SF can drain your wallet, you should eat here
. It's good, tastes healthy
. They try to get you in and out fast since the place is way too small for  the demand - this mean you might have a bit of a wait
. The soju drinks are actually good
. The egg noodles are fresh and taste amazing
. Maybe the best place to get soup in SF when your feeling sick?
author: Shannon Z.

description:
Another amazing place just steps from my front door.
Hot Sake, garlic edemame, and a big bowl of steaming Tom Kha soup. mmmm. Great on a week day, theres less people.  
Its warm, dark cozy, and smells  healthy. Their soundtrack sounds SomaFMish. I went here on shrooms once and only freaked out alittle.
author: Janet D.

description:
First thing I have to say, is man are they efficient in their water refills.  I swear, we were eating, taking sips from our water, and 2 sips in, the bus boy would be on top of it, filling it up again.  I don't think my water ever made it past the 3/4 full mark.

With that being said, I like it here.  Its dark, and has a neat atmosphere, and even though the tables are really close to each other, there is still a sense of intimacy....i guess it also depends on who you go with.  Some have had their worst first date here, some have had a really nice first dinner date, but its intimate nonetheless.  We got there at a perfect hour and had choices of tables, but when we left, there was a line to get sat, so most days I'd expect a wait.

They highly recommend the garlic edamame in the menu, and I concur.  It was the perfect amount of garlic.  Just make sure if you are on a date, they eat them too...so your breath is equally as delightful.
Portions are reasonable to share, and I would recommend sharing whatever you get, so you can get the best of all of it.  Past trips I've gotten the soups, as well as the noodle dishes, and I have no complaints here about the food.  Reasonably priced as well.
author: Lauren F.

description:
FYI - This is mainly a noodle place; variations from Vietnam, China, Thailand, Japan, and Indonesia.

Why is it that the appetizers here are so much better than the entrees? They were out of the Shrimp Spring rolls, so we had to go with the Vegetable Spring rolls. Those and the Garlic Edamame are simply fantastic.

My Apple Martini was good. 

I got the Coconut Tofu Curry something. That was okay. So, 5 stars for the appetizers, but 3 stars for the entrees. They use citrus instead of heavy oils, so maybe I'm just used to more flavorful and less healthy oils.

I didn't know that they also own Kan Zaman and Bistro 9. Interesting.
author: Ken L.

description:
Here, I'll help you order.

Large Bottle of Nigori Sake
Garlic Edemame
Tom-Kha-Chicken.

HOLY SH%#*

You can thank me later.
author: Adam L.

description:
