I just don't get it. I waited an hour for this?! Maybe I didn't order the right thing at all, or perhaps my expectations were a little higher.. I mean, you are a noodle place. I'd expect ALL the noodles to be good.  Why specialize in noodles if they're going to suck?  

My Shanghai noodles were edible - lots of beef/chicken and tofu. Portion was huge, so you get your money's worth in size. As far as taste, it was just drenched in teriyaki sauce, and the noodles reminded me of the instant egg noodles that come in a bowl. You add water, let it sit till the water sorta goes away, and then you drench it in sauce yourself - the kind that comes in a separate little packet with the bowl. Do you guys even know what Shanghai noodles are SUPPOSED to taste like?

If I didn't have to wait so long for this, I might've enjoyed my experience more. Atmosphere is interesting, and the place is packed, at least I know for a Thursday night. Water was often refilled. 11 of us were snugly tucked into that one circular booth facing the front of the place... It was a little difficult getting the servers' attention, but it was packed...

Shanghai Noodles? Again, I say - barely edible. But only because I have poor taste and can eat just about anything without too much trouble... Maybe I should've tried the pho-like noodles instead. Gone there with a smaller group, perhaps?

Oh, and the comments about this being a favorite Thai place for some, W-T-F?!?!?!?!?!?!
author: Tinna H.

description:
On a cold night Metro strolled into the Citrus fresh from a little tour of the Haight, looking for the latest in Shabby Chic. I was burned and tired and sat at the counter. I just wanted a little Thai tofu soup. In walked this tall man in a natty pinstripe suit, adorned with gold cufflinks, gold watch, gold grill, wearing dreads and smiling a HUGE, happy, "I own the world" smile. He was trying to place a togo order and was having trouble deciding. He and the staff were on a first name basis with one another. Bored after placing his order, he decided it was time for a chat.

Dreads: How are you man?
Metro: Good. Thanks. It's cold out.
Dreads: Yes. But I gots me something that keeps me wom an' hoppy.
Metro: Well you're a lucky man. 
Dreads: Let me show you happiness mon.

With that, my bedreaded, well dressed, new found friend reached into his pocket. I thought, "Great, of all the places, of all the times, the last thing I need is a freak yankin' out his..."

GIANT VINE OF CANNABIS??  

Metro: Friend you better put that away. I mean it's Haight street and all but the Summer of Love has long since past.
Dreads: Na werries. Ah carry da card.
Metro: There are cops all over here.

I was confused. I mean here was the twin of Will-I-Am, pulling out a huge stick of "Al Green" and waving it around, in public, sniffing it like a giant cigar under his nose with unbelievable pride and joy.

Dreads: Betta than American Express!
Metro: Card carrying?
Dreads: Ahz need dis fama con-deetion. Dah's not a coppa in here dats could touch me.

I laughed. His take out order arrived. He thanked everyone and strolled out as happily as he had walked in. Now I'm convinced, when I hit my ancient years, or if I develop a "condeetion," I'll apply for THAT card!!

The Citrus Club (aka Cannabis Club) has some inexpensive, quick fare that tries to blend the best of all in the Asian soup and noodle world. Sometimes it's a success...other times it's just a quick bite to eat before grabbing a movie or shopping Haight St. Though not bad for the price, avoid the popular school nights when the USFers come down fr. Lone Mountain.
author: Johnny C.

description: I am a huge lover of Thai food. Huge. i can't get over the amazing flavors that Thai has to offer. Having said that,  I've been here once before, and it was alright. I thought I'd go back and give it another try. I ordered the Tom-Kha soup and the Vietnamese spring rolls. Usually these are some of my go-to Thai dishes. I am currently writing this sitting next to my flavorless Tom-Kha soup, and worst spring rolls I have ever eaten. i don't even want to finish it. I paid $15 for a meal that I want nothing to do with. I think I might go throw it away after I finish this review. Save yourself the time, and head to eat Thai somewhere else.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Not sure why everyone is so all about this place.  Its just ok.  The noodles are fine, nothing inspiring.  The soups, meh, so-so.  Everything here needs a fair amount of doctoring up with sriracha, soy sauce, lemon wedges.  I liked the sound of the cold buckwheat noodles, but when they came it was a coconutty disaster. I'm not quite sure what people are lining up for.  

But, hold your horses.

 I do LOVE the garlic edemame.  They are crazy freaky good.  If they just put that sauce on everything here I think I would be more of a fan.
author: Emily X.

description: Citrus Club is a great mainstay of the Upper Haight. The service is a little spotty, but the affordable, tasty noodle bowls sure make up for it. I appreciate the array of vegetarian and vegan items. Faves include the cold soba noodles, the bbq tofu spring rolls, the tom ka with tofu (it's spicy!), and the sweet citrus glazed greens and noodles.
author: Bee H.

description:
This is probably one of my neighborhood's best places to eat. Lunch and dinner are both reasonably priced, I don't think anything on the menu is over $11.00. They have HUGE portions and the best Thai Iced Tea (they use soy milk instead of condensed milk.) They seat you quickly unless it's a Friday or Saturday night when you will end up waiting 20 minutes or more. They have a waiting list, and they're really good about it, so if you feel like waiting, then go for it.

Ah, but the food sure is worth the wait. I have tried at least 6 things on the menu and my favorites are the Jade Noodles with Shrimp (a mound of spinach-flavored noodles, with coconut milk, shrimp, garlic and snow peas, sprinkled with chili flakes) and the Hot and Sour Vegetable Soup (a sink-sized bowl filled with Tom Yum broth, broccoli, baby bok choy, and tofu.) The Garlic Edamame are to die for. I don't know what it is about their garlic sauce, it's just so delicious. I agree with some reviewers that the food is pretty Americanized, so if you want a more authentic Pho or Thai dish, go to the Inner Richmond (Clement Street.) 

Their sauces are not oil-based which is what they mean by "healthy" on their menu. I've had some of the dishes that people have mentioned were bland. I don't know why some of the dishes have SO much flavor and some have none. I've been disappointed a couple times. I don't necessarily like their peanut sauce, it needs more kick. I brought my best friend to the restaurant once, and she happened to get a bland noodle dish. We "fixed" it by pouring the leftover sauce from the Garlic Edamame. Problem solved.

Vegetarians love this place because they offer great veggie and vegan dishes. Where else can you get vegan Thai Iced Tea, or Barbecued Tofu Spring Rolls? Their specials almost always include some appetizer of vegetable and tofu soaked in their famous garlic sauce. 

Citrus Club is probably the most appealing at night, when you've been walking around Haight Street and you need a drink. Come in, sit down, eat a huge bowl of steaming noodles, drink a sake cocktail, beer or plum wine. Eat some dessert. Go home full, happy and reeking of garlic.
author: L. L.

description:
You can never go wrong with Citrus Club if you enjoy Asian food, more on the Thai inspired side. This place is never a let down, and most people enjoy it. 

Food is delicious & flavorful. I've enjoyed several of their dishes including their special Jade noodles (the noodles were made from spinach), good noodle soups, and I have heard that the Garlic Edamame is good. A good portion, and inexpensive dishes. 
The serve a few selections of beer, wine, and cocktails. 

Service has never been a problem. Employees are usually nice, and helpful. The restaurant isn't extremely big, so it can be a lil squishy! 
Especially in the front where u can sit at a bar like area, but the little area people tend to wait for their tables as well...so it can get a lil crowded. If there is a wait, walk in and write your name down for a table! Gets crowded on Friday nights and weekends. 

It's always delightful coming here to dine. Not a bad atmosphere, dimly lit to enjoy a semi romantic date. :)
author: Catherine O.

description:
I really enjoyed the decor. It was very inviting and had a great atmosphere to it. The prices were decent and were very friendly. 

Menu was long but easy to read. It was good though the curry could have been thicker. My friend had..... (I forgot since we went awhile ago). But I just remember it being good.
author: Toby H.

description:
While you can usually get seated promptly, sometimes the wait for food takes awhile. That was the case last night when a friend and I stopped in for dinner and waited too long for our Thai coconut tofu noodle soups (YUM!).

But aside from that, the food is generally pretty tasty and the portions are huge. I'm a fan of noodles, especially soup noodles so this is a nice place to grab a bite on a casual night out.

The restaurant can be a bit noisy so if you're planning on having deep serious conversations, expect to be practically shouting you secrets across the table.

The appetizers could be a bit more interesting. After eating here several times within the past year, I'm over the spring rolls. I still order them, but eh, they aren't that special. Though, the mixed fruity drinks are definitely nice.

Overall, it's a place where you pay a fair price for somewhat unique food if you're too lazy to make dinner at home. But I wouldn't go there too often, as I could see myself getting bored of this place real quick. (Ideally, this is a 3.5 star place, but I'm being nice with 4.)
author: Viv C.

description: This place is delicious. The noodle bowls are some of the best I've had. Fresh ingredients and vegetables. I'll definitely be going back.
author: Addison H.

description:
My brilliant friend Tim and I went here for lunch after shopping at Amoeba today.  This is my neighborhood and I've been here a few times so I feel comfortable reviewing the overall food and service.  

My experience is that this is a great place for lunch.  The various soups are hearty, tasty, and huge.  I had two appetizers for lunch: the soba and tofu and the BBQ rolls - both delightful!  My pal had a shrimp noodle dish - wonderfully tasty and spicy.

The food was brought promptly - the waitress was super-attentive.  And The Citrus Club has just the right amount of decor - funky yet classy (some of their new art is quite beautiful).

A great casual date place with wonderful, inexpensive, and imaginative food - GO!
author: Jim S.

description:
Pleasantly surprised by this place. I was just expecting something decent to fill my very empty stomach following a reading at the lovely Booksmith down the street. TCC surpassed expectations and my stomach's natural capacity. For dinner, I ordered a special, Cashew Shrimp over noodles. It was delicious, the food was stacked high on the plate, and it was so morish that I stuffed myself silly. I also had the Electric Lemonade, which was blindingly blue and fussy looking, but it tasted great, strong and tart and I thought it complemented the shrimp nicely. The noodle dishes looked better than the soups to me, but my fellow diners enjoyed their soups even if they were beaten halfway through the bowl. It's the size of a serving bowl. We all took home a doggie bag for tomorrow's lunch.

Our server was sweet and super cheery.
author: Annie H.

description:
This place is a hole in the wall.  the food however is great.  It is cheap and always way to much to eat in one sitting.  high quality food and a pretty cool schene.  sometimes a wait to get seated on Friday and Saturday Night.

My favorite is the Garlic Beef and Shitake Mushroom!
author: Eamon W.

description:
It's aight.  Totally caters to WP pallate--thangs are mild-ified...more fusion-ish "Asian" food (read: contains noodles or rice).  Good for vegetarians.  Reasonably priced, big portions.  Go here if you're hungry in the middle of Haight shopping.

Don't piss off or insult the waitress... there was this dude who was being a jerk, and she totally told him off... hahaha!

drinks are good.
author: Grace M.

description:
Good Lord, I miss this place.

I wouldn't know a "good" fusion place if it punched me in the back of the fuggin head and ran, but damnit, I like the CC.

Peanut noodles in a bowl the size of your head.  Spring rolls.  Beer.  The Upper Height.

It's on!
author: Sam P.

description:
This is my first Yelp review because the food was so horrible that I HAD to share.

Pad Thai:
I'm surprised by how well rated this place is after going there yesterday, because I was very disappointed with meal. I ordered the House Pad Thai and it was pretty appalling. I've had my fair share of Pad Thai and this tasted NOTHING like pad thai. My friend and I both thought it was closer to an Alfredo pasta dish than pad thai. It was so bland and had this weird milky/creamy texture. I've had instant/fast food pad thai that tastes better than this. I'm not a picky eater but I didn't even want to eat more than 1/4 of this before I decided I had enough. 

Jade Noodle:
My friend ordered this and I had a bite of his food to see if it was any better than my pad thai. The noodle was an odd (as well as off-setting) teal color. I get the "jade" reference but it looked like food for children and didn't look appetizing at all. Taste wise, It was slightly better than the pad thai, but comparable to Panda Express. 

The service was fine.
author: An H.

description:
This is a hit or miss kinda joint. Only have ever had their take-out... here we go...

Once I ordered a cold, curry noodle salad with chicken - they forgot the chicken. =/ The noodles were lonely without the meat! I once ordered a warm yellow curry noodle dish - it was fine but that's pretty much it... kinda bland flavors... It sometimes takes a while for the orders to be completed because the kitchen is small, the restaurant is packed, the staff is flustered, though usually keep their cool under stress. You can watch the cooks conjuring up the dishes through the front window. 

Maybe it's time I eat in at The Citrus Club and might get a better dining and food experience.
author: Christine C.

description:
I dined at the Citrus Club several years ago and I remembered it being awesome. When we were starving and in the area yesterday I convinced Adam to get take-out.. 

I ordered the Yellow Coconut Curry with Tofu and Nuts.. SUPER BLAND... I sprinkled salt over it and still no flavor.. I was soo disappointed. Adam ordered the Marmalade Coconut Lemongrass Shrimp and his was way better, not worth going back better, but better anyway. 

I'm so bummed, maybe my palate has changed with so many good restaurants in SF. I may give this place one more try, I feel like I have to.. but only once more.. When I do.. I'll let you know!
author: Monica S.

description: Freshest noodles and veggies I've ever had. Pad Thai was delicious, so was the "garlic vegetable" dish. Awesome ginger tea, a bit on the sweet side.
author: Daniel G.

description:
There is no reason to go to this noodle restaurant.

First, it was ridiculously busy when I went here.  Granted, it was a Saturday night and I had a group of 6 people, but we waited an hour and a half for our table.  That would have been ok if the food was good, but it was a big fat let-down.  Half the dishes I tried (garlic beef and shitake mushrooms, Shanghai noodles) were decently tasty--pretty much your standard oyster sauce-flavored, pan fried noodles.  They were verging on too salty though, with none of the rich "wok hei" flavor that is the hallmark of really authentic Asian noodles.  Maybe I'm just a noodle snob, but you can get some freaking delicious noodles in the Sunset district that would blow these out of the water.

However, two of the dishes I tried were just plain disappointing.  The "house pad thai" was a complete misnomer.  The noodles were too thick, covered in a sticky peanut sauce reminiscent of the "pad thai" that involves half a jar of Jiff.  The tiger shrimp curry noodles were flavorless and sort of sour, although I give the restaurant props for generous portions of delicious shrimp in the dish.  

Oh SF, I expected better from you!  Now that I live in SoCal, I like to visit my former home and remember the good food times I had up there.  Citrus Club just made me sad...  Ok, maybe that  was a bit dramatic.  But seriously, don't come here.  (Or come on a weeknight and sit at the bar if you do.)
author: Megan S.

description:
Casual Thai with diffident service anchors this end of Haight Street, where the Club tosses up fire-steamed noodle dishes while the rolling fog crashes in the Park outside.  Be prepared for a long(ish) wait... esp. on busy nights... but as long as your Tivo is up don't worry about the delay and just go with it.

I'm a fan of the core Pad Thai offering and judge the derivative options accordingly.  The environs are cozy, the street scene comfortably walled off.    

I have never had a bad meal here & is a great find to share.
author: Jim W.

description:
Original Review: 7/18/2007

I really like this place. Great food, fun atmosphere. Yes, the bathroom is nasty and odd... The place is probably dark for a reason, in the daylight I imagine it could use a visit from Mr. Clean. But check my review for Sam Wo to see what I have to say about dirty asian restaurants. :P

They are pretty famous for their coconut soup. I'm not a huge soup fan but it is tasty. The best part about this place is how much food you get for so cheap. Dishes are easily 2 meals and $6-$9. Great for take-out. 

This is a 'put your name on the list' place, so be sure to do that right away. Wait usually isn't long. 

I would be very tempted to give them 5 Stars if they delivered. Boo!

Edit: 1/3/2007 - I just had to go their menu to remember my fave dish so I'm putting it on my review... I am in love with the Shanghai Noodles. YUMMM in my TUMMM]

NOTE: The Shanghai Noodles do not have any peanut or sesame in them! :-)
author: Ali R.

description:
I really love the food at this place. I've had a few different dishes now and they've all been uniquely satisfying. The tofu pad thai is amazing and the last time I was there I had some shrimp coconut dish that is a little different tasting at first but it definitely grows on you. And, the garlic edamame does NOT disappoint.

It's a little hole in the wall joint in the haight but I almost had to give this place just 3 stars for a few reasons. 

Firstly, it just feels a little dirty inside. Also, this past time we were surrounded by fruit flies! Gross. Their soda was also short on syrup but I'll let that one slide.

All in all I chose to give this place 4 stars because this is what it deserves. Despite the fruit flies, the food here is awesome and you should give it a whirl. It's also INSANELY cheap for the portions which makes it all the more better!
author: Kristin R.

description: I love the Citrus Club. I've been coming here for years and had lunch there on my brithday. This time, it was the Soba noodle appetizer and spring rolls for lunch. In the past, it's been Noodle soups and Bun salads. It's always fresh and refreshing. I had a birthday dinner here a few years back and remember having a delicious dinner and accomdating service. It's best during the mid-afternoon for a late lunch when it's not too busy. Dinner can be crowded, and take out is always generous and hot. I'm not a fan of coconut, but their coconut noodle dishes are not too heavy like other Thai restaurants. It's always a winner!
author: GHADA Y.

description:
Cheap (most entrees under $7), pan-Asian fare that is big on portions, small on flavor. The place can be really busy on the weekends, so plan accordingly. Luckily, Citrus Club's Haight Street location has a lot of time-killing options. I've been a few times and can comment on the following:

Chicken satay w/ peanut sauce - pretty straight forward. Kind of dry.

Fresh shrimp spring rolls w/ peanut sauce - very well packed with noodles, mint, shrimp, lettuce. The 6 piece order is large enough to share with as many as three people.

The Thom Ka Chicken (coconut broth with carrots, cabbage, snowpeas, cilantro, galanga, onions) is hearty and rich in coconut flavor, with plenty of veggies and fresh herb flavor to mix things up. Slippery rice noodles and chewy chicken pieces provide texture.  It is pretty hard to screw this up. Can also be ordered vegetarian. 
Note: all the soup bowls are practically as big as your head! This is a three-serving alert!

Twice tried the Marmelade Coconut Lemongrass Shrimp with spinach noodles, snowpeas, and onions. For the most part, the dish makes good on its delectable sounding name. Impressed with the amount and size of shrimp. As expected, the marmelade/coconut sauce is sweet and creamy. Then again, I will lick clean the plates of anything that has coconut milk sauce in it. One fatal flaw: spinach noodles tend to be overcooked and mushy, rather than with a nice bite. 

Last night, I ordered the Yellow Coconut Curry Tofu & Nuts (flat rice noodles, tofu, peanuts, bean sprouts, cucumber, carrots, and onions in a "a sweet and spicy curry sauce"). DO NOT ORDER THIS DISH! Call me demanding, but I expect something proclaiming to be a curry dish to taste like curry. Or at least for the love of Vishnu, taste like SOMETHING! I managed to salvage this dish at home by boiling up the leftovers with some chicken broth.

Miscellaneous to note:
Cheap selection of Asian beers and other beverages (e.g., cocktails, wine). Service is not bad; waters were constantly refilled. Tables are superclosetogether, which can either be really annoying or fun. Do your table neighbors a favor and save up a really juicy story to tell your dining companion(s)...maybe it will help them forget how blah their food is.
author: Steph P.

description:
The Citrus Club is money.  The food is really good, and the atmosphere is good for a date or just for hanging out.  If you want to have a serious private conversation, though, you should probably pick a quieter, more well lit place so you can hear what the other person is saying and read his or her body language.

When you come here, make sure you sign your name on the sheet on the clipboard on the wall.  If you don't, you might be standing there for a half-hour.  My only real problem with this place is the wait, although I've also been seated right away.  It's also very easy to miss while you're walking by on Haight Street.  I've had to double back many times.
author: John S.

description:
I hate all the noodles here.  
So not authentic, which is okay if it tastes good, but here they just throw things together hoping it'd work, but it does not work.
There is no depth or complexity to the taste of anything here.
author: Wakako U.

description:
I know tons of people knock the Citrus because it's not that authentic vibe you expect from most Asian restaurants, but I'll give this baby a 5 because I have yet to run into something I don't like. Yes, I'm Asian so I should be more discerning, but if it is good, I am not one to complain.

I typically order to share: Tofu Triangles, Spring Rolls. What I don't share is my lemon and coconut chicken noodles. I happen to really enjoy this dish; it makes me freakin' happy and sedates me before I go to Amoeba to spend my future kid's inheritance. 

Tips: Everything here can be ordered a la veggie, so don't freak out if you like the garlic beef but can't stand the beef part. If something says "chili flakes" let them know how much you can handle: mild, medium or see Jesus. Parking here isn't all that, but you can find good non-metered parking on side streets. Sizewise, that bowl of soup could well serve a family of four, so consider sharing with someone or come very hungry.
author: Charlene L.

description:
OK The food is AWESOME. I recommend the coconut thai soup and the garlic shrimp dish. also the appetizer of the bbq tofu rolls are awesome. the portions are huge and the food is cheap. the food is yummy delicious and healthy and fresh. 
the waitresses are kinda rude.  there is always a wait. and the chairs are super uncomfortable. its small and very loud and impossible to hold a conversation.
but the food is fantastic....yummmmmmmmmmmm
author: Dana C.

description:
Not just pho! If you like noodles and you like asian-inspired, do it.

Really, all the noodles have tons and tons and tons of flavor to them. I would recommend going on an off time though, as it can get crowded.
All noodles under $9. A good option for vegetarians.

Things to try: Shanghai, any of the citrus & coconut combinations.
author: Sasha T.

description:
After reading the reviews and trying the beef and shittake chow fun, i've become a fan. 

It's pretty tasty. Very greasy but hey, it's asian food, what can you expect? The greasier the better. 

The garlic edamame was not bad. But then again edamame is always good. Garlic soy sauce or just sea salt will do. 

I'd probably go here again. I'm just not a fan of their bar like bathroom. blegh. 

Service was quick.
author: Eugenia Y.

description:
When I lived in the neighborhood this was a regular haunt for a weeknight dinner fix of yummy Asian fusion flavors.  And when I'm in the area and want a reasonable meal that isn't a burrito, Citrus Club always hooks me up.  They've got tons of vegetarian options that are not an after thought.  And you can eat a ton without spending a ton while getting served rather than standing in line.  Though dinner waits for a table, especially on weekends, can get out of control.

Post-yogathon in Golden Gate Park, I headed over with my boyfriend and friend to get our hunger pains taken care of and we couldn't have chosen a better place to take care of such business.

The garlic edamame is finger licking good; I mean you will literally be licking your fingers and pressing your bare fork into the garlicky goodness to pick-up the last chunks of the flavor explosion.  And the barbecue tofu spring rolls are packed with fat pieces of tofu, the usual stuff and a special sauce.  So satisfying.  The seaweed salad with tofu is very tasty and it is ample in portion.  The spicy lime and coconut noodles are a true delight of buckwheat noodles mixed with creamy spicy sauce and it's only $4.50!  And if you are feeling carnivorous, you can add chicken for $2.  I love the fat rice noodles with the oh so tasty garlic shrimp.  And the spicy coconut soup will open your sinuses if you are feeling stuffed up and just generally under the weather.

Citrus Club is such a great restaurant choice to have in the Upper Haight.  There is really nothing else quite like it.  And most nights, unless you are totally starving, it is worth the wait.
author: Sharon R.

description:
Don't run from another "Asian Fusion" noodle house. This one stands out for two reasons, it's cheap and it has great ambiance. Who doesn't want to check out hot San Franciscans throwing food all over themselves trying to use chopsticks? At least it is tasty food! Seriously though, it is a great respite from wandering up and down the Haight and is a good place to really REALLY consider if you want to get that nose piercing or the tramp stamp tattoo. 

The drinks are not strong. And that is sad 'cause they have a pretty good selection of what seem like promising sake treatments. The red wine was Safeway select. BUT the actual food was yummy and the portions were reasonable. If you order one of the big soup bowls, it will be plenty for one for lunch. 

Great date spot when you are on a budget but want a bustling vibe. If you don't have a date and want one, consider eating at the bar. Some of the boys when I was there seriously looked like James Blunt. And that's spicy, steamy AND fragrant!
author: Miel H.

description:
Not sure what to say - some things are beyond AMAZING (house garlic edamame, shanghai noodles, cashew chicken, garlic beef and mushroom) and some are almost inedible (chili-glazed tofu & greens over rice noodles).

Order well and you'll love take out and eat in.  But make sure you order well or you'll be sorely regretting the huge pile of noodles in front of you for the rest of the night.
author: Jessica S.

description:
New to the hood: I've been 3x.  Commenting about my most recent frequent during Valentine's Day wknd (we were the ones in the full-on 80s outfits).

Whatever we ate was good (not 'bland'!!!) but can't remember specific dish titles, in part because the **SAKE MARGARITA** was AMAZING. I know what you are probably thinking "but how can a margarita be made with anything but tequila?"...my friends, it CAN be done!

Service/friendiness had been spotty the other times I was there but, to my pleasure, that turned around!  I sat at the bar with friends and our server was a genuinely happy gal and we barely waited for our food/drinks.

If you've never been, try it out, judge for yourself... I recommend it to friends...
author: Ash E.

description:
Walked in with 3 others at 7pm, told it was going to be about a 20-30 minute wait. 40 minutes later, they called a party of 4 that we were ahead of. Half an hour after that, we finally got seated. They comped an appetizer though, so I didnt' complain.

Nothing really stood out though; everything was either all right, or almots amazing yet had some fundamental flaw that prevented it from being so.

The adamame in the garlic sauce somewhat missed the mark, because all the flavor was on the inedible part of the pod.

The satay was good, not great.

Got a chicken salad which could have been amazing had they not overloaded it with dressing. My friend said the same thing about his dish, with them overloading it with garlic. Myu other friends though did get a delicious coconut curry soup.

Prices are reasonable, but given the long wait for ok food, i'd rather try somewhere else....i hear Ploy Thai next door is good....
author: Mark A.

description:
It was a beef explosion.

I was meander Golden Gate park, and upon stumbling on the bison, and I had an insatiable desire to eat beef...morbid I know.  But being with a dainty young lady with an affection for carbs we decided to go to the Citrus Club, whose name I have no idea about.

Atmosphere:  Its really really...dark and small, reminds of me of an apartment I lived in college.  You enter a small corridor where there is the "pasta bar" where single person seating is available for noodley goodness.  Inside is densely packs 2 seaters crammed into a small space.  Overall, pretty basic interior, and the tone is pretty casual dress, jeans and a Tshirt.  Of not the bathroom is tiny, with a sink facing the tables, so if you have to go tinkle, people will know about it.

Service:  Was prompt and fast by staff.  No white coats or party gloves, just people ready to get you in and out.

Food:  Your pretty standard fare for Noodles.  You had wide selection of soups, egg rolls, and noodles of both the meat and vegetarian persuasion.  I had the Shrimp Spring Rolls, which were pretty good.  I then partook in the Garlic Beef and Shitake mushroom Noodles, and my friend the Garlic Shrimp and Shitake Noodles.  Overall, very good, with large portions and a ton of beef and mushrooms.  I eat like no tomorrow usually, and I was damn near ready for dawn.

Date Factor:  This is a pretty casual place, not really a first date places, but chic enough to take a person after a long day shopping or exploring.

Mommy Factor:  being in Haight, my mom might not dig the Rastas selling me sunglasses or the vibe of the place.  No a place I would bring the kids either.

Bling:  4 egg rolls where $4 bucks, and both noodle dishes were 6-7 bucks a piece.  All in all about 25 bucks for the two of us for a pretty filling meal.

Upshot:  Cheap, tasty food served in a broom closest, that you might want to use the bathroom before going to....then again I am particular about you knows when I go number 1.
author: Zaid A.

description:
Oy.  

Walking into Citrus Club, I had high hopes.  The decor was nice and the wait staff was also nice (that's what got them the second star).  

HOWEVER, the food was a big disappointment.  We got the coconut lime noodle salad with chicken and the tom ka gai (which had noodles in it too).  First, the salad had too much sauce on it.  Second, and much more importantly, there was virtually NO taste to either the salad or the soup.  To top it off, when I asked for more lime, I was given a bowl of SLICED limes, which meant very little juice, and what WAS there got all over my fingers.

Please please please, Citrus Club, at the very least, give us wedges of lime so we can add much needed taste to your bland dishes.
author: Kerrie L.

description:
I adore spicy Thai food - and this place definitely hits the spot! Kinda dark and the bathroom creeps me out, but otherwise wonderful.

But really, this place gets all of its stars for the drunk woman I met on New Year's Eve. My friends and I hit this place up before going out - so granted we were a little overdressed - and two of us were cornered almost immediately by a woman hounding us about our height. I'm quite tall for a girl - almost 6'2 - and my friend is 5'10, and this woman started SCREAMING about how she loved that we were amazons who weren't afraid to wear heels. She hugged us, she sloshed drinks everywhere, she even had her boyfriend take a picture of us (even after she asked for our nationalities in regards to why we were so tall)!!! The patrons were scared - the bartenders and servers were scared - hell, I was scared! Still hilarious. 

Food's good too. I love this neighborhood, and I really love the Citrus Club.

------

EDIT 5/21/07:

While this place is increasingly becoming my go-to place for comfort food in the Haight (their coconut curry can do no wrong), I must take a star away for being witness to a particularly skeevy moment involving a rodent/insect of some sort yesterday.

Waiting in line for a table, we heard the waitress shriek, point at the ground in the kitchen, and then run out of the room. One of the cooks acted quickly and stepped on it, whatever it was, smushed it into the ground, then swept it up and threw it out.

I have no idea if it was a rat or a spider or a cockroach, but it did put something of a damper on dinner.

------

EDIT 5/22/07: Four words for you: WORST. FOOD. POISONING. EVER.

I did love this place until it turned me into a ridiculous mess. I blame the bug on the floor. 

All stars taken away.
author: Devon S.

description:
I don't get it. 
Low on flavor.  High on mush.  I've heard great things about this place, but the flavor of the pad thai was pretty close to the flavor of the other noodle dish we got.   
My Cosmo tasted like windex. 
Quantities were huge, though.   And my company was good.
author: Maria C.

description: Good Thai food in the Haight. The acoustics are quite loud, though, which creates the unfortunate "shout in order to be heard" dynamic on a busy night.
author: Shalom O.

description:
This place is one of the first places I went to when I moved to the Haight...I go here every time I get a chance! everything on the menu is amazing! their Chicken Sate appy 4 star, order the peanut dipping sauce with it, Amazing! The Fresh spring rolls off the hook! But the Piece De Resistance is the Marmalade Coconut/Lemongrass Chicken (also can be served with shrimp)! This is by far a dish I dream about! I have Ciliacs Disease so they can make it with their rice noodles as a gluten free/Dairy free option... It is a huge helping of noodles and tuns of chicken, I always ask for extra cilantro and green onions... I tell myself that I'll save half and have it later, but it is sooo good I can never seem to stop myself:)
The service is great, the wait can be long...but it is always worth it! I usually try to get there before 6 as after that your wait will be at least an hour, but even at an hour it is always worth it!
I highly recommend this as a can't loose place to take a date or friends from out of town!
author: cleolvr D.

description: I felt I had a cold coming on so I got the hot and sour veggie soup. The broth was nice and spicy exactly what I needed ,but I wished there was more broth then veggies which were just ok.
author: Chris D.

description:
Rude wait staff and terrible, terrible service.

We went here to grab a quick bite on a Sunday night to wrap up the weekend with close friends and accomodate a vegan's diet in the group.

After signing up our party of four on the "list", we waited over a hour in a crammed hallway somewhere between a bathroom and people eating. To pass the time we sipped on some "blended han margaritas", which we ordered from the bar. While drinking these horrible margaritas that get ice stuck in the straw, we got to enjoy watching the wait staff seat countless parties of two and three.

Ever hear of putting a two top together? 2+2=4!

Apparently not... 

So after the wait staff flunked math class and we drool more over people's food we ask the waitress why she can't seat us. First she ignores us and seats another party. Then she comes back at us from the dark abyss and tells us that  "she isn't crossing our names off the list, and no one is asking for us to wait."

Never in my life have I seen that level of arrogance in a restaurant or from a server. Unbelieveable.

Needless to say, we never got seated, left promptly and ate across the street at a little Thai place that probably serves 100million times more authentic food than some slop in a big bowl.

Note to waitress at citrus club: life isn't so rough working in a shitty noodle house. It's not as hard as elementary math anyway! Get your eyes checked.


Never again. Citrus club sucks.
author: Andreas T.

description:
Ok I have been going to this restaurant forever and a day and finally wanted to sit down and write a review! Literally you can not go wrong with this place. Sometimes if you go a the height of dinner time there is a little wait, but in general this place is amazing. If you eat there, the atmosphere is dark and almost mystical. It is definitely a trendy date spot.
As for food, if you eat there or order to go, it is all amazing. For starters I would either go with the house garlic edemame or the spring rolls. The edamame are tossed with this amazing sauce to perfection and the springs rolls are served with this amazing peanut sauce. For a main course I always have either Hot and Sour soup or their Yellow curry with tofu and nuts. The soup is a great blend of spicy and tasty veggies, as well as a little bit at the end. The curry is everything you want from a curry but not over powering! 
Lastly, their portions are huge some you get another lunch or dinner with it! Yum!
author: Katie H.

description: This place is pretty good if you like Asian Fusion. I'm not a huge fan of sauces that come right out of a bottle and I feel like a lot of the recipes included sauces or flavoring that had that taste. The salad and noodle dishes are the best way to go. Small and a little dark inside. But an overall cute atmosphere.
author: Natasha S.

description:
Went there with 7 other friends for a birthday dinner. The place is kinda small, so I can understand that it took sometime to get us seated. Fine. When we ordered our meals, the service was decent, and the food was so-so. Out of the eight dishes we ordered, one was very good (coconut shrimp with wok-tossed spinach noodles), and all others were so-so.
 
Now for the kicker. Very, very rude wait-staff. All they seem to care about is to churn the tables, and get their tips. One of the Asian girls working there, a pretty face with a very foul mouth, made it abuntantly clear that all she cared for was the money. 

I would not recommend going here. This is a service economy, and I think these Asians need to be reminded about that. The customer service attitude at The Citrus Club is no different than any of the multitudious Chinese restaurants in San Francisco. I am sure you know what I am talking about. My suggestion is to go out to eat where the food AND the service makes the occasion a pleasant and memorable one. The Citrus Club clearly does not fit that bill.
author: Raj D.

description:
Crowded, curt servers, loud, ridiculous wait time on a weekend evening.  But yum yum yum!  There's a reason this place is always crowded-- the food is fresh, healthy and cheap.  I've had some out-out-out rude servers in my time, but not at the Citrus Club.  They have definitely been rather short with me, but I try to give them the benefit of the doubt that it's due to having more tables than they can comfortably handle as well as a bunch of to-go orders.  Who knows, maybe I've been lucky.

I plan to spend some wait time when I come here, and I bring good enough company that I can ignore the loudness, etc around me and just enjoy the food.  Then again, maybe next time I'll call in a go-go order...
author: Nicci S.

description:
Hooray, a new favorite restaurant in the city! The Citrus Club has a great vibe, with a cute ambiance (think hanging tropical lamps and sparkle lights) AND they play great music. It doesn't get any better. 

The food is delicious, not to mention affordable. We ordered the garlic beef noodle dish and the coconut shrimp soup, and both were delightful! I couldn't believe what we were getting for 7-9 dollars a dish. I love the fun atmosphere, happy people, and great service. Combined with the amazing food, well, you've got yourself the perfect dinner out.
author: Michelle G.

description:
A bowl of brothy-noodles and a little sake or tea is heart warming! i love going here when it's cold outside or if i'm hungover. you might have to wait for a seat, but when you get there the food comes out quick. plus it's open later than most other upper-haight options. 

My favorites are the soba noodle seaweed soup and the tom ka soup. also the spring rolls are yummy. i stick to veggie stuff so my 4-star rating is based on that. i've been coming here since the place opened and i would have to say it's been pretty consistent...decent cheap noodle dishes, high hipster turnover (tonite especially), dim-seedy lighting, no-so-appealing bathroom. service is hit or miss depending on the mood of who's seating/waiting on you. if you don't feel like dealing with the scene, call ahead for take-out.
author: Isabel C.

description:
I used to love this place. Good, cheap food.

After three visits- I have decided to never enter this building ever again and I shall only refer to it as "that which shall not be named".

If you happen to live around the corner like I do, just get it to-go. There's one extreamly rude and bitter lady that works there who is personally responsible for my hating the place now. They need help with their hosting techiniques and their service. 

If you DO go-- get the buckwheat noodle salad (lime/coconut) thingy. Its super cheap and big enough to be lunch the next day too.
author: Minx A.

description:
One of my favorite places to eat in SF. Whether you want a HUGE bowl of awesome soup for about $7 or some of the best noodles you've ever had,  they serve up straight Goodness.

The Hot-Sour Vegetable soup with shrimp or the Marmalade Coconut Lemongrass Shrimp that come with the spinach noodles are both my favorites. I could eat them any day of the week. Sometimes I'd order one to eat then and the other to take home.

No matter what you get, it's served hot right out of the kitchen and your food will continue to cook after it's served. The noodles in your soup only get tastier as they soak up the flavors and your noodle dishes soak up sauces.

The waitresses are nice, the atmosphere is cool and casual and the music is usually pretty chilled out lounge or something similar.
author: Alex B.

description: This place has one seriously downhill in food quality.  The last couple times were dreary, and tonight was the last straw.  I understand that pad thai is done differently everywhere, but the one at Citrus Club tastes like cheap peanut noodles of the lowest caliber and the beef pho had a one-note broth, decent accompanying produce and two measly slices of  poorly cut, low grade meat.  I won't be back.
author: Quinn S.

description:
I live two blocks from Citrus Club, yet don't go there very often.  I went last night, and remembered why I don't go out of my way to eat there.

It's too bad, because I really want to like Citrus Club.  It's convenient, it's definitely a good deal in terms of prices, and the concept is great.  But somehow the execution falls flat.

I guess what really bothers me is the translation from menu description to actual entree.  Every dish on the menu sounds fantastic - I love pan-Asian noodle dishes, and I should be loving this food.  As others have pointed out, this place smells amazing - just walking by the restaurant, your nose draws you in.  But every dish I've ever had at Citrus Club ends up being disappointing.  The food is just bland!  It lacks flavor, tends to be sweet rather than spicy, and tastes like it is trying to be "health" food.  As my dining partner said last night, halfway into her dish, "I'm bored."

The other issue I have with Citrus Club is the service.  I'm not expecting five star dining type of service - this should be a friendly neighborhood casual dining hang-out, not Gary Danko.  But despite the frenetic pace of the wait staff, we had to wait a really long time to get our food, the staff seemed to avoid us when we tried to catch their attention to ask about the food, and the order was wrong.  I'm sure we could have asked for the food to be fixed, but after waiting 40 minutes to get our dishes, we didn't want to risk another long wait.

Citrus Club isn't awful.  In fact, I wish I loved it here.  But I just can't seem to get excited about the food, and I simply don't understand why there are long lines out the door.
author: Angelos K.

description:
People seem to love this place.  But for whatever reason, I feel kind of guilty as an Asian eating here... sort of like a "poser Asian", as if I'll have my Korean-ness revoked and be kicked out of the club.  It makes me understand why my Mexican boyfriend feels uneasy when I make him go to Taco Bell and try to get to admit out loud that he likes it.

The food doesn't really taste authentically anything (which I guess is covered by the "Pan-Asian" categorization).  It's not particularly bad or good.

When I'm feeling under the weather and not wanting to leave the 'hood, their beef broth (from their version of Pho) seems to do the job of clearing my sinuses.  

When I'm up to driving or taking public transportation, I'd rather go to Pho Hoa Clement or Yummy Yummy.

Tip:  Don't get fooled by their jade noodles which are a beautiful bright green.  They're pretty to look at but taste just like any other noodle, though.

UPDATE:
I have no shame.  I have fully embraced the generic Asian food-ness of Citrus Club and no longer just get it to go and sneak off with it to eat upstairs in the BF's apt.  The chick sitting at the bar slurping at her bowl of noodles ... that's me.  I love Taco Bell.  Why can't I love Citrus Club?  One more star.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Citrus Club: it's inexpensive and the portions are monstrous. The per lb. price is probably approximately equivalent to a heaping 4$ burrito (I like to evaluate food by the per lb. price -- classy). But Citrus Club is actually a cool place. It's the sort of place you can go to with a couple of friends on a Friday night and feel like you did something relatively exciting, which is not really true of El Castillito (and I am not, not for a half second, maligning El Castillito). So, in my book, Citrus Club is a special and spectacular place. 

I always carefully eat no more than half my meal so that I can call the leftovers lunch the next day. I did have one traumatic instance when I eagerly opened my leftovers bucket only to discover that the waitress had given me someone else's leftovers -- someone not even from my table. Though I considered eating it, my good judgment got the better of me and I tossed it (no mouth crabs for me, friends!). 

Finally, I should mention that the food is good. I would even say very good. No, no, no ... it's not Gary Danko. But it's super tasty. So let's appropriately adjust our expectations for a dish that's less than $6 and praise these noodles for what they are. I recommend.... everything. The coconut noodle soup, peanut noodles, chicken coconut noodles, veggie noodle soup... it's all highly satisfactory.  It spans comfort food and exciting food in just the right way. I have never left unhappy.

And that wait is never as bad as it seems.
author: Beah B.

description:
I LOVE this place.  The prices are very reasonable and know that you WILL be taking a doggy bag home.  The portions are ricoculous!  I had the garlic prawns with shit-talkin' mushrooms and some garlic edamame.  Dem darn shit-talkin mushrooms had me laughing so hard...
har har har....
author: Jessica M.

description:
I tried this place for lunch the other day and all I can say is that you have to go here and try one of their garlic noodle dishes.  I tried the garlic shrimp dish with fresh snap peas and shitake mushrooms and it definitely made my mouth happy.  The garlic sauce was finger lickin' good and the mushrooms had so much flavor that I couldn't help having this surprised look on my face after I took the first bite...and I kind of had to fight back the urge to lean over the couple next to me and be like "Is this for real???"  The only thing I didn't like about the dish was the mushrooms were cut in large chunks and I think they could have been sliced a bit thinner, which I'll try to request next time I go.  

The decor was standard, the table seating was a little too close for my taste, and the waitstaff seemed like they were on some imaginary deadline, but the service was prompt (I got my food in less than 10 minutes after ordering) and prices were cheap, so overall a good, efficient, affordable, experience.  I'm definitely going back...soon.
author: LaSha G.

description:
The Citrus Club has a variety of Asian noodles. It's worth a try, but I think there are other places in SF that are much better. 

Garlic Edamame = Great appetizer to start off with. The sauce is delish! I'm not a fan of edamame and I still ate a bunch.
Pad Thai  = a bit different from the ones I've had from other restaurants, but still good. 
Yellow Curry Noodles w/Tofu & Nuts = too light for my taste. Needed some more flavor.
Noodles w/ Garlic, Beef, & Shiitake = Good
Shanghai Style Noodles = Good, but nothing over the top impressive
Peanut Noodles = My friend said it was just ok, nothing really worth noting

Noodle dishes run from about $8-$11 dollars and their portions are good sizes. Nothing fancy, but still nice on the inside. The space is small, so there might be a wait.
author: Felicia C.

description:
Thai iced tea was super good and we didn't have to wait. The shrimp wonton soup I got was massive! I ate all the wontons and felt like I ate a ton of noodles but it didn't look like I made a dent at all.

The place was really dark and pretty cramped, kinda excessively. I like to be able to see while I'm eating and not bumping into people if I want to move a couple inches.

All in all, pretty good. I'd like to try their non-soup items too.
author: Emily M.

description:
Went here before a movie at Red Vics and had a pretty disappointing experience.  I want to say you get what you pay for, but I know way to many inexpensive tasty places with good service.

The only thing that I liked about this place was the over-sized shrimp spring rolls.   The tiger curry shrimp has a bunch of overcooked shrimp, heap of noodles, and tasted bland (curry?!).

Service was non-existent, we had to flag someone down every time we needed something, nobody came to us and asked us how it was or if we needed anything else.  Even after they cleared our plates they disappeared.

This place is good if you want a cool inexpensive carb load and don't care about good service.
author: Elicia W.

description:
Garlic Edamame...oh.my.sh*t.
Who knew soy beans could be coated in garlic-e heaven?!? One of the top 10 things to ever be in my mouth 0_0
author: Mia M.

description:
My boyfriend had the 'coconut curry noodle soup' with fried tofu it was slightly bland but I would definately order this again it was still delish. 

I got the citrus crispy noodle salad, it was fresh and zingy! I love the citrusy sweet dressing.
author: Ann M.

description:
Long, comfy bar with high chairs.
Low light. Red walls. Steaming cauldrons.
Cool music (they apparently play off an iPod)
I recommend the egg-drop noodle soup, haven't tried much else.

Especially nice on 
- a cold/rainy/foggy day, when noodle soup can warm the cockles
- if you are loitering in the Upper Haight on a hippy/GGpark trip

They don't have SriRacha Thai Sauce (w/o which Pho is faux).
Ask for their chilli sauce separately, and it comes out in a lil bowl.
author: Amit S.

description:
I dont know. I came here once and here is what I recall.

-Quick Service
-Nice Bathrooms
-Very large portions
-Inexpensive
-And some sort of Coconut chicken noodle dish that I have been craving for the last year, but cant seem to find :(
author: Andrya H.

description:
There are all sorts of things you can legitimately complain about when it comes to the Citrus Club:

long wait
no parking
not very authentic cooking

But I think there is more to love about it. 

The amount of food vs. price ratio has to be among the highest in San Francisco.

I have no idea what you people are talking about, I've always found the service to be really friendly and efficient enough.

Food comes fast.

At 6 or 7 bucks per entree, ya'll need to stop whining.
author: Jason R.

description:
Awesome food. Awesome service.*

My boyfriend and I had eaten here last week for the first time after hearing good news about the place. The atmosphere is very relaxing and serves as a break from the hustle and bustle of snooty shoppers and hobos that inhibit Haight Street. We began our meal with Vietnamese spring rolls, made of fresh ingredients and a tasty dipping sauce that had a slight sweetness to it. My boyfriend had the Pho-Ga chicken noodle soup. The right amount of seasoning AND enough meat and noodles to leave full for the rest of the day. I had their house pad thai which was awesome!* It sorta tasted like an asian inspired pasta because the sauce was very creamy, but it was still very delicious. To top it off, I had the citrus punch, a citrus-y slush, to relieve my tongue that had been throbbing from the spicy sauce provided. Yeah, I'm a light weight.

Highly recommended for casual, relaxing dining.

* Awesome is the highest form of flattery...for food, at least :)
author: Angela H.

description:
Yeah, it's a three.  Food's decent but certainly nothing special, it pretty much does the job but I'm not exactly going out of my way to get there or sending anyone else their way.  

Their portions are ENORMOUS - as in family style enormous, and they are cheap.  Spring rolls are good, my favorite thing to order is a vegetable soup with buckwheat noodles.  I fish out all the veggies and leave enough broth and noodles to feed another two people.

Given the dearth of exciting dining options on Haight (if you disagree pls send me a message because I'd love to know what I'm missing) it is one of my favorite spots in that part of town.
author: Jenny S.

description:
This is exactly the kind of food I could eat all day, every day, for the rest of my life!  I ordered the cashew chicken, one of my all-time favorites, and it was arguably the best I've had.  The ingredients were so fresh, the flavor was not boring, and by the time I couldn't eat another bite there was more than enough left over for me to bring home and eat at midnight :)

Delicious!
author: Christy K.

description:
Since this is my one and only experience here I'll give the place the benefit of the doubt and not 1 star it... I had what was quite possibly the worst pad thai in my life here this weekend. It looked and tasted like pasta primavera with coconut milk and brown sugar. After a few bites I reluctantly gave up and let the eaten portion gel into what felt like silly putty in my stomach. 

I don't think everything here is bad. The people with me ordered variants of tom ka, which looked decent but they were served in what looked like 2 quart bowls. I'm not sure who could put away that much noodle soup and I'm not sure I'd like to see it if they did.
author: Nate S.

description:
Was there for the 2nd time last night.  Love the noodle, although I know it was not the most authentic Asian food.  Specialized in NOODLES, if you are a noodle lovers, got to experience this once. The taste is bold but it can be too salty for some ppl. The service in the morning was faster than at night. I prefer the ambiance in the morning. Great place for people who loves to eat in the dark. 
Tried and loved: the Mandarin chow mien, The Garlic Beef and Shitake, Cashew Chicken noodle.
Not as much: The Marmalade, with jade spinach noodle. (due to the thick coconut milk taste) It's like Asian white sauce, only they used coconut milk.
It's a fun place to hang out on Haight st..
author: Yeanne H.

description:
I love this place.  I wholeheartedly recommend the Garlic Beef and Shiitake Mushroom noodle bowl.  Think massive bowl of noodly goodness.  *drool*

Also, I typically hate spring rolls and think they taste weird, but these were the best ones I've ever had.  They had this great wrapper, tasty filling, and peanut dipping sauce to top them off.

I also recommend the cold, unfiltered sake to go with it.  Mmm.

Love it.
author: Julie E.

description:
Sometimes, I go to a new place and want to run home and write a review. That's how I first felt about Citrus CLub, but now I'm glad I waited.

The one dish I get over and over, the spicy lemon chicken, is really good. And it costs $7 and can feed me twice; no small feat, let me tell you. So anyplace that approximates my goal of $4 for a meal is alright by me.

But now that I've been a few times, I've gotta say- the menu is a little limited, in that there isn't much variety among dishes. They seem different, but aren't really. And it's very very crowded.
author: Caitlin E.

description:
When my "first timer" out of town friends come in for a visit this is the go to eatery for them to be instantly impressed. It's quirky and charismatic San Francisco at it's finest (without being pretentious). 
My friends always praise me for taking them there: "That was soooooo good, thank you so much for taking us" o r even, "You are Awesome". "Thanks for picking up the bill it tasted really expensive" (Totally affordable to do this... given it is a pay day week for me).  The food really is amazing for what you are spending.

So now I have come here to give credit where it is due.

Citrus Club will not only show your friends what something Not on Fisherman's Wharf is like but will continue to make me feel lucky that I live here and am not just here on holiday. Although it is right on Haight it has a real neighborhood feel to it.  

My secret to getting a quick bite with the risk of it no longer being quick: If I'm only with one or two people, I ask to be seated at the bar and usually by pass a 15 + minute wait. You can still all hear each other, and if you really want to look at each others pretty faces just walk over to Hobson's after your hearty delicious noodle soup.
author: Rebecca S.

description:
Sitting at Citrus Club last weekend after the Bluegrass Festival. 
Stu: Olivia you know you made out with Eileen last night
Me: Say whaaaaaa?
Eric: Yea, you don't remember... you guys were all over each other
Ron: We couldn't pull you two apart
Me: Really???? Where was I and why did I miss it????
One of the best conversations i have had regarding a night drunkenness and the hangover soup. 
I like Citrus Club. But frankly it can be a hit or a miss sometimes.... Know what you like and stick to it... that's hard to fuck up.
But man their hot and sour soup did me proper that day! 
YAY
author: o. c.

description:
Thai coconut soup with extra tofu, garlic edamame, and an Asahi Extra Dry.  Perfect beginning to a night out.  Cheap as hell, but a little slow and the wait sucks especially on weekend nights.

I like the cramped atmosphere.  I always have a good experience here with friends.  I tend to see a lot of very uncomfortable first date types here, but if you're sitting next to one of these couples it can be kinda fun to eavesdrop on the awkwardness.

The portions are huge as has been said.  Beware of when you walk out with your left overs though.  The street kids will ask for them.  Once when I gave a kid my left over soup he came running back to me a few minutes later asking me if there was meat in it.  I guess even beggars can be vegetarians.  My friend's appropriate sassy response was "Call your mother. She misses you."
author: Wendy C.

description:
This place is da bomb! After B2B, freaking chilly weather in short shorts, a few miles of walking and loads of beer, it's best to have some greasy food to mellow the afternoon out.

The narrow restaurant made you wait in line while having people brushing against you as they are leaving. But looking at the guys tossing the woks and working their magic made the wait totally worthwhile. And I almost wanted to go up and tell them I can eat standing without a table.

For a group of 5 people, it was only 28 bucks each (including tips), and that included 6 hot sakes, Vietnamese spring rolls (excellent sauce), the tossed noodles that have good flavour and lots of grease (yum), and the delicious coconut as well as green tea ice-cream with a side of fried bananas, that it not only filled my stomach happily, but also helped subsided the 9am beer belly and chilly foggy goose bumps.
author: T L.

description:
I really enjoyed this little gem last night having dinner with a new friend. First, it just smells good in there! It also seems to be a popular place seeing you have to put your name on a list and wait in line. It doesn't take long to be seated however and it also gives you the opportunity to see the MASSIVE bowls of soup heading out to their respective tables. The soup was great and absolutely huge, enough for 2 people easily. I had the special of the day which was the Shrimp Wonton soup and it was great. 

Yet another great new place I've discovered here in SF...I love this town!
author: Gabriel R.

description:
Where do i even begin? The portions are large, the selection on the menu is bountiful. Unfortunately, everything was terrible, the only thing that made me not entirely hate the place was the thai iced tea. Even then, the thai iced tea was not even that great. Overall it was a bad experience. 

If you are looking for a cute place to go to that has a wide selection of thai food, you are looking at the wrong place. That is unless you are looking for a restaurant that serves TASTELESS food. They had the right ideas, but they did not carry through their selection on the menu. It was quite sad. 

The price of the food was cheap, as was the quality of the food. 
The sign on the door is deceiving. It may look interesting, but believe me, its really bad food.
author: Tony W.

description:
Went here for the first time yesterday and I really enjoyed it.

Prices are nice and you get a decent amount of really great tasting for for that nice amount of money.

I had the Shanghai Beef which I was thoroughly happy with (there was enough for me to take home), and my bud has some kind of green spinach noodles with a really tasty curry-coconut creamish sauce.  We couldn't figure it out.  He said it was like an asian alfredo sauce but I think it was a coconut -curry.  I could just look at the menu and find out but I'm really too lazy right now.

Service was nice.  Pretty girls who didn't seem to carry the normal 'tude that I was expecting.
author: Josh L.

description:
I like how quickly they can put some take-out together for you, but I don't actually like the way it tastes.  I got a noodle dish that had about 4 pounds of noodles and a minuscule amount of sauce. It was so boring!  

The only thing I've had here that was good was the garlic edemame.  That dish is super good though, so if you're up for just a snack and a drink this would be a fantastic stop on your way to another locale.
author: Karyn J.

description:
After drying off and drinking up a bit at the Chrissy Bee Gallery, we meandered across the street to Citrus Club, which Padmae k. had described to me as a better (cheaper) version of Straits Cafe. I was intrigued, and delighted to find it not at all crowded. We didn't wait more than ten seconds before sitting down in a luxurious corner booth. I had instant visions of finishing a glorious meal and flopping over right there to sleep.

I got the special salmon dish for around $10, which by Citrus Club standards is sorta pricey, mind you. It came out piping hot, rested on a bed of garlic noodles, and was delicious. I tried a bit of my friend's beef with noodles dish and that tasted great also.

With our bellies full, we ventured onward....
author: Patrick G.

description:
I don't want to call the Citrus Club a place that employs lairs, but then again, it's probably equally as offensive to call it a place employing morons.  You be the judge.

My interaction:
"Your order will be ready in about 15 minutes."
*about 30 minutes later*
"Here's your vegi pad thai"

Perhaps my waitress didn't know the proverbial "dill-io," or maybe she just didn't like the cut of my jib.  Either way, I stood around waiting for my pad thai 15 minutes more than the deal was for.  

Sure, I probably wouldn't have gone to eat somewhere else had I known of the extended wait, but I would have... NOT SPENT 15 MINUTES WAITING IN THE CRAMPED HALLWAY.

As for the pad thai itself, it was a tad too sweet for my tastes, as well as slightly watery.  But at $6, I suppose these flaws are excusable.
author: jack p.

description:
Busy little place and after eating there I understood why. As other reviewers had noted, Citrus Club is very inexpensive and the food seems somewhat healthy because of a lack of fried items on the menu.

There was a line of people there when we arrived but we were seated in no time and the food started coming shortly after we ordered. Can't go wrong starting out with the spring rolls. The Peanut Noodles were all right but Shanghai Noodles were so much tastier. For dessert, the bananas with coconut icecream were a nice way to end a meal.
author: Kristi K.

description:
4 Stars go for the food and definitely not for the service! 

Yummy-yum vote for Citrus Club. The portions are a bit outrageous, but it was the first time when i tried the famous Vietnamese soup and it was delicious. I enjoyed it very very much...

Will sure comeback, but next time will have to share my portion of the soup at least 3 other peeps :-)

Thanks Citrus for making a great dinner for me!
author: Katja S.

description:
I've only been to Citrus Club once, as I am not a San Francisco local, but they have the best garlic edamame ever! I have been dying to go back and dine at this restaurant again.  I honestly don't remember what else we ordered, but I know it had noodles, garlic, and beef and it was really good as well. 

If you like garlic and asian food, I would recommend this place
author: Garrick F.

description:
I read about this place awhile back and heard good things. It's a very quaint little restaurant that looks like you're inside of a tiny vietnamese village on the inside. They had the regular menu items that you would see if you put a Thai/Indonesian/Vietnamese cafe together. I ordered the beef pho and shrimp spring roll. The sauce for the spring roll could have used a little more sweet soy sauce, and the beef pho could have used less white pepper.

The place itself was cute. It was a nice tucked away place off the Haight that you could bring a friend to lunch for and not have to overhear everyone's conversations around you. I would go again if I wanted a somewhat americanized version of asian fast food.
author: cynthia b.

description:
I'm so stuffed, and it was so good--and cheap, considering the quality.

The beef in my Pho was great quality, the servings were huge but healthily filing, and the beer was nice and chilly.

The service was very overwhelmed but did their best. 

I'll definitely eat here again when I'm nearby or passing through.
author: Caroline C.

description:
I first thought, "Citrus Club, no way."  From the outside it looks like it would be a nudie club where the girls cover their who-has with pineapples and oranges.  However, it's not.

Once you set inside, it's really a cute place, I swear!  The menu is filled with noodle dishes and noodle soups.  I had cold noodles with Coconut Lime dressing (with Chicken).  It was delicious, especially when I added the hot sauce that is on every table.  My bosses looked delicious as well - and it was not his first time there. Portions are huge and prices are cheap.  Win Win Win. 

I will be going back... I only wish they delivered, how sweet would that be!  Now, go and get your self some noodles.

For the corkage fee go to www.SFCorkageFees.com
author: Brittney B.

description:
Nothing creates pure joy and happiness quite like a ginormous bowl of noodles on a cold day. Actually, fresh veggie spring rolls with delicious, delicious peanut sauce come pretty close. In fact, so do grilled tofu skewers with barbeque sauce and yet another amazingly yummy peanut sauce that is different from the aforementioned peanut sauce. Vegan kids, you know that Asian food is your friend, I don't have to tell you that, but it's hard to sift through all of the many, many Asian restos in the city to find those that are worth a trip out of your neighborhood. 

The Citrus Club is definitely worth it! There are 3 or 4 different vegetarian noodle bowls that are tasty and enough to feed an army or one very very hungry vegan. The appetizers are stellar. I have really high standards for spring rolls and these had a nice selection of good veggies and the peanut sauce was the perfect balance of savory and sweet. The tofu skewers were crispy and meaty and very satisfying. Be sure to get these! Also, I didn't try any of them but the cold noodles sound good too, and there were a few veggie selections. Basically, this place is totally worth a trip up to the Haight and the pain of ignoring Ploy II upstairs and Kan Zaman across the street!
author: Jeani H.

description:
I would give this place 3.5 stars.
Round a half a point up because although its a tight fit, its usually a happy, lively tight fit.
Large portions, bold flavors, inexpensive.
I've been here about 5 times, including last night.
Food is always consistent.
Service is always prompt.
Round a half a point down because although service is prompt,
"robotic" best describes its personality.
Its ok.  Sometimes good company and a bottle of Nigori is all the personality we need!
author: Barry A.

description: Went in last night around 8:15PM to have some tom kah soup with chicken and some tea.  Woke up this morning at 4AM with severe stomach cramps and explosive diarrhea.    I've had diarrhea and vomiting for 7 hours on and off in 30 minute intervals.  I will never eat here again.
author: David C.

description:
I used to like the citrus club ALOT, the food was different and tasty. However, one time i ordered a coconut vietnamese noodle dish and got sick. Maybe it was because my stomach couldnt stomach the oodles of noodles dripping with yummy coconut milk. But yeah, totally got sick for a day from eating that. 

I would give it a try, prices are affordable, staff friendly, and you can see them cooking-always a plus for me!
author: Amy S.

description:
As my friends from the East Bay would say, Citrus Club is DA BOMMB! 

I have been going to CC for 10 years now and have always ordered the same wonderful dishes consistently: garlic edamame, tofu and string bean appetizer, and the garlic beef and shitake bowl.  Not only have I ordered consistently but the food has always been consistent. Good good good.  AND INEXPENSIVE.

Drawbacks: 
-  usually a 15 minute or more wait during the evenings (but only because they don't take reservations and they are sooo fucking good) 
- the wait staff is usually pretty crappy except the one (thai?) girl who has worked there for as long as I've gone
- they are playing the same Chill Out CD they have been playing for 10 years.

And if those are the only drawbacks then how can you go wrong? Unless you found a cockroach in your food. Which I never have.

There's nothing like stuffing your face with the Garlic Beef Shitake noodle bowl and then immediately rolling over on the bed (because it's soo good you have to eat it in bed), and going "ooohhhhh i'm soooo fuuuullllll"
author: Jerkey J.

description: The best freakin edamame I've ever had! Oh my lord. Think garlic fries at a baseball game, but with edamame instead. Apparently they're well-known for it. My noodle dish was pretty tasty & prices are cheap.
author: K M.

description:
Had the cold soba noodles with a lime coconut dressing on a rare hot SF day and it was so good!

The chicken satay was as boring as most chicken satays.

Service at the bar was friendly and prompt.
author: t w.

description: Large portions, cool atmosphere, long wait usually.  I'd rate this an above-average eating experience, and a little bit classier than other joints you'd find on Haight (though it's on par with Alembic, which is just across the street).  Last time I went I put my name on both waiting lists and chose the one that seated me first.  Make the restaurants work for your dollar, honey.
author: Bill H.

description:
It's borderline ghetto in here.... if you've visited the bathroom, you've definitely crossed the line. But, decor and atmosphere aside (c'mon, you're in the Haight) the place serves good noodles and if you're here that's probably why you made the visit.

Had another satisfying lunch here of chicken and spinach eggdrop noodle soup and stir fried veggies with tofu. Totally comforting. They have a wide selection of noodle dishes- no frills, straight forward. And starters and sides like vietnamese spring rolls with peanut sauce

Perfect way to end a long day of shopping or just if you're in the mood for some noodles and soup!
author: Nina H.

description:
Delicious delicious food!  Also very cheap.  Their pad thai is amazing....not like any typical pad thai you've ever had. The portions are big enough for two meals.  The only complaint I have (besides the wait, but it's small and can't be helped) is that the tables are a little too close together...again, probably because of the size of the restaurant.  
Try the tom kha. Yummy!
author: Bharu J.

description:
Came here with some friends. Atmosphere is nice and not too over crowded although I can see the place being packed evenings/weekends. 

Spring rolls are fresh but I think I liked the deepfried viritle better.

The Coconut milk soba noodle salad is soooooo good. I  recommend it. I am not in the mood to explain food but I can tell you it was damn good!
author: Sarah D.

description:
Love me some Citrus Club! I come here almost every time I visit San Francisco. Why? Well...

-They're ALWAYS good. The menu never changes, their prices stay low and their portions stay BIG. 

-Intimate seating, noodles galore and giant bowls of pho. Not the most authentic pho. but it'll do in a pinch. The Garlic edamame is a must!

-The bathroom sink. Yes, the sink. It's a germaphobe's dream! It sits outside of the actual bathroom hidden behind a beaded curtain, so you don't have to touch any knobs after you've washed your hands and it's accessible even if the toilet is occupied. I LOVE this.

If you're looking for good, cheap eats in the upper Haight area, check them out.
author: Dinah O.

description:
I really like the Citrus Club.  I live around the corner though.  I don't think I would be giving it 4 stars if it weren't for this fact.  If I lived anywhere else I would give this place 3 stars.  
But here's the thing.  My neighborhood is just not the most "grown up" of the hoods in SF.  We don't really have a whole lot of places to go have a fun sake drink with some friends and throw down some tasty Asian-ish noodle dishes (it isn't the most authentic noodle joint!).  So, they get points for giving my living space some variety.  
That being said, the food is not bad at all.  The noodles are great, it is not greasy, and it is cheap!  If you are up in my neck of the woods this is not a bad place to stop by for food and drinks.  (Though be careful because it can be crowded).
author: Blake W.

description:
DAG YO!
This place is muy yummmers.
I love the hot and sour soup. The House Garlic Edamame is very yummy.
They have cider there and some tasty saketinis.
Great place to cure a hangover.
author: Amanda M.

description:
I can't decide between 2 stars and 3 stars.  So 2 1/2......NOPE, after writing my review....2 STARS!!!!!

The food was mediocre.  Had the spring rolls which were okay.  The peanut sauce was pretty tasty but Osha Thai has a much more superior peanut sauce.  

My sister and I split the Yellow Cocunut Curry Tofu and Nuts and the Peanut Noodles.  The Peanut Noodles were good, but neither my sister nor I were fond of the Yellow Coconut Curry.  We had a few bites and returned it to the waitress.

Service was slow.  The waitress took forever to give us the check and never came back for it.  We tried to pay the cashier, but were ignored.  All in all, I don't think I will come back here for a long time, if ever.
author: Christina S.

description:
YUM!!

Citrus serves up delicious variations of your traditional noodle and soup dishes for a VERY fair price.  

Pros:
-Cool ambiance: low mood lighting, interesting art, dark walls, lots of wood, great array of low key electronic music in the background.
-Large portions (esp the soup!)
-Fairly cheap!
-Quick service.
-Never have to wait too long.
-Take out tastes just as good.

Cons:
-It's a little cramped inside.
-Weekend, dinner-time line can be a little long.
-Parking around the Haight can be a pain.
author: Ryan T.

description:
Love the visual atmosphere, especially sitting at the bar.  

Highly recommended:  
Bok Choy with Shiitake Mushrooms and Garlic (the sauce has star anise in it and it is To Die For!!!)

Hot & Sour Soup with Tofu - the bowl is MASSIVE and usually makes for 2 meals.  I've only managed to finish it in one sitting twice and I've probably been here at least 20 times...  Perfectly done veggies, tofu is deliciously chewy and the salty, spicy broth has the perfect amount of that amazing red oil slick on top (required in all Hot & Sour soup, as far as I'm concerned).  Delicious!
 

Highly Disappointing:
Sometimes the service is just incredibly bad.  You can be the most easygoing custie in the whole world and still get massive attitude.  I can understand some grouchy-ness during a busy dinner service, but during a mellow/quiet week day lunch I think it's totally unacceptable.  

I avoid going here at night or on weekends - too crazy busy and the place is so small that you wind up feeling like cattle pressed up against the wall and totally in the way of both servers and custies.
author: Karoline C.

description:
