When I got my first glimpse of the soup bowls my immediate response was "That is the size of a dog bowl!"  I am just as fond of leftovers as the next girl, but damn those servings are huge.  One bowl of noodles or soup could easily be split between 2-4 people.  With servings that large, it makes me sad to think of the amount of food that is wasted because people can't eat that much in one sitting and don't want to be carrying around a box of food for the remainder of the night.  

That being said the prices are good and you will get enough food for at least two meals.  The food itself is ok, but not great.  

I have never been by when there is not a line going out the door.  So get in line when you are willing to wait at least 15 minutes before getting seated.
author: Amy M.

description:
I am here (or take away) once a week its my go to spot in the hood.  On a cold and rainy day there is nothing better than he Pho-Ga (Spicy basil chili chicken soup).

Must try the House garlic edamame and the spring rolls are the best in the city.  I think I have had everything on the menu and the portions are very generous.

It gets busy but worth the wait.  The only bad spot is eating at the bar next to the door on a cold night but if you are hungry and its the only seat in the place sit there.
author: G R.

description:
The citrus club.

A good place to take friends to catch up over a bite to eat. A great place for a healthy crisp fresh salad. A great place to stuff yourself with creamy bowls of delicious carb packed noodles. A good place to get some bang for your buck.

Not a good place to come looking for culinary excellence, subtlety or sunlight. Seriously people. If you have seasonal affective disorder... This is not your place.

The atmosphere is sort of a cross between what I imagine an opium den might have been like in the early part of the century, and a tea room... But more modern. It's a very small place, and to get tot he dining room, you have to walk by the kitchen, which is behind a bar, much like those little to go chinese places. It has one small window, and I remember there being a lot of red... I don't remember whether that was because there was a red light, or red walls, or red paper lanterns or what... but there was an essence of red about the place. In a nice way. 

I had forgotten that I actually like this little place. Usually when I order a small salad, I expect to get a little plate or bowl of greens. This was a HUGE bowl STUFFED with freshly chopped greens with fresh cut, uncooked mushrooms carrots peas, and a a tangy citrusey dressing. I couldn't even finish it! 

My boyfriend got some sort of creamy prawn noodle dish, which was delicious. A little carb heavy for me, but not unexpectedly so. Definitely something I could order when I'm in a different mood.

It may not have blown away my inner gourmet, but I was certainly happy when I left. I had a belly full of bright healthy food, and an imperceptible dent in my wallet.
author: Mindy L.

description:
Kind of a strange long skinny set up with a bar as you go in and then a little room in the back.

Its cool. I always wonder about places with the chopsticks just sitting there in what amounts to a vase. Seems a noodle house thing. I was sitting in there eating with my chopsticks and looked across the room to a woman jovially talking to her friend while stroking and playing with all the chopsticks in the vase on her table. Made me really think twice about continuing my meal.

I just ask for a fresh pair or a fork now.

Really like the food. Its kind of loud, not the kind of place you want to go to have a heart to heart conversation.
author: Marz W.

description:
I really don't like waiting in lines when I'm hungry.  And this place will *make you wait* and keep you a little anxious that you might have missed your name being called amid the deafening din of the space.  Come to think of it, maybe this is a deliberate tactic to get you to order multiple sake martinis once you finally sit down... The line seems to go faster if you have get there early (before 8) and/or have a small party - each time I've been, I've noticed two people go way faster than 3-4. One person who'll sit at the bar will have hardly any wait.

However: delicious, veggie-friendly, cheap, quick, and unique fusion-y food makes it worth it in the end, and makes your out of town guests who just waited with you outside in the freezing fog for an hour see what the fuss was all about and thank you profusely for dragging them out there.

I especially like the veggie spring rolls and the cranberry saketinis which I compulsively order every time.  My fave noodle dishes are the marmalade jade noodles with coconut shrimp (for which they will sub tofu, both are good), and the garlic noodles/shiitake mushrooms with either beef or shrimp (and which I've only had with tofu).  I really did not like the Pad Thai or the peanut noodles, and the yellow curry tofu was meh.

So maybe it's hit or miss with the noodle dishes, you have to yell to be heard across the table, and there aren't a lot of great tables for groups in the place - groups of 3+ get to sit by the bus-room, bathroom, or at the humongous round table in the middle... well, I guess it must be either the crack in the peanut sauce or the saketinis that keep me hungry and ready to come back.
author: Laura T.

description:
When I heard about the SF Department of Public Health publishing their food safety inspection scores online, guess which place I searched for first? Yup. And guess how they scored? 

71 percent. 

Doesn't sound too horrible because it's still technically a pass right? Well let me help put things into a little perspective: you know that Civic Center Burger King on Market & 8th that caters mainly to the homeless  and cracked out denizens of  the SOMA/TL neighborhoods? That one scored a 99. The Citrus Club, by contrast, was guilty of various health code violations including (but not limited to): failure to maintain cleanliness, deterioration of unapproved materials (??), improper cleaning, and sanitization issues relating to "multi-use consumer utensils". Eew, right? 

Not really! The Citrus Club is possibly one of my most favorite restaurants ever; the "Mommy Soup" is by far the best noodle bowl and it's dirt cheap for what you get, which is like, a gallon of broth and a clump of rice noodles the size of your head. See?
author: Jenn W.

description:
3.5 stars, if possible.
Ah the Citrus Club.  Giant steaming bowls of noodle soup.  Sake drinks.  Lots of pretty good memories.  But the more I think about it the less I can recall any memorable meals.  I mean, the food's not bad.  Good, actually.  But not that memorable.  It is served in elephant portions, so the value is excellent.  Often I'm in a noodle soup kind of mood and in those cases Citrus Club doesn't disappoint.  They have a pretty good wonton soup that will feed you for dinner and lunch tomorrow.  Some of the noodle dishes are pretty bland though.  I usually end up  adding half the pot of hot sauce to get it to taste like something.  For what you get the prices are really reasonable.  

I guess the real criticism of this place is the service.  Even though the food ranges from mediocre to quite tasty (but nothing special), the place is almost always packed to the gills on weekends and most weeknights.  Why people choose to wait for an hour to eat here is beyond me.  The food is worth snaggng the two last bar stools, but not worth waiting for.  I haven't had problems with rude service exactly, just inattentiveness.
author: Mags P.

description:
Its definitely not worth the wait for dinner, or going out of your way to go there, but if you're in the Haight at lunch time its worth the few bucks for a big bowl of yummy noodles at the bar and a fresh juice martini-concoction.  And the inevitable Bjork playing over the loudspeakers.  

Really, though;  I'm not sure I've ever been there and *not* heard Bjork playing.  Thats a whole lot of noodles and Bjork.   Yummy noodles and Bjork, but Bjork nonetheless.  Can I stress that some more, please?  

You end up pouring Bjork in your broth like hoi-sin sauce;  kinda sweet, kinda salty, and all of a sudden you're trying to hold your chopsticks like you would if you were in Iceland (if they used chopsticks in Iceland, but why wouldn't they? We of non-Asian-descent use chopsticks here), and you're floating around the ceiling amidst the eternal Christmas lights signing Joga or Human Behavior in a high, squeaky voice in between slurps of mediocre pho' or lemongrass noodles.  And,  if you have an appetizer Matthew Barney rushes in with a giant knife to chop more garlic for your wok tossed veggies.  What's better than that?
author: Nora B.

description:
To be fair:The atmosphere outside the place pretty much says that you will be trafficked into some slave ring if you step inside.

 It's dark looking and the kitchen is not a pleasing sight. (Also, for the longest time I thought the place was called Noodle House. Way to mislead me, awning bitch).

However, this place kicks ass.

When you actually DO get inside it looks like its been designed by an an African schizophrenic. The colors vary from dark, homey woods to blood reds and protruding angles. I'm not sure they marry well, and subconsciously I was a little uneven. 

But fuck that, onto the food:

The portions are gigantic. I got the Spicy Curry Tiger Shrimp and my co-diner got some sort of Lemon Chicken. The noodles in hers were great and had a sticky, thick, filling feel that worked good with the minimalist chicken. My curry plate was good except for the saddening lack of tiger shrimp in my dish. What the hell is with asian joints skimping my goddamn shrimp? There are few things I enjoy more than a plethora of shrimp.

Anyway, its inexpensive and you surely can take left-overs home so it's worth it. Service was okay, maybe a little slow for my taste. Anyway, I would give it 3.5 for good measure.

What the hell is asian fusion, anyway?
author: Jay C.

description:
This place blows ZAO's out of the water! If it wasn't for that annoying wait I would come here everyday! Garlic edemame, shrimp spring rolls, wok tossed noodles, I don't need anymore than that. And it comes with so much food!

It's a small and dark space, so it's very cramped. But the workers here sure know how to work around that; super speedy service and my water was refilled every 5mins. I was thirsty that night.
author: Deanna T.

description:
In the interest of full disclosure, I worked at the Citrus Club as a bartender for a year back in 2006.  To be honest, while the space is nice and cozy and the location is great, the food is totally mediocre.

I'm not sure if it's because the hipster wannabee's and hippies of the Haight can't afford anything better (that's ok because I was there once), but really, "The best soup in the city", "Edamame to die for'?

I once had a girl ask me if the chicken stock was vegan?  Seriously?

C'mon folks.  Sure it's cheap, but on a busy night I couldn't believe that folks would pack in the place and wait upwards of 45 minutes for an average bowl of soup or stir fry noodles.

If you're looking for a good cheap meal in that Haight, the Citrus Club fits the bill.  If you're looking for some good authentic Pho or Thai noodles head out to PPQ or Marnee Thai in The Sunset (Irving and 20's).
author: Mike T.

description:
Why do I always get the same thing when I am here? Because I know it will be good, Chicken Pho and fresh spring rolls with shrimp! I have tried a few other things and they were just A-OK, the pho is good and the service is friendly, and it is in my hood. You can eat here alone and sit at the bar, go on a date or with a small group of friends. There usually isn't much of a wait and they have a decent sake and beer menu.

There is better pho places in the city although the combo of location, drinks and atmosphere makes it a good place to get your asian noodle fix!
author: Bobby B.

description: Food was above average, my beef noodle soup came with an interesting broth that had hints of cinnamon. The serving sizes were large, which was certainly welcome. Service was very slow however, which was a shame. Nice ambiance, I especially liked what they did with their bathroom area. If I'm in the area I'll probably go back.
author: Casey U.

description:
The man firing up the wok in the window looked legit, but the food disappointed. Bar stools and tiny seating area made it look like a hole in the wall. Maybe it was what we ordered--some sort of chicken stir fry noodle dish. But I've had better in mall food courts, sorry Citrus Club. 
On the plus side, lots of vegetarian options, and watching the wok man prepare the chow fun looked like that was a better choice. I don't think there's much food stuffs to choose from on Haight Ashbury anyway, so what can you do, eh?
author: Jasmine O.

description: This is one of my favorite noodle places.  The hot and sour soup is therapy.  Every time i'm in SF, i have to come here within the first week
author: rahul c.

description: Truly can't beat the price here...the portions on the soups are enormous. My pet peeve about this place is that they don't chop the vegetables small enough. Because the vegetable pieces in the soups are so large, they can't really absorb much flavor. Fast service (lightning fast for takeout) mean this is a go-to place in the neighborhood.
author: Thom N.

description:
I've got to be honest with you all; good service at a noodle spot is hard to find.  Last night I met some really cool folks at a Bay to Breakers after-party and we ended up here.  I remember being shocked at how long the wait was, but I soon realized that most wise drunk people share the same sentiment; good noodles are worth the wait.

Just when I started contemplating why someone would have even named a noodle place "The Citrus Club", we ended up finding four stools at the bar which, by the way, had a bunch of great beers (including Sapporo!) on tap.  I remember the inside being kind of dim and red, and though it was kind noisy, none of us really had to raise our voices to hear each other.  The menu was comprised of a variety of noodle preparations from various Asian countries, which ranged from Pad Thai to Pho.  I ended up deciding on chow-mein (since it was my first time and chow-mein is like the Optimus Prime of noodles), and was thoroughly satisfied.  The portion was absolutely perfect, and the noodles were prepared just right with texture being very consistent.  It even had some generous chunks of mushroom!  During our experience, we consistently received friendly and fast service.  

The Citrus Club never claims to be anything it isn't (except for maybe a medicinal lemon and lime club), and delivers on all important aspects of noodle service.  I couldn't have asked for anything more from a place with such phenomenal prices.
author: Jordan R.

description:
This place is really cool!  Perfect place to take visitors from out of town.  Super fun low key atmosphere, great fresh tasty Asian noodle dishes.  Perfect for vegitareans, and meat eaters, very fairly priced, fast service considering how crowded the place can get.   

Put your name down and grab a drink at any of the bars in that hood, or belly up at the bar and drink a large cold Asahi.  This is probably the best restaurant in the upper haight, lots of variety, spicy, hot goodness.
author: Jon S.

description:
Some things are worth waiting for.  

Krispy Kreme, San Tung, Park Chow, and now Citrus Club.  

Why may you ask?

1.  Small intimate environment.  It's a small place.  It's not large and scary.  That said it's usually going to be pretty packed.  Go in, get a drink, and put your name on the list.  I had the Citrus Punch with Nigori and it was blended so well (yes blended fruity drink) that I didn't even taste the alcohol at all or notice it.  Hence my buzz 3 minutes later.  

2.  Huge portions.  If you are on a diet, you could maybe get one order and split it between 2-3 ways or take it home and eat 2-3 more meals depending on if you are a girl or guy.  Or you could pig out like we do and just not eat for days after.  (KIDDING!- kidding about the not eating, but not kidding about the pigging out part!)  

3.  Despite huge portions, you have CHEAP and reasonable prices.  When you are in a tough economy like we are, this is key.  When I say reasonable and cheap, we're talking about appetizers that run from $4.95 to $6.95 and huge noodle dishes running from $10.  (BTW, remember that $10 goes for 3 meals)  

4.  Carb lovers paradise.  Can we say NOODLES?

5.  Variety- ranging from the starters and bar snacks ( satay, tofu, stir fries, soba, spring rolls, soups, salads, edaname) to the soups and noodles (pad thai, chow mein, peanut noodles, shrimp) and the grilled stuff like short ribs, anyone loving Asian cuisine and noodles will be happy!  

One thing that wasn't the highlight for me: the garlic noodles that came with the short ribs: weren't garlickly at all.  Maybe because I was mentally comparing to PPQ garlic noodles, or maybe because I couldn't taste even a BITE of garlic, but they were a huge let down.  Once I got over the lack of garlic flavor though, as noodles themselves they were okay.  

Service is quick, and the wait really is not that bad if you get a drink.  Drinks make everything seem to go by faster, don't you think?
author: Denise B.

description:
I will definitely be back here!

Went for a dinner with friends last night.  

We all shared bites of everything, and everything was just really good & flavorful.  Huge portions, particularly for the price.  Will SO be back here again!
author: Buffy M.

description:
Citrus Club combines the ambiance of an elegant, candle-lit club with the food and prices of a small neighborhood noodle place. I loved the signature Garlic Edamame, a heavy garlic oily extravaganza. I recommend pairing this with a lighter entree, which I didn't do. Post-dinner fatigue aside, the Shangai Noodles were also delicious, dripping with dark, thick sweet sauce. 

Be prepared to attract a lot of attention if you plan to later walk down Haight carrying your leftovers in a box...
author: Lisa C.

description:
Me likey the noodle!!  Me likey the counter!!  Me likey the Tsingtao!! 

 Me no likey waiting!!  Me no likey slow service!!  Me no likey tight spaces!!
author: Maz N.

description:
I *finally* tried this place at long last, after many enthused raves from friends.  With a name like Citrus Club, I had my doubts.  They were not totally unfounded.

The ambiance: 
Dark, cozy and full of sumptuous smells.

The wait:
Pretty reasonable, maybe 10 minutes for 4 folks on a Monday.

The appetizers: 
Great garlic edamame and totally yummy coconut cream/mint noodles.  Fair-to-middlin' bbq tofu rolls.

The entrees: 
I asked for my pad thai "really, really hot".  It was not at all spicy.  I usually don't get pad thai at restaurants- my personal version is just too damn good, but my pal said this was the BEST he'd ever had.

It was totally uninspired, and seemed to have been kissed with the barest hint of chilies- not the "incendiary rain of searing death-lava" I'd explicitly begged for.  My girlfriend wasn't too into her sweet chili tofu, but our friends seemed to dig their stuff.

The portions:
Huge.

The service:
Generally snappy and friendly.

Wilst I returneth?
Probably- it's a decent inexpensive place to catch dinner in the upper haight, which is generally a bit of a culinary desert, especially at night.  

I'm not going to have the cold night sweats dreaming about this place, or anything, though.  I'll probably just make this sh*t at home.
author: George C.

description:
Located in the quirky and hippy Haight, how can one ever hate Citrus Club?  It's a lil notch up from a totally  hole in the wall joint, but  has the tastiest noodles around the hood!  This Thai & Vietnamese fusion has some really great cheap eats with spunky flavors.

The place is small (located right across Kan Zaman), and is not the best place for large groups, but if you get there early enough before prime rush hours (lunch, dinner, etc.), you can secure a table without a horrendous wait.  

We ordered the Vietnamese spring rolls for appetizers, which were delicious and accompanied with sweet peanut sauce.  Hot sake is also quite pretty tasty and strong! For the main course, I tried the spicy yellow curry with peanuts over rice noodles, which was fabulous!  The portions are huge and tasty.   The service is ok too, but go here for the experience of some delish fusion food.  And for dessert, we had the fried bananas with coconut ice cream.  The latter was particularly striking because of the small coconut bits interspersed in the cream!
author: Megha S.

description:
I'm not exactly an Asian cuisine expert, but the food here is simply excellent.  I've had my share of pho, pad thai, spring rolls, and other dishes, and Citrus Club made each of these items in accordance with the highest standards.

I'm going to pass on rating the price-range of this restaurant, because whatever the prices were, I completely forgot.  My visits to the restaurant involved me picking out dishes from the menu without too much regard for the price.  At Citrus Club, you get more than you pay for.

Also has a wonderful atmosphere, good decor, pleasant lighting, and all the ingredients are very very fresh.

Highly recommended if you're over in the Haight/Stanyan area.
author: Alexi A.

description: i heard that you will wait in a huge line to get in at night, so we've eaten here after the lunch time crowds. HUGE portions, seriously, but the bf looves the heaping delicious bowls of noodle with the side plate delivered of fresh basil leaves, jalapeno peppers slices, and more!, try the shiitake app (yum) and i usually enjoy one of the specials, grilled beef and veg. and sometimes the service is slow, so come relaxed and ready to be full. work off the amount you just stuffed into your belly by enjoying haight street.
author: Abigail W.

description:
Good good!!!!  I love the Shanghai noodles and the Thai coconut soup. The garlic edamami is pretty good too. I tried almost everything in the menu, most of the options are very good. Had some bad experiences with some boring dishes like the peanut noodles, but they have a great variety in their menu. The price is excellent and a lot of the meals are very big, enough for two if you don't have a big appetite. The waiting was never too long, except when I went to celebrate my husband's birthday with another 6 people. Btw, they charge 15 bucks if you take your on cake, which I thought it was kind of a bummer. But oh well, they have a dessert menu and ended up washing more dishes so I guess it is fair??
I just don't give it a 5 because the waitresses are not that nice, they can be a bit moody sometimes. 
It is fun to watch the cooks while you wait in the bar area....
author: Fabiana H.

description:
I love this  place. I think it is the best on the haight and I will purposely go here just b/c. 

Best Beef chow fun noodles on the planet.
a bit crowded space and sometimes loud...but that's to help the workers cook faster.
author: shanestar h.

description:
I ate here about 2 weeks ago and I'm still thinking about it. Seriously. 
This place is a dream...a happy place...the kind of place that when you leave you want to kiss the cooks then light up a cigarette. 

This noodlehouse is really some of the best grub I've ever had. The soups are phenomenal. All of them. The portions are so large you have leftovers for the next 2 meals. And it'll cost you less than $10.  My friend had the Marmalade Coconut & Lemongrass Jade Noodles. I tasted it and had to stop myself from moaning inappropriately. Holy Christ. It was like velvet in my mouth. Hot and steamy and beautiful. Like butta. And the cocktails are delish and only $5. You can't go wrong. Oh god! I almost forgot to tell you about the spring rolls. I've had a lot of spring rolls in my day and these, by FAR, are the most exciting. YUM

Yes its busy and loud and it might take a while to get a seat but just chill the fuck out and wait. Have a cocktail. Its worth every minute. I went there with 8 people and the service was really good. She even split the bill for us.
author: Krystal B.

description:
Well Friday night and maybe on a date... or not who knows, I ask "-----" any good places to eat at Haight.

Citrus Club!

Well sure, its a place i can review, so lets go for it!

Off the bat, the place is PACKED, this was around 9PM... 
- we waited maybe for 30 min, and just ended up sitting at the bar, which wasn't so bad, except that we would get a gust of cold air every time the door was opened.
- The waiter was swamped, but still friendly and attentive, so hey it's the thought that counts!
- The restaurant had a mid- 20 to early 30 crowd, and was loud as hell!
The Food:
- I had the Shrimp and Shitake noodle bowl and the lady had a citrus salad, both were REALLY good, which was surprising, seeing how damn cheap this place is.
- The Sake blew, but we drank it anyway
- Oddly enough, we mixed both the salad and noodles together, and it tasted pretty good.... 
[side note] one of the cooks dropped the chopsticks he was cooking with, and KEPT USING THEM!!!! this was after we got our food... but damn....

Hey food was cheap, and good. Not the nicest place to take a date.... or whatever you call it, but for good food, it isn't too bad
author: Kelvin M.

description:
The reviews are true. The basic entrees are not so awesome. You can get a better stirfry with noodles or pad thai at any number of "authentic" restaurants. 

The hot-sour soup on the other hand... incredible.

Gigantic. Hot. Sour. Salty and delicious. Chock full of soft but never overcooked veggies. Loads of tender rice noodles.

It makes my nose run, my eyes water, and my stomach scream HALLELUJAH.

And the surest cure for a hangover I have ever met.
author: Erica H.

description:
Stopped by this place after a book signing when the fog was rolling in and the temperatures dropped to a misty cold.

The restaurant is dark and rather narrow, but opens up in the back.  We were seated relatively quickly at the bar (two of us, 7:30pm, Thursday) and were given our utensils, menus and two glasses of water.  So far so good.

We ordered the standard Vegetable Noodle Soup (which thankfully was made with a vegetable broth) and the Thai Curry Tofu Noodle Soup.  The bowls were very large.  The amount of noodles in each bowl also equated to about two orders of pho.  The soup for each felt clean, non-oily and the flavors were fresh.  We couldn't finish either one so we brought it home for a full lunch the next day.  Needless to say, the portions were generous.  We also ordered a large bottle of hot sake.

They played The Postal Service CD the whole time.

It was a wonderful experience and would definitely go back.  The price was right, the taste was great and it was a fine dining experience.  The place is a little too tight and dark for my liking, but that surely shouldn't take away from the food itself.
author: Alexander S.

description:
Update - Decided to give this place one more try, just in case. Still sucks for all the reasons noted below.

------

People who think of this as great Asian food probably haven't ever had truly great Asian food. Roll over to Clement Street for noodles - Pho Hoa Clement, King of Thai, Spices, and Taiwan Restaurant all do noodles 1000 times better for just as cheap.

Honestly, I have no words to express the level of blandess here. The dishes (spring roll, salad, noodle dish) weren't just lacking in flavor - they were a flavor black hole.

Oh, the irony that the only thing in our order that should have been delicately flavored, miso soup, was so salty that it made my tongue shrivel like a raisin. Really, how do you f*ck up miso soup?
author: Cate C.

description:
Pretty much what everyone else here has said:

1)  It's Cheap.
2)  It's good.

It should be noted that there are quite a few options for the vegetarians in your life.

The portions are *HUGE*.  I have only eaten my entire dish once, and while I'm not a fatty, I can pack the food away when presented with something tasty.  I really like the Garlic Beef with Shitake Mushrooms.  I mean, doesn't that just *sound* good?  It is, try it.

I have never had a problem with the service.  As a matter of fact, my food has always arrived quickly, and with a smile.
author: J. B.

description:
Pan Asian noodle joint that offers spring rolls, pho, soba, noodle salads, wok tossed noodles, tea, sake, beer, mixed drinks and more.  In other words, there are plenty of choices if you like noodles and alcohol on the side.  Nothing you get will be "authentic" but it will be reasonably good.

I've eaten here several times and the food is fresh and the portions are just right.  I wouldn't say anything was really spectacular but it is a good place to go to hang out with friends who don't appreciate the dumpy authentic noodle joints and want a reasonably priced fresh meal ($6 to 8 for a noodle entre).  Reminds me of King of Thai Noodle (with the open kitchen) with less personality. 

The atmosphere is cozy and inviting. Dimly lit.  It can be noisy because the tables are close together.  It looks much better on the inside than it does from the outside.
author: Lolia S.

description:
I was introduced to this place by a friend as a "great Thai restaurant", so my inital reaction to it was similar to the reaction I had when someone took me to Chipotle for the first time because it was "the best Mexican food ever". So, a little confused, and a little disappointed.

Time has passed since then, and I now work on the street. I decided to give it another try recently, and had the cold coconut lime soba noodles. Pretty good. Not mind blowing, but pretty good. A few more weeks passed, and then San Francisco turned into an OVEN. Cold noodles sounded like the only edible thing, so I ordered the Zaru Soba. THAT was delicious! Cold soba noodles, tofu, and wasabi with a bit of wakame salad on top and some soy dipping sauce. The best part was that it was only about $4. 

Citrus Club has won me over. But to those of you expecting cut and dry Thai, Japanese, Vietnamese, etc. food....you're not going to get it.
author: Vanessa R.

description:
Yum! I had veggie soup with the clear broth and my friend had shrimp wonton soup with a coconut broth. Both were delicious! We also shared the Vietnamese spring roles. They had lovely fresh mint and the peanut sauce was quite good. 
Inexpensive, fast service, overall a good find!
author: Elsa E.

description: Very Tasty large portions of Asian food. I really like their wolk tossed stuff but their soups are also great. The food here is very clean and the staff is friendly.
author: Cody L.

description:
I was on a meatless kick last weekend so I decided to get the yellow curry, coconut tofu noodles. Maybe it was my day-long lack of meat, but half an hour later, I was hungry again!  I don't want to say it was because of the "Chinese" (read: Asian) food stereotype. I'm going to blame it on carbs.. yeah.. stop burning so fast carbs!

Don't get me wrong, despite the being hungry again, it was decent noodle dish and I actually like tofu a lot, but I think the dish would have been better with some beef or chicken. Even with the curry, the dish tasted a bit bland. It also lacked texture. The tofu was too soft, and I didn't even know it was there. 

In other news, I tried my friend's garlic noodles with beef, and I am totally going to get that next time!
author: Hue L.

description:
Holy crap, that shit is goooooooooooooooood. Good enough for me to brave the sea of dirty hippies on Haight.

I've been here twice and swapped plates both times so I've had the pleasure of trying five of their dishes. Lemme tell ya: The coconut curry tofu business and the spicy coconut lime chicken deal-io are good, but they PALE in comparison to the cold coconut lime buckwheat noodles, the garlic beef & shittake mushrooms and the shrimp of some variety with the spinach noodles. These last three are PHENOMENAL!

And don't miss the ginger tea. Even if you're not a big tea fan.
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
Never have I experienced such quality eats for mere pennies (okay, dollars, but dollars are the new pennies these days)!
Citrus Club is fabulous.  I am lucky to live within walking distance so I do frequent this spot for dine-in & take-out.  
It gets crowded during peak feeding hours, but if you have the time it's worth the wait, otherwise just get it to go.
Soups to die for & heal you when you're feeling under the weather... just try it!
author: Heather P.

description:
This place will satisfy my hunger for noodle soup.

Don't order the beef pho... it smells and taste like cinnamon and ya'll know that then they didn't put the star anise in the broth. 
Tom Ka is decent and big portioned... like whoa.

Gave my left overs to the bums outside... good deed for the day.
author: Anna S.

description: This is my favourite place to get a bowl of soup. I always over-order and I never regret the tasty leftovers for the following day. I think the soup I've had the past few times was a Thai coconut broth with prawns.
author: Stacey C.

description:
Pho Ga Chicken Noodle Soup to go - my tried and true cold remedy.  That gets 5 stars from me!

Cheap and delicious!
author: Chris P.

description: I come here at least once a week! That's how much I love it. I've tried every soup on the menu but love the shrimp wonton the best. It's simple and big enough for you to take home for lunch the next day. The garlic edamame is also insanely good. I recommend it over the reg. one.
author: Maria C.

description:
If there was a sixth star this place would get it.  Perfect little restaurant.  At the end of Haight so it can be a challenge to find parking unless you have good parking ju-ju like I do!
HUGE portions and lots of delicious choices. My vegetarian and meat-eating friends are always impressed by the menu. The vegetable hot/sour soup was made by gods and sent down to Citrus Club.  My favorite appetizers are the garlic edamame, BBQ tofu spring rolls and the soba with tofu. The wait staff can be a little off putting, but if you're going to a place for the company of the waiters try Gary Danko not here.  Usually they are fine and as long as you smile and act nice, they'll do the same.
The bar has seating but when the place gets crowded it can be a little tight with people waiting behind you eying your eats.  Stay back this grub is MINE!  Love Citrus Club.
author: Jasmine B.

description:
Good food, crowded, a festive place for a reasonably priced dinner. Would get five stars if the staff were nicer. 

Try the spring rolls, the edamame, and any of the noodles.
author: Cate F.

description:
Great spot for lunch or dinner.
I've had he Pat Thai (sp?) It's so good! and the portions are generous!
It's affordable and the service is pretty fast. 
The soup bowls are HUGE! The Thai Ice Tea is great too!
author: Michael F.

description:
***Edit Oct 7, 2011***
Oh Citrus Club, I feel sad typing this.  I've been eating at your restaurant faithfully since ~1999 and have had many memorable times there and with your take out.  However, the last few times I've been, in the past year, things have been less than your previous high standard.

Last night for example, I asked to take home my favorite hot & sour soup w/ tofu and was only given a small portion of what I had left in my bowl - what happened to my other half of soup?!  I think you only filled 1 takeout container when really, my leftover soup would have filled 2 containers.  The containers are smaller than they were 5 years ago. I was disappointed I did not get all the food I paid for, this after tipping 20%.  

Also, the back corner upstairs harbors flying bugs.....had to swat the bugs away constantly through our meal.  

Usually their takeout process is swift and efficient.  The last time I was there for pick up, it was 5pm on a weekday and empty.  While I waited in the front of the bar for 30 mins, my food was not ready.  I inquired and nothing.  Finally, I could see the kitchen forgot my order.  Ok, that can happen, but how did they miss the order from the one person standing right in front of them!  NOTE:  their takout portions seem less than their in house portions for the soup. 

Overall, the experience has declined.  

OLD REVIEW from 2006:
My comfort food!  I've been eating here since 1999 and nothing else satisfies me the way Citrus Club does. 

 When I was not working, I would come here at 2:00pm and sit by myself reading a book while working on a bowl of noodles for over an hour.  The waitresses got to recognize me and I started getting even faster service.  They are fast and not overly friendly, which is fine with me.

Now, I call for take out.  My fave:  Hot & Sour Tofu.  There is always a line, but take out takes only 10 mins!

Oh, don't ask for rice; they don't serve it.  It is a NOODLE house.  And don't expect it to be thai, or vietnemese, or chinese in cuisine only.  It is a blend of influences.  And it's cheap!
author: Yelper H.

description:
This place has a great vibe and the food is usually really good.

Last time I had the grilled ginger chicken and my friend had the beef pho. The chicken dish was AMAZING.. so tasty! The sauce was plentiful and perfect with the noodles and chicken, the chicken was cooked really well, the noodles were some of the best I've ever had, AND the portion was large. The beef pho was pretty good although it had kind of an interesting taste (maybe ginger?) and was not as good as other beef pho I've had in the city.

All in all, if you're on Haight and want a delicious meal, go to the citrus club!
author: Andrew H.

description: So I like the ambiance. The dim lighting is nice. But the noodles I tried were okay. I don't even remember what they were? But I do remember the Shanghai noodles being good. I was expecting a little bit more from this place, because I saw the "Zagat rated" stickers, but I should have not depended on that alone. Despite how I feel about the noodles, the garlic edadame is good! I really liked that! Such an addicting appetizer.
author: April D.

description: Citrus Club is my favorite noodle bar in the city.  I particularly like the Pho-Ha-Noi Beef Noodle Soup and Tom Ka-Thai Coconut Tofu Soup. The portions are very generous and I can never finish the whole bowl.  They use citrus extracts instead of cooking oil which doesn't make you feel bloated after the meal.  The lines can get a little long but it's certainly worth the wait.
author: George L.

description:
This place needs to get over itself.

The food used to be okay, but he woman behind the bar who takes your take away order should get a job that doesn't involve working with the public. 

She's ALWAYS rude, but last week was it. I will never eat there again. Not only did we get the usual rudeness over the phone, but then when we got there, she was even worse. Waiting, waiting for our order - finally I asked if it was ready. Got the whole neck thing and all - "uh, it's not ready yet" and turns her back to me. Waiting, waiting another 10 minutes. My husband went in and asked her if it was ready. Oh, whaddaya know - she never placed the order! All of a sudden she was all smiles and good service. They even gave us some free extra food. We got it home to eat it and it all sucked. My husbands dish was wrong and mine wasn't nearly as good as it usually is. And whatever they gave us to make up for the wait was inedible.

Never again. If the food rocks and the service sucks, that's one thing. But to have someone be flat out rude to you and the food suck, well, there's plenty more places in the Haight to eat. I'll just have to expand my knowledge of Ploy's menu when I want noodles.
author: Teri M.

description:
My now solidified go-to place for takeout soup.  Portions large enough for 2 - or two days. I'm a takeout creature of habit and these are the two CC soups I habitualize:
 
1.Tom Ka-Thai Coconut Tofu Soup -  totally yummy. I break the tofu into little pieces. Ask for NO CILANTRO if, like me you HATE that nasty little leaf.  Yes they add sugar or something sweet, but everyone does it.

2.Pho-Ga Chicken Noodle Soup - it will heal you when you are sick, or sad, or cold, or just hungry. Its so friggin' good with garlic, basil and bean sprouts. 

I just went elsewhere for #2 and was sorely disappointed. I will return to CC begging forgiveness and swearing allegiance.
author: tara s.

description: This place is only really passable in my opinion. The highlight of our meal was the satay sauce that came with the spring rolls - our mains (Pad Thai with shrimp and Cashew Chicken) were pretty average and felt like something you'd throw together at home if you were low on time and cash. Service was fine, but I wouldn't go back. If you do venture there I'd say go for one of the soups - they looked like they might be better.
author: Clare G G.

description: Good Thai, large portions and very fair prices. very good option for a night out with friends.
author: Gio S.

description:
I really don't get what's so great about their noodle dishes.

eh.

the good parts:
- garlic edamame. i willingly smell like garlic all day to eat this stuff. so addicting.
- sa choy vegetable noodle soup. use the hot red sauce (i'm not going to even try to butcher the spelling on the real name of it) for extra flavor.
- hot and sour vegetable noodle soup. good for clearing out the sinuses.
- tofu spring rolls with peanut sauce. delicious light snack.
- the cocktails. I had some orange margarita thing once and it tasted like it was made with fresh squeezed orange juice. yum!

when you call and order takeout 9 times out of 10 it's ready in a snap.  the staff is very friendly. watch out for special orders, i've had it messed up quite a few times.
author: Jb O.

description:
Ok, the pad thai does not have quite the traditional taste.  I ordered it expecting that traditional taste.  However, I was quite pleasantly surprised with their fresh take on the dish.  It was very good.

Slightly cramped, but very welcoming and cozy atmosphere.
author: Josh H.

description:
I would only recommend two dishes. The mixed veggies app and the garlic edamame. 
I was disappointed by the spicy lemon and coconut chicken noodles. If I had no idea of the ingredients I would never know what was in it. There was no absolutely no flavor. The garlic beef and shitake mushroom noodle dish (recommended my other yelpers) was greasy and the beef was dry and overcooked. 
There are too many other Asian restaurants to bother with this place.
author: Alex G.

description:
Fantastic Thai food. Best in San Fran so far! I went with a friend that was showing me around Haight and Ashbury. I was hungry for some vegetarian Thai food and this place hit the spot. It was a small intimate restaurant with a great earthy vibe.
 The pad thai was delicious and I also had a spicy vegtable soup. I love the side window view (it's a small view of the side of the buidling decending to lower levels) I'm big on window views while I'm eating.
Great food. Great service. Highly recommended!
author: Jasmin A.

description:
I get their" MAMA's CHICKEN SOUP" a few times a month.
If you like chicken soup..this is The Best in S.F.,....a nice clean soup,shredded white meat chicken,fresh basil on the side to add, thin noodles, fresh bean sprouts....
To Go is prompt, and for there, the service is friendly, helpfull..and the price is right. A Plus in S.F.
author: jesse r.

description:
It's cheap and the portions are big! 

I ordered the shrimp wonton and rice noodles in coconut soup. Although the wontons were sparse and it was cabbage overkill, the soup made up for it. It was creamy, milky, and overall, was really filling. It's perfect for a cold or rainy day! The bowl is huge. I would recommend this dish to share between two people. The fresh spring rolls were just okay --- the sauce wasn't as peanuty as I like. I would skip this and try one of their tasty cold noodle salads for an appetizer.  

The place is small, so I would expect a wait during lunch and dinner hours.
author: Kat M.

description:
For some reason the song "I want candy" from the '80s just popped in my head---delete "candy" and insert "noodles." 

Mmmm noodles. 

I'm a big pho phan, and Asian food fan in general. So, when my friend Emily suggested this place, I got excited---I'm new to the Bay Area and love trying new restaurants. Plus, I love the Haight so ya.

I had the beef pho, my bf had a mixed veggie noodle soup, Em had the tom kah, and her bf had pad Thai, I think. 

The wait was rather long, the service was slow, and collectively our food was just OK, not fantastic, not horrible--a solid C+/B- (however the place gets a 98% for cleansliness according to the Department of Health--so at least I know I didn't eat any rats or cockroaches). 

Interestingly, this place is Zagat rated--maybe that's because they have Optimator on tap---which is pretty damn awesome in itself. Plus, the aroma when you walk in the door is fantastic--as is the 98% health rating, but I already mentioned that. 

I'm gonna stick to other places for my pho, but I'll probably end up eating here again after a trip to Amoeba records across the street.
author: Liana V.

description:
Since I work on Haight St., I am always looking for a restaurant that will get me a quick, filling portion that isn't overly expensive. I can eat Asian food just about every day of the week, so Citrus Club ended up being a hit for me. The portions of the noodles are more than enough, the to-go box of peanut noodles I ordered had to weigh nearly a pound. The chefs make Viet Spring Rolls (cold ones) when it is slow, so they are a really fast option if you're pressed for time like I usually am. The menu is not very large but offers a variety of appetizers, soups, and noodles.

The service is a bit sluggish at times, but being assertive can always fix that. If you're shopping the street and want a fair priced meal, definitely take a look at their menu. :)
author: Taylor S.

description:
Ooh OOh, my turn!  I love this place.  Let's not lie, Caitlin struggles to get out of the Marina.  FiDi/Soma for work, Marina for play.  Shut up yelpers, you wish you could live where I live, show the Marina some love.  Anyway, I don't eat in the Haight much, but this place is worth a trip.  Every entree is HUGE and AWESOME.  It's one of those places where even when you don't think you can eat anymore, you still do because it's so good.  I had some sort of noodles and some kickass edamame that was flavored with chili or something.

I like the atmosphere, kinda dark and sketchy, but in a good way.  Really.  There are REALLY interesting people that come in here, like people in costume.  Or with florescent hair.  I live in the Marina, but I can still appreciate some sweet neon green hair!
author: Caitlin D.

description:
I tend to come here for lunch... Alot. It's cheap and near my house. 
I almost always get the same shitake beef, and whaterver garlic-sauce veggie and tofu they have on special. 
Everytime I've tried something new (cold noodles, or noodle soup) Thay have both been very bland. 
I'll stick with my usual.
Oh yeah. I gave an extra star for the Tamarind candies. Yum!
author: Karlee D.

description:
What's in a name? Citrus club- it sounds like you could go a couple ways with it. Cheesy Miami beach trance-athon like its 99? Maybe. Jamba Juice knockoff (shoutout to those who remember juice club- hollah for Cupertino!)? I could see it. Or maybe even a super elite club where only the elite Mandarin Oranges of the world go to see and be seen (this ain't no OrangeJulius- yeah, you navels will have to slum it down the street....)

But Citrus Club the pan Asian noodle house? Not my first guess but damn, it works. From the outside, it definitely looks a bit rough around the edges, but inside its nice. The food is defiantly pan-Asian (minus the blandification that seems to come with this food class). Hungry for pho? They got it. Shanghai style noodles? hell yeah, hook me up. Thai satay- pho' sho.

Its got it all, plus some seriously huge portion sizes for such low cost meals (entrees at 6 buckos, in SF? seriously). 

Oh, and as other reviewers mentioned, they keep those water glasses so full, you think they were draining hech hechie reservoir by themselves.....I loves it.
author: Tim V.

description:
1. The worst service EVER.
2. The worst service of my life.
3. Horrible service.

A good restaurant is great food, great service, and a great atmosphere. Well, the Citrus Club had the atmosphere down, has decent food, and horrible service. Thus, the reason for a 2 star. 

I ordered the BBQ tofu spring roll. After eying the spring rolls when I waked in I immediately craved one! I was really excited for BBQ tofu to add some flavor. My friends ordered the Pad-Tai and the Spicy Lemon & Coconut Chicken. 

First I don't even want to get into how bad the service was, but all I can say is you can REALLY tell when someone hates their job. And our waitress, hates her job. 

When we finally got our food (after we thought we were forgotten about) we were definitely disappointed. The Pad-Tai didn't taste like Pad-tai, I didn't personally taste it, but my friend was disappointed. My friend's order of Spicy Lemon and Coconut Chicken didn't really have a lemon or coconut flavor, but more of a creamy chicken noodle dish. And unfortunately my spring rolls had no BBQ taste at all. I had to cover them in dipping sauce. 

OVERALL: I don't think I'll ever come back here unless all I am ordering is a Tai Iced Tea. 

-Service Sucks
-Food is edible, but not what you'd expect having the restaurant named "CITRUS club" not any citrus twist or flavor what so-ever. 
-ambiance is cute.
author: Sarah T.

description: A quality place in the Haight where you can have a great time eating Asian influenced hipster cuisine. Although none of the dishes are truly authentic, I seem to enjoy ever one of the ten+ times that I've eaten here. It is good for groups and friends and the wait never seems to be too long. I wouldn't drive across town to eat here, but next time you are in the Haight, check this place out. And a high-five if you can guess the flavor of the candies they pass out with the bill.
author: Brian J.

description:
Food was good but not great - my yellow coconut curry was a bit bland.  Portions are very large - neither me or my friend were able to finish our entrees.

This place really wins because of it's great service, inexpensive prices (only $21 for two entrees and an order of spring rolls), and proximity to Amoeba.
author: Tessa M.

description:
Dearest Sweet Baby Jesus,

Though the exterior is ridiculously ghetto, I'm happy to report that  Citrus is actually very good.  The space is relatively small, but they put it to excellent use.  The excellent lighting choices create a nice, comfortable ambiance.  The food is delicious, the quantities are huge, and the price is reasonable.  I'm officially a fan.  Oh, and the ginger tea is rad too.  

Cheers,

Matthew
author: Matthew H.

description:
This place is really good for what it is. When I have a cold I love their spicier noodle soups and when I want some comfort food noodles I have their Garlic beef and shitake mushrooms (with the chow fun noodles). Unfortunately, the shitake mushrooms have this odd and super sweet flavor, but I work around them and all is well. My other favorite is the garlic edamame. 
I have not gone here in forever because it is one of those places that you can tire of if you go too often. I also have not felt like a huge bowl of noodles in awhile... but if I do (and if you do), this is a solid option. 

PS. It is mega-cheap!
author: Amanda C.

description:
Umm...it's okay. This place seems to be immensely popular, judging by the constant lines out the door.  But it just doesn't seem very authentic or very well done to me. Is it Thai? Is it Vietnamese? Who is running the show here? 
Tom Ka is one of my favorite things in the world to eat. It's just okay here. It seems to be missing some omg-it's-so-delicious ingredient. The vietnamese spring rolls were pretty good but they're all raw ingredients and hard to screw up. They did fall apart easily. :(
Also, I could smell the bathroom from where I sat at the bar. Dude. I can't imagine what it's like for those poor schmucks who sat at the table *right* next to it. 
They have pear cider on tap though - unexpected for an "asian" restaurant so that's a yay.
author: Rennie L.

description:
I am convinced the coconut curry soup here keeps me healthy during cold and flu season.
 
Generally, a good place to grab dinner. The other highlight for me is the BBQ Tofu spring rolls. Most other dishes are hit or miss.
author: Laura H.

description:
NO MEMBERSHIP REQUIRED!

Why is this called a club?  Much like the Members' Only, there is no exclusivity as they let everybody in.  No dress code or nuttin.  

Food wasn't too bad, just expect the eat noodles.  Interesting oilly noodles.  They put a nice spin on your typical asian noodles and it is appreciated.
author: patrick o.

description:
Love the food! Good with the prices. 

but HATE the wait. I feel like I'm always waiting in line and the restaurant is so tiny that you're crammed against the wall for a good 30 minutes as you await your table. get there early or go on a random weeknight (and still get there early).
author: linda t.

description:
Every time I've been to this restaurant, they've had a long line waiting for tables. But if you're alone, you can usually find a place to sit at the counter/bar.

It's the kind of restaurant that you go to so that you can say that you had a hard time getting in. The food is good and I can always count on the Lemon and Cocout Chicken being above-average.

Should be a fun place to go to with a crowd.
author: Chris J.

description:
In the cold, hard light of day, Citrus Club is dingy, has only the vaguest notions of "clean" or "sanitary", is occasionally plagued w/ flies, and has a restroom worthy of a dive bar. Should you happen to get the table beside the window, you can also experience the trace smell of refuse from the adjacent alley.

So why the 3 stars?

coconut lime noodles. and sweet ginger tea.
hardly a reason to order anything else.
author: Astrid X.

description:
Service is no good, but if you get it to go it will rock your tongue.  If you get it to go you also get more food.

I love the peanut chicken soup........

They have those nasty Soju cocktails too !
author: David S.

description:
Five stars for the garlic edamame. HEAVEN!

But minus two stars for the weird pad thai. This may seem harsh, but the the sauce tasted...mayonnaisey. I don't know what they put in that sauce, but it's just kinda weird. Also, I've never before had tomatoes in my pad thai....so that was weird too. I love tomatoes but they don't fit here.
author: Beth T.

description:
I know this place is popular and busy but i only see crowded, dark and so so over priced asian food. 

Most of the dishes ive tried look pretty but under performed when compared to typical asian restaurants when it comes to flavors, heat, etc.
author: w l.

description:
I have never had a bad meal here. The pad thai is absolutely incredible and doesn't have the heavy tomato sauce you often find in restaurants. The spicy curry tiger shrimp are also delicious- I like asking for it extra spicy... yum!

A word of warning: never go here on a weekend night or you will wait a very long time. The restaurant is tiny so get here early if you don't want to stand around for ages.

One time I dined here I looked out the window and saw a rat climbing the fence. Not going to lie- it was a little discerning.

Overall, I think this is one of the better evening spots in the Haight. It's consistent, affordable and a great place to head with the girls and talk if you know the right time to go.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Oh my! I have spent my whole day yelping when I could have been working on some nuclear magnetic resonance or string theory or protein folding. And you know you have Yelp Fever when you can't wait to get home and review a place. I hadn't even eaten the food yet!

It was a lovely day in the Haight. There were lots of pretty girls out and about. There were also some really ugly girls too but I wasn't girl watching, I was food hunting. I walked right by "The Best Thai Noodle Place" and Ploy II and straight to Citrus Club. I looked at the menu for about 15 seconds and decided on the Shanghai Noodles. I ordered them and the girl behind the counter said it would be 10 minutes. It was more like 3! And then there's that adorable server that's been there for years-- the one that wears her hair in two little Minnie Mouse buns. I like her but I wasn't there to adore the waitresses, I was there for the food.

I would have eaten there but I hadn't showered yet today so unlike many of the Haight Street regulars, I decided to do everyone a favor and take it to go. I couldn't wait to get home because I was so hungry. When I finally did get home I ate that stuff faster than Kobayashi defending his title. It was hot and delicious and Shanghai-y.

Citrus Club has a solid menu, good prices and generous portions for a great value. That was the serious part of my review.
author: Hunter G.

description:
No stars.

I was giving it a second chance because the restaurant we wanted to go to was closed. I'm not sure why we even stayed for the food. We had a choice of a table either at the bathroom or at the kitchen door.  We chose the kitchen door.  It was as if we were in a wind tunnel that was blowing dirty dish water smell the whole evening.  I know it's a small house but why put a table there?  I cannot understand how the restaurant stays open and busy all the time.  With all the choices of "real" Asian restaurants in SF, why go here?  It's not even that it's inauthentic.  It's tasteless and disappointing.  I felt as if I had not only wasted money but also calories.  I I don't think I can even put into words how terrible the food was.  I am flabbergasted by the degree of mediocrity this restaurant spews out dish after dish.
author: Marisa S.

description: On the cheaper side and big portions.  But they use MSG (who uses MSG in 2012??) and if you order for pickup it's likely that you'll be missing components.  Ordered the Chicken Noodle Soup today and when we got home discovered that they'd included one (literally) leaf of basil.  The soup is all about the basil.  Be sure to check your to-go order before you leave the restaurant.
author: Beth B.

description:
Stopped by for an afternoon snack. Place was relatively empty; there were maybe two or three other parties there. The waiter was very friendly and helpful. Got the special of Thai Coconut Shrimp Wonton Noodle Soup for $9. It came out within minutes. But it ended up actually being my dinner because the portion was huuuge. Easily enough to fill two people.

Pretty tasty stuff, too. A bit spicy for my taste, but that's my fault. Was basically like a Thai curry but a bit more liquidy, plus noodles and wontons. The wontons were very good; right up there with the best I've had. Probably one of my new favorite restaurants in SF.
author: Chris L.

description:
It's a great place to come get a full meal and have food left over! I definitely recommend the garlic edamame--surprisingly fantastic. I also ordered the Shanghai noodles which were quite good. 

The interior is nothing spectacular, very casual. The service wasn't anything to write home about--seat yourself and didn't have any recommendations for what to try. 

I will definitely go back sometime soon.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Cool place! I went here last night for dinner and have to say it really is a fusion space. Not only do they serve an eclectic menu of Asian cuisine, they play smooth blues music in the background at the same time! 

As for the food, the green beans w/garlic and tofu starter that we ordered was yummy. I loved my pad thai! It felt healthier with the freshly diced tomatoes and green onions and light seasoning. The portion sizes are huge so if you're hungry, this place will not disappoint. Not bad on the wine either, the house cabernet was great. 

If you're looking for a laid back place with good food and classy music, the Citrus Club will leave you smiling.
author: Swetha G.

description:
A narrow pizza joint turned noodle bar.  Seating and ordering was a complete cluster.  It took 15 minutes to have an order taken and received it in another 15.  My friend received her meal 30 minutes after mine.  The wait staff was friendly when they could be found.  The food was not well prepared, but there was a lot of it.  Though the meal is inexpensive, the cash saved will likely be spent on a stomach pump.

inexpensive + huge portions = 2 stars
author: Mark T.

description: Seems like it used to be a lot better. My friends noodles were super soggy and tasted like dish water. My noodles were also super overcooked and just turned to mush. If you can't keep everything more fresh, have a smaller menu.
author: Jonathan P.

description: Best noodle! I love it because I can have my veggie with the yummy noodle. Storming weather out, what is better than a bowl of steamy noddle soup?
author: ivy h.

description:
I live right around the corner from this place, so I get take out on a regular basis.

The food isn't fantastic but it's definitely not horrible either.  The best thing about this place is the amount of food you get for your money.  

I paid roughly 6 or 7 dollars for one pad thai dish that was able to feed both me and my hungry boyfriend.
author: Maddie M.

description: Great ambiance. Love what they did with the decor! Decent food. Could be more flavorful and authentic. The noodles need more spice.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Citrus Club is a charming little hole in the wall and one of the only decent places to get take out on upper Haight street.  If you decide to dine there, count on there being a wait. The line moves quickly though, as does the service and the crowded little joint is an entertaining place to people watch. The food is prepared in the front of the bar right where you walk in so you can also see all the hot pan fry action while you wait. 

As far as the food itself goes, I have never ordered anything that wasn't delicious. My favorites are Spicy Lemon & Coconut Chicken, Garlic Beef & Shiitake Mushrooms, Hot-Sour Shrimp Noodle Soup, and the House-Garlic Edamame. Get a couple of dishes and share with your friends. You get tons of food and it's really inexpensive.
author: Kimberly B.

description: I really don't know why some people swear by this place. I have always left incredibly dissappointed. Don't order the pad Thai. They really shouldn't even be able to call it that. Also, the seaweed salad with tofu is actually a tiny bit of salad with huge chunks of raw, unflavored tofu. No bueno. Waste of my time and money.
author: Cagrie B.

description:
First off: if you're in a hurry, this isn't the place for you. You will wait.

That being said, this place is awesome. The first time I came here, it must have been a weekday because we were seated fairly quickly, but the second time, we waited for close to an hour. The atmosphere is really nice. The lighting is dim without being totally dark, and there are nice touches to the lamps and walls and stuff. We were at first seated at the corner table, which smelled like anything from garbage to public bathroom to sewage, depending on the angle, but the waiters were kind enough to let us move to a less, er, fragrant table.

So really, the main attraction here is the food. That's the way it should be, and that's really all I base my ratings upon. Someone here mentioned that the waiters are sort of inept at times, which is true, but the FOOD.

I have had two things, both noodle-based, which as far as I'm concerned, is where it's at. The first time, I had a soup that is similar to pho, though I don't remember what it's called, and it was deliciously flavorful and a little spicy without ever being bland or abrasive. 

The second time, I had the lemongrass coconut spinach noodles, which comes with onions and snowpeas. I would probably eat a tire if it was cooked in enough coconut milk. But not all coconut is created equal, and this was a higher being. The noodles were perfect, the snowpeas crisp, the onions cooked EXACTLY how I like them: not bitter but not soggy, and on top there was parmesan cheese (I think) which seemed weird at first, but then again, everything is fusion around here.

I tasted some other people's dishes, and had the spring rolls, and everything was good. There was a noodle curry soup, vegan hot and sour soup (if you're into that), and a curry noodle plate thing, and everything was tasty and awesome.
author: Mea H.

description:
The owner who owns Bistro 9! 

I'm a fan of Bistro 9 so of course I have the try out the other restaurants by the same owner. So after a nice mani/pedi/ and wax, my friend and I decided to go across the street to eat at the citrus club. Not really a big fan of asian fusion and eating at another asian fusion place only reminded me why I don't like the cuisine. No offense to the citrus club but its not their food....its the cuisine. Its just not...authentic. I ordered the garlic noodles and it came out looking and tasting like chow mein. Their Pho comes in a huge bowl and big spoon. It was eh..ok. 

Nevertheless, I still like Bistro 9!
author: Jenny K.

description:
AWESOME food if you are willing to put up with the shitty service. The waiters always seem annoyed with you but I have learned to not care because I don't know how I would live without their 'Vegetarian Spring Rolls' or 'Peanut Noodles'! :)

P.S. if you have the opportunity.. sit at the bar. The bartenders are MUCH nicer and more "doting" than the servers. If you don't mind people standing behind you while you are eating.. since the entry is very narrow. :P
author: Casey Jane D.

description: Love Citrus Club! My boyfriend introduced me to this place and we go probably every other week. The garlic edamame is soooo good! I also am a huge fan of the ginger BBQ chicken and the miso soup. Honestly, you can't go wrong, they have something for everyone. The prices are cheap the food is good and I love the atmosphere. I am totally diggin the decor with the candles, low light and a dark Asian fusion theme.  The only downer I can say is that the last three times I have ordered a ginger ale it was just soda water, no syrup.
author: Karlie N.

description:
In a word: Underwhelmed.  

Yes, the prices are low, but that's cause the food is so-so.  The space is cramped, the dim lights in the back room flicker in a ghostly way. Our waitress was not particularly mean nor friendly.  The beef in my Garlic Beef & Shitake Noodles was very dry.  I probably won't go back there again. There are plenty of noodle joints that I know have much better food and better service and are just as gentle on your wallet.
author: Emily L.

description:
This is really a 3.5 rating.

PROS:
Good food! Everything on the menu is a bit unusual, event he pad thai isn't your standard pad thai. The Lemongrass and coconut Shrimp on jade noodles was awsome! I think its cute that the food theme of this place is noodles. We also got the garlic edemame - fantastic. Fast water refills (this is so rare) and cheap eats mean I would go back.

CONS:
From the outside it looks like a $hit hole. Once you get inside its cute though. That photo above must be outdated.
The bathroom was GROSS.  One little toilet that looked like a dive bar toilet and  you could smell sewage - thank god we weren't sitting near it.
Crowded and busy, so be prepared for a wait or come on an off time.
This guy brought more chopsticks over for the cup holder on our table. All the while fingering and stroking the chopsticks with his bare hands - um no thanks, I'll take a fork and please don't touch the prongs.
author: Jessica L.

description:
The first thing I noticed about Citrus Club is that it's packed with young, nubile hotties. This is a bad sign. After all the buzz, I wanted to see, smell, and taste food so good, that even the most portion-controlled stick figure model girl would gorge herself and have to be rolled out of the restaurant. No such luck.


 Granted, the highly-vaunted garlic edamame is delicious and the salad is damn tasty. But the hot noodle dishes? Overcooked and mushy. Broths? Thin and underflavored. Yes, subtlety is a key element in much Asian cooking, particularly the delicate simplicity of dishes like pho noodles, but when I find myself noticing the subtleties of boiled tap water - and not the basil, sliced meat, and other ingredients - there's a problem.


 Overall the food isn't bad, by any means, and the prices are fantastic, but is it ever worth the long wait and huge crowds to eat here? Only if the main taste on your palate is eye candy.
author: Omid T.

description:
there was once a time when I would've gone with one star, but you've proven yourself Citrus Club, I have to admit. 
Thank you Citrus Club! 

Best thing for me is the sweet peanut dipping sauce, not to plain, with a hint of spice, and not too chunky. Comes with the bbq-tofu spring rolls, but i'm sure you could get some on the side.

Next up, the won ton soup... With silver noodles and green onions on the side, if you get it to go... 

I'm going down the list as one loyal foodie member of the Citrus Club.
author: og c.

description:
Good food, and nice decor. I found the service to be a bit pushy in trying to get us out as soon as we weren't actively eating. Every five minutes, the waiter would come by and ask whether we wanted a box for the food we hadn't eaten yet. 

My peanut noodles with chicken were tasty, although the peanut flavor didn't jump out at me as much as I would have hoped. The garlic edamame is probably the best edamame I have ever tasted. A pretty good meal for the price (probably two meals considering the huge portions).
author: Dana L.

description:
Citrus Club, so tasty, so tasty!

I am a fool for not eating here in the past 4 years, and if you like noodles and a good time so are you. I had the lemongrass shrimp with spinach noodles, they were very tasty, especially for the price. If you want a good meal with friends, good price and very good girl-y drinks (sake cranberry martini, sake bombs, etc.) or just something hot on those cold nights, check out Citrus Club.

We ate at 9, on Thursday, and they were filled, so expect a wait during peak hours, but it's worth it.

I'm sure to go back.
author: Tom E.

description:
Can I get an OH EM GEEEEEE?

I freakin' LOVE this place, MAN!  Here's what you do to get the best Citrus Club experience...

1. When you go in and it's busy, write your name on the list and offer to sit at the bar right away.  Often times the bar seats open up faster and if you mentioned the bar first, you sit first, capeesh?

2. Get the garlic edamame as an appetizer, it's BOMB.  Get some imported beer, and if you're really feeling it, some sake (the one I ordered came in a Martini glass and whatever it was, it rocked).

3. Get the spicy lemon and coconut chicken from the wok tossed noodles list.  It has bean sprouts and egg noodles and MIGHT be the best thing you have ever tasted IN YOUR WHOLE ENTIRE LIFETIME.

4. Be gluttonous.  I know in my case, it doesn't matter how much I eat while I'm in the restaurant, there will always be leftovers.  We're talking major portions for minimal dollars.  A real bang for your buck.

I convinced my roommate (she's new to the city) to take her out-of-town friend here just about 3 weeks ago.  She's already been back like 3 times.  ADDICTION!

The End!
author: Shannon M.

description:
Originally, a group of friends and I were going to head to Cha Cha Cha for dinner, but the wait there would be 1 hour and the host was very rude.  So we walked down the street and decided to try here.

We had to just wait for a little bit since they were cleaning up the table and preparing it for us.  Unfortunately, the way that the restaurant was built/designed, there was really no room to wait for your table except in the long hallway.  So I was constantly in people's way getting in and out of the place.  Also our table was right next to the bathroom.  My friends could see the people washing their hands and checking themselves before they left the washroom.  It was odd.

The service was good and the food was not bad.  It was really interesting flavor to it; definitely a Asian-fusion style.  They serve all types of Asian noodles.  We ordered the beef-shiitake mushroom noodles, pad thai, and lemon chicken noodles.  They were all good and tasteful.  The portion were good sizes too.
author: Melissa T.

description: first time i went, seemed great because i was trying all types of 'fusion' food in the city. second time i went back, (and boy was i hungry), food came about 30 minutes later, everything tasted 'sweet'-seemed like they put alot of sugar to all the dishes including soups and noodles. I had the ginger chicken with garlic noodles.  the chicken was pretty tender and there was alot of food - noodles AND chicken. so i was satisfied from that perspective.  :)
author: Sophie L.

description:
I've been to the Citrus Club a few times and always had a great time.

The food is super tasty, and FRESH! And I'm always surprised on how low the bill is!

The atmosphere is great too, a little cramped though, but hey it's popular.
author: Adrian H.

description: Probably the second busiest restaurant in the Haight after Cha Cha Cha, which is right across the street.  Indeed, at 8:30 on a Wednesday we still had to mill about for a bit.  But whereas Cha Cha Cha's delicious tapas are worth jumping through hoops, Citrus Club doesn't have much to offer except sexy lighting.  The tofu spring rolls (and, for that matter, my Nigori cocktail) were downright bland, the "spicy" tiger shrimp curry was anything but, and even their garlic edamame, while inspired, misses the mark a bit, simply because the garlic flavor really only gets on the *outside* of the pod, leaving the beans as flavorless as ever.  Which would make this place pretty unremarkable, if it didn't attract such hordes of inexplicably tastebud-lacking people.
author: Wes M.

description:
i'm usually kinda skeptical of asian-fusion places (how can one chef be good at all asian cuisines?!?). overall i thought citrus club was decent but not really spectacular...

came in a group of 4 and shared (all noodle dishes):
-grilled korean short ribs (probably the best thing we had. ribs were grilled and seasoned nicely)
-spicy curry tiger shrimp (noodles were kinda dry and lacking in flavor)
-house phad thai (again, the noodles were dry and slightly flavor-less)
-garlic beef and shitake mushroom

i will give them extra +++ for great prices (~$7-10 for most dishes) and large portions.
author: Vy D.

description:
The atmosphere is fine if you're having a casual diner with some friends. I wouldn't bring a date here.

The sauce that comes with their shrimp spring rolls is amazing, so I always start with those.  I've had the garlic edamame, but can't say it was all that great.  I prefer my edamame with a little salt and not much else.

The main dish I usually get is a garlic beef and noodle concoction.. I can't  remember what its called.  And, it is usually really good.  But the other night they had ginger marinated grilled chicken over noodles in their specials.  I saw a few of those get brought out while waiting for a table so I decided to give it a try since it looked good.  I'm hoping it is something that is on the menu or specials list often, because it was quite good and its what I'll be looking for next time I visit.

All in all a really nice place with a casual setting and good food.
author: Jeff S.

description:
I don't spend too much time in the Haight but I did drop by this place once.  It's packed!  The food was mediocre, and the place was tiny.  Not too into having people bump into me every few minutes.  I mean it's bad enough at the bar, but when you're trying to eat...!

You get the point.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Love love love. I'm addicted to their beef soup, and the serving is big enough to comfortably feed two people. 

The place is usually crazy crowded, but well worth the wait. The counter seating is first-come first-served, so snag it up if you can.
author: Anna A.

description:
I am a huge fan of this place after eating there only once.  Who can beat $6 for the hugest bowl of noodles you've ever seen in your life?  I brought half of it home and it's going to be lunch today.  

I had the lemongrass chicken and it was very tasty.  I'm not such a huge fan of fat egg noodles though, so I wish it had come with some vermicelli or something instead of those.  Yay for fresh broccoli though :)  My friend had the beef flat noodles with snow peas.  It was yummy too, that's what I'm going to get next time.  Even though it's a little more expensive haha.  Tons of people came in for takeout while I was there, so maybe the next dinner I host I'll come grab some stuff from these dudes.  I can't imagine a more perfect lunch break or cheap dinner.  

Service was whatever, they told us to sit anywhere and their service consisted of handing us giant bowls of noodles.  At least it was fast!!  I'll definitely be back here often, I can tell already!
author: Becky N.

description:
I'm not a frequenter of Citrus, been twice so if you don't care for a non-regular's opinion move on.  I eat out noodles about once a week and probably make em at home another day of that week... even though the Bay area has nothing on west coast cheap noodles, this place just couldn't compare to the 3 star (at best) shops I know out here.   

Service is with a smile and I guess the clip board system works but I've seen it foul a few patrons on both occasions.  Yes the food can be good, so I won't dis the value but it definitely needs more OOMPH for taste (there's no chili sauce? ...just rooster sauce... hint-bring your own next time you go!)

I may still eat here again, I'll probably have to fall over drunk into the front door and not be able to navigate back from the long noodle counter.  Cheers
author: Austin V.

description:
I used to come here a lot when I was in college and craved noodles. What can I say? my mummy raised me on noodles. This isn't the authetic stuff tho mind you. The menu has one noodle dish from every pan -asian area. none of it is really out of this world, but all edible in one way or another.

came here with a friend recently when he mentioned wanting noodles. (thang long felt too far away ) I'm must say, Citrus Club isn't what I remembered.

First of all, we were seated next to the bathrooms (last table available), and people walked in and out behind us all night. It also didn't feel too sanitary...
I ordered the cocunut shrimp noodles and he ordered the lemongrass chicken. We swapped halfway to try eachother's plates and it turns out both our meals tasted exactly the same. slightly coconut-y without much flavor. 

we also shared a fried banana desert which was not so fried. It's not the crusted tempura style I expected ( or remembered), rather it was just pan-fried, not even warm in the center.

1 star for feeding me while I was a starving college kid on a budget.
author: Scarlet S.

description:
