I love noodle-y dishes...spicy, steamy and fragrant... ahhh. So I was looking forward on a cold saturday night. There was a long line, but we were seated in short time. We asked to move to a better location(as we were cramped and seated next to the restrooms), but the waitress had a rushed attitude.. she did finally move us, but to another cramped location even though there was better seating nearby. My partner ordered his one and only dish that he likes there, so I order another, the yellow curry tofu. My dish was so very bland, it left for a lot to be desired. My partner ended up sharing half of his dish with me(the shiitake and shimp rice noodle dish). A lot of chattering coming from everywhere(as we were so cramped), and tasteless music, it felt very distracting, not relaxing in the least bit.

Sooo..meh... not a very good experience.
author: Vicky P.

description:
We went for dinner and next day for lunch. For dinner I had a Yellow Coconut Curry, that I think the cook forgot to put the sauce on. No flavor whatsoever. Just noodles, cucumber and carrots. I should have returned it.
The next day for lunch I ordered a Pad Thai.  It was bland and flavorless. It could have been much better if it had more peanut sauce and grounded peanuts instead of whole peanuts here and there. The noodles of both dishes were great though.
Nevertheless my husband had a great experience. Both of his meals were really good. For dinner he had a bowl of Pho soup that was great. The next day lunch he had a cashew chicken that was really good. I was jealous!!

The place is very nice and clean with modern decoration, friendly people and good service. The prices are very good, cheap in comparison with other restaurants. The only thing is that the tables are too close to each other and at dinner is a little loud in there. 
I will go again and ask to put more flavor on my food :)
author: Patricia D.

description:
My favorite place on a cold day...hot soup! Yum!

I ordered the soba noodle soup with shrimp, filled with tons of fresh veggies and a delicious broth. Definitely too much to eat all in one sitting...hooray for leftovers!

The service was a little slow, but the yummy food makes up for it.
author: Pam W.

description:
Mmmmmm.  MMMMMM!  Citrus Club, I love you.  I love you even when you make me wait in a super long line down a long, dark hallway.  I love you because your food comes to my table so quickly, and always so delicious.  I love your garlic edamame, and would eat it on even a first date.  I love your coconut tofu soup, with shrimp added, because it is soooo delicious everytime.  I love the leftovers your provide me.  I love that once, you made me and my friends a table where once it had not existed.

Citrus Club, I love you.  I will happily wait any length of time to eat your delicious food.



But Citrus Club... don't worry, I love you still... but you made my gluten-free friend very sad by your lack of gluten-free options.  His problem.. not mine.
author: Carrie A.

description: Still a huge fan. Right around the corner from our apartment. Always delightful, always delicious. Quick service, super affordable.
author: Kelly F.

description: I don't get this place.  A few years ago, I live in the Upper Haight for a month and ate here twice a week.  The food was OK but nothing too special.  Now I remember why I went there so much, the cashier was cute.  So, the other day, I gave it another shot with a friend of mine.  Oh God, it was terrible.  I hate writing bad reviews but this restaurant was so busy at lunch time, I don't think a bad review will hurt their business.  We had the noodle in brown sauce and it was so salty.  The veggies was stale too.  We also had the lime green cold noodle and it was so creamy, almost inedible.  I went for cocktails with my friend's wife on another occassion at Suppenkuche, of course we talked about food and she confirmed the same thing about Citrus Club, too salty and worse, the noodle is overcooked.  Ugh.
author: Christian N.

description:
Very good food and a funky, cozy, downtempo-driven urban feel.

Portions are generous and there's lots of variety on the menu (though almost everything involves noodles). The prawn dishes made me particularly happy...

Gotta love a restaurant that gives you tamarind candies with your check!
author: Derek B.

description:
I always take out of town guests here. The food is excellent and the prices all around $10 or less. I call it California-Asian fusion cuisine. Everything is good! The noodles taste homemade, the veggies fresh and crisp, and the soup bowls are huge!! The food lacks any greasy or heavy quality to it, I always feel like I ate diet food but got the satisfaction of a cheeseburger. I don't know the name of this dish, but my favorite has beef, shitake mushrooms and noodles. The prawns and jade noodles are also good. The soup is a must on a chilly night. Stay away from the peanut noodles, unless you like noodles with a scoop of crunchy Jiffy on it. That is really the only bad choice on the menu. 
The only problem with this restaurant is the wait. It is very small, not good for a big group, and the wait is always around 20 or more minutes on a busy night.
author: Colleen P.

description:
My second experience here was better than my first, which involved a 45 minute wait and a painful, tear-streaked splintering of our group.  This time, we ate dinner at 9, seemingly avoiding the hordes wandering Haight street in search of sake and noodles.  

I wasn't blown away by the food, but a drink, appetizers and a main course were had for less than $20 per person, including tip, which is impressive for non-diner fare in this city.  That reminds me of a younger age, when my eyes were still full of innocence, where putting down a $20 bill at a decent restaurant meant some useful change, dammit. 

My peanut noodles were satisfying.  They could have been spicier, but that's a minor complaint.  In general, everything could have had stronger flavor, including the spring rolls we got for appetizers and the sake martini I had.  Maybe the soup would have been better.  Something to try next time.
author: Jay M.

description:
I liked this place the first two times I went. Tasty noodles. But this last trip I was saddened by the absolute lack of taste in their Tom Ka with tofu. Maybe it was the tofu, maybe it was something else, but no amount of soy sauce and hot peppers could resuscitate this dying dish.

Might go back, as I liked their jade noodles in cocunut sauces. Stick with noodles though- that seems to be what they do best.
author: Vee B.

description:
Coconut chikn thing, great
lime cilantro creation, ooh yeah,
viet spring rolls, fresh and fine,
everything bigger than expected and tastier too (almost always)
bathrooms kinda chic but kinda strange too, an experience
service, well thats one word for it, another might be zen- like as in nothing at all

But you always get your food eventually.

Speaking of crack=garlic, the water guy musta been riding the white horse cos every time one of us took a sip he was there, bam, super sensing water guy who can hear the quitest swallow of aqua and know it is his duty to replenish your glass, lest the customer leave on account of the otherwise non-existent service. He was amazing. We started messing with his game by taking small sips real fast to see how fast he came back, my wife got carried away with it, she can be cruel, in a sweet way... He didn't miss a beat. Genius. Or methamphetamine. I don't mind.
author: Steve S.

description:
I enjoy this place every time I go. The portions are huge, so it's good if you have someone to share with. Forget going here on weekends because of the crowds, staff is nice and informative, and the food is tasty. Lots of choices on the menu.

Every Soup I have had there has been excellent.

I look forward to eating here a lot during winter.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
Service not great considering very few customers at 1pm today.  Food arrived extremely fast, waitress could have smiled once or twice is all.

I had the vegan soba soup, more flavorful than expected and would have been good on its own.  I decided to add the spicy "red" sauce because I was feeling like some kick.  I would come here again.  I want to try some of the other things on the menu like the BBQ tofu appetizer.

Thai iced tea was just past the point of being too sweet for my taste, but not so much so that it was unpalatable.  With the salt and spice of my soup it tasted good, on its own it would have been a little much.
author: Peter v.

description:
Yum... this place has great food at a very good price.  I always get the Spicy Lemon & Coconut Chicken noodles ($6.50), it comes with egg noodles but I substitute it with rice noodles and get extra sauce on the side.  The egg noodles are ok, but it's so much better with rice noodles because the egg noodles seem to have an off-taste to them- especially with this sauce.

This place "is what it is", like my boyfriend says, the food is substantial, great portions and great prices.  They also have really good beer to cool you off from the spice of some of the food.  It's not fancy here, but at night the lights are low and the candles are lit- so it makes for a good night out.

Go here for a nice meal, and if you go at night (especially on the weekend) expect a wait.
author: Michi R.

description:
Everything I've had here is tasty.  The portions are large; I frequently split entrees/soups with my peeps.  The ginger tea is good.

No full bar, and thus, no fifth star. 

It's in the Haight, so the best time of year to go is during Burning Man.  You know, when all the wannabe teenage hippies are gone.
author: Andrew M.

description:
The Citrus Club is good for what it is. It's good for cheap, fast meals. Soups are better than anything else on the menu, so I wouldn't stray far from that. You can definitely go here and order one soup bowl for two people - 3 of us ate for under $20. And had leftovers.

The Citrus Club is NOT good for these things: actual enjoying a meal. It's noisy, and not conducive to conversation. You can't linger because they want to turn the tables quickly. It's super dark and always feel like you're in a cave. Staff are not all that friendly and they always look harried, which makes the meal a stressful experience.
author: Carla B.

description:
Do yourself a favor and try the cold noodle buckwheat soba appetizer (they call it the lime and something noodles). VERY delicious and tasted great. 

They have a large noodle selection to enjoy (I had the garlic noodles), but I'd stay away from the BBQ meats as both the garlic chicken special and the beef satay appetizer were both kinda dry with no discernable special flavor.

Good beers available, and asian liquor was available as well (plus wine and the usual). The service was friendly, although they are quite small and crowded in there so don't expect to be waited on hand and foot.
author: Justin M.

description:
This place is YUMMY!! Although we had to wait for a while for a table then we decided to sit at the bar with my son. It was probably the only place I could sit at a bar with my 5 year old and have a good dinner!! The food is great! ----------- 

I ordered take out last night and to my surprise the food was NOT half as good. Not only did they give us very little portions but I found HAIR at the bottom of the box!!! YUCK!! This is the second time in 2 months that I have found hair in my food dining in San Francisco. What the heck don't the cooks here wear hair nets??? YUCK!!! Obviously I had to lower my rating~!! HAIR!! YUCK!
author: Z A.

description:
The atmosphere, decorations and cheap food sold me when I first stepped in. It's a really small space with ephermerial lighting and good music in the backgroup. The menu offer all types of Asian  noodles, from vietnamese soup noodle to cold  japanese soba n(wheat noodles). 

Considering the place's name, I order the orange mint soba noodle. It was okay...fairly up to par... for $4.95. But, being in the atmosphere and the hustling and bustling of the place, somehow it made the food taste good. It's comforting when you're there, especially when you're enjoying a glass of wine and eating some hearty noddles. 

So, because of the experience, I give this place 4 stars. I think it's a good place for two...to eat, chat and catch up. Although food really wasn't out of this world...but cheap and up to par :)
author: My V.

description:
After a long, hard afternoon cruising along Haight Street, one might find themself needing a quick asian fusion fix, and that's when we happen to stumble upon Citrus Club.

Well to be honest i was with a huge group and didn't feel like putting up a fight, so i went with the flow and took the "Citrus Plunge"!.

Its a quaint little spot, super noisy. We didn't have to wait much to be seated, i guess we arrived before the crowd kicks in.

I ordered the coconut curry and tofu rice noodles, which were pretty good, others in my group ordered the peanut noodles, the pad thai, some soup.The food was really fresh, piping hot and flavorful. 
They have a lot of vege options on the menu which was insane! (i'm a vegetarian). They also serve sake.

This place deserves 5 stars but the service was super slow, we had to wait for 30 minutes for the food. Oh well, it was a welcome change from all the other boring joints on haight. Give it a try.
author: Tushar V.

description:
From the outside, Citrus Club looks a little sketchy.  The awning is kind of old, you can see the kitchen from the window outside, not that appealing.  But, once you go inside, it is much cuter!  They serve in huge bowls that make everything look even yummier.  I usually get my food to-go because I live so close, however, I really should eat in because I like the vibe in there.  

It is really reasonably priced and the food is good!  I really like the vegetarian spring roll appetizers, and many of their noodle dishes.  I generally order the mild dishes, so I'm pretty sure if you like spice you would need to add a little something to your dish.  Citrus club is a very affordable, yummy place.
author: Lauren H.

description:
The Citrus Club was good!  Not sure about citrus, I don't think I had a single citrus when I was there.  It's a nice atmosphere, but a little small and crammed in.  The food was really good.  Not your usual asian noodles, but the flavors were good, and nothing was too salty.

We shared three noodle dishes amongst four of us, and it was plenty of food.  The Thai Iced Tea was pretty good as well.  We got the small size and it came out pretty big.

I definitely will go back when I'm in the area again.  No 4 stars because I don't think I'd go out of my way to eat there, but it's definitely a nice place.

Too bad I didn't notice any citrus things...
author: Art C.

description:
My brother and I went here for his 1st restaurant experience in SF. He loved it, I love it. Enough said.

Try the spicy coconut lime noodles with chicken. You wont be sorry, unless you are allergic to chicken or coconut, then you might want to steer clear because I would feel bad if your throat swelled up in the middle of some ginger tea.
author: Big W.

description: This is place in my new weekly favorite! They served us quickly and attentively. The hot saki was a little to expensive, but we didn't mind. For starters we had tofu bbq spring wraps which were amazing! I had the cashew chicken noodle plate and it was delicious!! My friends had soups which were generous sizes and super yummy. I really enjoyed this place the ambiance was nice and intimate, with really good music! I can't wait to eat there again.
author: Jessica M.

description: Just by hearing their name you would never guess this place served up some delicious asian noodles. By far one of my favorite noodle houses in the city. I'll have to try some more things on the menu but the dishes that my friend and i got were out of this world! I had the Spicy Lemon Coconut Chicken and it was filled with yummy veggie and chicken delicious-ness. My friend got the Cashew Chicken and wow, that dish was super good. Can't wait to go back and try some of their soups!
author: Suzan L.

description:
Although I don't get out to the haight as much because I live in Bernal and there's so many delicious restaurants in the Mission, whenever I'm in the neighborhood, I'm always up for Citrus Club.

My favorites: veggie spring rolls with mint (yum!), peanut noodles, any of the soups, and marmalade shrimp noodles. Although I've eaten here probably 15+ times and everything I've gotten has been delicious so you can't go wrong - plus is super cheap!

Also they do take out so you can order ahead, pick up the food and eat in the park or at home!
author: Maggie K.

description:
Love this place for a cheap eats option!!!

I have to disagree with the reviews below...  We had wonderful service!  My girlfriend and I sat at the bar (could have had something to do with it) and a very cute bartender waited on us, providing impeccable service.  (We were on the waiting list for a table before deciding to sit at the bar, during which time the waitresses did a wonderful job of communicating and keeping everyone happy).

And the food ~ AWESOME!

We started with the much yelped garlic edamame.  So so so good.

And the Vietnamese BBQ tofu spring rolls.  The spring rolls were nice and fresh and crisp and that sauce (I am a sauce connoisseur) was fantastic.

We shared the Mongolian beef over egg noodles special.  Very very good.

And couldn't pass up on the fried banana with coconut ice cream goodness for dessert.  

We each had a glass of wine and the total for two (with more than enough food ~~~ be warned, the portion sizes are large ~~~ ) was $43.

Now that's what I'm talking about in this economy!
author: Liz B.

description: The food was good. The problem was our waitress. I went with a friend and the meal was fine. We were finishing up and my friend requested the bill. The waitress brought the bill and my friend paid in cash. The total was close to $34.00 and my friend put down $40 in cash. The waitress never came back with the change. It is not that we are cheap but it is not the waitress' decision to decided to keep the entire amount without even asking.  We waited. Asked for the change 3 times. By that time, my friend was annoyed. The waitress acted like she didn't speak English for a while. We sat waiting. When she realized we weren't going to just leave like everyone else she pulls this scam on, she brought over the change. She went back and forth to the kitchen and to the register several times and then emerged from the kitchen of all places, with the two $20 bills that we had given her. She had never even put the cash in the register (yes, we watched her). She brought back $5 and some change. By then my friend was super annoyed. It had taken her longer to get the change than it did to eat our whole meal. My friend was angry and only left $2 on the principle that this woman was being bully. When we left, I said thank you to our waitress, and she just gave me a dirty look. The food was good but the experience was ruined by the greedy waitress. Had she had been professional, we probably would have left her a $10 tip. Unless she is the owner, I don't know why she didn't put the cash in the register. She hadn't even entered the $40 payment to the register. She ended up having to do so to get change minutes before she came to us with the change. It really seemed as if the waitress was trying to pocket the entire cash payment for herself. Glad we didn't use a credit card here. She might have decided to write in her own tip and possibly make us pay a penalty for not catering to her needs.
author: Jessica G.

description:
I've been eating here since I was in high school. I love the food because its comfort food, but I know it's not one of the best restaurants in San Francisco and the service is mediocre. 

I love coming here for soup when I am sick, or eating the spicy coconut noodles when I am drunk on haight.
author: Nicole F.

description: Great cozy restaurant. Good prices and tea. Cashew chicken and pad thai very good. Lots of food! Will fill you up. Cheap good food.
author: Rhea S.

description:
Loved the garlic edamame! Great prices! 

Shared 2 entrees & the edamame, just $9 each! Definitely going back again!
author: Eliana M.

description: Great variety and very reasonably priced. I had the vegetable noodle soup and it was delicious. I'd definitely go back again.
author: Jaclyn B.

description:
Why do I try to fool myself into believing that I actually want to go elsewhere in the upper Haight? I don't know. I could possibly eat Citruc Club for lunch or dinner every day -- there's enough variety, delicious noodles, soups, meats and fish, the service is quick (takeaway is faster than sitting down though), it's inexpensive and dammit, I just like it.

On many occasions, I've discussed Cirtrus Club with even the most discerning eaters and at the end of the day, although there are so many other places to go nearby, you just can't go wrong with their Thom Ka Gai soup with noodles at any time! Okay, if it's ridiculously hot, get the cold buckwheat noodles...
author: D. R.

description:
Love this spot for a cheap, easy, filling meal. THE IMPORTANT PART IS CAREFUL ORDERING. There are a couple things on the menu I love and when I stray from these items I am often disappointed. If you stray, chances are you will discover something bland. I personally don't care though since the things I like are more than enough to keep me coming back.

HITS:
-- Spicy Lemon & Coconut Chicken (w/ broccoli) - yes! creamy yum!
-- Garlic Beef & Shitake - I've started referring to this as "the umami bowl". Star anise (a bit strong in the mushrooms perhaps) pushes this over the top into incredibly satisfying zone.
-- Recently on the "specials" there has often been a curry and shrimp wonton soup. It's good (though once it was a little on the bland side -- order it spicy to be sure!)
-- Oolong Tea
-- Spaten
-- Garlic Edamame - good, but I rarely order them - there's no way you'll have too little food.


MISSES (bland):
-- Pho
-- Pad Thai (seriously, I know people get scared of trying new things and just order pad thai but DON'T DO IT)
-- I've tried some other things in the distant past but don't remember what.
author: M W.

description:
I LOVE the pad thai here!!! It is not a traditional style pad thai meal, but is a bit creamy, with a hint of coconut milk and finely chopped, fresh cooked tomatoes... this may sound a bit weird (it did to me), but this is honestly the best pad thai I have ever had! I crave it constantly.

and the BBQ tofu spring rolls with peanut dipping sauce are soooo tasty! (and quite filling too, for a mere starter)

Don't let the trashy, drab exterior of this building influence your decision. Once you are inside (their decor is nice, very relaxing) and eating a meal you will be so glad you came here.
author: Sam S.

description: Consistent delicious satisfaction found here. The seating capacity is a little slim but there's a counter/bar area that works and they are very fast if you get your order to go. My favorites are the wok-tossed noodles. For less than $10 you can have a gallon of soup or huge dish of noodles packed with fresh ingredients. Serious food-to-price deals.
author: Edmund C.

description: This by far one of my favorite restaurants to dine at when I visit San Francisco on business. There's a lot of wonderful cuisine on Haight St., but The Citrus Club is the tastiest and not too expensive place to eat at. My favorite things to eat there are the Pho Ga, Garlic Noodles and the Garlic Edmame. The Sake based mixed drinks are also delicious and off the hook...
author: Ron D.

description: Their hot and sour soup is to die for! The ambiance isn't great (noisy and very crowded), but the food is delicious and the wait staff is friendly and efficient.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Lets start out with the good things: great atmosphere, perfect for a date, especially a first date because if things get awkward, it's so loud that you don't always have to be talking and there is enough going on that you can let your eyes wander.

The story: So, I went here for the second time in about 3 months the other weekend. I had the hardest time deciding between what I got last time (because it was SO tasty), which was the coconut lemongrass pasta over spinach noodles with tiger shrimp...and trying something new. This sauce was incredibly tasty, and I ate half of the seriously giant portion. However, I have this thing where I must try new things on the menu. What could be better than having multiple favorites at one restaurant so close to my home?

Unfortunately, my risk-taking did not produce any new favorites. I ordered the sweet and spicy chicken curry pasta, and it was possibly the most boring pasta I have ever tasted. It did not taste bad per se; it just did not taste good. I think pasta with butter would have been more exciting. My boyfriend on the other hand, ordered the Mongolian beef special which was very tasty. I ended up eating off of his plate most of the time, going so far as dipping my bland pasta into his excess sauce.

Will I go back? Yes, but only for my initial favorite and the fun atmosphere.
author: Sophia L.

description: Spicy lemon chicken noodles were very good and cheap
author: Joshua R.

description:
Hipster noodles.
but they're actually pretty tasty.
it's just that I don't want to deal with all the outta town visitors with their Amoeba bags full of LP's they can't even listen to. 
Always long lines at this place.
Girls love it. So you may want to endure that wait to impress your lady.
author: Tomas V.

description:
SF Food Inspection Rating: 100!

goodness. this is one of my favorite restaurants on the planet. every dish is so good and affordable. i personally love the shang hai noodles or the spinach noodles with a creamy garlic sauce and shrimp.

the only downside is you have to PAY for the tea BUT the tea is amazing. I suggest ginger. yum.

you'll probably see me around there.
author: Kristina C.

description:
My boyfriend took me here for Valentine's Day (also my B-day) as a surprise. I heard so many positive things about this place, that I was really happy. The wait wasn't too bad because we chose to sit at the counter. 

Menu came, we chose an appetizer of Beef skewers, one of the special items (Garlic-Ginger Chicken on a bed of stir fried noodles with bok choy) and an item on the regular menu (Stir fried Spicy Curry Tiger Prawns). The skewers came first, and they were slightly burnt. The meat itself had a very odd texture to it, almost not beef tasting. It wasn't really marinated properly, just tasted like someone just slapped on some beef on a BBQ and served it to us. The dipping sauce of peanut something was bland as well. 

As for the main dishes, my boyfriend's dish, which sounded so delicious, basically (I swear I'm not making this up) tasted like, again, someone throwing some chicken on the BBQ and serving it to us. The chicken was placed on a bed of noodles which tasted more like teriyaki noodles with bok-choy than garlic-ginger. No meaningful flavors in the mouth, just teriyaki and grilled chicken. 

My dish, had no Tiger Prawns. Tiger Prawns are big. My little shrimp were the medium size ones you buy at a grocery store. The dish basically consisted of this: Noodles that had some curry "soup" poured over it and shrimp thrown in. Top that off with Chili Powder and you have spicy. However, again, no medley of flavors dancing around in my mouth. If you took the noodles alone and ate them, they tasted bland. You had to skillfully grab the noodles and "soup" to get the flavor. 

Overall, the dinner tasted very amateur. If you've never eaten really good food, then you won't know what I'm talking about. The price is good; the food is really average though. 

I'm an optimist and gave Citrus Club another try with some friends, and again, I walked out disappointed. Between the 8 of us, nothing really was phenomenal. Go to Le Soleil instead
author: Beatrice K.

description:
Every time my friends visit, I take a trip to the Citrus Club. It may not be the best looking place and may not have the best service, but the food is so delicious and so affordable! 

I agree with the masses, however. The service can be really terrible. I've waited for so long for my food before, but I personally think it's worth it because I literally crave the peanut noodles from time to time.
author: Morence L.

description:
Cheap eats. Love the garlic edamame.

Best to go during the mornings on a weekend. It's a pleasant experience. I never ordered to go so I don't really know.
author: Adrienne H.

description:
Why oh why can't all cheap sake be served in oversized martini glasses?  

Oh yeah, food, good, cheap as well, delicious, want it, yum.
author: Dave K.

description:
When you have been in a relationship for a long time and you and your partner  have the unspoken understanding that you aren't going to be all that cooth with your eating, THIS is the place to Pig Out!

The soups are gigantic, as are the noodle plates, and every single thing i have tried there has been spot on delicious!

Its a bit cramped, but i enjoy that. A great place to go with a bunch of Buds as well. 

A date and myself shared one order of soup and one Pad Thai and still took some home to eat later after a bowl of another kind

wink! Bravo!
author: angelo b.

description:
Yum.  For sure.  Its in the Haight and on the weekend its packed.  If you're feeling sick and mom isn't around to make your favorite vegan noodle soup, come get a bowl of chicken soup here.  It's cute, a great date spot..and bars to hit nearby afterwards.

But don't think you'll be able to lounge - they're pretty obvious in terms of wanting to turn the tables quick for the next coupl-ey to experience noodle mania.
author: Denmo I.

description:
This is my Sunday night spot. After a long weekend of drinking, shopping, cleaning, laundry, etc. All I want is a nice Hot Sour Vegetable Soup or Shanghai Noodles with carrots and tofu. Some bbq tofu or shrimp spring rolls are perfect as appetizers. Friendly staff. 

No parking, well yeah, it's the Haight! However, you can pay for parking right on the corner (across the street from Cha Cha Cha) or go around few times til you find a spot. Long wait, you have to know the good times to go, otherwise, you'll wait a while or just seat at the bar and eat.
author: Anabelle B.

description:
THE FOOD AS A LEFTOVER THE NEXT DAY IS EVEN BETTER!

I'm a Food Networker - and if you know food - the Citrus Club is great California Asian Fusion restaurant. 

What is not to like about the Citrus Club?  

It is simply this:  Upscale Cuisine at dive joint prices.

Speaking of, that is exactly what the Citrus Club is... A yuppie dive joint.  

Meaning:  Atmosphere is a little cramped when full, don't go with a group bigger than 2 if possible, and the bathroom is clean but but very "Haight" (you'll see).  

I cannot seem to stop eating one dish:  Coconut Lemongrass Shrimp with Spinach Noodles.  I am salivating thinking about it.  

Their edamame' with garlic sauce ($3.95) is a must as an appetizer , even if your not an edamame' fan you should order this.
author: Michael C.

description:
Anyone who says this place has great asian-fusion needs to find a new place to dine. Upon walking in it took them about 5-10 minutes to greet us...and once we were seated i finished about 5 glasses of water before the server came to ask us what we would like to eat.

We started with the kabobs which came out in a 'somewhat' timely fashion for a appetizer. the hardest came after we finished the appetizer. somewhere between the 20+ minute wait for our main course (i had the noodle soup, my friend had the thai noodles) the people on our left who ordered 10 minutes after us received their food about the same time in which we did.

My noodle soup came in a big bowl with about 5 pieces of sliced beef and very little noodles filled with msg-filled broth. I could have made some top ramen at home and still come out with 8 dollars more in my pocket as well as a satisfied stomach.

Upon asking for our check...it took about another 15 minutes to get that. 

I have yet to understand why so many people lined up for the citrus club. It is definitely one line i don't plan on waiting in. ever.
author: Dan N.

description:
They need to sell T-shirts here that say "I Can't Believe I Ate The Whole Thing".

The food here is absolutely delicious.   Pick a dish and next thing you know you've got a giant plate (or bowl) of food in front of you.  I've had both the Grilled Ginger Chicken noodle dish as well as the Peanut Coconut Chicken dish and both were great.  Unlike other noodle places, they definitely don't skimp on the meat, as both dishes were loaded with chicken.  You start eating ravenously, get full but then find yourself picking at your dish until it's gone.  You know, you hit that point where you're saying to yourself "If i keep eating I'll feel disgusting" but in this case you decide you won't feel that bad.  The Spring Rolls and/or Garlic Edamame make excellent starters.  

You walk in and feel like you're in some backalley kitchen in Bangkok or Hong Kong but then you proceed further to see quite a posh restaurant.  The low lights and candles are a nice touch.  There's a full bar with Sapporo and Gordon Biersch on tap.  Probably the only knock is that there isn't much on the menu that isn't noodles, in case you're with some people interested in different fare.

Yeah, it is definitely small and not recommended for parties of more than 5.  The wait can definitely get bad, but if you notice a long waiting list, I'd recommend taking a walk across the street to Murio's for a quick drink and then heading back.  Despite these disadvantages, I find the food to be too good to give it a lower rating.  Let's just say I won't be turning down any invitations to dine here anytime soon.
author: Steven R.

description:
I went here for the first time on Sunday and I'd have to say it was ok...

I guess for a noodle house that serves all sorts of asian noodles, you can't really expect all of the dishes to be good.  I had a curry, tofu and peanut noodle dish.  I can't say that I'd order it again.  The flavor seemed a bit watered down.  My friend and I shared a shrimp dumpling dish as an app, and that was decent.  The service was good though.  The waiter came by several times to refill our water and to ask if we needed anything.

I can't say that this would be a first choice for me though.  I think I'd rather take a stroll across the street to Cha Cha Cha.
author: Fran H.

description:
I've eaten here more times than I can remember and I cant remember ever not being completely satisfied with myself afterwards. For starters, the food here is just delicious! So many blends of exciting flavor and yummies! My particular favorite are the vegan spring rolls and the Thai coconut vegetable noodle soup. They have lots of vegetarian options which is a major plus.

The service can be a little slow, but it's usually due the fact that the place is usually packed! There's usually a waiting list, but I'm a patient kid so I don't mind standing in the hall for a table.

All in all, I love this place, a 5 for sure. The service and wait is worth it for the amazing food.

Check it out!
author: Kelly R.

description:
I and two friends escaped fully fed on delicious food for under $40 including the tip. 

I had the Garlic Beef & Shitake Mushroom noodles which were amazing. The beef was so tender it nearly fell apart in my mouth, and the noodles were excellent. I let a friend eat the mushrooms since I let him try one and he swapped me part of his Pad Thai to take them off my hands! 

The wait is long though. We came on a Monday night and the line stretched to the door!
author: Rebecca L.

description:
I love it here.
We come at least once a week!

Their soups warm me during a cold, foggy SF day and since it is usually, cool & breezy, I have an excuse to come more frequently.

The onslaught of weekend traffic is too much, so I recommend going for an early bite during the week!  It's not really an ideal spot for a large group, but definitely a must try.
author: Molly M.

description:
It is a common fact that the Haight is not famous for the food, but this place and few others are exceptions. 
The Citrus Club has the best shrimp spring rolls ever, add some hot sauce to the original sauce they bring with them, and just try. You will understand what I mean from the first bite, really. Also, they have some really nice hot soups (shrimp is my fave), and fried banana as a dessert (only rare occasions, of course)...  Some noodle plates are good too, but I prefer soups here. 
I also like the interior - candles, nice music, cozy environment... 
Yep, I'm a fan.
author: Ksenia B.

description:
Walk in - sign up and eat some great food. Love the curry tiger shrimp dish as well as the marmalade coconut shrimp. It is a little small so if you are claustrophobic - maybe not for you. Also having one bathroom can be somewhat tough (at least for my wife). 

Check it out for lunch when it is not so busy or when you are in the neighborhood for an Amoeba excursion.
author: Chris L.

description: Don't go here unless you want to get sick. I had the Tom ka-Thai Coconut Tofu Soup and was sick for a couple of days. The noodles didn't even taste that great. The spring rolls were okay, not great by any means. Save your money, go to the Pork store cafe a couple of blocks down. Or, go to McDonalds a couple of blocks down the other way.
author: Si O.

description: The garlic edamame is a requirement if you stop in here. The soups are all great and HUGE. You'll definitely leave with lunch for the next day. Fun little environment, usually pretty good music playing.
author: Caitlin S.

description: Okay, 5 stars really, but I have only tried 3 dishes here. My favorite is the Lemongrass Coconut Shrimp with those green spinach noodles. Seriously, seriously salivating right now....so bomb. And yes, it gets crazy crowded as it seats maybe 15 parties of people...so order take out!!
author: Meredith M.

description: Loved this place!!!  The portions are HUGE though, two people could totally share one bowl of soup, if you get two, expect to take home lots of left overs.  We also had the garlic edemame... DELICIOUS!
author: Melody H.

description: This place is much better for dinner than lunch, for some reason the lunch chef is not so good. Also, try not to sit in the back by the backdoor...kinda smelly. But the dinner food is excellent.
author: Raychul M.

description: This place serves all the different types of Asian noodles (Thai, Vietnamese, and probably others too).  The owner appears to be Thai but the restaurant is done to appeal to everybody.  I find there tends to be a wait for table even on weekdays.  I've ordered the vegetable tom yum noodles, where the soup was fine and the noodles were so-so.  I can imagine the other items being the fine because (no offense!) since the aim of place seems to be fusion style and appeal to masses, it probably lacks emphasis on authenticity.  I will give credit that, once seated, the servers are generally pretty good despite the crowd (or it could be because, since I've only gone alone, they sit me at the counter where I closer to everybody).
author: H K.

description: I definitely agree that this place is hit of miss. I've gone a few times, but I went last night and I got my food about 2 minutes after I ordered it. They're not even trying to fake that their food is made to order. I'll admit the Mongolian Beef special was tasty, but I think I'm over the soups. Their hot n sour soup is more like Pho, not a traditional hot n sour. The place is inexpensive, but in my opinion they could charge a little more and have better food.
author: Katherine B.

description:
yum-the spicy coconut lime noodles, yummy!
With or without chicken is great also!!
They are busy busy when I go :) got to have it!
author: Clementine O.

description:
Cashew chicken was BOMB. 
Large portion, great price.
Very tasty. Hoisin sauce and hot sauce available at table.

Romantic. Dim, candle-lit ambiance, with red walls as the backdrop makes it an intimate date spot. However it was kind of loud (dining area in the back is kind of small and gets crowded at dinner time), so one may have to project voice (yell) in order for company to hear you (how romantic, right). 

Complimentary candy was given at the end of the meal to mask unfresh breath that may arise. LOVE IT.

Amoeba Records is down the street, so if you're in to music and movies, this is the perfect place to browse as your food digests.
author: Eddi K.

description: BLAND and too many flavors mixed together, which I never thought was possible. Both my friend and I were disappointed with our food, which were two different dishes that they used the same bland sauce in. We ended up giving our leftovers to a homeless man, but I'm not even sure he ate it.
author: Bob F.

description:
This is a very small, busy, yet easygoing Asian noodle joint.  Prices are very reasonable.  Service is fast.  Drinks aren't too expensive.  There is a lot of variety of people and the hostess lady is very accommodating.  

The only drawbacks?  The front door, when opened, which happens frequently, sucks in cold air off Haight Street that billows into the dining area.  Another thing we noticed was a large rat that was hanging outside the little interior courtyard windows while we were eating our edamame.  It was rather enormous, but at least it was behind the pane of glass.  

Citrus Club serves a lot of dishes in outrageously large white ceramic bowls.  This is especially the case if you happen to order their soups.  The pho is delicious, with the broth slightly flavored with Chinese five spice seasoning.  The beef they use is lean and tender.  

Do not order the coconut lemon grass chicken.  It is kind of bland.

It would be nice if they offered diners a spice tray with their food.
author: Rachel E.

description:
Granted, I did not try the noodles....but this satisfied my craving for a healthy ("no please please no more mexican or italian) lunch and I was pleasantly surprised by the nice surroundings (I wouldn't say trendy but not scummy).

Not everyone would love the seaweed and tofu salad  - and frankly, i probably wouldn't all the time - this was hard core slabs of tofu (bring on the soy)-but it tasted great on this day.  Very clean.

Also liked the shrimp fresh spring rolls.  Didn't like them nearly as much as the ones at Sunflower (I think that is the name) on 16th b/w Valencia and Guerrero, but still good.

And lastly, had the chicken with green beans.  Decent quality chicken, a bit overcooked.

With an iced tea, it was less than $30.

GIven the surroundings, I'd go back.  would I wait on line? No.  But we ate at the bar.
author: Laurie A.

description:
After walking up and down Haight for a while, my friends and I opted to try Citrus Club.  It was crowded, but we were able to sit at the counter without waiting.  The waitress was friendly and attentive, and we ordered quickly.

Very decent drink menu, and the appetizers were outstanding.  I managed to consume all of my garlic edamame even though the portion was pretty huge.  The chicken satay was also very tasty, and my friend raved about his spring rolls.

After such awesome starters, our entrees were a bit disappointing.  None of us tried the soup, but the pan-fried noodle dishes all seemed to be lacking something.  The peanut sauce was really rich but slightly bland.  The beef and shiitake mushrooms were overpowered by the citrus flavor.  It was...okay.  Maybe I'll just stick to the appetizers next time.
author: Erin H.

description:
Now, this place I like alot. The servings are "GD" huge! Too much for one sitting. Even splitting  a bowl is needed sometimes. 
The lay out is alright. Sometimes you sit too close to people you don't know. Other than that, it's one of the few places I frequent.
author: Lou Z.

description:
Really, there are two reasons why I like this restaurant. It is right next to my salon and the bathroom is nice.

I am not an expert on noodles, but I have had a many few in my day and most all were better than this. So unmemorable that I can't actually remember what I ordered. Something with lemongrass (that I didn't taste) and green, gooey noodles. It was bland and more like coconut milk soup with a ball of overcooked noodles at the bottom. The tables are crammed to close together in the back - I couldn't actually move my chair back to get out unless I moved my table. Perhaps the diluted and boring conversation my pals were having added to my experience, but come on. I can easily ignore the friends if the food is good, but when I can't even ignore the food with the friends?
author: Zara E.

description:
Great edamame! Try it. But after you appetizer, watch out for the spiciness. I don't quite remember what I had here, all I remember was that is was spiceee-y! Better watch out.

Also, the wait was a long one. But worth it.
author: Gabor C.

description:
Other reviews are pretty much correct.

-It's cheap
-It's not fast
-It's not as authentic as it could be
-Pho is good but I've have better- my noodles weren't whole :( they were broken so i had to eat them with a fork.

Overall it's good for Haight St cheap eats but not a destination.
author: martin l.

description:
definitely think there are better noodle bars out there than citrus club, but citrus club does a mediocre job.

whenever i come here, im usually moderately satisfied with what i get. this time was a little different. i finally found something worth paying for....the coconut broth with noodles. it was soothing and had a small punch of spice. really warmed me up for the winter season.

a few dollars overpriced.
author: Melanie F.

description: The food is good but the service is embarrassing. Last night my brother and his girlfriend waited for about 10 minutes up at the bar and ordered a few food items. When we arrived and I requested that we get moved to a table, the server told us that because my brother had ordered they could not accommodate the move. I looked around and spotted about 7 free tables and re-asked. After my asking her 4 times that we would like to move to a table, she agreed and moved us to the table closest to the bathroom. My boyfriend and I ordered food and it took 30 minutes. Luckily the food was great so we ended us satisfied. I must have some bad karma here becuase when I was a broke college student 10 years ago I came here to split a bowl of $8 soup with a friend. After they sat us and ordered, they came back and told us that we would need to order another item off the menu or we would have to leave. Sadly $8 was all we had and we had to leave with heads low and belly's unhappy. I say...take your money elsewhere.
author: Dominique R.

description: It is about time I make a review here, because my dining experiences here span over a decade!  I must say that I have always had a positive experience.  Very consistent with the food quality, and service.  The prices are very reasonable too!  Citrus Club is sure thing. It is great for dates, friends' night out, and taking guests from out of town when they want to tour the Haight-Ashbury.
author: Jack M.

description: It's cheap, casual, dark & cozy and pretty yummy. All over a decent place to grab a bite, but the food won't knock your socks off.
author: Sara W.

description: Great ambiance and attentive wait staff. My water was never empty. Came in for a light dinner and was satisfied with the veggie spring rolls and beef noodles. The best part of the meal was the sweet ginger tea. I fell in love. Overall a very pleasant experience.
author: Kacey B.

description: If you love noodles or have the cravings for it. This is the place to go. You get a wide variety of noodle dishes from good portioned plates to soups. I don't live in SF and rarely go to the Haight, but I will have to remember this place when I happen to be in the neighborhood again.
author: Chad B.

description:
First things first. Garlic Edamame! Let me repeat.... GARLIC EDAMAME!! Don't forget to order this. Perhaps the best single food item that has ever entered my mouth. Its a little steep at almost $7 but it is worth every penny. 

I have been about 4 times now and am completely satisfied every time. I would highly recommend the hot and sour vegetable soup. The tofu dish with curry was also really good. I don't think you can go wrong at this place. I would definitely recommend going for lunch because it can get a little crowded around dinner time.
author: Chris V.

description:
Tucked among overpriced vintage shops is this sweet little noodle cafe. I had the Garlic Beef Shitake noodles . . . it was delicious comfort food. My husband had the Shrimp Wonton soup . . .good, until he added to much chilli sauce and then he couldn't eat it without sweat dripping off his head.

We did have to wait a REALLY, REALLY long time . . .and we got there at like 5:00 on a Wednesday.  So expect a wait.
author: Emily M.

description:
I really like noodles. So it's no surprise that Citrus Club is a frequent stop for me. The bowls are bursting with flavour, the prices are spot-on reasonable and the tea is delish.

Try the daily special, you'll probably like it. :)
author: Paul S.

description:
* food is SUPER tasty
* atmosphere is ok, kinda cramped and noisy
* service is good

I crave their food all the time, I can't say that about many restaurants...
author: christine c.

description:
I'm totally in love with the vegetarian spring rolls.  Not only are they awesome, but the peanut sauce they come with is awesome -- and the price is awesome:  6 spring rolls for $3.95.  BEST. DEAL. EVER.  
This place is also great for when you're sick and you need a big bowl of soup -- 'cause a BIG-ASS BOWL OF SOUP is what you're gonna get.  We're talkin' huge, people.  
Casual atmosphere, fun date place.  Love it!
author: Jacquie M.

description:
Great Pho and excellent appetizers

Start with garlic edamame - order this, even if you don't like edamame, you will eat every ounce and practically lick the bowl.  Also very good are the fresh rolls - all varieties (shrimp, tofu and bbq tofu) are excellent.

The Pho is consistently excellent. 
The Pad Thai is only okay
Yellow Curry noodles are fantastic

The other upsides, of Citrus Club
- inexpensive and great value
- if you're going solo, you can usually get a seat at the bar immediately 
- good for medium sized groups
- take out is ready quickly 

Be sure to grab a piece of the free candy on the way out the door!
author: Doug C.

description: I Love this spot!  The portions are gigantic and loaded with delicious veggies.  I like coming here and sharing an order of spring rolls, salad, and soup with a friend.  The ambiance is nice and they play good music.    I would recommend the hot and sour vegetable soup- it is my #1 cold cure when I am under he weather, and the citrus salad with cilantro dressing is awesome.
author: Chelsea C.

description: CC used to be my goto spot for peanut noodles (and the thai coconut curry shrimp wonton soup that is like crack), but lately it just hasn't been as good.  It makes me sad.  I used to drive up to the city from Cupertino to get CC noodles.  I don't know what happened, but it makes me sad that Citrus Club isn't as yummy anymore.
author: Meghan S.

description:
As new residents of the neighborhood, my wife and I are trying all the restaurants on Haight street.

We found Citrus Club to be interesting -- and very inexpensive. The food was fine, not bad but not anything special.

The Pad Thai had a creamy, peanutty sauce ... and was nothing like Pad Thai. It was actually sort of tasty, but you had to tell yourself that what you were eating was not the standard Thai noodle staple.

The Spicy coconut lemon chicken was also okay ... though not spicy at all. It also seemed a bit creamy for an Asian noodle dish.

The waitress and busboy were very nice and attentive, but the hostess was kind of cold and slightly bitchy.
author: Ron E.

description:
ew.  i'm so annoyed.  giant cheap bowls of noodles that have almost no flavor?  i think the people who line up to eat here are the people who love paying $5.00 for a gargantuan mediocre burrito they can get two meals out of.  i don't care that it's not "authentic" asian food, i mean if it tastes good i'll eat it, but really for $8.95 you could get a ten times as tasty bowl of pho at almost any vietnamese place in the city.  the pad thai was equally gross as it was loaded in sauce and littered with pieces of unripe tomato.  tomato in pad thai??

i did however think the waitresses were cute and pleasant and enjoyed the slight "american ex-pat in in hanoi visiting the ladies of asia den of iniquity" vibe they were rocking.  actually now that i think of it it's total yellow fever that keeps people coming here because the food is CRAP.
author: Jessie J.

description: I come here for soup... tried a couple other things before and they were pretty good but if theres not a long wait I like to come to get the beef noodle soup. Garlic edamame yummy snack while waiting for soup too :) Prettydark, long waits, small & wait staff not the friendliest but overall A-ok
author: Alyssa S.

description: Do you know how much I LOVE Citrus Club? Probably not. The vegetable soup with tofu and noodles (Sa Choy?) is probably one of my favorite things on earth. It's always screamin' hot... with fresh veggies...and the tofu is cooked just the way I like it. I wish there were a Citrus Club in Philly. I miss you Citrus Club.
author: Jessica W.

description:
I went here the other week with a friend of mine for dinner. This restaurant is a really great place for Asian fusion noodles. We started off with the house-garlic edamame and it was really good; I highly recommend it. The soy sauce and garlic flavors compliment each other.

For my entree, I had Spicy Lime and Coconut Noodles. The flavors were great but personally, I realized that I don't like cold noodles. The prices are good for the huge amount of food that they give you. Definitely two, maybe three meals in one dish. 

The only thing that I didn't like about the restaurant is that it's so dimly lit. They try to create a romantic, candlelit atmosphere but really, it should just be a fun restaurant where people come and get cheap, good food. 

Even though my dish wasn't the most fabulous thing this time, I would definitely go back and try other entrees. 

Service was good and parking is what you would expect for the Haight.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
generous helpings at reasonable prices. everything I've had has been a tad under-seasoned, but still worth the trip.

The gf got a huge bowl of soup while I went for the garlic beef over noodles. incredibly quick service and friendly enough waitresses.  try the coconut lemon chicken or shrimp wonton soup. you may need to spice it up yourself, but it's a delcious palette to work with.
author: Seth S.

description:
This is a pretty good place to go for an overwhelmingly large bowl of vegan noodle soup.

The wait was kind of long, but it was a Saturday night.  Once seated, the service was good.  I had the Thai coconut tofu soup, which was mild, yet tasty.  The price was extremely reasonable.

If I were ever feeling a bit under the weather, this would definitely be the place to go and get a huge bowl of soup and some sake.  Instant wellness.
author: steve m.

description:
OK, I just picked up my pho ga (chicken noodle soup). It's really awesome--put in some chili sauce, plum sauce and a squeeze of lemon (which all comes in the bag with the bean sprouts and fresh basil) and you are in hot soup heaven. Not to mention it being a very healthy meal.

However, the woman behind the counter has the personality of a turnip. Do I care? not particularly. I didn't ding her a star for it.  I just grab my grub and go. Information gladly given, but please refrain from unnecessary  conversation.
author: Donna B.

description:
Alright! So, I went to the Citrus Club last night with a friend for the first time. This tiny place sure has great turnover - and with good reason. First off, the place is small and people are packed pretty close together. This causes it to be bit noisy at time, but it's all part of the fun atmosphere there. If your party is larger than two people, you may have to wait a bit since most tables seat only two. 

As with most noodle houses, the food is super tasty, is a generous portion and cheap. There's a good selection of choices, either pan fried noodles or noodles in soup. You can order beer, wine and a select list of hard alcohol drinks as well. I walked away with a bill under ten bucks and plan to do so again next time.
author: Michael A.

description:
I love taking people from out of town to the Citrus Club. It's reasonably priced - last week the total for 3 entrees, apps and tea was around $30 - and there is always something on the menu that matches everyone's taste. If I lived in the Upper Haight, I would eat there every day. The hot and sour soup is to die for (all variations); the beef Pho is the best you'll get without lurking some hole in the Loin. Always quick, down-to-business, friendly service - even when busy. It's got more of a modern flair than a typical Thai/Vietnamese restaurant, but that's what makes this place great - it feels authentic, yet it's like a step above the ordinary drab surroundings found in similar places around the City. I always manage to miss the crowds when I visit the Citrus Club... knock on wood! 

I had to alter my star rating a bit because I have gotten super mushy noodles before. Also, if you get soup to go, make sure you have another bowl handy wherever you go... The container they give you is large, very flimsy and isn't great for taking somewhere like GGP (2 blocks up Haight).
author: George R.

description:
I tried the Hot & sour soup-  It was awesome! But be prepared to sweat! I also liked their garlic edamame; yum.

The reason why I took off a star is becuase of the service; it took too long to get some!
author: Grace H.

description:
Yes, you will probably have to wait in line and there is a slight chance your waitress will be slightly sassy...but who cares (you'll get over it). This place is great and I will tell you why.

1. Hot and Sour Soup
2. Peanut noodles with chicken
3. Thai iced tea
4. BBQ tofu spring rolls (aka: my reason for living)
5. If you order soup to-go, all of the ingredients come in separate containers to avoid getting mushy. My roommate gets take-out a lot, and the soup lasts a while like this.
6. Once you sit down, service is quick & efficient
7. Citrus Club + movie at the Red Vic across the street = amazing night you will never forget.
author: Elena M.

description:
There are all sorts of things you can legitimately complain about when it comes to the Citrus Club:


 long wait
no parking
not very authentic cooking


 But I think there is more to love about it.


 The amount of food vs. price ratio has to be among the highest in San Francisco.


 I have no idea what you people are talking about, I've always found the service to be really friendly and efficient enough.


 Food comes fast.


 At 6 or 7 bucks per entree, ya'll need to stop whining.
author: RugJones

description: Huge fan of any of their soups!  Have had the coconut curry, hot and sour and a few others!  Soups always have very deep flavors and are large portions.  Staff is not necessarily the most hospitable, but their soups make up for it!  I am not a huge fan of their pad-thai or Singapore noodles.  I will stick with the soups and avoid their pan fried items!  LOVE the SOUPS!
author: Adrienne B.

description: Portions are large and prices are affordable thus the 4 stars. Some dishes are really bland but others make up for it. You just have to try and see which ones to cross off your list. They get really busy so prepare for a wait but the staff run around like crazy trying to make it all happen so they do try hard. Avoid the bathroom is you can.
author: Moe Moe M.

description: This place used to be amazing, but the last 4 times I've eaten here the food was horrible. The poor food safety score has followed the downward trend in food quality. The last time I ordered from here the vegetables in my soup were rotten (not an exaggeration -- they were gray with what looked like mold), the edamame was overcooked, and there was a random piece of meat in my vegetarian dish. I used to love this place, but the quality has decreased so drastically that I can no longer give this place a 5 star rating.What a shame!
author: Kate S.

description: I had heard good things about Citrus Club's soups, and decided to drown my cold in their hot brothy goodness this morning since I've got the sniffles. We ordered the chicken pho and the curry soup with shrimp dumplings, and sadly, both were just meh. It made me think that maybe the Citrus Club is trying to do too much. I mean, can we really expect them to serve the best of Thai, Vietnamese, Indonesian, etc, etc like their menu promises? Perhaps they should narrow it down to a country or two.
author: Nicole G.

description: Say you're with your friends, and one of you wants vietnamese, the other wants japanese, the other wants chinese. If you can't decide on one, then Citrus Club is the answer because it has all sorts of asian noodles! It's also fun, casual, and cheap. Now of course the pho or soba or chow fun isn't gonna taste like a place that specializes in one kind of food, but for a place that has all these varieties, it's pretty damn good.
author: Emy s.

description: Came here with some friends last week and don't really see what all the fuss is about.  I had the beef and broccoli special which was served atop noodles that were flavored with a fair amount of honey.  It was tasty, but nothing to write home about.  Were it just the food I'd give the place 4 stars, but when taken into the context of the long wait for a table, slow service, and cramped space I'm just not seeing much of a reason to come here.  The menu also seems to lack any kind of focus other than offering Americanized takes on foods from various Asian countries.   Not a terrible place to eat, but nothing worth seeking out either.
author: Joshua W.

description: When we entered the restaurant, it looked small so we sat at the bar. We didn't realize there was more seating toward the back. I ordered the pho and it was served in a generous bowl. It had a sweet aroma I never smelled from pho before. It was very pleasant. The ginger tea was very good. Overall, I thought the food and service was great.
author: Siv L.

description:
ordered:
- garlic beef and shitake mushroom noodles. excellent! delicious and full of stuff
- orange and mint salad. bad! the description is deceptive since it's just a ton of noodle with few greens
- spring rolls: good! spicy, fresh and fulfilling.
- banana with coconut ice cream. it was kinda harsh since we will never have anything as good as this dessert, ever

story: we never returned anything at a restaurant before but we had to this time. the "salad" was a bland mistake and our waitress gave us some looks at first but was totally cool afterward. I think she even gave us an extra scoop of ice cream =)

overall, great place with excellent staff. the wait can be a bit long, but hey, you can take a nice walk to the panhandle or just go down haight to pass the time. the lights can get too dim and if you sit in the wrong chair, you'll be right next to the bathroom door WAFT. 

don't order any salad.
author: ZacKandMeL M.

description: We ordered Shang Hai noodles and it was too salty and the appetizer was blan.
author: Kongkaew T.

description:
When my friend and I arrived, there was a small line forming out the door. We figured we'd have to wait awhile but since it was mid-week and only two of us, we got a table pretty fast. We ordered some drinks and noodle dishes. I ordered a rice noodle dish with tofu and sweet chili sauce. It was good but only if you like sweet/savory dishes. My friend ordered a coconut chicken dish. Both were pretty good.

Over all the prices were really good, If we hadn't ordered drinks we'd have gotten out of there under 15 bucks total. The ambiance is nice and the service is okay.  The noodles took a little while and the wait staff wasn't too friendly.
author: Vikki P.

description:
Nummers in my tummers. My fav restaurant in my neighborhood. 
Go early because there can be a bit of a wait afer 6pm on most nights.
I recommend the fresh spring rolls ( best peanut sauce ever), garlic edamame, and the shitake beef noodles.
author: Kathleen T.

description: Coconut lime buckwheat noodles...I dream about them.  In fact, I want them now.  Coconut-y, tangy lime with a spicy kick...are they freal?  Omg.  The pho is EH, skip it.  This place rules.
author: Emily T.

description: Man, this place is incredible. I dream about it and have to force myself to try other places because this is always my go-to.
author: Hanan H.

description: by far the worst "thai food" i've ever had.  The food tasted like it was in the garbage before they put it on our plate our swear it was sooo bad
author: Astrid I.

description: Went here on Sunday after the AIDS walk. I've never heard of this restaurant but as my friends and I were walking, we saw this place was pretty crowded so we decided to try it. crowded usually means pretty good food. I ordered the Yellow Coconut Curry Tofu with chicken and it was pretty good. Not the best tasting curry I've ever eaten though. The BIG negative comment I have about The Citrus Club is that our server was pretty rude. She flat out told my friends and I that it would take about 30 minutes to seat us and maybe its better for us to not eat there. Seriously, what kind of server says something like that? I DEFINITELY would NOT eat here if my friend didn't want to try this restaurant so badly.
author: Vicky P.

description:
I am never let down by this place.  AMAZING.  Worth waiting in line for.  Very affordable, great food.  The garlic edamames are DELICIOUS.  I can't ever get enough of them.  I make it a habit to mix the rest of the sauce left over with my noodles.  FYI, Garlic Shrimp Noodles w/out shitake mushrooms is fantastic.  The alcohol is great.  Electric Lemonade and the orange margaritas are so good, I recommend them.  If you're not up for alcohol, I highly recommend the Ginger tea.  Sweet and totally what I wasn't expecting.  A very pleasant surprise.  

Run now.  I'm on my way out the door!
author: Olivia S.

description:
Citrus Club is great.  I order take more than I would like to admit as I often loiter at Cold Steel (right across the street).  I love all the soups, but beware, the carrots are still pretty crispy and quite large in area, though not in thickness.  I hate curry and coconut but somehow I love this joint.  The peanut sauce that comes with the Vietnamese spring rolls is...well...it's the reason I order them!  

Forget getting a seat without at least a ten minute wait if you show up after 700.  
I would not recommend showing up with more than four people.  Two is best for faster seating times.
Take out is great...fifteen minutes max, even when they are swamped.  Big fan of take out.
author: Kelley W.

description: I ate here a few months ago with some friends, and it couldn't have been more delicious. Had a chicken orange noodle salad. It was exactly what I needed on a rainy afternoon. The portions are huge and the prices fair. I wish they were located where I live now :(
author: Grace H.

description: I have to update my review based on subsequent experiences. Great food, huge portions, great price. Go for the coconut curry soup, stay away from the Pho. Great friendly service.
author: M L.

description:
Miso had a strange sweet taste I could imagine other people  being into it. The garlic edamame also had that sweet taste and was over cooked. The lemon coconut chicken was bland and the chicken had that freezer burned chicken taste.

Near so many better options there's no reason to ever go there again.
author: Ben G.

description: This place is right around the corner from us. Great inexpensive noodles. The pad Thai is different, more creamy, the peanut sauce is yummy---fresh rolls with tofu or shrimp recommended, cold coconut or citrus noodles reall good with shrimp too. Awesome shitake and shrimp noodle dish. Overall great value for the price. :)
author: Alex S.

description: For some reason I have always wanted to try The Citrus Club. Every Sunday when I head to the Haight for some Pork Store breakfast I am intrigued by the words 'noodle house'. Finally our time came to try it out after returning our zipcar after a long hectic starving-in-traffic trip. We ordered the special appetizer which was garlic string beans with tofu and red bell peppers. This dish was a-m-a-z-i-n-g. So flavorful from the garlic, red chile and soy, I wish it was my main dish atop a mountain of noodles. I decided to go simple with my entree, got the peanut noodles with julienne carrots and cucumbers plus bean sprouts. The nice thing about this dish was that it came with tons of crushed peanuts so it had plenty of texture. And the serving was huuuuuuge, hello today's lunch! My bf enjoyed the sweet chili noodles with tofu and greens. Another big serving with plenty of veggies and firm tofu with a bizarre but addicting sweet flavor. Service was friendly and quick, and the $4 Sapporo on tap was nice. I'd love to come back and try the bbq tofu satay, the bbq tofu fresh rolls and one of the veg noodle soups.
author: Cori W.

description: I like the food here, and it is a pretty good bargain.  I would personally like more spice in the dishes, but that is my personal preference.  I would rate this place with at least one more star, but the dive atmosphere does not warrant that.  The place should be gutted, and start all over again from scratch.  On the other hand, if this place actually got the facelift it needs, the prices would probably reflect it.
author: Dean F.

description: A big bowl of soup.  Not bad, but not particularly amazing.  And even though they had lots of tables available, they made me wait until my dinner companion was there before allowing me to sit down.  I'd suggest going elsewhere.
author: Douglas P.

description: The food was good but the service was AWFUL. we saw our waitress once to take our order, she didnt even bring us menus. The bus boy was running the restaurant practically. When we ate dinner our waitress did not give us the time of day and as soon as the bill came she would not stop hovering. it was incredibly rude. although the food was great, that poor poor customer service was a turn off.
author: Scott B.

description:
[edit] I've been back a couple of times since this review, because I now work in the area, and I'm adding one star because it's not crowded and obnoxious for lunch, and the food hasn't made me puke again.  But the food is still pretty nondescript and it seems like some of the different sauces are interchangeable. [/edit] 

UNSPEAKABLY AWFUL!  this may be the worst restaurant i've ever eaten at, and i eat at mcdonalds!  it was also packed on a saturday night, and i can't understand why.  i ordered the "pad thai," and the server brought me a bowl of noodles that were boiled for about 2 hours and covered with some kind of disgusting, slimy white alfredo sauce from a can.  nothing else in it but noodle mush and white sauce.  i looked around at the different dishes that everyone else at my table ordered, and it all looked like the same overcooked noodles in white glop sauce.  it makes me feel ill just thinking about it.  in fact a little while after i ate i went outside and puked on the sidewalk.  the menu was full of inane twaddle, too, something about cultivating a passion for noodles in their customers, so that we can in turn share our new-found passion for noodles with the rest of the world.  oh great, just what i need, to cultivate a passion for (pitifully, disgustingly prepared) noodles.  i can't wait.  and another bit about their soba noodles being particularly "healthy" soba noodles.  as opposed to what--poison soba noodles?  do their noodles contain 2 hours' worth of vigorous excercise and a sensible outlook on life?  i wonder what exactly makes their strings of flour and egg healthy, while the strings of flour and egg at other restaurants are unhealthy.  this place sucks, i forget what i paid but it was 100% a waste of money.  i hope the owners lose their shirts.  our server was pretty cute though, and i hoped she would lose her shirt, too!
author: Mynameisdavid M.

description:
i've had some serious hits (shanghai noodles, spicy coconut lemongrass chicken over spinach noodles, the special edamame, chicken noodle soup when i have a cold) and i've also had some misses (the icky boring spring rolls, the questionably bland coconut soup, sketchy service).

citrus club is in my neighborhood and is pretty much a go to for noodles on the fly and on the budget! You can get two excellent meals out of one 7-10$ entree.  My personal favorites are the shanghai noodles (beef, mushrooms, tofu with udon noodles and a yummy sauce) and the lemongrass coconut noodles (i sub chicken for shrimp and loooove the creamy lemongrass coconut sauce and the weirdly electric green spinach noodles!).

my only gripe with citrus club is that i always want to yknow....expaaaaaand my culinary horizons but each time i deviate from my preferred club order, i walk away disappointed.

life lesson: stick to what you know and stick to what you like.....at least at citrus club.
author: Brooke M.

description: I can't believe that I haven't written a review on this place yet.  I've been coimg here for a few years and I can say its always good.  I love the noodle soups and kinda crave them.   The line can be a little long at times but its worth the wait.  Once you sit down, service is pretty fast.  Try the garlic edamame and the tofu spring rolls!
author: Rachel C.

description: Excellent, fresh and cheap.  My favorite dish is the coconut noodle soup with tofu.  The cold basil coconut noodles are super tasty as well.  I also like to change things up a little and order the BBQ tofu spring rolls, which are unique and delicious.  They are very accommodating if you want to share dishes, so I recommend ordering a bunch of things and trying them all.  Cute interior, fast service.  One of my favorite noodle places in the city.
author: Kristin P.

description: Really horrible, uninspired tasteless food. How people WAIT IN LINE to eat here is beyond me.
author: Maria D.

description: Good noodles, big portions, friendly staff and clean.  It's a nice place to enjoy a good meal.  The sake margarita was interesting.  Like nothing I'd ever tried before.  It's a great place to visit if you're on Haight and don't feel like pizza.
author: Corey V.

description:
two words: garlic edamame.

well, I like more than that, but it's the garlic edamame that I dream about ...

Citrus Club is consistently what it is. I love soup; I could eat noodle soup three times a day every day of the week, so CC regularly hits the spot. thankfully I live around the corner - if I had to find parking in that neighborhood I might never go ...

the place is always packed, so I very rarely eat in. it's not packed because it's amazing at what it does. CC is packed because of aforementioned consistency, its price [very reasonable], and it's overall healthy bend. to-go is fast [10 minutes tops] and I have CC on speed-dial. a favorite.
author: Rachel W.

description: Inexpenive but really tasty pan-asian cuisine, perfect for noodling around: they come in all sizes and flavors, from cold noodles in Asian salads with "citrusey" dressings to soups and wok-tossed. Yum Yum!
author: Nish N.

description: I love noodles. I tried a dish with chicken, broccoli, and a peanut sauce. Super yummy. Took home the leftovers and ended up finishing them later that night.
author: Nicole F.

description: Mmmm.. i heart the citrus club..  I love that you don't need a reservation (sure, you have to write your name on a list, but that's cool with me), and that they always seem to have delicious specials..  Noodle soups are tasty, salads are flavourful, and portions are healthy enough so that I usually end up eating the leftovers for lunch the next day.  I always leave fully sated.  Yum.
author: Dennis Y.

description: Really good and fresh food. Had peanut noodles with tofu, yum.
author: Lauren S.

description:
If this place wasn't just around the corner from our house we probably wouldn't bother eating here. Alas, for those nights when we're too lazy to cook and craving noodles we get take-out from here.

Most of our experiences with Asian fusion has been pretty good. This place...eh. We've eaten here at least half a dozen times and still have only found 2 dishes that we like. Not even love, just really like. And we end up getting them in addition to another dish we're willing to brave ordering. 

The garlic edamame is pretty good. Hard not to please us with the combo of two of our most favorite things to eat.

The garlic beef and shiitake mushroom with chow-fun is our go-to. We've tried it with prawns, but found the beef much more satisfying with the dish's sauce. 

The other upside to this place is the huge portions. We always have leftovers.

As for the stuff we've tried but didn't jive with: 

Pad Thai: weird, soupy dish with tomatoes. I know it's a fusion, but of what??? So totally put off by it, and didn't taste anything like pad thai.  I would never have guessed that this was supposed to be pad thai.

Peanut Noodles: just...peanuty. That's pretty much it. Not much flavor to it but peanuts. Slightly sweet, but that's it. Very bland.

Korean Short Ribs: over-cooked, dry, bland. Husband ate it up anyway, didn't want to waste it. The garlic noodles it came with was tasty. That's pretty much it.

So, unless we're really craving chow-fun (and specifically their chow-fun), we don't go here.
author: S. C.

description: I always have a pretty good meal here. The Mandarin style chow mein is really tasty and the service is usually quick and courteous. It won't blow your mind, but it's cheap and pretty darn delicious. If your on or near Haight, it's probably your best option, for sure.
author: Michael E.

description: After reading reviews of The Citrus Club I decided to give it a shot. Came here last Saturday for lunch with my girlfriend and this place moderately met my expectations. Upon arrival, we were seated right away. We ordered edamame for an appetizer which was reasonable. My gf ordered the house pad thai and I ordered the shrimp curry noodles. A big fan of pad see ew, the noodle game was different, but a change from the norm and I this dish made me more of a fan. They didn't put much shrimp in the dish but that's a given for most places. The house pad thai was really good. The portions of the two dishes we had were good enough to feed 3-4 people. Prices were a bit sketchy, but for the portions, it's reasonable.
author: JJ N.

description: I went to there weekday, so place is not busy. I like inside! I chose shrimp wan tan soup with noodle. It was a lot of noodle. I couldn't finish. But soup was good! I like it.
