My bf chose chaw men. Yes i like it too. If i go to there, i will try chaw men!! And so cheep! I saved money!! But i used taxi..... cost was more...taxi... But really i want to go to again!
author: Ria D.

description: My first thought was, "I don't get it", but the place was crowded for a reason. There is nowhere to stand and if you sit at the bar, the diners waiting for their table are standing over you and staring at your enormous bowl of soup and drooling. Having said all that, the soup is to die for. The portions are ridiculous. I had lunch for two days. They sometimes have the shrimp won-ton special, which I highly recommend. Add some of that red sauce that sits at your table/bar, and you have yourself a winner.
author: E. N.

description:
FOLLOWUP 11/08: The Cipro that was prescribed seemed to kill whatever bug I acquired at the Citrus Club. It's very odd that the SF Health Department review now lists their "score" at "100%," even though the site previously listed the fact they were caught storing meat at ROOM TEMPERATURE in the "danger zone." When inspector went there, he measured beef sitting there at 60 degrees - apparently HIGHLY toxic and likely the cause of my poisoning there. Another inspector went there a MONTH later and Citrus Club STILL was caught storing meat in the "danger zone." Ridiculous. Luckily, I have printouts from the website AND the DPH that DO show this - but why DPH remove the facts once the restaurant got lucky/fixed the issues long enough to get a "good" inspection?

Why is the Department of Public Health NOT showing the *history* of a restaurant's inspections - this was MONTHS ago and certainly relevant to whether or not you are safe to eat at an establishment (or a hint at why you are vomiting and crapping all over a few hours afterward). I'm calling my supervisor today, the DPH inspection reports are useless without a track record available to diners/victims.

-------------
Careful where you dine - ESPECIALLY places you like. http://www.dph.sf.ca.us/eh/Violations/Loc_CurrentViol.asp?LocationID=2325

Last week I woke up with severe symptoms of food poisoning a few hours after consuming my favorite Citrus Club chow fun dish (which didn't taste like it usually does here). 36 hours later it was so bad I was in emergency room on IV. Really bummed, I used to like this place a lot.
author: Zen T.

description: One of San Francisco's best bangs for the buck. Be prepared for delicious noddles and soup that come in huge portions. Make sure to order the garlic edamames.
author: Alexandre d.

description: Decent, but bland.  Where is the fish sauce?  I had to compensate by dousing my soup with sriricha (sp?) sauce and hoisin sauce.  My big bowl of soup was all broth and there were hardly any noodles.  The sauce in one of the dishes was composed primarily of sugar.  I love cheap Asian food, but taste does not have to be a comprimise.  That being said, if I was in a bind in the Upper Haight, I would probably come back, but it would only make me miss my mother's cooking even more.
author: Tangerine L.

description:
Can you say FRESH???  I always feel like I'm getting the best and freshest ingredients here.  The service can sometimes be a bit slow, but I really understand given how busy that place is and how many take out orders are going out the door.

Extra plus that they have pear cider... it proves the perfect compliment to the super clean & crisp palate of the food.

I love the peanut noodles with chicken.  All white meat (which is important to me) and nicely tender.  Rubbery chicken is the worst & I've never seen sight of it there.

Two thumbs firmly up.
author: Kelly W.

description:
The Citrus Club is an excellent stop after visiting Haight Street's Amoeba Records. If you're feeling spontaneous, you can put your name down on the waiting list and *then* head over to Amoeba to kill some time before you're seated. 

The atmosphere is almost always crowded, and they don't take reservations, so be prepared to wait a few minutes if you're with a larger group. Usually, couples get in quicker due to the high number of two-person tables. 

Nothing beats their lemon-lime sake martini for starters. They offer a wide selection of spicy, sweet, and hot noodle dishes. Everything on the menu tastes great, that's the amazing thing about Citrus Club. However, if pressed, I'd absolutely recommend the vegetarian spring rolls and garlic edumame as appetizers, tiger shrimp over jade noodles or spicy coconut chicken as main courses. They also serve an exotic-tasting fried banana dessert which is *very* good and not too sweet.

Overall, it gets five stars for the lively, yet dimly-lit setting (which makes for a romantic and cozy date), excellent service, and affordability- dinner for two with appetizers runs less than 20 dollars.
author: Alex G.

description: for cheap, moderately healthy eats this is one of my favorite places. I go here with my boyfriend all the time and we get the garlic edamame, the vegetarian spring rolls, the marmalade noodles (spinnach noodles in a coconut cream sauce with shrimp, tofu, or both) and a small pot of tea--all to share--and it costs $20.50 before tip. I love this place! the miso soup is alse really good, and only costs like $3. It is probably on of the best cups of miso soup ever since they put lots of yummy stuff in like tofy, bok choy, and shitakes...highly recommended. Keep in mind this isn't fine diding, but for inexpensive food that is warming and comforting, but not greasy or gross--this is a great spot!
author: Amanda D.

description: Citrus Club serves good, cheap, healthy-ish food in a pleasant setting.  I am so excited to have finally discovered such a restaurant in SF.  Three of us shared three starters (garlic edmame - awesome!, tofu satay - fine, vegetable spring rolls - good), a huge bowl of noodle soup (fine), and two pots of tea, and we only spent $11 each (including tax and tip).  CC is an excellent value - I will surely return since it's just a short MUNI ride away from my apartment.
author: Grace W.

description: Good food - well-priced, good portion size. Quick service.  The tables are very close to each other...you might as well think you are eating in a campus dining hall.
author: Shweta V.

description: Took a gamble and lost! Menu looked interesting, but execution was extremely disappointing. As soon as we sat at the table we felt like we had made a wrong decision, the place is pretty grungy and smelled like a damp bar. Our waiter was a drone, his service was slow and less than mediocre. He was constantly checking his phone and texting, then handling plates coming out of the kitchen. Food was dismal, made with no care or pride, my pad thai was a gloopy soupy mess, not even edible. Not even close to what a pad thai is supposed to be! Would never go back.
author: man d.

description:
i may as well rent a booth here. not good for groups of 5 or more, the wait is awful. we do it a lot, but we have to wait:) it's always worth the wait;)

make sure you eat those candies they give you with the check. they are so amazing, i always steal a handful when i am leaving:) hehe
author: rachel F.

description: I love the Citrus Club and it is ALWAYS very dependable. Food is delicious and prices are very reasonable, I just wish they delivered. Yeah, I can be lazy especially when it's chilly & rainy, so I'd eat here more often if I didn't have to do pick-up. Always get the garlic edamame, soups are delicious, most noodles dishes are good(not so much on the curry tofu & nuts), love the spicy lime & coconut salad! If you are standing nearby - go inside!
author: Gwen V.

description: I volunteer nearby and we ordered dinner from Citrus Club a few weeks ago.  I've been craving peanut stuff lately so I went with Pad Thai with prawns.  When we got our food, my box was clearly labeled, but the contents were not even close to pad thai.  There were noodles, tofu, and some thick, coconuty sauce, but none of the peanut & prawn goodness that I was looking for.  It wasn't bad and there was a ton of food, but I was still disappointed.
author: Katie S.

description: I want to give them more stars, I really do. I love the garlic edamame, and the atmosphere is nice too. BUT the noodle dishes I've had there are really lacking in...well, flavor. And that just doesn't fly with me, baby.
author: Veronica B.

description: Pretty much a default spot for me when I can't decide on a place to dine. The servings are large! Food is good for the price. The best item on the menu, in my opinion, are the fresh spring rolls. Best in the city. If you want the spring rolls, do not arrive too late...they sellout often.
author: Victor I.

description: One of my favorite place in the city.... The noodles, soups, everything's good. And the price are amazinly cheap according to the portion! The only problem: it's crowded during the WE evenings.
author: Christine C.

description:
yum.  cheap.  yum.  

good eats, good sized portions, and inexpensive.  i don't care if they aren't "authentic" asian fusion, everything tastes good.  and they're always packed, so they must be doing something right.  i've taken 3 of my friends there recently at different times and they all loved Citrus Club too.  lots of vegetarian/vegan options too.  i like to sit at the bar - since they're always so busy, that's the best way to get seated right away, and it's perfectly fine for 2 people.  and the service is fast.

and for dessert - green tea ice cream w/ nigori (unfiltered, milky white, sweet) sake poured over it in a martini glass - TRY IT!

great place to go for a quick bite before or after a movie at the red vic or hours of browsing the stacks at amoeba records.  or to warm up w/ a nice hot bowl of udon after a walk in the park.
author: Suzanne A.

description: Yummy noodles and spring rolls. There dishes aren't very authentic or heavily flavored but good nonetheless. They have a great chicken soup too and the prices are excellent. For some reason, I must have a Hefeweizen when I eat here. It just goes good with the food here.
author: Scott M.

description: I've taken everyone here my parents, people visiting me from out of town, my boyfriend, etc. The food is great -I esp. like the garlic shitake noodles, chicken soup, and the tofu spring rolls (stay away from anything curry). The portions are huge and the atmosphere is warm. Service is ok -the waitresses & waiters could smile once in a while or something.
author: Kat F.

description: I've come here multiple times because the options on Haight are just limited and they are usually better than the rest of the bunch.  But today, I order the pad thai and I ask for chicken when it usually comes with shrimp.  What I get is pad thai but smothered with I dunno, peanut sauce?  I think they just slopped on some other chicken dish on top of my noodles to make it with chicken.  So it ended up being one soggy mess.  I didn't bother to bitch because I waited long enough for it to arrive.  I picked out the noodles to eat but never again.
author: Pelle Y.

description: Haven't eaten here in ages- but I was around the area and it sounded like it would hit the spot. Well unfortunately it missed the spot...i just find their food a bit bland, like it's missing an essential seasoning and I can't put my finger on it. I had their special, which was the Ginger Chicken over Garlic nNoodles...it was good but it can use a little "umph"...other than that if you haven't been- i say it's worth checking out and tell us what you think?!
author: Jaimee T.

description: This place is pretty much perfect.  I especially recommend it for a cloudy/rainy day.  If you are sick its even better.  Enormous bowls of fragrant broth and heaping mounds mounds of noodles, vegetables, and/ or meat make everything better. And its quick and easy.  This is one of those places that is more than the sum of the parts.
author: adam b.

description: I am sorry, but I love this place. Yeah, the waitstaff can be rude, and slow, and totally forget your order, but that is part of its appeal. The food rocks and the sake is good. I have always been a follower of good, cheap noodles and soups, and Citrus Club takes the cake
author: Sara A.

description: I like this place, but I'm never blown away by it.  The food is really reasonably priced, though, and I always leave with leftovers, so bonus points for that.  Some of the dishes are a bit bland for me, so I can't give this restaurant four stars.  It's definitely worth a stop if you'd like a decent, inexpensive lunch while shopping in the Haight, or prior to bopping around the neighborhood for cocktails after dinner.
author: Kathleen P.

description: OK so I had the beef soup...its was alright, I just wasn't impressed with the only thing being in the soup but pieces of beef some chives and noodles, I was looking for more veggies ya know?? Oh and the other thing was, it took kinda long and it wasn't even really that busy. I was kind of bummed by how long it took.  I didn't have a drink there but i saw the menu and they have a lot of fun stuff for drinks so if your looking for drinks with your lunch theres the place! The girls that work there are really sweet too.
author: Sloane G.

description: Great menu, great specials, great take-away, great staff. Thai coconut shrimp wonton soup. I salivate when I think of this soup. The hot and sour soup is good, too, but in no way comparable to the Thai coconut. I daydream about eating this soup and it is a sure-fire cure to a down-and-out, crummy day. In this case, I suggest bringing the soup home and sitting in front of the boob tube, watching The Jersey Shore, or your respective guilty pleasure.
author: Megan D.

description:
The chicken egg-drop soup is incredible.

The Good:  Honestly, the chicken egg-drop soup reminds me of my grandma's chicken noodle soup and I can't get enough of it.  Seriously, my friends make fun of me because no matter how many times we go, I order the same thing.  Absolutely everything is good, but I've been stuck on my favorite for a while.

The Bad:  It gets super crowded and the wait can be quite long.  Most of the staff is really nice, but there are a couple of waitresses that aren't.

The Ugly:  The quality of this place was down for a while.  I had dropped from my almost weekly visits to once every few months, but they're back baby!  I'm there almost weekly again, and it's amazing broth and perfectly cooked noodles every time!
author: Scott L.

description: Not fancy, but if you are in the mood for a filling, healthy, quick meal--this is the place.  The soup bowls are almost embarrassingly large to call it a personal soup bowl, but I can manage to eat it all usually!  Chicken egg drop soup is a favorite, but the noodle dishes are great too.  You can be in and out of here in 30 minutes if you want with comfort food that does not weight you down.  Excellent value for every day.
author: Rita G.

description:
Really the only restaurant in the Haight worth going to.

I lived a block away from Citrus Club for 3 years and would always get takeout from there. The garlic edamame is a must for any first timer, but everything is good. 

Citrus Club is an island of goodness in an ocean of mediocre to bad restaurants in the Haight. I'm not sure if it's high rent that drives other good restaurants away, or something else, but most of the other places just aren't that great and seem to cater to tourists. Cha Cha Cha is the other exception for tastiness, but the place is too popular for it's own good and you'd be better off going to the mission if it's tapas you want.
author: J B.

description: Cheap bowls of noodles - stir-fried or in a soup. But the true star are the wok-tossed garlic edamame. You'll stink like hell and no one will want to kiss you for a while. But who cares? This sh*t is delish! Don't come with more than 4 people. You might have to sit at separate tables or wait for ages to be seated.
author: Marie M.

description: I gave this place three stars because its right in the middle of what I think should be a sliding scale for these kinds of places.  And that scale slides depending upon two factors: the time and the amount of alcohol in one's bloodstream.  The later and drunker you are the better this place looks (especially if you want something other than a slice of pizza or lucky penny).  The earlier and more sobber, the more you realize that this is just cheap thai food set to a beat.
author: Jason S.

description:
The first time I went here was such an amazing experience. The prices were incredible for the huge amounts of food we were given. The food was good too! I had the peanut noodles and was in love. You can take left overs home and they taste even better! 

However, the last two times I went I was rather disappointed. The service was poor and the food quality had gone down. But maybe I just need to go when theres less of a rush. Either way, I think its a great place to take a date. It's small but cute, lighting is perfect and the prices are awesome!
author: Navi K.

description: It took me too long to find this hole in the wall little cave of thai love. It's a cute setting, though rather tight inside. Good date place. Dimly lit, red themed and the portions are great for the price. Good for veggies and noodles. mmmph! I'm a sucker for shitakes. I'm also quite picky about pad thai, and this one is deliiiiiicious.
author: Jessica P.

description: Damn good value here. Hands down best chicken noodle soup in San Francisco. If you ever get sick and need some chicken noodle soup, then this is your spot. This is not your Mom's chicken noodle soup, but it will knock your socks off. When I walk into the citrus club, I am immediately reminded of the scene from Swingers where Vince Vaughn and Jon Favreau meet the cocktail waitress and Dorothy for drinks. ANYWAY...... you will get a solid meal here under fifteen bucks.
author: John S.

description: Thai cuisine on Haight is no rarity. I'll keep this short. As far as noodle houses... these dishes are fucking amazing. And cheap. Cheap + amazing = Chamazing. Garlic Beef and Shiitake, wow. Soups (pho like) wow. Shrimp and mint leaf spring rolls? Double wow. Great drinks, cool Pan-Asia meets  Haight tacky interior, super quick, great and friendly staff, and delcious. Since I moved to the upper Haight I have eaten here at least once a week. It puts the Yum in Tom Yum Gai.
author: Jonny C.

description:
simply b/c i cannot give every review a rating of 3+, citrus club gets a TERRIFIC (not terrible) TWO! the hot hearty heaping helpings of noodles  are a booming bang for your buck, a beautiful balance of quantity and quality. some of the veggie noodle dishes, meh..any of the spicy goodness with galactic garlic, marvelous. casual, comfy and cozy!

psst: do not sign in on the clipboard under a stage name such as donkey! or donald duck, the hostesses don't find it as hilarious as you or i do.
author: Hae-Jin K.

description: How could a combination of noodles, delicious vegetables, tofu and peanuts be so incredibly boring that I got bored eating it? I do not know. But this place has some of the most boring food I have ever eaten, even though it sounds good on paper.  I think I could have done a much better job with the same ingredients at home, which is saying an awful lot, since I am not exactly a natural chef.
author: Rebecca H.

description: This place is so cute and has an amazing selection of Japanese, Chinese, and Thai noodles! Really inexpensive, I shared a salad and noodle bowl with a friend and we STILL wound up with food comas, each of us, haha.
author: Christy M.

description: Nothing fancy, just huge, delicious piles of noodles. If you want cheap/good/plenty (which I often do) go to Citrus Club. You might have to wait a bit, but it's never bugged me. Very vegan-friendly.
author: Jami W.

description: I went to citrus club last night for the first time after hearing rave reviews of cheap tasty eats from friends for years.  I ordered the coconut curry tofu soup.  The portion size was huge.  I could probably have fit my head in the soup bowl without too much trouble. The flavor was good and spicy.  There maybe could have been a little more variety in the vegetables in the individual dishes.  That's my only complaint.  Prices are extremely reasonable too.  With tax ad tip my half of the bill was about $10.  I will definitely go back to try some of the other yummy looking items on the menu.
author: logan y.

description: Can't beat it for a pool-sized bowl of soup for six bucks.
author: Alison C.

description: Very reasonably priced with huge portions. Service is usually pretty good too. I'm a fan of the Thai Coconut Noodle Soup and the Spring Rolls.
author: Kori M.

description:
this place is ok,  maybe it was just my experience.  we were seated promptly at arrival, but one thing that REALLY threw me off were the flickering lights.  i'm sure they were attempting to dim the lights to a nice ambient level, but it was so sporadic that the lights would beat full blast then two seconds later i'd be eating in the dark.

the food had a lot of flavor, but i don't know if its a good or a bad thing.  maybe it was too much of a mediocre flavor.  i dont know.  overall,  i'd say i'd eat here if i had to, but if i had the choice i'd choose somewhere else.
author: Stephanie C.

description: Super nice staff and the food is fast! This is a great little place where they seem to be cooking all around you. I do like it in here better off peak to sit at the bar for the attentive service and to watch them cook these huge amounts of food. Service is pretty good even when they are packed, and that is a lot of the time. Take out is also great because of the quality of the food. Call ahead and double park because if you do find a spot you might as well stay and get some drinks. Fresh tasty food, bbq tofu rolls, pad thai, noodles, I haven't had anything I didn't like here and you get a ton of it.
author: William R.

description: I like this place.  It isn't my favorite, or a a go-to place, necessarily, but I've been here a couple of times, and remember liking it.  It is a little cramped, but the dim lighting creates a nice ambiance.  My last trip put me at this table adjacent to the bathroom, though- not my preferred place to sit and eat, however.  Still, I ordered a specialty item... some beef w/ broccoli dish.. or something like that.  I shared this plate with my date, who ordered the Grilled Ginger Chicken, which I thoroughly enjoyed more than my dish.  Very flavorful I thought.  Anyway, I'll probably go back at some point.
author: M S.

description: Agree with Todd H. - ordered pad thai and was very dissappointed. There are other things on the menu though that are better, like fresh spring rolls and garlic chicken.
author: Marina S.

description: Whenever I crave Asian Fusion, my boyfriend and I like to go here. They have the Tom Ka which I like to get with won ton (it's on the special list) and another favorite for appetizers is the seafood salad with tofu. It is so refreshing and delicious. Today I also had the garlic green beans with tofu stir-fry for an app and it was sooooo savory. I have never had a problem with Citrus Club and it's often busy so beware because sometimes there is a line. The service is pretty good and the atmosphere is pleasant.
author: Veronica C.

description: Great value - lots of food for what you pay.  Try the tom yum soup if you have a cold - best remedy for a cold ever!
author: Matt S.

description: I love this place. So cheap but still delicious and hip feeling. Great place for early dates where you want something cool but don't want to invest a lot of cash. The portions are pretty huge. the wasabi-roasted peas rock!
author: Leigh M.

description: I don't understand how this place is packed most of the time.  The food is horrible...and I live pretty nearby and have tried it 4 times, hoping to prove myself wrong.
author: k. w.

description: First of all, Asian Fusion is usually bad and this is no exception.  I ate some curry noodle concoction that was super bland.  But the kicker is that I went here on a weeknight with a couple of girlfriends to relax and have a mellow dinner.  We were still chatting and finishing our beers when the waitress started giving us the evil eye.  Ignoring her, we continued to talk, drink, etc.  A few minutes later, the waitress came over, and asked us to leave!?! Because they needed the table!!?  What? We were not even finished with our drinks?!?! What kind of service is that.  1 star for this place.  I will NEVER go back and I always tell this story every chance I get.
author: Alison O.

description: I love this place! Great food and cheap too! I've never had a bad meal here, and it's so inexpensive I never feel bad about getting a drink or two. Great atmosphere, like everyone else has said, if the wait is long there are plenty of places to hang out till your table is ready. This place is a bargain!
author: Elissa D.

description: I think the citrus club is pretty good. Ive been twice and each time I enjoyed it. The garlic edamame is fabulous and the serving sizes are huge so for the price its a great deal. Some of the noodle dishes are a little bland though, I had the orange citrus noodles with chicken and they were orangey but thats it, they really needed another dimension, like mint or cilantro, I had to add a bunch of soy sauce but then it was decent. On the other hand my bf's soup was fabulous so I think its kind of hit or miss on certain dishes. We had good service and it wasn't at all crowded at lunch time (the only time Ive been) All in all I find them to be a good cheap and fun noodle place.
author: Meg L.

description: i don't dine in much anymore, I leave smelling like some sort of fried food - clothes and hair just reek.  BUT, I order take out at least monthly.  I get the same thing and I LOVE it - jade noodles with shrimp, coconut and lemongrass.  Just watch Take out portions.  We got gypped once, but only once. Phew. The "mommy soup" also has helped during sicker times, but is low on flavor (how it should be for the purpose). Skip the saki martinis.  Get the Hef and maybe ginger hot tea.  Pad Thai is okay, citrus salad is big, refreshing, but not a complete meal, the veggie spring rolls need the peanut sauce, but still aren't great, but I do like the garlic edamame. Service is indifferent, but fast and they fix problems without a fight.  Cheap for the flavor and portion.  Friends tell me the beef soups are good, and remember, meats can usually be swapped and subbed for each other and/or tofu.
author: Lindsay B.

description: This is my favorite noodle place (Pomelo is also really good, but comes in #2). Lots of variety and not a lot of $$$. I keep going back for the garlic wok tossed edamame (it's good, just bring some gum to cool off that dragon breath afterward).
author: Russ T.

description: This place is decent. They have all different types of noodles from different Asian countries, from pho to pad thai to soba noodles. Portions are somewhat large, but i wish it wasn't so pricey (compared to a 5.75 bowl of pho at regular pho restaurants, i think the bowl of pho here is 7 or 8$, correct me if i'm wrong) but ingredients are fresh, I would know, they were getting vegetables and what not one time i was eating there and pushed it from the front of the restaurant, up the stairs, to the back.
author: Anh P.

description: I feel compelled to warn people that, if you order pad thai here, that is not what you will be getting.  Actually, it should be in quotes.  The "pad thai" comes smothered in a sticky, heavy peanut/coconut/something sauce on what appears to be bad fettuccine with some chunks of onions and tomatoes -- literally, not even an attempt to make the dish match what is listed on the menu.  The worst "pad thai" I've ever eaten, and I've tried a lot. Almost inedible and certainly not what I ordered!
author: Megan B.

description: If you love noodles the way I do, you should definitely eat here. If you can go for a weekday lunch, or off-time, go for it, as it is a small place with no reservations and often a long waiting list. The fresh rolls are divine and I love the orange-mint noodles! Their soups are huge and tasty, and the garlic beef is garlicy goodness. They also serve thai ice tea, a personal favorite splurg.
author: Aimee B.

description: I love the Tom Ka soup and the buckwheat noodle spicy coconut salad!!!!!
author: Jamie K.

description: Citrus specializes in Fusion cuisine, bringing together Thai favorites along with Chinese and other signature dishes. While I may not be to heads over heels regarding their noodle dishes, consistency makes Citrus one of the better choices for this area of Haight. The soups here are orgasmic, as Citrus dumps a hearty bowl of udon noodles, vegetables, and your choice of meat, tofu, or chicken into a succulent broth. I love the atmosphere here, and the staff is always willing to go out of their way for the customer. There is something to be said about their fine selection of music which always seems to be top notch. Amoeba is across the street......Reccomended.
author: Kenny G.

description:
fresh shrimp spring rolls
hot-sour shrimp noodle soup
orange sake martini 
large oolong tea

you can't go wrong with these... 

try it.
author: Dot K.

description: Normally, I don't tolerate long lines or bitchy waitresses.  After all, there are plenty of noodle joints in the city.  But this place is really that good.  I get the coconut prawns and load it up with plum sauce.  I am bursting at the seams after 1/2 of it, have lunch for tomorrow and spent less than $20 with beer, dinner and tip for someone who occasionally deserves it.  My new philosophy on Citrus Club is to treat the eye rolling when you ask how long the wait is and the hurrying you through dinner as entertainment and giggle at how silly they are.
author: Kerry M.

description:
its aight. 

i hate that this place is always packed with a bunch of people who think its actually good asian food. because its not authentic or anything its like the recipe for people who arent asian. 

but i do enjoy it none the less. i usually get the beef pho or the hot and sour soup is pretty damn good...even though everything on the menu sounds good i go back to the pho. they make everything really simple meaning theres only a few ingredients in the soup unlike traditional pho and you have to add hella shit to it to taste better. 

come here when its not a busy hour or you will wait forever. or get it to go. the service is hit or miss. some days its fast and other days you are waiting a while. 

they have tamarind candy they give you at the end of the meal, my friends and i play a game of how many can we steal from the jar on the way out. its very fun. 

the bathroom is really cool, its like part of the restaurant. by cool, i mean not cool, if you go here you will see what im talking about.
author: andree t.

description:
There are other places I prefer, but the food here is always satisfying and almost too plentiful. 

Oddly enough, every time I've come here is after seeing something at the Red Vic. I guess I just don't hang out in the Haight all that much.
author: Nicole A.

description: I love this place!  You should definitely have the BBQ tofu rolls or shrimp rolls(just vietnamese style spring rolls) with peanut sauce...sooo good..and simple!  How many times have you had Edammame?..sushi restaurants...trader joes...whereevs...Now have you ever seen wok tossed garlic edamamme anywhere else?  I have not and I keep my eye out.  If you like soup bowls as big as your head and creative noodle dishes this is the place...and the price is right! Very creative and simple...and hip for that matter:-)
author: Daniel Q.

description: I'm addicted to Citrus Club.  Truly.  Since moving to the Upper Haight two months ago, I have probably averaged having Citrus Club's Marmalade Coconut/Lemongrass Shrimp Noodles twice a week.  The portion size is large enough for two meals if you can take half home, which makes the price a VERY right $4 per awesome noodley meal.  The wait for your noodle order isn't very long, but, if you desire an appetizer, get the House-Garlic Edamame.  Seriously.  Now, I can't give a full five stars because 1) I've yet to find another dish as good as the MC/LS noodles, 2) the wait for a table, due to Citrus Club's popularity, is often unbearable, and 3) I don't like the idea that noodles can have such power over me.  This addiction isn't healthy; I need more variety in my diet, Citrus Club!  Awww, don't look so glum.  I'll always love you, Citrus Club!
author: Ben D.

description: Went here last night for dinner. Again had never heard of this spot before dining here. Inexpensive and yummy, non-greasy food. Big plates that will have you pretty full when you are done. Decent service. They don't take reservations and it seems to be really popular. Put your name on the list and prepare for a bit of a wait. But you could always have a quick drink at a nearby bar and come back.
author: Heather L.

description: I'm a fan!  I enjoyed the food and the drinks, and a lot of the menu was tempting.  Service was terrific.  The interior is unfortunately cramped.  My small group waited about 20 minutes for a table on a weeknight, which is reasonable.  Minus 1.5 stars for comfort.
author: Brett N.

description: Better dishes than your average noodle house, and much better atmosphere than the standard white walls/bright lights combo that seems to be the industry standard decor in these kinds of restaurants in San Francisco. Expect a wait on the weekends as this place is usually crowded.
author: Chris B.

description: First time going here last week and I loved it.  The low lights make it an excellent place for a date!  The soups and spring rolls we shared were so-so but we were really just there to drink.  Had a really tasty sake margarita, yum!
author: Mary R.

description: Started with the garlic edemame, which was fantastic, but it didn't just go downhill from there, it fell off a cliff. What a let down. My friend and I split 2 dishes, some sort of pepper sauce veggies and tofu and then the yellow curry tofu. Both claim to be spicy dishes, but not only were they incredibly mild, they had no flavor whatsoever. I had to cover them in siracha and hoisin sauce to even remotely enjoy it. Maybe other dishes are better, but I'm not trying again any time soon.
author: Jennie H.

description: This place is F#%^ AWESOME!! My friend took me here after work. He said one entree is good enough for 2 ppl. He ordered pho and I can't remember what I had. I think something with garlic and noodles MAYBE chicken or tofu (it was a few wks ago when I went) DAMN! cheap and SERIOUSLY way too big.
author: Christina C.

description: This place has been hit or miss lately. They need to add some flavor to the soups. Pretty cheap and big portions.
author: Raymond M.

description: I love their spicy lime and coconut cold soba noodles salad and they are 4,5$ too. Tasted also chicken noodle soup and, besides the humongous portion, the broth was really good. Maybe not a first-class noodle house (I don't even know if they are homemade) but pretty inexpensive, reliable and the atmosphere has something of an Amsterdam bordello to me, you know, that decadent dark-reddish intimate ambiance. I like it.
author: Dario B.

description: I'm glad I happened to see a "review near me" about citrus club, because I had been meaning to add it to my go-to list in SF.  Its a super busy place with long waits and loudness, but really good food. I got some spicy concoction last time and it was awesome. My girlfriend's dish wasn't as good, but still managed to disappear!
author: Nick H.

description: I sort of feel guilty writing this review because some of my coworkers love this place and strongly urged me to try it. However, I felt strongly enough to just go at it. There is nothing remarkable about The Citrus Club. There are so many other restaurants that offer similar, but better tasting food. I may have ordered the wrong dish, aka Shanghai Noodles, but I really can't understand how you can screw up a super simple noodle dish. Maybe they should have chosen to take on one type of Asian cuisine instead of trying to tackle them all. Two stars because I'm still curious as to why my coworkers love it, and I may come back to try the Garlic Beef and Shiitake Mushroom Noodles that they raved about.
author: Phoi B.

description: The Citrus Club is one of my favorite spots in San Francisco.  It's super-cheap and the noodle bowls are amazingly delicious.  It's a great option for vegetarian food in this corner of the Haight, and you definitely get your money's worth.  Love it.
author: Micaela L.

description: The general consensus after eating here is that it's fine and the portions are large, but nothing that we had really blew anyone out of the water.  The peanut noodles were more peanut than noodles, the coconut and lemon chicken noodle thing was more noodles than coconut and lemon, and the curry was pretty good but not stellar.  They do give you a ton of food, so that's nice, but it's a ton of reasonable but not overwhelmingly good food, so I don't know how much of a draw that is.  In some way, this is related to the whole, "don't buy something on woot.com just because it's a good deal if you never intended on buying it in the first place.  unless it's those sweet woot lights."
author: Dave E.

description: Much easier to bring a crowd here than to Ploy.  Great food and always a fun place to cram in with a bunch of friends.  Again, portions are always a little more than enough, so don't get carried away with the menu!  Very good.
author: Amy M.

description: Fresh heaping portions that make me feel good.  Rather than cooking in oils they cook with natural citrus.   Can't beat the price and this is a fun place with friends.  Once I had to wait at the bar for takeaway a few extra minutes and they gave me a complimentary beer - cool!
author: Nadia B.

description: Citrus is my local noodle place. It's good as far as cheap asian fusion places go. I give it four stars rather than three because service is quick and friendly. The peanut sauce is great for dipping your spring rolls in, and I'm a big fan of all their entrees. The actualy food quality is essentially mediocre, I mean, you won't leave the place going, "whoa that was the best meal ever", but it's better than a burrito or pizza or burgers, so if you're in the Haight, drop by for a quick tasty meal.
author: Tal K.

description: Just went to get takeout. The back part of the restaurant looked lovely and cozy all lit up in red. The crowded, cold, noisy hall where we waited to order and then for our food... was not so great. Still, I was excited to chow down once I got home and out of the rain and cold. The BBQ tofu spring roll appetizers were pretty good. Unfortunately my main entree--the mystery yellowish noodle tomato "Pad Thai" was oh so unappealing and I had to stop eating.
author: Beth L.

description:
nothing really tastes like its supposed to here (pad thai, especially) but you get a lot of food for cheap (well, they raised their prices about a year ago from super cheap now to just plain ol' cheap) and when there isn't a line (not sure why people line up for this place as there are other cheap eating options in the area) it's not the worst place to be on haight.

but only if you don't expect anything to taste the way they're supposed to.  anything in a soy-based black sauce will taste the same no matter what it's called. the beef mushroom wide noodle dish is consistently salty (i know cause i've had it a few times, but then again, i've had it more than once, so take that with a grain of salt, he he.).  also, anything thats is called spicy on the menu never is.  but you can fix that to a point with the sriracha-like sauce at your table - i say -like because theirs is a little less sweet, which is good.  their garlic edamame is ok.  they don't take AMEX.
author: Nikki F.

description: The citrus club is a great place to have cheap,quick,tasty asian food, fresh ingredients are what I enjoy the most here. The vegetarian spring rolls are so damn good what is in the sauce? also great to dine in or take-out. I have been here over 20 times so they must be doing something right.
author: stevo A.

description: I can't give it more than 3 because it's nothing special, but it's not bad either.  I was there when there was no wait, so that was great.  It's cheap and filling.  The garlic shrimp was garlicky and had a good deal of shrimp.  It was exactly what I signed up for, no more, no less.  Would I take people there to impress them?  No.  Would I go with other people who are sick of overpaying for everything in this city?  Yes, yes I would.
author: Rachel W.

description: Mmmmmm.... noodles. Cheap prices, huge portions. Good place to go with a group of friends.
author: Pamela B.

description: Amoeba and Citrus Club.  It's a perfect Sunday.  Any kind of noodle soup and you can't go wrong.  Super cheap.
author: Jon K.

description: The food is really great though. Very, very fresh. I like to get the soup to go. They bundle all the ingredients separately so it doesnt get soggy on your way home. Then you can make it how you like it. Its a really excellent date place. The lighting is perfect and it has a funky decor. There is usually a line though and it takes a while to get your food, so be prepared to make a long night out of dinner. And, I don't think they have real alcohol, only soju.
author: Jacey C.

description: Great food, big portions, cheap prices, kind of a semi local hole-in-the-wall place & an excellent wait staff working the floor. Been going here for a couple years now and the food is always consistently outstanding - my boyfriend and I go at least once every 2 weeks. He's big on the Pad Thai (get it with shrimp & chicken) I usually run the gamut from Marmalade Coconut Lemongrass Shrimp, Garlic Shrimp & Shitake Mushrooms, Garlic Beef & Shitake Mushrooms, Shanghai Noodles, Tom Ka (coconut soup) and yes I too am a fan of the Pad Thai Noodles...2 nights ago I had a new item and it was great! The Korean Spare Ribs over garlic noodles. The grilled flavor of the spare ribs with sauteed kale was incredible.
author: Michael E.

description: This may be the best bang for buck in the city, we went there(two of us) for dinner and had two apps, two entrees and a bitcher of Sierra Nevada, and with tip was still under fifty bucks(that is with a 20% plus tip for the stellar service).  I try to eat here at least once a month and bring as many new people as possible it is that good.
author: brian m.

description: No flavor at all, the satay is just plain grilled chicken and the "peanut sauce" was ground peanuts in coconut milk.  The food has little to no flavor at all, which is hard, but I don't think they season the food, not even salt and pepper.  If you order noodles in a peanut sauce you get noodles with peanuts on top and bland meat. I don't know why they are always so busy, there are two Thai places on the same block that blow this place out of the water.
author: Shani H.

description: I don't know why I didn't give it a 5.  Maybe because I had to sit way too close to people, but some might like that.  This place is pretty dang good!  I love garlic, so I got garlic beef with soba noodles.  Kicks the hell out of every noodle place I've been to thus far in this city.  Thumbs up, and won't drain your wallet
author: Amir B.

description: One of my favorite places in the city.... The noodles, soups, everything's good. And the price are amazingly cheap according to the portion! The only problem: it's crowded during the WE evenings. So if its after 8 plan on a drink at there bar before you get seated. Its worth the wait and the left overs!
author: Joe M.

description: I've never had anything bad to say about this place! EVERYTHING I've ever had has always been perfect. The spicy foods are hot, but not lava. The soups have just the right veggie to noodle to broth ratio. And the edamame is the best in the city! Highly recommend it. However, I'd pick a random time to go because it fills up quick and you end up having to crowd the doorway (it's not that big of a place). But it's worth the wait!
author: Brian B.

description: Great, light, fresh Southeast and East Asian food with a vegetarian bent. Nice bar seating for a quick, relaxed stop in for dinner--comfortable for rolling solo. The house nigori sake is generously poured as an enormous serving filled to the brim of a single large cocktail glass.
author: Jonathan R.

description: So I know this place has bitchy waitresses and a smelly bathroom, but I still love it for the pho. I always get it with added veggies. Try it, you will never turn back. They have screwed up my order several times when I get take out, and I always ask for exactly the same thing... so I would eat in if I were you. But it's definitely a favorite and totally worth the bitchiness!
author: Lauren M.

description: Inexpensive, cozy full-service pan-Asian noodle joint well-loved by Upper Haight locals.  Beer/wine/sake only.  A sign says "restroom's for customers only," which I thought was a typical small business malapropism until I realized there's only one.
author: Gil S.

description: I used to like to come here until one day I mysteriously bit into something crunchy in my spring roll.  Funny, none of my other bites were crunchy.  I dismissed the thought and kept chewing quickly.  But I never want to go back.
author: Dana C.

description:
Someone below mention it is alot like eating in a college campus cafeteria. 
Yes, if you are a self respecting adult it is hard to endure the level of service provided by the young hispster-like asian woman whom has worked their for ages. 
The restaurant insists on holding "makeshift" table set ups for large groups of 4 and more...even during lunch...when there are only two other couples sitting in the joint.
It is ridiculous. Plus most of the two tops are place right by the airy breeze of the restroom.

Its tasty, the secret is in the amount of oil and grease. 
It is not clean Thai or Asian fusion by any means. 
The tables are greasy from all the grease in the food.
Be prepared to experience anal leakage...yes, its the grease!

It tastes good because it is actually quite bad. If you want a delicious and might I add CLEAN experience, without heaviness or guilt,  go to PLOY ii its right next door. 

Seriously.
author: Honey L.

description: Really yummy, fresh, tasty and inexpensive.
author: Patty M.

description:
when it's an hour to two hour wait at cha cha cha and that hookah place across the street, citrus club is a good stanby.  it's dark and moody, good for a date on a budget (i don't think any drinks or food items are over $8)....the noodles are a bit hit or miss...the beef broccoli noodles were great, and i suspect that any dish with those green jade noodles are delish (they get really soft and tasty when they soak up all the oil and spices from the dish).

will go back if i'm craving some serious carbs....
author: Tabatha Y.

description: This place is so good for cheap asian food in the haight-asbury area.  The environment inside is great and the service is pretty good too.  I actually would put 4.5 stars, because it takes forever to find parking in the Haight-Asbury area.  If you go there and eat, make sure you want to stay and shop around too.  For the price, they give you a pretty good portion.  I would recommend this place to anyone that wants to eat asian food near there. :)
author: Amy A.

description: Great place for a quick bite to eat, the shang hai noodles are very tasty and with most dishes under 8 dollars, can't be beat.  I like the Nigori sake in cocktail glasses.  Also, the staff are hot.
author: Dmitri A. N.

description: From the front of the street, this place does not have a commanding presence. But then my friend was looking at the menu near the door and recommended this place. We had a seat inside the dark interior. I ordered Shanghai noodles and when I had my first taste, it was delicious! Also, it was not too expensive like some other Asian Fusion restaurant (which I don't want to mention). A nice neighborhood restaurant in the HAIGHT to walk into on the spur of the moment.
author: herm p.

description:
it still smelled like the bathroom.

i still like their food, but it's hard to enjoy it when your sense of smell is being attacked.
author: Rosalee C.

description: Came here tonight for dinner with two friends, and it was very tasty! We all ordered completely different dishes (two soups and one noodle bowl) and they came super fast! I had the coconut tofu soup, and it was absolutely delicious. Great flavor! We also had some drink (including sake) that hit the spot. The place was packed, but a table for three came up quickly. The food came out very quickly, too. Plus, it's super reasonable! You can't go wrong for a casual (and VERY filling!) meal here!
author: Anne A.

description: Heard the C.C. was good for soup. But the day was young and the temperature was getting up there, so i opted for the cashew chicken noodles - a very satisfactory meal! Also sampled the imperial rolls that could have been wrapped a bit tighter... i will return for soup!
author: wayne s.

description: The garlic edamame is the best edamame on planet earth.  I'm from the country so the first time I tried the edamame here, I tried to eat it whole.  My bad, no edamame on the ranch.  The shrimp won ton soup, almost worthy of a last meal.  Great place to take a date before seeing a movie at the Red Vic.  Good ipod selection, friendly staff, decently priced.  Check it out.
author: Curran J.

description: I feel like everybody we met in San Fran recommended this place and i have to say i wasn't really dazzled. It's good Asian food but nothing to write home about. Cute little interior and ok service.
author: Sarah F.

description:
citrus club is in no way ground breaking, but it is reasonably priced and most things taste pretty damn good.
the marmalade noodles are a personal favorite, lemongrass and coconut are best friends with jade noodles and they all hang out in my tum tum and have a great time.
miso soup is awesome, love it chunky style. other soups are fine, but probably better elsewhere. the house salad is good, v. citrusy! (crushing irony) and the spring rolls and garlic edemame are tasty too.

service is fine. i have had the same 2 servers every time i've been there, so maybe they are just working too much, but ladies, i beseech you, smile for us!
author: shaine h.

description:
yesterday was a really, extraordinarily beautiful and perfect day. 

 it was sunny and hot.  even though i did have to work it was super mellow.  i hardly got a phone call or an email all day and i was sorta just free to clean and play music and do laundry.  on my walk to fedex i noticed that everyone was smiling, making eye-contact and even saying hi..... and this is in SoMA.  people hardly take the time to spit on you down here.  and even though i looked like complete hungover shit yesterday the mechanics still whistled like they do when i'm in heels....so sweet guys thanks.  

something springy and wonderful was definately in the air.

further proof: on my walk back from fedex i had a moment of worry because i had to get paid as i was flat broke and we had no $$$ in the bank.  i had this vague hope that upon my return to the studio i would find a check had come in the mail. and guess what?! yes it did. a huge HUGE fat check which is nothing but good news for all of us.

so when kitten called me as i was driving home in the SUNSHINE because of the new d.l.s., and asked if i wanted to go to citrus club with her and devin i decided that yes i did. because A. i could now afford it B. it's yummy and C. on a glorious day like this how could i be expected to go home alone and clean my room?

and this is the final piece of evidence. irrefutable proof that yesterday was perfect: unfriendly asian hotty hostess at citrus club - you know... the one who never, NEVER. NEVER EVER smiles. smiled at us. not once, not twice, but like five actual BIG smiles - with teeth. and about two little kind of smirky smiles.  it may never happen again but i swore that simply because of that miracle i would yelp citrus club.

HERE'S WHAT YOU NEED TO KNOW: very good food, excellent service (water fillage is like the best in the city) great portions and cheap.  bbq tofu spring rolls and the lime coconut noodles for ten bucks - trust me try them. you'll thank me later. and they do not serve alfredo sauce in any of their dishes. that is a lie. and also alfredo sauce does not come in a can.  IT'S A CREAM BASED SAUCE YOU FOOL.  darwin award - two entries down.
author: marin m.

description:
you gotta get the garlic edamame beans! the chicken coconut curry soup is lacking something but it still hits the spot.  the spring rolls are delish too.

also, prepare yourself for a long wait. the sever was a little rude. but whatever, i don't f*ck wid people who serve me my food. know what i mean?

but once your seated, enjoy because you'll be hella hungry. i give this place 3.5 stars.
author: Renae C.

description: Can't speak for much of the menu, but garlic beef or garlic shrimp anything is delicious.  Prices are cheap, especially for the huge portions they give you.  I always end up taking half of the dish home & snacking on cold garlicky noodles later that night, which is okay by me.  Also, I usually don't like soju drinks, but I can throw back a good three fresh orange margaritas and leave happy.  Yes, it's tiny, yes, it's cramped.  So do everyone a favor and just don't go on weekend nights!
author: Irene C.

description: I was once enamored with Citrus Club, with its sweaty Blade Runnery pre-apocalyptic pan-asian vibe going.  Not to mention the fact that your food came faster than you can say "Saketini".  But then I came to the realization that I was basically paying people to make stuff that could be made by any idiot with a rice-cooker and a penchant for giant bowls of assorted stuff.  I suppose it's a philisophical point, the idea that food in restaurants should be prepared by professionals with greater culinary powers than you.  But then again, how many shows does Rachael Ray have now?  In other words, they cook it so you don't have to.  That has some value all it's own.  And to paraphrase another yelp reviewer, I haven't barfed yet.  Three stars.
author: Gabriel E.

description: I went to the Cirtus Club today and I thought the food was excellent.  Most of the dishes on the menu were inexpensive (less than $10),  I ordered a Mandarin-style chow-mien with shrimp.  It was delicious.  The best noodles I've had in a long time.
author: Sergio M.

description: C Club is by far my favorite place to get cheap eats in the city. I don't think of it as any type of cuisine, it's just Citrus Club! I've been there hundreds of times, sometimes several times a week. Just know this when you go. There are many great things on the menu, including the Tom Ka, Hot and Sour soup, coconut marmalade jade noodles, garlic edamame, tofu satay, etc. I order them every time and they never miss. BUT, there are a few misses on the menu. I can't tell you what they are, it's just my taste. But try it and if at first you don't succeed, try and try again. It's such a great spot, who cares about the service or the pad thai!
author: Kylie S.

description: Recently began eating here, and I think it's pretty good.  Cheap prices, large portions.  The chicken and the shrimp wonton soup could have used more flavor, but the noodles were tasty. I've also tried the cashew chicken and enjoy it, though I wish it had more toppings with all those noodles.
author: Erica L.

description:
I didn't want to start my first yelp with a perfect. People might get the wrong idea and think I'm easy, not true. I was just eager to review probably my favorite restaurant in the city. 

Perfect for any mood...date, casual, family, mistress, boss, lone wolf...with a menu to suit any Asian fusion fan. I'm not being subjective even though I got laid one night solely because of the atmosphere and the garlic edema-me appetizers. This place is great...helpful staff,all-though it is a little dark at night and is usually crowded but those are small faults in an excellent restaurant. Spring rolls and garlic chicken are amazing as well. The soups look like I want to jump in and swim while slurping, and they are almost big enough to accomplish. 

GOO and have fun friends.
author: Jeff P.

description: Love the food, hate the service.  When I am really hungry and want to eat well, I drop into the Citrus Club.  The service isn't slow, it's just that a few of the waitresses are so cold and unwelcoming; they are a drag to deal with.  I understand that having to deal with people all day can basically blow.  When I'm through with my day I need to sit in solitary confinement for at least an hour before I can deal with any more humans.  But while working, I am still polite, courteous and sometimes even charming when dealing with my customers.  Yes, we get it... you don't like your job.  But suck it up and be nice to people who are nice to you and give you money.  Then, when you are done with your shift, you can run home and continue hating the world.
author: Cupcake X.

description:
NOT CLEAN!!! No STARS!

Tonight I got take out and after eating half my soup, and thinking that there was maybe something weird in it in this one bite, i saw a worm float to to the top of my bowl. It was either a giant maggot or a caterpillar. When I called they said "Oh it was probably in one of the vegetables." like that was no big deal. Effing gross. Will never ever go back.
author: Wendy M.

description: There were three of us and we each ordered a different noodle dish and split an order of shrimp spring rolls.  The spring rolls and the Shanghai noodles (beef, shiitake mushrooms, tofu and udon noodles) were really tasty.  The Pad Thai, not so much.  The peanut sauce was creamy like alfredo sauce.  The portions were huge.  All in all, not a bad place to grab lunch and a beer, just don't order that Pad Thai.
author: Jason K.

description: Really really good food and , exceptionally well priced. The exterior is a bad indicator of what this place really is, once you get past the long bar there is a cool/cozy dining area which is perfect for a (cheap) date or small groups. Its a total comfort place but also not embarrasing to bring new people to.
author: Serene M.

description:
i will always love this place. sometimes you have to wait forever for a table, which is a bummer. but worth it!

to be fair, i go between a few dishes every time i go and haven't tried much else, but haven't heard the best things about some of them.

my favs: beef & shitake mushroom noodles, grilled shrimp & scallops over noodles, garlic edamame! (omg so good), and a few of the soups which have always been nothing short of delicious.
author: sarah k.

description: I used to go here all the time when I was an undergrad at USF. I love their wok tossed noodle dishes (especially the peanut noodles) and the pricing is great, especially on a student budget (under $10). But the last time I went back, the food didn't taste the same...if wasn't that good to me and I was rather unimpressed. Even the service that time I went wasn't how they usually were. I'm still giving Citrus Club the benefit of the doubt and rating them with 4 stars since the majority of the time the food and service has been good.
author: Janel Y.

description: Pretty good, mostly forgettable vaguely asian food. Big inexpensive portions are the order of the day here. Hardly a destination place, but a good respite after a Haight shopping expedition.
author: Stellah D.

description: A Haight-Asbury favorite. Citrus Club is not only cheap, but also very good. Usually packed on weekends, drop by on a weekday evening and you'll have little to no wait for a table. Large sized portions of pan-asian noodles await you.
author: Nishan K.

description: Asian-themed noodle and rice dishes, cheap and quick. I liked the coconut-lime cold noodles but overall, I think it's mediocre at best. I love Pomelo more than this place.
author: kristin e.

description: After a typical shopping spree through Amoeba you'll need a snack to regain your energy...won't you?...well the Citrus Club is within a stones throw away from Amoeba and it's the perfect place to do just that. Their house garlic edamame is delicious. The seaweed salad hit the spot. And a little combination of the ginger tea (it's sweet) AND peppermint tea makes everything alright. Fast service, pleasant waitress and a big round table booth for the three of us to lounge in and open our cd's was the perf ending to a shopping trip on the Haight.
author: Monica H.

description: This little gem is the place for noodles.  Dark, cozy atmosphere and cheap!   We had the peanut noodles and they didn't disappoint.  Dishes are plenty to share so your bill is very manageable.
author: TX O.

description:
this is my favorite stop for food in the haight, and it's the perfect place for a sunday afternoon meal after an afternoon in the park, or before the movies at the red vic. yes, it's busy and you're likely to have to wait for a table, and there is only one table that accomodates more than four, so if you walk in with six people at a busy time, you'll probably regret it.  but it's open in the afternoon, so it's a great pit stop for the afternoon's shopping when you don't have to deal with the crowds. 

the atmosphere is great, low lighting and good music and all sorts of interesting people there but not in the look-you-up-and-down oh-so-hipster kind of way. so you feel like you're in an actual restaurant as opposed to some fluorescent-lit noodle place with formica tables.

foodwise, there's something for everyone. any dish can be made with tofu, too. the food is asian fusion, and i think a lot of us hit on a favorite dish or two and that's what we crave. i love the grilled salmon or chicken over garlic noodles. it really is flame-grilled, and a big portion.  their pad thai is not a traditional recipe, which is a plus to me since i don't like real pad thai (and i live in thailand part-time, so i know what that is). it's really more of a coconut noodle dish, but it's tasty as heck. the shrimp wonton soup is great, too.

if i'm less hungry, i just get an order of chicken satay (real chicken in thick pieces) and some cold tofu rolls or the seaweed salad with tofu, which has a little spicy zing to it.  and get a glass of nigori unfiltered sake to go with it -- thick, creamy and zingy, i'm hooked on that stuff. 

it's a good place with friends, but it's also one of the few places where it's faster and easier when you're solo, since there's rarely a wait to sit at the counter, and you can watch the super-efficient chefs and wait-staff at work.  all the staff is great there, and the thai waitresses help me practice my thai, for which i'm eternally grateful.
author: leslie a.

description: The portions here are HUGE!!  If you like garlic and you also love edamame, they have both combined in one dish that will leave you with cravings for more later on.  I think the other secret ingrident they put in there is liquid "can't stop".    The noodles are great too but I highly suggest sharing.  I haven't met a person yet that can polish off a bowl by themselves.  Besides, you can recreate your own Lady and the Tramp experience!
author: Cyan C.

description: Some of the items on the menu are great, others are average. I enjoy eating here, except the whole restaurant seeps into your clothes and hair...  after I leave I smell as if I were working as a line cook.
author: Jon F.

description: Bang for your buck!  American-sized portions for a not-so American restaurant.  Pretty impressive fare.
author: Shiho F.

description: I thought this place was pretty good. I've been jonesing for pho lately and had the beef noodle one here. It was okay but I tasted the other dishes on the table and mine was the least tastey. Cool atmosphere and folks, not too loud at any point. We went on a Sunday and it was a pretty short wait but I think we may have been lucky.. Would go again if I was in the area and wanted noodles :)
author: rukshan b.

description: The place was definitely happening and I give Citrus Club credit for being very original and creative in the cuisine but the food itself is very average.  My friends and I left the place very unfulfilled.
author: Debbie Y.

description: Definitely a place I'd go to again. I love the feel of the place. the food was great. I'd have to say that the only issue was that it was ridiculously packed. Though if you are willing to sit up on a bar stool you shouldn't wait too long. I was sitting within 5 minutes of walking in. I'm glad I stayed. The food was great and as I said the feel was so awesome. The wait staff was friendly and even gave us a free beer that we didn't order simply because it looked like we needed a beer. Talk about a boost huh?
author: Roderic C.

description: One of my fav places in the city for dinner....and a good place for a date.....Ameoba is down the street...great way to really see if the 2 of you will click.  I'm a fan of the HUGE soba noodle soup and spring rolls.  If you want a sodium overload, go for it all, but seriously, its a lot!  Fast service, good prices, come out smelling like the kitchen though.
author: ERICA E.

description: I have never been disappointed by the Citrus Club... always delicious & distinguished dishes at good prices.  My favorite meal to-go:  the hot and sour shrimp soup- they give you the soup and put the noodles and shrimp in a separate container.  What you've gotta do is get some of that hot sauce so you can dip the shrimp (yum) and then add the noodles and veggies to the broth.  So you get a kickin shrimp cocktail and big bowl o soup for under $8!!  The garlic edemame is to die for...  literally, you want to die afterward because you know your breath is rank, but you still want to lick the plate.  I recommend to-go because the service can be a little slack, but best noodles for the buck!!
author: Tara G.

description: I dig the dimly lit atmoshpere, low-price, and tasty noodle dishes.  Particlarly the ones heavy on the garlic...hmmmm.  I used to crave noodles from this place, now living in the Mission, so have learned to tame that craving.  Cool spot to meet a friend for a casual dinner (or lunch).
author: Adrian N.

description: Had Lunch with some friends here they were a little slow with the service (I don't know if it was because they had just opened) but the food was good and the portions were more than plenty. Of course we had to have the fried bannanas with mango ice cream which was just DEE-LISH!!! always a nice way to end a meal :)  Can't wait to go back.
author: Lena M.

description: Great noodles at great prices.  It's kind of like a lounge at night.  I don't remember what I had here, too many drinks LOL!
author: Dong T.

description: The Haight has so many mediocre food options that prey upon tourist traffic.  This place is surprisingly good, with great prices and good atmosphere to boot.
author: Cully W.

description:
meh. i was running around the city helping my sister find something. we were starving. she didnt want a falafel. i didnt want pizza. we tried citrus club. 

she had the garlic shrimp with portabella mushrooms, her boyfriend and i the yellow coconut curry with tofu, our mother who happened to be along had the hong kong style chow mein... schmea. ok  but not something to sing about. 

i was tired and irritable, so maybe that added. also i should have gotten something protien heavy since i was feeling a bit snarky. apparently average sisterly annoyances trumped my judgement and maybe its my fault for ordering the yellow curry. who knows. i think i was so hungry i ate like a machine b/c there was a spot of it on my shirt hours later and no one told me.
author: Niki M.

description: Oodles of noodles! Cheap, delicious, great for the chilly, rainy months. Nothing too awe inspiring, oh, except for the nubile waitresses. Still, can't beat a humongous bowl of noodle soup when you tire of shopping the Haight.
author: Colleen B.

description: I like this place. I went there on Thursday for the first time, and randomly again on Saturday. The first time, we had the garlic edamame (yum!), veggie spring rolls, and then I had the hot & sour tofu soup and my friend got the Tom Ka - Thai Coconut Tofu Soup, and we traded halfway through. The hot & sour soup was good, but I thought the coconut soup was great! The next time I got it again, as well as the shrimp spring rolls, and my friend had the Garlic Shrimp & Shiitake Mushrooms, which was interesting & yummy. The place is very dark, and you'll probably have to wait awhile, but it's pretty cheap and the portions are HUGE. Seriously, like 3-4 people could split a bowl of soup and be full. Mmm, leftovers.
author: Janet G.

description:
TONS OF BUGS IN SOUP!!! I ate lunch there with a friend - we both ordered the special shrimp and wonton soup. About half way through it, my friend says "Oh shit. there are bugs in my soup. lots and lots of small bugs." I look - f**k. me too. Lots. Like over 30. I'm grossed out, but calm. I mean, stuff happens.  So, we tell the waitress. She is completely unalarmed and says that "Oh. The bugs probably came from the vegetables. I will tell them to wash them better next time." She leaves. What? She comes back and offers to comp 1 of our 2 soups. I am so confused.  I say "Why would I pay for any soup that is infested with bugs? That doesn't make any sense." She goes to talk to the manager. In the meantime, they serve the same soup to the guy sitting next to us. The same bug soup. The waitress returns and says that both of our soups are free. Nothing about it being nasty. Nothing about stopping other people from eating it. So I check the Health Dept Site. Score = 71. NASTY.

06/07/07 - Looks like the Dept of Health score has dropped to 68.  Way to get shittier, Citrus Club!  I love that one of the citations is that they don't post their report.
author: Beth F.

description: One of the better cheap eats in the city.  Good location at the heart of Haight Street.  Try one of the soups.  Portions are large.
author: Andrew R.

description:
I love this place!   You don't pay much (it's inexpensive), you get really great tasting food and lots of it and the garlic edamame is seriously addicting!  One of my favorites places.  Try the Lemongrass and Coconut Chicken.

Don't be discouraged by it's outer appearance.
author: Jaden V.

description: I 've only been here once during a month long visit  last year, but between all the dish switching among friends we enjoyed all the tastes. Even the pad thai seem to have a slightly different flair to it, and sometimes I have dreams about it. The atmosphere was cozy in the back corner booth that we shared with 6  people, and so I will go back here the next time I am in town.
author: Alison B.

description: Yelp currently has this place rated just right at 3.5 stars.  I have never had a spectacular dish, but never had a really bad one.  You are almost always wishing the food had a little more ommph, but most have nice touches, like the subtlety of the spices in the Pho.  Living for two years in the inner richmond made me appreciate this place, because on a cold, foggy night when I didn't want Sakura, Citrus Club was guaranteed not to disappoint.
author: Nicholas E.

description: Addicted to the coconut curry soup.  I never get anything else.  Garlic edamame as a stater.  This is my comfort food.  Serious cravings.  My BF is on the way home with some now.  Much cuter in the evenings when the candles are flickering.  Plus it is really cheap!  It's a great low maintenance date spot.
author: mademoiselle m.

description: Cute place, but the "Asian Fusion" took some of the Asian out of my noodles. It wasn't bad - just not for my fobby pallet.
author: Candy C.

description: What a disappointment!  The vegetables were soggy, the sauces were unpleasant tasting.  I had the tofu with chili sauce-- the sauce tasted like a bottled chili sauce with too much sugar added, and the flavors did little to bring the other vegetables alive.  My partner tried a beef dish-- the beef was unpleasant tasting and tough.  Both of us felt ill after eating there.  The major reason they seem so popular is that they are cheap.
author: s j.

description: I absolutely LOVE this place!  The food is awesome and CHEAP! The two best combinations in a restuarant!  Also has great service too!  You have to get their hot and sour noodle soup!  Their garlic beef with shitake mushrooms chow fun is awesome!  Its a small place and its can get really busy on weekends so plan on doing some waiting for a table, but it is sooooooo worth it!
author: Chloe G.

description: i thought this place was pretty tasty! :) i liked the spring rolls and cashew chicken ordered + cozy atmosphere.
author: Hula H.

description: I wouldn't eat here again. BUT, if you do get drawn into this restaurant by its Zagat stickers like I did, order something with garlic. That's probably your best bet. Their Mongolian beef special over noodles and grilled chicken over noodles was good (according to my friends) - but they one of the worst pad thai's I've come across. Also, the yellow curry tofu & nuts did not live up to its description on the menu. Way too bland for my taste!
author: Katrina R.

description: The grilled ginger salmon was probably the best salmon plate i've ever had! Not to mention the garlic edamame was amazing!
author: carlos A.

description:
Interesting place for sure.

If you are looking for really traditional Thai food, then pass this place by and head a few doors down to Ploy II. However if you have an open mind, and like to try new things, give this place a shot.

This place is definitely more of an Asian/American fusion restaurant, and it's pretty tasty. I had the Lemon Coconut Chicken, and while it was definitely not what I expected, it was very tasty and had me craving it again today.

All together a fun place, with a great atmosphere, and some delicious drinks.

3 stars.
author: Brian S.

description:
This place is just awesome, and I honestly think that people who don't like this place have hateful hearts. Everytime I go to this place, I ask myself why I took so long to come back.  The Thai Tea is consistently good, and I almost always order the same thing, and am always happy with it.  What I think I love best about this spot is along all my different food habits, from vegetarian to carnivor'ian... I can always get my order tailor made.  Not very many joints can do that and still provide good flavor.  CC wouldn't be consistently packed in the way it is, if it wasn't good...  

Okay, so I can admit that sometimes the service is slow, and the spot itself is a bit cramped.  But somehow I get into CC and almost feel like I'm in a different country hahaha...
author: The Dreaded Critic S.

description: Simply put...I had a great bowl of Shrimp Won Ton Soup....and it was huge salad bowl size. I added chicken...and along with all of the veggies...in a rich chicken broth....it was a McCovey Cove homerun !!!! The Citrus Club is a funky litle place...but as comfy as a hug from grandma.
author: Robert V.

description: Cool vibe. Great for a noodle dish and a cocktail or some Sake. Service was very welcoming. The only bad thing was a large portions. I ate meal, which was quite delicious, but finished it and was a quite full. I'd recommend getting some appetizers and then maybe sharing a noodle dish.
author: Mike L.

description: The food is tasty and the price is right!  It's the perfect place for a casual dinner, just be sure no one is on the Atkins diet...the noodles are what makes this place fabulous!  You can easily have an entree and drink for under $15...and that's the beauty of this place!
author: Sarah D.

description: I just went here for the first time a few nights ago with someone who loves the food. I had the pad thai and seaweed salad. They were both good, I had to put alot of the chile sauce from the table into the noodles, but maybe next time I just will ask for it to be spicey. The seaweed salad was my favorite, I could eat it all day. Service was very good, someone is always walking around to clear something out of your way, if needed.
author: Amanda P.

description: The food is nothing to rave about, but it's relatively healthy and the pricing is quite reasonable.  Kudos to the management for making an effort at adding some style to a place that is basically a noddle joint.  Some of the waitresses have been working there for years so they must be doing something right.  If you want to avoid the crowds and live in the area, phoning in an order and then picking it up is the way to go.
author: Tony P.

description: Just went out today to Citrus Club with my sister! I absolutely love this place! I especially loved what I had tonight: Garlic Shrimp and Shitake Mushrooms with noodles! Fabulous! Always busy but can you blame them? The food is soooo good! The soups are also good like the sweet and sour shrimp soup! For a good appetizer try the teriyaki chicken roll! good service and affordable!
author: Mel P.

description: Most people are familiar with the adage "location, location, location".  Well, I'm sure that it's the primary explanation for the success of this restaurant. In a nutshell:  mediocre pan-asian food offered for cheap prices at a location experiencing mucho foot traffic.
author: Momo R.

description: This is a last resort restaurant when I'm stuck in the Haight trying to avoid traffic on the bridge.  First off, why do the waitresses all have to be a size 0 and wear sexy outfits?  Something about that riles my feminist sensibilities.  Secondly, the food is really bland.  The spring rolls are ok, but they aren't wrapped tightly enough so everything collapses upon your first bite.  The bbq tofu rolls taste like Bullseye Barbecue sauce with some sprouts mixed in.  The salad lacked salad dressing.  The Citrus "Punch" lacked it.  If only there were better places to eat in the Haight . . .
author: Samantha R.

description:
tasty food - i had the special of beef and broccoli with jade noodles...flavorful and fresh.  

service was a bit slow, but i liked the atmosphere - this would be a great date place with the low lighting and cozy feel.  definitely would go back!  

only reason i gave it a 3 was because of the tummy ache i had afterwards - it might just be me though as the friend i was with felt fine!
author: Lauren V.

description:
huge portions and, as everyone likes to call it, "asian-ish" food.

the drinks are good and the crowd is diverse, warranting a return trip
author: Charles C.

description: Don't let the banner and so-so look outside of Citrus Club fool you.  Inside this upper Haight noodle bar awaits a ecclectic mix of people and solid menu.  I reccommend starting with the house garlic edamame and not punishing oneself with the house's hot sauce; which I always seem to do.  I'm talking major heat.
author: Catrinel A.

description: A very solid restaurant. Noodles, yum! Beer, yum! And all at very reasonable prices. Check out the spring rolls with peanut sauce. They're so tasty that I *have* to order them every time I go!
author: Margo M.

description: Love, love, love this place! My friend David brought me and my best friend here on a visit to SF three years ago.
