Since moving here, I make everyone that comes to visit me go here at least once. The staff is so friendly and my boyfriend and I get our favorite server everytime. She is the sweetest! There can be a slight wait for dinner, but it's worth it or you can sit at the bar. Definitely order the garlic edamame if you are super hungry. Usually the noodles are filling enough though, so I frequently forgo the appetizer unless I am with a large group. Very reasonably priced. Shanghai noodles are my fave, but their Pho Ga is a life saver too.
author: Naomi C.

description: I'll be honest-- I make a mean noodle soup and come from a mom who dishes up the finest of Asian cuisines (Cambodian, Chinese, Thai, Vietnamese....we're a mixture of all the wonderful worlds). But even a burnt tongue and chalk for a palate can figure out that this place is just awful. I ordered beef pho; my friend ordered veggie noodles with broccoli. The soup tasted like it came out of a packaged bouillon for pho (I know because I've made packaged bouillon pho before and it's bad!). That was a bounty of goodness compared to the overly sugary, yet dull noodle dish. The sugar was the only thing you really tasted with maybe a dab of soy sauce; the broccoli looked like it'd been sitting out for days. I could have made a better dish in a drunken haze.  The food is tolerable-- that's the bottom line.
author: Helen T.

description: I love this place.  WE have been here to dine as well as ordering take out.  The prices are cheap and the food is really fresh.  This is a healthy, tasty, cheap eat!
author: Michelle M.

description:
hot n sour vegetarian soup? get outta here i'm all over it like white on rice.

this place is delish but minus 2 stars for being run down and dingy. i can get past the super crowdedness but print new menus for god's sake!
author: Kenna T.

description:
This place is really good, yes! They have a wide variety of affordable and delicious pan Asian soups, noodle and rice dishes. The servers are generally fine, nothing to write home about, but consdiering the kind of baditude endemic to the Haight, this place suffers less than most.

I knocked one star off because parking is tricky in the Haight, and because whenever I bring my four year old to dinner at CC, while the staff is pretty accomodating, the fellow patrons look at her like she's an extraterrestrial from another planet rather than just an extremely small human being.
author: Darien W.

description: Forget you if your not down with the Citrus Club. Sit down and have yourself some of those Garlic Edamame and a big bowl of Beef & Shitaki. The smell alone will knock you over.  I love that it's not perfect, yes it's small and the lines can be long but all good things... If six adults and two toddlers can eat and drink for under 120.00 I am on it. The pitfall IS. I no longer live in San Francisco so I have to grab it while I am in the city or dream about it till the next time.
author: Jamie M.

description: I'm not from the Nor-Cal area, but when I go back there, this is definitely a place I'm going to visit again. It's a great place to go to on a chilly day, especially with hot bowls of noodles awaiting you. The prices there are great, especially with the size of the portions. The BF and I spent about $24 bucks for an appetizer, two entrees and drinks. I didn't even put a dent in my beef and chow fun noodles, and i was ridiculously stuffed.  The BBQ tofu spring rolls were excellent, and it came with a great dipping sauce. The servers are great, and they were pretty attentive. I went there at lunch time, so it wasn't super crowded. Parking can be a little bit of a pain, as it is on Haight Street.
author: stephanie v.

description:
you know how sometimes you order the vegetarian noodle soup at an asian place and you get a big bowl of tasteless hot water with some cabbage and carrots floating in it? not so here. we're talkin' a supersized bowl of soba noodles, broth of the perfect saltiness, loaded with broccoli, snow peas and other yumminesses. totally hit the spot on a dreary, rainy, wintry night. and set me back $6.95

my friend thought the ginger tea was too sweet, but i liked it. nice atmosphere, too. we lucked out and got two comfy stools at the bar. it was busy, but in a lively, ooh-i'm-out-on-a-friday-night! sort of way. low prices, and we had no trouble with the service. 

i'd come here again.
author: jean w.

description: So, where do I begin... hmmm.. ok so I think this is a great place to grab some Ice Tea and some spring rolls...Im not a huge "noodle/soup" person, and there is a lot of that on the menu; though my dinner partners do enjoy the selection. Great prices, the service is a little shitty, BUT its haight, and they dont smell so Im cool with that. Great place if you met someone at a bar, made plans to take them on a date and didnt want to invest too much into it!!
author: Liz C.

description:
After a friend told me this place was great, I decided to give it a try.

A friend and I had the following:
BBQ tofu spring rolls: a mess and a half and not worth it
Pad Thai: This was udon in coconut milk, not pad thai
Spicy Tiger Shrimp: Udon noodles in mediocre yellow curry

This place is just americanized asian food. Why even both with it when you can get authentic pho, pad thai, or chow mein anywhere else in the city.
author: Saikat P.

description: Fake noodles from parts of Asia.  Everything tasted bland or Americanized.  To top it off, service was beyond turtle-slow.  I can't believe I'm giving it even one star.  Dont' waste your money here.  Unless you're craving noodles to the point that you'll die and can't walk just a few blocks, to perhaps one of the Thai restaurants on the block, this is not a good choice at all.
author: Mellie P.

description: I went here with some friends and we sat in the back, the odor of urine and fecal matter was too strong to stand.  Combined with a pile of noodles hitting our open toed shoes under the table was too much, we had to walk out without ordering.  I give 2 stars just because the food could be good, who knows I haven't eaten here, but don't think I will in any near future.
author: Stephen H.

description: This place lives up the name Citrus that's for sure, the minute you walk in your nose gets slammed with a four ton truck of citrus scent!!  Probably be cause the waitress' are constantly squeezing fresh juice near the front.  The food here is good. Definite menu item to order is garlic edamame! The only reason it scores a three star not a four is the wait for three of us took a a little over and hour, the place is small, so if you go try off peak times for sure.
author: Don I.

description: I love this place for the drinks. I love the food too but I can make everything on the menu at home at 10% of the price so I'll stick to the sake martinis and stumble home.
author: joann p.

description: Amazingly good, charming and I cannot wait to go back. Try the Hot and Sour Vegetable Soup.
author: Jerry S.

description: It's a good spot.  Their theme is using citrus instead of heavy oils and overall, I would say their food is a little bit lighter than the average.  You can gorge yourself on the ample portions and not feel completely nasty afterwards. They have lots of soups and noodle dishes.  The garlic edamame is great.  I will sometimes dump any of the leftover sauce onto my meal when it arrives-- it's that good.  The Tom Kha w/ tofu is quite tasty.  I would assume you can add meat in there and it would also be good.  The shitake and garlic noodles are also yummy.  I go here on a fairly regular basis.  Ploy II Thai is 2 doors over and a good alternative if the Citrus Club is too crowded.
author: Zach J.

description: Was worried at first - we stood there for some time waiting for staff to acknowledge us, and when they finally did they asked if we had signed in on the waiting list (which was hanging unnoticed on a wall) - and we were the only people waiting!  Once seated the staff was fine, and the food was good, servings large, prices reasonable. Had a salad (huge and fresh) and some Vietnamese rolls - really liked the peanut dipping sauce, enough that I finished it plain.  All in all a good meal for the price.
author: Ranger A.

description: When I need me some Tom Ka Tofu, all doctored to my specific spicy tangy needs, I hit this spot. Super yummy. Some of the other stuff is kind of hit or miss.
author: Rhubarb M.

description: Great food but sometimes the wait is too long.  The staff seems like they don't want to be there or just tired of serving because they aren't really personable.  Basically, hi welcome...what do you want to order?...then here is your food. Then towards the end they ask you anything else? OMG if the food wasn't so good, I wouldn't come back for the service. Try this place because it's a flavorful menu!!
author: Jay S.

description: I was there late afternoon on a Sunday and it was already starting to get packed. Ordered garlic shiitake beef chow fun, excellent!!! Too bad parking is kind of a mess in the Haight . . I will try the garlic edamame next time
author: Gil G.

description: This is a fun spot. I like sitting at the bar to watch the cooks, man are they fast! I usually get the BBQ Tofu spring rolls which are great and the hot-sour shrimp noodle soup is fantastic. Its a great place to go to alone or with a date.
author: Thomas F.

description: I come here regularly as I live in the area.  Their spring rolls are hands down the best I've ever had, along with their incredibly amazing peanut sauce.  I alway get extra cuz it's so freakin good!  Not to mention the price.  I can get an order of spring rolls & an entree for less than $20, and I always have leftovers so it's good for two meals.  Can't beat it!
author: Erin S.

description: All around great food. I have ordered a few of the noodle dishes. I recommend the garlic beef noodles. I did not enjoy some lemon coconut chicken noodle dish, but the garlic edamame is on the order list.
author: Sarah W.

description: Overall enjoyed the Citrus Club experience. The darkly lit restaurant gives it a cool vibe. Tried the chicken pho and tofu coconut soup. The pho is OK, certainly better options in the city are available. The tofu coconut was tasty, something worth coming back for.
author: Joseph S.

description: The best garlic edamame that I have ever had.  I eat them every time that I go.  Try the spring rolls as well.  I love the candies at the end....
author: Joanna S.

description: I have mojor cravings for Pho, and citrus club definately helps relieve me. Its kinda crowded but the garlic edamame make up for it!
author: Misty D.

description: I really wanted to like the food here. The ambience is great -- beaded curtains, fun stringy lights, dim lighting and good music. The food is cheap -- between $6 and $9 for entrees -- but you get what you pay for. Go here if you want lots of cheap food that doesn't really taste that good.
author: Wendy C.

description: I never actually eat in the restaurant, mostly because I have no patience for waiting. So, I love it for the take-out.... The Mandarin Chow Mein.... I could live on that stuff. So much food for the money, you can revisit it again the next day for lunch!! The service isn't very friendly, even when you get it to go.... so don't expect much.
author: Megan D.

description: I love places like this...cheap, bustling, and damn tasty. I think that I could eat an entire bucket of those garlic sauteed soybeans and be perfectly content. Noodle bowl was pretty good as well, and for some reason any place that randomly sells cheap unfiltered sake in huge martini glasses passes the test. Maybe because I love sake, maybe because it's just ironic. Not sure I care either way.
author: Nicole S.

description: Mmm...yum!  Asian noodles in a big bowl of veggies, tofu, and soup.  This place is somewhat small, but a great place for lunch.  Service is fast and friendly.  I'll be back!
author: Apollo L.

description:
I only ever eat one dish at the Citrus Club- chicken noodle soup pho style, but usually change up the appetizers. I love pho, but if I eat it at any traditional Vietnamese restaurant I get sick and vow never to eat it again. So I opt for chicken pho at Citrus Club b/c it's definitely not your authentic Asian restaurant and I haven't gotten sick so far. 

The decor is definitely on the yuppie side for being on Haight Street, but I used to go to USF which is just up a few blocks and it beat eating at the cafeteria. Hmmm... I suggest trying this place if you're on Haight street and looking for some noodles, it's affordable and I've always left happy and full.
author: Samantha F.

description:
strolled into the citrus club while exploring haight ashbury for the first time with my hubby. we were there for an early-ish dinner on sunday, and didn't have to wait at all. the place looked kinda dark and dingy when we entered but we got a lovely little table by the window right at the back. we ordered chicken satay, hot-n-sour chicken soup and the house special ginger chicken on garlic noodles. the waitress was helpful and our order arrived rather quickly. we were shocked at the portions and had to struggle to finish it. the house special is among the best i have ever had and the chicken noodle soup was basically tom yum soup - which was a tad disappointing but it tasted really good. the satay wasn't typical but tasted fine...no thrills there. fell for the chilli sauce on the table though - yum yum! :) what else - oh the thai ice tea was too sweet so i didn't  dig it too much.

if yelp let us give half stars, i would give the club 3.5 :)
author: Shradha B.

description: I have been here numerous of times with everybody, dates, girls night out, birthdays, etc. word of advice be there early to sign in for your tables; there are crowds and space is a bit cramped. food is yummy and seriously reasonable for frisco-- 6 bucks for a huge bowl of hot surpy noodles! go there for the food!
author: Hana ..

description: Really, what is not to like about this place? The food is tasty, the service is attentive, the wait (if any) is relatively short,  sake martinis, plus it is cheap. The soup, all good. The Spring rolls are delicious, anything with those shiitake mushrooms in them has an excellent chance of being fantastic. A few words of warning though: DO NOT order the Pad Thai. It is not very good, and probably should be called something else, like Pad Thai inspired....Otherwise, the place has a nice vibe, and a good atmosphere.
author: Scott R.

description: Alright, I have to admit, I'm a little obsessed!  I first experienced the Citrus Club when I was sick with a bad cold.  A friend said I needed some soup and that was the place to get some "bomb" soup.  Aside from the non stop entertainment (it's always an adventure in there seeing you are in Haight near GG park), the food is amazing.  The hot and sour shrimp soup is to die for!  The extra perk is that they serve you a tramendous amount of soup that you have no choice but to take the rest home!! The prices are ver reasonable as well, I never spend more than $20 when my boyfriend and I go.  So I say that the next time you are in the mood for some "bomb" soup, please hit them up, it will be well worth your time.
author: Samantha R.

description: The place is really nice decorated and the waiters are really kind. It's not that big, so it could be advisable to book in advance, especially on weekend. There is also the possibility of dining by the bar, though. The food was delicious, in particular I loved the Noodle Soup (try the Hot-Sour Shrimp one, you won't disappointed). Least but not last, the price is really reasonable, compared to the quality of food. A must for Asian-food lovers!
author: Steve E.

description:
I used to live around the corner (cerca 2002), and this was my favorite neighborhood haunt, other than Aub Zam Zam for lemon drops. I would always get the fresh spring rolls and the Soba rau kau (sp?) soup to go and watch hours of Sex in the City on DVD with my friend who lived almost above the Citrus Club and relish our yummy takeout.

Went back here the other night after many years and found that the menu and prices hadn't changed, and neither had the music. They were playing an Ozomatli album and the whole experience took me back 5 years....Loved it and loved that the prices were the same!!

Same experience, same fresh food, same good prices. Way to go Citrus Club for not changing what was already good.
author: M B.

description: Consistently yummy, I love the chicken noodle soups, and the shrimp wonton soup is extra awesome. Start with the spring rolls and get a bowl of piping hot soup, and you'll be in and out in no time- I'd avoid ordering much else off the menu, it can take ages for anything that's not soup to arrive.
author: teriaki b.

description:
if ur a noodle-fiend like me, u have to try citrus club.. don't expect to find a nice (or clean) dining experience here - it's pretty ghetto. but the food? it's amazing... and trust, it's worth it. 

the wait can be pretty long, but if you're with a small crowd, just grab a seat on the front bar area. i never really have to wait for those spots. and the waiter who covers the bar area is spot on - i was never waiting around for him to come around but he wasn't overly intrusive either. just the perfect amount of attention and care. :)

i've only tried a few things from the menu... the chicken noodle soup is a must for hangover days. but really, try the shanghai noodles - they're my fav so far. tender beef, shiitake mushrooms, veggies on yummy sauce and noodles. this place is def on my regulars list
author: Lucy C.

description: Pooring rain,  7 for dinner, perfect spot--- The Citrus Club.  Huge portions delicious green tea and great sake.  The perfect place to hang out with friends.
author: Ona E.

description:
one of my all time favorite places to eat in sf.  great atmosphere, good drinks, very tasty food and healthy portions (usually eat half and take home the other half).  entrees are in the $6-7 range and like said before, large portions.  usually opt for the spinach noodles. seriously everything on the menu is fantastic.  I wouldn't even know where to being with a entree recommendation but as for the appetizers, I always get the veggie spring rolls.  this is also a really good place to get soup when sick, very healing. really great to take a SMALL group of people, everyone will be impressed.  

downsides worth dealing with -  no reservations so since parking in the haight isn't the best (like the rest of the city) i usually drop a friend off to get on the list while i park.  the wait hasn't been that long and you can get a drink while you wait.  also, your entire party has to be present to be seated so this is kind of a catch 22 but has worked for me. not situated to handle large groups and cozy for small groups, best for 2-4 people.
author: T J.

description:
best asian noodles in the city
best thing on haight st!! even better than cha cha cha
author: Christopher L.

description:
This place was good! 

I went last night with a friend and we got the shrimp spring rolls and a bowl of spicy lemon coconut chicken & noodles, or something like that. We split both dishes and were definitely satisfied. It's definitely worth a try and I'm sure I'll go back - If it were closer to my apt or work, I'd make it a regular.

- It's definitely a great value: with a generous tip we each paid $10
- They are good at filling your water 
- I went at 6:00 on a week night and there was no wait (not that I thought there would be one, but people were complaining about the wait)
- I didn't notice if the waitress was friendly or not, but who cares?
author: Caitlin B.

description: Hella good!!! There food is so flavorful and noodles are saucy and delicious. I bring a lot of people here and everyone loves it. I have tried the cashew chicken, the shanghai noodles (my fav) tom kai soup, vegi spring rolls, and more.. everything I try I like so its hard to go wrong.
author: Nikki P.

description: foods GREAT !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! SERICE NOT SO MUCH
author: matt p.

description: really loved this place. very good food, not a long wait time, and the staff is very friendly. you wouldn't think a place that mixes several types of asian cuisine can do them all well, but you'd be surprised.
author: Aaron M.

description: It's one of the best value meals in the Haight. I love the Grilled Chicken and the Pho. Great place to go alone because there's almost always a seat at the bar, otherwise expect to wait.
author: Hurston P.

description: Can't even remember what I ordered the first (and only) time I ate inside this restaurant.  However, after getting the coconut soup to-go, I realized this place is awesome!  It's perfect because this place gets pretty crowded and has a lot of things on the menu not nearly as good.
author: Bridget R.

description:
only been the once, so might need a few visits to give a more rounded score

massive portions.  had;
bowl of drop egg chicken noodle soup - too big a bowl and too many noodles to find the other ingredients
beef and mushroom stir fry - really tasty but too much stodgy rice noodles ruins it

pretty cheap price

good range on the menu, but missing a few classic thai dishes

service was super quick (too quick!) but did lack any sincerity.
they just need a course in being genuine and having some fun and they'll be ok
author: david s.

description: Delicious noodles and best pad thai ever
author: Jewin F.

description: Who doesn't love the Citrus Club? Right on Haight Street, good ambiance inside, candles, pretty quick service, fairly cheap, large portions... try a curry or the cashew chicken...mmmmmmmm... 5 stars all the way.
author: Rebecca L.

description: Absolutely love this place! There were a few months there when I was goin at least once a week. I went back the other night and I can't believe I've waited so long to write a review. This unassuming little hole-in-the-wall situated in upper haight was one of the best things to happen to me since moving to SF. It's my go-to comfort spot after a long day, and never fails when I wanna take out of towners to a reliable restaraunt from a locals p.o.v. I've had quite a few of their menu items, but it's always the Thom Kha that gets me. Take anything you've ever thought about any other underfilling over lemon-grassed thom kha and throw it out the window. Here you are served a bowl of soup as big as your face, loaded with rice noodles and heaps of veggies and tofu (meat and seafood may be added as well) and a broth that will put all other thom kha to shame. The wait can be pretty long, but I've recently discover that if you sit at the bar, you can still get great service and our meal came out in about 5 minutes! Give this place a shot! 5 stars accross the board!
author: Brandi B.

description: Pretty good pan-Asian cuisine.  The spring rolls are pretty authentic, and the noodles are good.  Very reasonably priced.  The best part of it is the location though - a great way to start an afternoon out on the Haight.
author: Ann B.

description: One of the best pan-Asian restaurants in town.  Reasonably priced, and the noodle dishes are absolutely incredible.  It can get loud and crowded, but if you get a table in the back (especially if it's in the corner), it's definitely worth the wait.
author: Paul H.

description: Was really looking forward to this place based on a co-worker who used to rave about it.  Also, I've seen the line when I walk by.  The Spring Rolls were decent, but the Tiger Shrimp noodles that I had were completely flavor-less.  This made absolutely no sense to me.  I can't explain it.   The other dish we had was a Yellow Curry Tofu noodle dish with the exact same problem.    Unfortunately, it is not worth the wait, and I don't really need to go back.  However, it did appear to be a fun place to get drunk on saki.
author: Dylan C.

description: Yummy and priced pretty reasonably for the innovative dishes they serve. Get a place at the bar or the back. The lemongrass with beef was good.
author: miriam b.

description: This is such a great, cheap noodle place in the Haight, with very good food. If you go there just for the garlic edamame, its worth it!! SO good!! I have my "goto" meal that I crave so I haven't strayed too far on the menu. The garlic beef and shitake mushroom nodles are the best!! We also like the lemon coconut shrimp. The line can easily be out the door on a weekend night so make sure you get your name on the list and get there before you are starving!! Just writing about it makes me hungry!! YUM!!
author: RC B.

description: Great food, great drinks, and it's such a perfect way to start your night before a movie at the Red Vic Movie House.
author: Scott M.

description: Cheap, good food, good beer, good sake, good apps and on Haight! Perfect for bringing friends from out of town to. The noodles are great and they somehow reduce the oil usage by using citrus, not sur ehow that works. Great staff too.
author: Chris G.

description: Not a fan of Upper Haight but I will venture in for a little Citrus Club. First time I went there I was very intrigued by everything I saw people eating. I then became even more intrigued when I saw how affordable the dishes are. Unfortunately, that night I ordered a soup that had almost ZERO flavor. Sorry I can't remember the name. But since that first try about three years ago I have given it another chance and keep going back. Some of my staples are the shrimp Vietnamese spring rolls, Coconut Marmalade Chicken something noodles and the Shitake Beef Noodles (with the wide Chow Fun kind) All that for around 17 dollars. Aside from my first visit, I have yet to order something I didn't like. It is a pretty tiny spot but I always love dim lighting. The servers are always nice despite how crowded it gets. Minus points for no delivery.
author: Erin W.

description: You can't go wrong with the noodles in this place. The pan fried noodles were really good, and the soup noodles seemed wonderful also. Cheap prices and a fresh menu (you can watch them make your food) make this place a must-go!
author: Franco R.

description:
The menu isn't the most diverse around, but if you like noodle dishes and being stuffed with said noodle dish for $7, then this is the place for you.

The daily specials are pretty good, but the starters aren't great. Stick to the entrees says I.

The wait can sometimes too much, and they are a little inefficient with how they seat people. To be honest, if I didn't typically get it to go, I would probably go a lot less frequently.
author: Kaveh A.

description: Pretty much what everyone else is saying about this place is dead on. I got here one evening right before the infamous long line and was lucky to take a seat at the bar. Don't let the wait discourage you.
author: melissa h.

description: YUM. Marmalade glaze shrimps with spinach noodles. Citrus Club I love you.
author: Jessica R.

description: This busy place can get dark and romantic (yet crowded) at night.  The portions are always large but the food ranges inconsistently from okay to good.  The noodles, soups (mmm..coconut soup!), and sake are all worth trying out.  The prices are quite low for its location on Haight.  They don't take reservations but simply write your name on the sign-up sheet on the wall and wait for you name to be called up.  Citrcus Club is one place worth checking out in the evening and its location on Haight couldn't be any better.
author: Scott G.

description: An old favorite recently rediscovered.  Amazing value for the ambiance in the noodle house.  Great service and delicious soba!
author: Jessica V.

description:
three stars for being consistent

the place does get pretty crowded and theres never any parking but thats a given... but once you get your butt at a table its all worth it. the edamame is really tasty especially the garlic one- and the noodles are amazing and most of the entrees are huge so e.  the only thing i didnt like was then we asked the server if she would recommend the bbq tofu spring roll- she said no (i appreciate her honesty) but the fact that she couldnt think of a better alternative kinda sucked. we ordered it anyway.
author: Annie L.

description:
This place used to be my top choice for cheap, healthy food, but their awful service and witless food prep has forced me to all but cross it off my list for good, with only two dishes that are worth suffering through the terrible service nowadays.   The story isn't pretty; read on if you must.

It was cold out.  I was in the mood for noodles.  I wanted to try the Sweet Chili-Glazed Tofu & Greens.  The bouncy waitress wrinkled up her face and shook her head, "It's not good, it's too sweet."  But I like sweet, I told her, I usually get the Marmalade Coconut, Lemongrass Shrimp.  By the way, what kind of waitperson badmouths a dish and tries to talk a customer out of a meal?  Puzzled, I scanned the menu for another dish that was new to me, Yellow Coconut Curry Tofu & Nuts.  I attempted to order it.  The waitress suggested the beef special instead.  Copping to her game of trying to increase her tip by forcing me to order the most expensive dish on the menu ($12.95), I insisted on the curry noodles.  She shrugged.

15 minutes later, a lukewarm, virtually tasteless blob of rice noodles appeared.  I had to search for the nuts, tofu and vegetables.  Although it was early in the evening and not busy at all, the waitress didn't check in with me during my meal.  I had to hail her down for the check, at which point she asked me if I liked the dish.  I told her that I wished I had ordered my first choice.  She looked blankly at me and turned on her heel.  

I didn't want to let one bad experience stand between me and what has generally been a good eating experience, so I returned a week later.  I sat at the same table but had a different waitress.  I wanted to try that Sweet Chili-Glazed Tofu & Greens dish I tried to get the last time.  The menu boasts "glazed crispy tofu" which sounded just like what I wanted.   When I was served, once again, a solidified mass of rice noodles, I started poking around for crispy tofu pieces.  I came up with four soggy, tasteless chunks of very UNglazed, UNcrispy tofu.  

I called over the waitress and asked her about the dish.  Did I get the right plate?  Did I misread the menu?  I was getting another blank look.  Doesn't the menu say crispy glazed tofu?  "No, we don't serve anything crispy," the waitress tried to help me understand.  Apparently "Pile of Jiggling Bland Noodles" doesn't look good on menus.

It's time for this place to take inventory of what they do well and drop the act.  They do fruity drinks.  They have one outstanding soup, the chicken pho.  The Marmalade Coconut, Lemongrass Shrimp is tasty but definitely NOT a healthy dish.  What exactly is this restaurant about?  I think the waitstaff is as confused as I am.
author: Sarah E.

description:
don't go here unless you are planning to get shanghai noodles. sometimes i want to order doubles, because it is so good. the thai iced tea is good, but really, i only care about shanghai noodles.

i take off a half star because once they were out of the noodles normally used for shanghai noodles, and it just wasn't the same. i take off another half star because there is always a huge line. [because of the shanghai noodles!]

ps. vegetarians make sure you get s.n without the mushrooms, they are cooked not vegetarianly.

p.p.s. i just read all the reviews, and i think everyone is unhappy because they are not getting shanghai noodles. seriously people. SHANGHAI NOODLES!!!
author: Tara A.

description:
This place is perfect for the ultra-hip shoppers that patronize the outdoor shopping mall Haight Street has become. It is a small place with tables and chairs pushed to elbows distance from each other. If you are eating with only one other person, chances are you will be dining either with one of you with your back to the kitchen door and will be bumped occasionally by the hurried servers, or next to the hip beaded curtain that leads to the sink that is just outside the toilet room - which occasionally smells like a back ally used as a piss pot by drunks and bums. 
  The food is dropped at the table with all the care of an overworked single parent placating an unwanted child on the way out the door for a blind date at the local bar. 
 This is a bit unfair, as I have occasionally been there and had a good server, but this is rare. The food is usually dropped off without a word, and good luck if you need something else. 
 The food itself is okay, on average. Some of it is really good, some of it is beyond bland. Remember all those early vegetarian dinners that gave vegetarian food a bad name? Pasty and no flavor? Like that. 
Tom Kha soup =  A+ 
Pad Thai = What the hell is this?
 Pad Thai was white and pasty and flavorless. Oddly similar to a strange and tasteless jar of Tahini sauce I bought once. 
 If you come with four people, and/or order liquor, the treatment and the table location greatly improve.
 Once upon a time I used to come to this place often. And, I admit, I am still occasionally drawn to this place for love of the large bowls soup. But the attitude has grown along with their prices, and I always leave in a bad mood. 
 Tipping less than %20 is a crime to me, and places that make me feel taken frustrate me. And I don't need to spend what precious little fun money I have to be made to feel a nuisance to those taking it from me.
author: Miss Kae O.

description: No point in repeating what's already been said. Just wanted to put my two cents worth in. Love the place and go there on a regular basis. You should too.
author: Pat M. Y.

description: Great place to go if you are craving for great noodles and soups! Price is pretty good too. Their garlic edemame is a must if you go.
author: Joremel A.

description:
msg?
my noodles weren't very interesting. it was kind of expensive, or i'd give 3 stars.
author: Joyce o.

description: Best Pad Thai I've ever had!!! I was kinda bummed they only had sake drinks and it was so small, but it added to the atmosphere so there fore it doesn't hinder my opinion of it.
author: Jenna R.

description: i cant seem to find the words right now to really describe this place....so I will just say, I've been here many times and I always look forward too coming back.
author: Lazylibra A.

description: Love this place.  Total staple for me and my husband.  Service is terrible but all the dishes are under 10 bucks and all of them are awesome.  I get the Shanghai Noodles every time and add a bunch of chili sauce and it always hits the spot.  The soups make for great take out on cold nights.
author: elizabeth s.

description: The lemon-lime sake martinis are to die for (However the orange and cranberry aren't so good)
author: A L.

description: Yum. Cool, mellow atmosphere. Nice break from the regular Haight scene.
author: Josh G.

description: My college pals were big fans of this place so we would walk over for some noodle lovin' every once in a while. I agree that th noodles can be a little bland but I am never shy with condiments and sauces and I love spicing things up. The garlic edemame are very tasty and I am a big fan of the Pho-Ga Chicken Noodle Soup. I have spent a few rainy afternoons here and it is perfect for that.
author: Sugey G.

description: Good cheap food in a lively atmosphere.  Sure, it's not the best thai food (or asian food in general) in the city, but it's not bad either, especially for the price. The soups are generally good, as are the shanghai noodles and the sweet chili noodles. Stay away from the pad thai though, as it's pretty bland and not much  more than a plate full of sprouts. Wine and beer are cheap too. Try to not sit at the table next to the bathroom. Also, as others have noted, it's not a good idea to come here on a friday or saturday night with a group of people, as tables are mostly for two and you'll find yourself waiting FOREVER!
author: SL N.

description: Cheap and fast, although it can get packed!  (but they do take-out)  I'm a sucker for the coconut soup.
author: Pedro B.

description: The only reason I cant give my tried and true SF favorite restaurant 5 stars is because the food can be inconsistent. But try again if your first time wasn't as fabulous as everyone told you it would be. Trust me, I've been going there for years, live in the neighborhood, and know its ups and downs. I love that its still cheap, fun, and they make yummy drinks to sip while you wait. My friends and I love the satays, tom ka soup, jade noodles, and chow mein. For a place that does such a high volume business, its bound to miss the mark from time to time.
author: summer r.

description: I have mixed feelings about this place.  I have been a number of times and sometimes it's good, sometimes not so good.  I like that there is a high turnover of food, so you don't feel like it's been sitting there for a while.  The noodle bowls are decent and the service is fine, but I think this place may be overrated.  I ordered pad thai and it tasted nothing like the pad thai I am used to...it had peanuts and tomatoes in it??  Maybe someone was having a bad day.
author: regina k.

description: The Citrus Club serves excellent Thai food and in very large portions.  The Tom Ka is so yummy and warm.  I brought it to work today and still have some left.  Check this tiny place out!!!
author: Bonnie Marie J.

description: I have come here a few times and whenever I leave I fell like a bloated fat piece of lard. Its like can I get some protein? Even with the meat noodle dishes they are shady, just giving a piece of a chicken. I like meat and just feel unquality when all I eat are noodles. The food is overrated first and foremost. They just have a big tub of greasy noodles in the back and just powder on some spice mix on each order to differentiate the meal from the other orders.
author: Ash D.

description: Yep, there's always a wait for dinner, but if you hit lunch at the right time (late afternoon), you will get a table pretty easily. Don't expect the service to stare deep into your eyes and divine your deepest desires, but do expect consistently good food, large portions, and a surprisingly light tab.  Citrus can best be described as an Asian-Fusion Diner, whatever that means.
author: Jabe N.

description:
I've been going here for years and have never been disappointed.  Friendly service, enormous servings and overall really good dishes.
I've never left hungry or broke.

Beware, if you order soup, its going to be enormous.  As in, you could dunk your entire head in the bowl enormous.  
The noodle dishes are also very large.
You can pretty much count on taking home leftovers.

Ive brought countless out-of-towners along with me and it has always gone over really well.  
The servers have always been very friendly and helpful/accomodating.
From the outside it may look a bit sketch (I mean, its the Haight, let's be real) but its quaint and comfy inside and well worth a try.
author: Christophe B.

description: I love going to the Citrus Club, especially with my friends.  The portions are huge and the food is more than satisfying.
author: Adonica W.

description: It looks so underwhelming from the outside, just a bunker looking building on a block of campy hippie monuments. But it is THE BEST. Spicy noodles = perfection.
author: Alexandra P.

description: I was so excited to go to the Citrus club until i stepped in to the place. I was seated by an extremely snobby waitress. And it didn't stop there, she was snobby and had an ugly attitude throughout the entire night. In terms of the food, i ordered the chili glazed tofu dish which much to my dismay was extremely bland. Being a lover for spicy Thai food i was greatly disappointed with my meal. The environment is something i did like. It's cozy and dark, and i liked the music they played. But a restaurant cannot live based on the environment. The heart of a restaurant lies with the chef. The only thing i recommend here is to not go there to stay. I get take out once in a while mainly because my friend loves the soups.......only take out though.
author: Waheguru Singh K.

description: The Pho Ga is wonderful. It's really all I've had here but it is sooo good and the perfect antidote if you have a cold. I'm looking forward to trying more things on the menu.
author: Jeff W.

description: Good food. Inexpensive. Large portions.
author: adlib a.

description: Let me just start off by saying... I LOOOOVE anything noodle based, so I was excited from the moment I saw the "Noodle House" sign. I don't know if a lot of people appreciate this, but their water is nice and lemony and that made me happy from the beginning. I got the yellow coconut curry noodles, which would've been perfect had they added about a forth of the amount of bean sprouts. Like I said, I friggin love noodles, so it saddened me a little when I couldn't have a whole bite of mostly noodles. I'd say this dish about twice as much bean sprouts as noodles. There's also a pile of fresh cucumber and carrots on top, which I like, but I'm not the hugest veggie person so for me a little less would've been better. Apart from that though, it was delicious and I would definitely go back next time I return to Haight Ashbury. One of my friends got the beef noodles with mushrooms which was an excellent choice (I stole some :D) that I would've ordered myself, but again, it sounded like a lot of veggies. Looking forward to my next visit :)
author: Gloria L.

description: Really not tasty food, at all. There are so many better options in this city!
author: L T.

description:
This is my favorite Thai food in the city.  The spring rolls are the best!
Everything is fresh and savory.  The entrees are big enough for two and let's not forget the huge bowls of soup for those chilly, foggy San Francisco nights. You know a restaurant is good when the kitchen is in open view allowing all the wonderful aroma's to fill this cozy little restuarant.
author: Beth G.

description: We went here for lunch and thought the food was alright.   This was our first restaurant in upper haight since we moved here and we thought it was okay. The spring rolls were amazing though!  The noodles..ah, tasted good with some of that hot sauce they have on the table.  Waitress was not overly friendly.  We will probably give this place another chance as it is right around the corner and the spring rolls are worth another visit.
author: Shilpa K.

description:
very tasty 
very fast
very cheap
very big bowl of soup
more shrimp than i could eat in one bowl
author: Renee L.

description: So, for those of us who love cheap, nice atmosphere, big portions places...this is it. I got the chicken pad thai...it was cheap, and in huge portions. the lighting is good...the people friendly (enough) and overall the ambiance was good. Why 3 stars? When I ordered to go, it took a half-hour and people were waiting out the door. So if you don't mind the wait, i'd give it at least 4 stars. If you're slightly impatient like me, check yourself before you get there.
author: surya y.

description:
yes. but don't you dare go there, it's mine.

i ordered the same thing the first maybe 10 times i went here because it was so good. i tried one of the specials last time in addition to the usual and, it too, was amazing. way too much food for two people but there is a minimum per person ($7 i think) order in the evening. fortunately i kept all leftover and they made a great breakfast/lunch the next day.
author: adams l.

description: Soooo tasty! Unsuspecting hole in the wall place from the outside. There was a long line for a table for two but we only waited about 10 minutes. The garlic edamame were incredible and the sake drinks were inexpensive. I had one of the specials- garlic vegetables with tofu. The portions- huge. The prices- cheap. I'll definitely be coming back again sometime soon! I'm going to smell like garlic for days but it's totally worth it.
author: Kari B.

description: Terrible service! When we were waiting for our check so we could pay, we noticed our server sitting behind us eating. So we asked another server if she could get our check and she rolled her eyes and said that she wasn't our server. I couldn't freaking believe it!!! This is after it was already a pain in the ass to order and then the server wouldn't let us sit at a bigger table that was open. Anyways, such a shame because I do quite enjoy their food.
author: B H.

description: big portions good food, solid flavor.
author: Naima B.

description: This establishment gets three stars for cheap food and a lot of it.  The service is perfectly adequate and the ambiance is pleasant.  That said I have had better asian food, having lived in the richmond.  Can be rather lacking in the flavor department.  Try the garlic edamame,  IMO best thing on the menu.
author: Kyle M.

description:
Fast, affordable, candles, music, yummy peanut noodle dish.

Dare I say more?
author: meg d.

description:
5 stars and heres why:
favorite place to have "long talk" dinners.
best 80oz bowl of hot/sour soup in town 
green tea ice cream with nigori. 

Beware of eager busser hands though!
they compete in time trials during dining hours.
author: Benzo K.

description: can anybody help me with the garlic edamame recipe? I live in the east bay and unfortunately can't go to the city every day
author: will p.

description: My favorite restaurant in San Francisco.  Start w/wasabi peas, get a pot of tea and finish with the spinach noodle chicken curry dish.  When I lived on Haight St in 05 I prob ate here at least once a week and now that I'm in VA, I'm looking fwd to eating there again on my next visit to the City.  They've inspired a few dishes I've tried to creat/recreate over the past 2 years, and I've come up w/some good ones, but never quite as good as Citrus Club.  It's crowded around dinner time, esp on the weekends, but service is acceptable and it's worth the wait.  It's also very affordable.  Def check it out when you're in the Upper Haight!
author: Jimmy G.

description: some dishes are hit or miss here, but the ones that are good you stick with because they're reallyreallyreally good. The garlic shrimp/beef noodle dish is a sure thing. and everyone always gets the spring roles which are also always tasty. The specials rotate-- and the tofu w/chinese broccoli is always yum too. the soups hit the spot if you want something fresh and light. and they're huge. its nice to get a couple dishes and share so you can try everything.
author: C. G.

description: Great place for asian cuisine. They had the freshest vietnamese roles ever. Also, you must try out the sake bomb in pear cider (not sapporo). My roommate and I had a great meal. Oh and the best part was their music! They were playing Karunesh..super chill on a Saturday night.
author: Arnab B.

description: My buddy Megan and I visit this place almost every week, before heading over to Trivia Night at Martin Mack's.  Between us, we've ordered about half the menu, and I've only been disappointed once (and the dish wasn't even bad--it just wasn't as good as Megs').  I could probably live in this restaurant forever and just eat spicy noodles and spring rolls for the rest of my life.  I don't know if the staff would go for it, but I'd be totally cool.
author: Becky H.

description:
I come where when I'm down and want to eat something that I know I will like, even if i never had it before. Since it is a noodle house, anything with "noodles" is great. I've eaten my dish and many others in one sitting and I never feel bloated. Which is weird because noodles tend to fill you up, in a bad way. 

The Fried Bananas is great. Nothing special, but i've had it before at other places that can mess that up.

The ONLY reason I can't give it 5 stars is because of space and parking. When Im upset and want to eat I don't want to drive around for 3 days looking for someplace to park for an hour. The place is also very small. I dont like to sit in a party of 10 when Im only there with one other person. 

The place does very good business, please move out to a bigger place. You can sit many more people and not turn away those people who want to come in but won't because the line is 15 deep.
author: mark h.

description: me and my roomate are pretty obsessed with their chicken noodle soup.  i also love that when you pick up your order to go they give you a bunch of fresh ingredience so that you can add as much or as little as you please.
author: shannon h.

description: This place is really awful. I have tried it three times with consistently terrible results. Last week I had the grilled chicken that was so over soy marinated it was completely inedible and the noodles were swimming in grease. The table layout feels cramped and service is rushed and unfriendly. With the plethora of truly amazing Asian noodle options in the city it amazes me that Citrus Club is still open. My guess is that the bulk of the customers are bridge and tunnel moms, dads and teen shopper/tourists slumming in the Haight .
author: M M.

description: A classic place for tuesday night take-out, or budget place to meet a friend that serves yummy healthy fresh food in a nice setting. watchout for the spicy factor though. they tend to pile it on -esp. in their curries.
author: Howard C.

description: I always avoided this place, the decor and lighting implied that it was expensive and snooty, but not the case at all. For cheap you can get a huge bowl of Pho that is really good. You might end up waiting a bit for a seat or for the food even, but it's worth it.
author: Mister D.

description:
WA WA WEE WA
best place for an overcast afternoon sweatshirt, sweatpants, and sandals snack.  oh yea and you partied your brains out last night.... if you don't like this place you are stupid... i wish i could say that i've tried a bunch here in my 60 or so visits over the past few years but the truth is i haven't..... 3 words....EGGDROP CHICKEN SOUP...it used to only be on special but now its a full time menu option......yyeeessssss!!... make a little side dip plate using soy sauce and sirachachachaa and you are set..... someone once recommended to get this with the beef broth insead... bad move... the beef broth is way too gingery. . . . stay away from those little asian mint (some kind of fruit) candies when you leave.  those r gross .  . yuck
author: Mike Honcho H.

description:
Super tasty, cheap, and convenient. The standard menu is consistent and delicious. Definitely try the specials if you can -- the red curry noodle soup and the shrimp wonton soup are delicately flavored and soothing. 

Traditionalists will likely be disappointed by the authenticity (but then, why would they go to a fusion noodle bar), but the flavors are good.
author: Pop L.

description:
I have lived in the upper haight for 3 years now and decided that I would give this place a try, as I have not been there before. So, last night after hanging out with friends, I decided to go get some thai food. Now, this was not the place that we wanted to go to. Our plans were to actually go to Ploy 2 (a few doors down). However, Ploy 2 was closed. So being just a few feet away, we tried the citrus club. I have listed below a number of reasons why this place is so terrible. Furthermore, I recommend that if you want REALLY good food, go to ploy 2. Or for that matter, anywhere else besides the citrus club. 

Reasons not to go: 
1. Terrible service (Our waitress maybe came to our table twice. And when she did, she was very bitchy. The bus boy helped us more than she did). 

2. The food (For all those that have written somewhat good reviews of this place, you must not eat good food. Here's what I got to say. The food has no flavor what-so-ever. I ordered the beef and broccoli dish and it was absolutely dreadful. It had no flavor, the beef was rubbery and furthermore, the noodles were very oily). My girlfriend ordered the sea food special and it didn't even have a taste to it. Another friend of ours ordered a tofu dish and she MAYBE took 3 bites of it, before telling us how terrible it was. 

3. Desserts (Now this is just terrible. If a restaurant can't get ice cream and fried banana's right, then there's a BIG PROBLEM! So, with that said let me elaborate further. I ordered fried banana's, first the bananas were not fried. Second, they put the ice cream on the same plate; it was to hot to even touch. It took about 2 minutes for the ice cream to melt and leave me with a big mess. I didn't even eat it, was a complete waste of money). 

4. Homeless kids don't even like the food. (I LOVE food, and hate to waste it. So, even though the food was terrible. I asked for it to be boxed up so I could give it to someone on the way home. This is were things get really funny. I gave the box to a homeless guy, and as I walked away I heard him say to his friend 'this shit taste terrible' and with that he chucked it into haight street). 

I hope that this helps the true lovers of food out there in their quest to have something that is satisfying. BEWARE THE CITRUS CLUB!
author: James P.

description: this was a very interesting meal.. when i walked in everyones food looked and smelt awesome but 2 of 3 dishes at our table were to odd to be called good. i ordered the coconut lemongrass shrimp and it tasted like a combination of honey prawns at a chinese restaurant and mac salad... tasted like a heavy mayonnaise base on noodles, shrimp, onion, and snap peas. i may have just ordered badly so am very willing to give it another shot.
author: Barbara C.

description: The quality for the price is unparalleled!  You really can't go wrong with anything on the menu.  Golden Gate Park is nearby so take a walk after your meal and bask in the afterglow of noodle heaven....
author: MIchael R.

description: I love this place. not only does the food taste amazing, it is also better for you then most other restaurants. It isn't greasy and all the ingredients are fresh and flavorful. This helps because the serving sizes are HUGE!!! The dishes are affordable and if you go with someone that doesn't mind sharing, one serving will leave both of you full.
author: Jessie H.

description: Love it a lot!  Who doesn't love cheap hot curry!  Best food on the block and good price, nice service FAST!  When I am hungry and don't want attitude and I like the bar scene.  They should expand!  Thanks for being a reaonable place to dine!
author: Shopper Savvy M.

description: My only Thai experience in SF. I would be more critical in Seattle, but I'm not sure if they have the same quality in SF. The atmosphere was cool enough, and it has a great location. The food was however very bland. We got the pad thai and a coconut noodle dish that sounded awesome. Both were bland and flavorless. I wouldn't recommend this to anyone that has had Thai food more than once.
author: Robin S.

description: on days you feel like a big heaping bowl of asian-fusion-y noodles, citrus club is a good place to go. it's usually packed to the brim (both the place itself and the bowl).
author: Kimi W.

description: i wasn't expecting this place to be any great shakes, but it ended up being scrumptious!  about 8 of us showed up at citrus club on new years eve late and waited our turn to be seated (not all together --- which was fine).  we ordered a round of sake bombs and cocktails, i got the saki punch which was tasty.  when it came time to order food, i had no idea what to get and wasn't really feeling any of what i read.  i was going to order the garlic edemame & chicken satay, but at the last minute changed my mind to the lemon & coconut chicken...it was amazing!  the only bad thing of the whole night was how they took my dish away from me before I was finished.  a definite must try --- go, you'll love it, we all did!
author: Lesley ..

description: First, the food is just mediocre. Few dishes are worth getting, and even more are not. However, the crappy service is what kills it for me. The waitresses there are unfriendly, inefficient, and just down right rude sometimes. Obviously a lot of people love this place, and I can see the appeal; It's on Haight, it's got some mood lighting, it's ethnic... But do yourself a favor, go somewhere else like Ploy II or Best of Thai. Better service, better food.
author: Mike H.

description: nice place, I like the dark decor....price fine and the food was tasty with much flavor...I will go there again...
author: Alex W.

description: I LOVE THAI FOOD.. and I love this place. It's very crowded and very loud. There's usually a line. I wouldn't go to this place on a first date or with someone I'd like to have a deep conversation with. The food is SO tastefull and the entree portions are huge! Prices are incredibly reasonable. My sister is in a wheelchair, so more often than not, we wait a little bit longer than anyone else would for a seat on the main level (the other level is only separate by two steps), but we're talking about 10 more minutes.
author: Vanessa R.

description: Had the spicy lemon grass chicken and it was awesome, especially considering the price.  Mixed in some duck sauce and chili sauce and it was to die for.  Ate the whole thing...even though I shouldn't have.  Good value and good food.
author: Scott W.

description: After years of passing this by as a fast food joint, I was so surprised to find that it was a full fledged restaurant! Amazing food and amazing portions! Great prices, especially for the humongous portions they serve. It is a bit cramped but is definitely worth it. Have been back three times now and have not been disappointed once!
author: Elysha K.

description: this place is so lame. they microwave frozen edamame.
author: sarah l.

description: i think they must put crack in their hot & sour noodle soup it's THAT good. the bbq tofu springrolls are out of this world delicious, as well. put that with some of their hot sake and i done gone died and went to heaven.
author: Kyra B.

description: This place is alright in my books! I got the miso soup which was awesome and the bbq tofu rolls...not my fav, I don't think I would get them again. The piece of tofu was just a little to big...and I felt something was off about the sauce. But none the less I WILL BE GOING BACK just because of the garlic edaname!!! So freaking good! My friends got some noodle dishes and they wern't aything special...but still good! Everything was super cheap and I feel like I got what I paid for. I would suggest it for a casual grab...try to get there a little earlier it gets crazy crowded around 8
author: stephanie c.

description: all i can say is: dinner for two for UNDER $12? shut up! sure, we only drank water, but c'mon! the food was tasty and served quickly. i'll be back.
author: Allison P.

description: This place doesn't look like much from the outside, but it's actually pretty cute on the inside, with dim lighting and little white christmas lights- nicer than your typical thai joint. The food was so-so, I think it depends what you order. We started with the garlic edamame. The serving was big enough for 4 but we were only 2 so we ended up taking half of it home. It was tasty but had too much sauce/oil, which got tiring. My friend had the tom ka coconut tofu soup, which was yummy, and again could have easily served a whole family! The pad thai was not so great. The sauce was too creamy, the noodles mushy, they added tomato which was weird, and it did not come with a slice of lime. However, I would go again to see if any of the other dishes are better.
author: Laura B.

description: Don't sit too near the bathroom unless you want to see people coming and going.  We usually pick the bar seats - a little cramped but quick and entertaining.  The cooks operate over gigantic open flames and are flipping and tossing everything right in front of your eyes.  I tend to get the big soups with tofu and noodles.  I leave sweating b/c of the delicious little hots in the sauce.  Among the best price in town for noodles.
author: d l.

description: only had one visit to citrus club, but i plan on returning this week when i'm back in the area.  tried two dishes, the cold orange mint noodles w/ chicken, and the... hot and sour soup i think?  both dishes were excellent, and i left feeling full, but not grossly "american stuffed".  there is a reason i'm asking my friends to take me back here, check it out people.
author: Sean L.

description: i cant get enough of this place.  cheap eats!  the trick is to know whats good:  garlic edamamea, veg. spring rolls, citrus salad, peanut noodles, miso soup, chicken noodle is good too and some nigori to top it off.  thats it.  no more, no less.  eets good.
author: tiffany m.

description: Good Deal for the money.  Best on weekdays especially for lunch.  Garlic beef my fave!
author: Matsuo F.

description: ehh...not bad food, but I can definately live without it.  i guess you pay for what you get.
author: mandy f.

description: Reasonably priced great-tasting noodles and big portions. Get it to go though b/c if you are in the main part of the restaurant you will smell the bathroom your entire meal, ew!
author: Cbr A.

description: favorite noodle slurpin cheapo meal in sf. you can split everything and still have a ton of food left over for a midnight snack. vegetarian friendly; order the garlic edamame after an amoeba records buying binge.
author: Domenique B.

description: nothing to write home about. food is alright, prices are typical. atmosphere is the only special thing. it's kind of cute-kitschy. nice change if i feel like thai w/o going to king of thai though. (not knocking KOT.. happen to love it.. just want to have something different some days.)
author: Mel L.

description: the 5 stars are strictly for the garlic edamame...i think that has become my new food crack!!
author: Jenny G.

description: i've only had a few of the noodle dishes and they were good but just a bit on the bland side.  but we LOVE the garlic edamame.  that alone brings me back.
author: jennifer l.

description: huge portions, bomb food, very affordable, wonderful atmosphere
author: alex m.

description: good cheap eats.  love the spring rolls and hot and sour veggie noodle soup.
author: Julia H.

description: yummers in the tummers. i'm getting hungry just thinking about this place. the lemongrass coconut noodles are mad crazy. they are just so tasty. and the bf claims they have the best thai iced tea in san francisco.
author: Beth W.

description: I've been coming here for years and have never been disappointed.  the Citrus Club is definitely in my top 10 favorite places to eat in the city and is easy on the wallet.  Start out with either the shrimp spring rolls or the garlic edamame.  My usual dinner staple is the garlic beef/shrimp and shitake mushrooms.  If you are coming here for the first time, then get this cuz it freakin' rules so hard with its sexy chow fun noodles and garlicky snap peas and mushrooms and sprouts...hmmmm.  Last night I ventured from the norm and got their soy marinated grilled salmon over noodles.  I can't stop thinking about how delish it was!  The salmon was cooked perfectly and the noodles and  accompanying sauce weren't over-powering.  I'm thinking about a repeat for tonight.  Also, if you happen to have a cold, then get some of their REAL chicken noodle soup.  It beats the pants off your mom's and your granny's.
author: Chard M.

description: long wait in line espescially if youre eating with more than two people. food is cheap but sometimes you get what you pay for. the service is good and its quick. but its only worth going for lunch. dinner. is just terrible.
author: Derek Alistair J.

description: i'm actually a fairly big fan of this place.  i mean, first of all, it's a cheap noodle joint, not a nice thai restaurant.  and the ambiance is decidedly third-world backpacker.  you go to sit at the counter or be jammed into a table that's designed to seat at least one less than's in your party by an aloof and somewhat hostile server, drink a beer, and have some noodles. but there's something about this place that's oddly comforting to me, i don't know why.  i usually get the garlic beef with shiitaki mushrooms, but the soups and the spring rolls (not fried) are pretty good too, as are the coconut prawns.  be warned about the pad thai though; it's not traditional (and in my opinon, not great).  good place to grab dinner if you live in the hood or before going across the street for a movie at the red vic.
author: brian g.

description: Shrimp pad thai, while reasonably priced, was soupy, low on the shrimp, and in general not very good.
author: Anne A.

description: Delicious delicious delicious.  The Pho Ga chicken soup and coconut lemongrass shrimp with jade spinach noodles are my personal favorites, but I've never had a bad dish from here.  The wait can be a little longer than I'd like sometimes, but is totally worth it.  I also order it for pick-up more often than I'd like to admit.  Great food, pretty cheap (I think most dishes are less than $10).
author: Julie H.

description: This is one of my favortie casual places to eat in the city.  Every noodle dish I have here is yummy.  I'm salivating just thinking about it now - must have more noodle!!!
author: Ziva A.

description: I've been going here for a couple years now, its one of my favorites.  Try the Spicy Lemon & Coconut Chicken or the Mandarin Style-Chow Mein.  The Vietnamese-Spring Rolls are great too.
author: Mike R.

description: Great food at an incredible price. I'm a fan! The spring rolls were amazing, and the soup was pretty good. They give you A LOT of food, which was nice. I wish they'd give a little less food and instead have hand pulled noodles. Oh well, can't get everything you wish for. Still, on my short list of fav cheap eats.
author: suz q.

description: I have to start by saying that I really enjoy the food here.  It is asian fusion so don't come here expecting traditional dishes.  However don't come here expecting good service either.  The wait staff are a grumpy bunch.  I went there at 2 in the afternoon and the watiresses acted as if we were inconveniencing them.  They wouldn't let us sit where we wanted despite the fact that the restaurant was pretty much empty.  We felt so offended by the rude service that we left and went to the blue front cafe (very tasty).
author: sarah m.

description: it's okay, but not great either....their noodle dishes are not that good compared to similar places.
author: ji k.

description: What happened to the place?!? I guess thats what happens when you focus too much on being cool and trendy and less on the ingredients.  When I first went in the spring of 2004 it was a decent neighborhood dig. A little out of place for the Haight but whatever. I had the "Homemade" chicken soup, not bad.. good portions decently filling. Fast forward to summer 2006.  Earlier in the year I had noticed a slight decrease in the quality but I decide everyone is entitled to a 2nd chance in my book.  So I take a date there as its one of the only remotely romantic place on the street.  I order a spring lemon chicken dish thinking it would be light and refreshing.. I end up getting something that tastes like it was put in the microwave and doused in MSG. Bad bad bad, very greasy and with the lemon flavor of a starburst.  Fortunately if you got a hankering for Thai there is still Ploy 2 a few doors down and Lotus Siam across the street. Much better.
author: Chris F.

description: four guys, appetizer, four big bowls of food, one pitcher of beer -- only $68 including the tip. that's a bargain in my book . . . and i walked away completely full and happy.
author: Bowen P.

description: Awesome food. Get the garlic edemame and shanghai noodles or sweet/sour soup/ or coconut curry soup. I love this place but expect a wait at dinner time especially with a larger group...
author: Monique D.

description: After walking around the Haight not wanting pizza my husband and I just happened into the Citrus Club on appearances alone.  We made our seat at the bar since the wait for a table could have been long.  I ordered the Shanghai Noodles and my husband got the Cashew Chicken.  Both were yummy and hot when they came out.  The wait for the food was a little longer than normal, but the restaurant was pretty busy.  I'll take good food as compensation for a longer wait any day.
author: Catherine S.

description: I enjoy their cool little vegetarian dishes, haven't ventured past those yet, but everything looks good. It's also the only place I've found, outside of Germany, with Optimator on tap!
author: David K.

description:
I would have put five starts but I've only been once, seeing as I live in San Diego.

The Environment was terrific, the food MY GOD, delicious, but the rules were a tad bit whack.

Me and my G/f really went to SF for some great quality food. This came to a surprise when our first oriental food stop was Utopia Cafe, which sucked super major balls, the food was under cooked and lacked in style and favor, but that's another story.
 Walking down ashberry and Haight at night, like good tourist, we had a choice of pizza, Mexican food or oriental, and by this review you can tell what we picked. IT was our last effort for something worthy. And it did not disappoint. We sat down, and looked around. The platter's were huge and filling. Even though their were two of us we only needed one bowl, but the rules stated Seven dollar minimum per person, so we choose to sit at the bar, where there was no such minimum. We choose one of there specials and didn't expect anything good, we just hoped. While waiting for our meal, entertainment was offered by the wok cook (very fun). The food was served and it knocked me back, it was perfect, the spices were delicious, and food filling. Each bite solidified this place, and when the bowl was over, I wasn't stuffed, I was satisfied. Its what we've been looking for. And I'm grateful to have found it.
author: R H.

description: Yummy cheap food.  Asian style noodles.  They have the best garlic edamame.  If you like nothing else here you will love their garlic edamame!  There is almost always a wait and they won't seat you if one of your parties has run to the atm to get cash, they'll just seat the next in line.  The service could be better, and the bathroom could be cleaner but other than that it is a good place for cheap eats!
author: L M K M.

description: I love this place. I don't live in SF anymore but I dream of there Vietnamese  chicken noodle soup. If you haven't been here it's a must. (FYI. . . great hangover food)
author: KATELYNN R.

description: Mediocre food with not much flavor. Or maybe I got the wrong thing...the curry tofu was so-so.   I glanced enviously at other peoples food which seemed better than mine.  On a positive side, the service is great, the quantities are big, and the food is cheap.
author: Michele Y.

description: I like this faux asian noodle house.  The portions are generous at low prices and the flavors are mild, but hit the spot.
author: LT B.

description: yummmy vegetarian friendly cheap eats!
author: Sia V.

description: love the location, love the food, love the drinks, love the atmosphere, love it! great place for larger groups, or more intimate dates.
author: Ilovelife Z.

description: So far so good.  My boyfriend and I hit up the Citrus Club for the first time on a busy Thursday night.  I put my name on the list behind five or six other tables for two.  While we stood around discussing going someplace else, three of those tables cleared out lickety-split and we were seated within 10 or so minutes.  I got shanghai noodles (A+) and the lemon-lime sake martini (A++).  I definitely have to go back to try out the dozen or so other dishes I wanted to order but didn't have room for.  And at each dish coming in under $7 it's a crazy good deal.  The only cons, and they are slight, are that it's so freaking dark in there I could barely see the food on my plate and green tea ice cream with sake poured on top is a wretchedly bad idea.  Each served separately is fantastic but together... nay.
author: Susan W.

description: We loved it the first time we went. Then, we went for lunch last weekend. The noodles were way too greasy. Wasn't that impressed.
author: Ed C.

description: the dinner that keeps on giving...the pepper beef noodles are the best i ever had, saucy, spicy, salty, sweet, all at once, and yet delicate. they're even good cold at 6am before class...
author: gray v.

description: The four stars are mainly for the price - this place is good, fast, and cheap.  The portions are ginormous and the atmosphere is cute.  It's no frills, but i've never had a bad meal there.  The hot and sour vegetable soup is fantastic and always leaves enough for leftovers...
author: Aliah K.

description: too bad tina had to go back to thailand ...after 10+ years the place doesn't seem the same...2 things i order..peanut nooooodles and Shitake beef....unlike any other..
author: dion l.

description:
noodles noodles noodles - i love it.   the food here was good, pretty cheap, and the portions are generous -- hard to go wrong with that combo.  i kept it simple with the chicken noodle soup (pho); friends had the tom ka soup (amazing), and the shanghai noodles (beef was a bit dry, but she said this was unusual.)

the line out the door was deceptive, and we were seated quickly.  waitress could have been a bit quicker, but i guess that's better than being rushed out.  one minor snafu was our dirty sake cups.  once brought to the attention of our waitress she brought us an extra carafe of sake to accompany our new clean glasses.  that's the kind of service i like!
author: Lindsey I.

description: We were looking forward to a great dinner, but what a surprise. There were 4 of us in our party. The waitress was quick to point out that there was a $7.00 minimum per person. When we told her that one of us was would not be eating, she lunged for the fork belonging to the person not eating. She was going to make sure that he didn't eat.  In the end, we ordered additional dishes that more than covered their minimum. Then, we had to ask for the fork to be returned. When the food finally arrived it was warm, at best - certainly not hot. The Pad Thai noodles had cilentro and tomatoes in it - not exactly Pad Thai noodles. The waitress practically threw the bill at us - what an attitude. After paying, she brought the check, with lots of 5's and 1's - She actually thought whe was going to get a tip!. We watched other employees and concluded that the "attitude" must start at the top. Nobody was very friendly.
author: A C.

description: just another super crowded, super trendy hipster restaurants that convinces you that their food is delicious by making you wait for ever for it.  i've only actually eaten their once, because only once have i had the motivation to wait for 30 minutes for a table.  it was fine, i guess.  i ate it because i was starving.  i just don't see what all the hype is, though.
author: josie p.

description: I loooove this restaurant! The chicken noodle soup is so huge and delicious. Whenever I'm in the Haight, I make sure to go.  I think it would be perfect for a date-low lighting, close tables, and easy on the pocketbook.
author: B S.

description: This place is amazing!  Get the thai coconut chicken or the garlic beef shitake.  Favorite place in SF.
author: Brian S.

description: This place is amazing. The best food and the best prices. You gotta try the garlic house edamame. The wait can be a little long and the place is pretty small but the food it outta this world.
author: Arden R.

description: I went to this place on last  Friday around noon!. this place was very crowed and make me think that food should be good. first the waitress sat me down and then wait for 5 minutes for taking my order, I ordered Tom Kha noodle soup. I'm sorry to say all vegetables( carrots) in the soup tasted very nasty and old. I wont come back for this place agian
author: Grace C.

description:
it's not fancy, but everytime i am in the upper haight i feel the need to visit citrus club for their delish coconut curry noodle soup (oh the saturated fat) and their veggie spring rolls.  

i am unfort. a huge coconut curry noodle soup fan and must rate theirs the best in the city!  yum!!
author: n. h.

description: I used to live right down the street from this noodle bar. If I could have it once a week, I would! I'm a big fan of this place.Because I'm a creature of habit, I always get the same item. Hot and Sour Shrimp Noodle Soup. YUMMY! The prices are pretty good too. On a cold day have some soup and one of their Sake Margaritas.
author: Marietta B.

description: All my friends said this was the place to check out. I was super excited to try it. I ordered the coconut curry noodles with tofu. But, unfortunately it was a disappointment. It was surprisingly bland and mushy without taste! I don't know how you can screw up curry noodles. I had to add more soy sauce and other flavors at home just to give it some taste. I was pretty sad...I might give it another shot and order something else next time, but I wouldn't recommend what I ordered.
author: C L.

description: LOVE IT! LOVE IT! LOVE IT! WOW!!! on those cold days you've spent shopping on haight this place is a staple. with big honking bowls of noodle soups, citrus club blends the diverse flavors of Asian cuisines. they have daily specials which make each trip unique and memorable. this place will hit spots you didn't even know you had! stop by for a bowl-it'll warm you right up!
author: Sasha R.

description: I absolutely hate waiting for a table here because the entryway is narrow and bound to be crowded.  I constantly feel like I'm in the way, but once I'm seated, I'm a happy camper.  The food isn't to die for, but with entrees priced at $7-8, it's good enough.  My clothing used to come out smelling like the food I ate (it's an open kitchen), but I think they must have improved the ventilation or fan system or something because my last couple visits were no problem.
author: Kristin F.

description: Excellent Asian Fusion cuisine right in the heart of the Haight. A good place to go if you cannot settle on the other Asian places in Hashbury. With excellent cocktails and a well-priced menu, this is also a great place to start the night with people who are down to get down. Be warned though, it can be difficult to get a table any night of the week.
author: Jeremy J.

description: Cheap. Everything is good.  Fresh ingredients.  Upwards of a 30 minute wait most nights.  This is a great restaurant for 2 people, but larger groups usually have to wait even longer because of the table layout and turnover.  I love the Coconut Noodle Soup with Chicken.  They also have excellent spring rolls and Thai Iced tea.
author: Brian C.

description: over rated i went here years ago and didnt like the food at all, went back a few  years later and it still wasnt good, there are soo  many better places in sf to eat go there
author: lord v.

description: Its a cheap and rad little place.  It used to be a lot better.  The food used to be more flavorful.  The place is dirt cheap and a good time.  The food now is just .......whatever.  It used to be my favorite cheapy place in the city.  Memories.
author: Josh P.

description: the food is good but the place is super small.. long waiting time to  just  to get a table .to tight ..not a kids place at all .. no parking .have to pay 10.00 for parking  to dark inside ...
author: joel c.

description: this place can manage to turn someone who wasn't even all that hungry to chow down. who needs gordon biersch garlic fries when you've got a healthier version of garlic edamame at Citrus Club. loved the fact that the soups were truly vegetarian, and most were even vegan. next time, i plan to order some of the ginger tea to-go. probably the best ginger tea i've had!
author: kirti p.

description: while i've dabbled with various dishes here, i have yet to make a return visit for anything but the vegetarian noodle soup. not that it's especially delicious, but it's close, well priced, and can really hit the spot on a cold day. the inside is usually crowded and often feels dirty, the service varies from fine to atrocious, and the food is just ok. with that said, the food is consistent, the portions are large, and it's the kind of restaurant that has something for everyone.
author: hannah c.

description: i have eaten at the citrus club many times and you get a good amount of food for your money... but my most recent time eating here was a disaster, i had brought 4 friends and our waitress was a total bitch! she didnt bring us spoons or bowls to eat with, and when we asked for ice water it took her at least 10 minutes to bring it.. so we were all putting our money together for the bill, when we realized we only had 2 dollars for the tip. her service was awful anyway, as we walk out, she follows us out and grabs me by the shoulder and started yelling at me for "not leaving a big enough tip" and said "this is a restaurant if you dont leave a big enough tip you can go eat at f***ing mcdonalds" after this i will never eat here again. i am literally scared of what she might do to my food.
author: kristen k.

description: my favorite place to grab a bite in the haight.  great portions and relatively inexpensive.  a bit cramped, but not a big deal if i'm just going with a friend.  i second a previous reviewer's comment about cooking with less oil.  i ate so much but didn't feel weighed down.  oh, yes, and i love the edamame.  much better than eating a side of bread.
author: J B.

description: it's nice to see this restaurant still up and running here after being away in the east coast for so long... often i find myself bringing out of town guests here, and almost all of them HAD to order another dish of garlic edamames.  that's how addictive they can be! ;-)
author: Gabe L.

description: it's definitely not the best but it's also not a crappy place to eat either. what makes it solid is that it's in the haight. the haight is great.. minus all the yuppies and hipsters
author: cr b.

description: This place sucks.  A friend and I took a seat at the bar in front of the kitchen and sat there waiting for a good 20 minutes without being acknowledged by any of the wait staff.  When a couple of seats cleared up at the other end in front of the bar area, we proceeded to wait another 10 minutes, until a became vocal and started saying out loud 'I'm gonna get on YELP and give this place a hella bad review."  IT TOOK ME TO SAY THOSE EXACT WORDS TO GET SERVICE AND OUR ORDER TAKEN.   THE OTHER 3 WAITRESSES WOULDN'T EVEN GIVE US THE TIME OF DAY.   So now to the food.  I ordered the 'Crunchy Noodle House Salad with (defrosted/pre-cooked) chicken.'  There was NOTHING CRUNCH or NOTHING NOODLE about the salad at all.  The chicken was nasty, COLD, and DRY.  They could've at least thrown it on the grill to warm it up.  The beef satay was SALTY, over-marinated and over-rated.  I can't believe I still left them a tip after our experience.  I will never eat at this place again.
author: jason c.
